DOC.HEAD: Federal Agents Raid Northrop B-2 Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with company spokesman's comments on search, GAO report recommending reduced spending on B-2, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents seized documents at a plant where Northrop Corp. builds parts for the B-2 stealth bomber, a Northrop spokesman said Thursday. The spokesman, Tony Cantafio, said the company previously has turned over thousands of documents in connection with civil lawsuits over alleged fraud in the B-2 program. In another blow to the B-2 program Thursday, Congress heard a recommendation that spending for the radar-evading plane should be scaled back because of doubts about the plane's ability to pass critical tests. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, cautioned that spending cuts shouldn't be imposed until after a study to ensure that slowing the program wouldn't result in higher costs in the long run. Frank C. Conahan, assistant comptroller general and a member of the GAO, told the House Armed Services Committee that the Pentagon should work with contractors ``to find out what the real cost would be to delay this, and if it isn't an awful lot, than I think I would concur in that decision to delay this airplane.'' Cantafio said he didn't know why the agents raided the factory in the Pico Rivera section of Los Angeles on Feb. 15 as part of the criminal probe, rather than subpoena the documents. ``They showed up with a search warrant. I don't know why. They won't say they were there,'' Cantafio said. ``They came in and took some documents on the B-2.'' He refused to describe the documents, and spokesmen for the FBI in Los Angeles and Justice Department in Washington didn't immediately return telephone calls. The Los Angeles Times cited unidentified sources as saying the raid provides evidence that a Justice Department criminal investigation into the $70 billion program is escalating after more than a year. Several civil and criminal investigations of Northrop are under way. Former employees of the Century City-based aerospace company have filed a whistle-blower lawsuit against Northrop seeking $20 billion in damages because of alleged civil fraud in the B-2 program. The B-2 is intended to be difficult to detect on enemy radar. The effect is achieved through use of fiberglass-like composite materials rather than metal, as well as a configuration with few angles or protruding parts.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe's Challenge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report; also on financial circuits.
DOC.HEAD: Part V: Japan Lukewarm to Expanding Business in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: When Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu toured Europe last month he demonstrated Japan's economic might by announcing almost $2 billion in aid to Poland and Hungary, dwarfing what the United States has committed. In contrast, private Japanese industries, known for their aggressive expansion elsewhere, are reluctant to plunge into a part of the world they see as inexperienced, ill-equipped and still emerging from 40 years of communism. A few prominent deals have been done. Suzuki Motor Co., for example, recently agreed to set up an automobile plant in Hungary, the first Japanese company to enter a joint venture with Eastern Europe since the tumultuous political changes there. But Eastern Europe remains virtually untouched by Japanese business. In 1988, Japan trade with the region totaled about $1.47 billion, excluding the Soviet Union. That's less than 1 percent of Japanese trade worldwide. Although many Japanese firms have offices in Eastern European nations, only about a dozen joint ventures have been established. No Japanese company has yet invested in Poland, East Germany or Czechoslovakia. Japanese businessmen have a range of reasons for holding back. High inflation rates, a heavy debt burden and inconvertible currencies make it difficult to profit in Eastern Europe, in their view. Restrictions on exports of high technology to the East bloc, a vestige of the Cold War that remains entrenched, also have reduced the spectrum of trade opportunities for the Japanese, who are leading exporters of high-tech items. Nonetheless, the changing political and economic landscape of Eastern Europe has piqued Japan's interest. The government has allocated $750 million for export insurance to encourage Japanese firms to trade there. To Daihatsu Motor Co., however, economic reform and Japanese government aid cannot alleviate the tremendous risks it sees. One of Japan's smallest automobile manufacturers, Daihatsu has tried for more than five years to set up an assembly plant in Poland. Although it developed an ambitious plan to build a 12,000-vehicle-a-year plant with Polish automaker FSO, Daihatsu failed to acquire enough financing and the plan collapsed. Last fall, FSO approached Daihatsu again. This time, said spokesman Wataru Shindo, the company has considerably scaled down plans _ it will export about 6,000 unassembled Charade models to Poland. ``We don't know whether we'll be able to meet our costs. At a scale of 5,000 to 6,000 cars, even if we fail there will be little damage done,'' Shindo said. Japan's largest glass manufacturer expressed the same caution. Asahi Glass Co. has been negotiating with Poland to set up a plate glass factory in the southern city of Sandomierz. The risks remain high, said Asahi official Shigehiko Tomita, and no commitment has been made. Tomita said trade insurance and other Japanese government support was necessary, but stability in Eastern Europe was more important. ``The political and economic situation in Poland is still fluid, and the risks great. The country has high inflation, and even though we think that democratization will proceed, we need to have some protection,'' he said. Shigeki Ura, a senior officer with merchant trader C. Itoh and Co. in Eastern Europe, doubted Japanese firms will attempt any large-scale investments. Nevertheless, he added, ``As businessmen specializing in the Eastern European market, we should not be so optimistic, but not so pessimistic. Economic reform and democracy will give us chances.'' Ura said Japanese firms differ fundamentally from European firms in their attitude toward developing the Eastern European market. The Japanese want clear-cut laws in place specifying what is permissible for foreigners, but some European investors are willing to overlook legal vaguenesses, Ura said. Despite Japan's reluctance, its neighbor South Korea seems eager to exploit opportunity in Eastern Europe. Yoo Chang-soon, chairman of the Federation of Korean Industries, South Korea's largest business organization, said recently that ``prospects are bright'' for direct investment there. ``Some big entrepreneurs have already studied plans for direct investment in communist countries,'' he said. South Korea established diplomatic relations with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia only last year and has a $91 million trade surplus with those countries.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Drug Dealer Returns 12 Years After Jumping Bond
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Twelve years ago, Larry W. Smith jumped bail to avoid a two-year prison term, saying he wanted to raise his 7-year-old daughter. Now he's come home to face the music, but he doesn't like the tune. Smith turned himself in this week after his daughter, Penny, now 19, joined the Marines. Prosecutors made clear his case had not been forgotten. ``He thought that 12 years would change things and that they'd go a little easier on him. But right away, the state's attorney said he was throwing the book at him for jumping bond,'' said his sister, Deborah Sprinkle, 35, who was arrested with her brother in 1977 on drug charges. ``Last night he called from jail and said he didn't know if he'd done the right thing,'' said Mrs. Sprinkle, who spent three months in jail after pleading guilty to distribution of methamphetamine. She spoke in a telephone interview Wednesday from Smith's hometown of Pekin, about 15 miles from Peoria. Smith, 40, surrendered to Sheriff James Donahue on Tuesday. ``He introduced himself and as soon as he said his name I realized who he was and that we had warrants on him,'' Donahue said. Smith was convicted in 1978 of selling methamphetamine, or ``speed,'' to an undercover officer and sentenced to prison. He fled after posting $3,000 bail. State's Attorney Erik Blanc said Wednesday he plans to pursue all charges still pending against Smith, including perjury, another drug offense and two misdemeanors stemming from a fight with police in 1978. ``Assuming he's convicted, it'll be up to the judge to decide whether any leniency is warranted,'' the prosecutor said. Richard Smith, 45, of Pekin, said he urged his younger brother to surrender. ``His main concern was raising his daughter,'' Richard Smith said. ``She knew her dad was a fugitive and that he was going to surrender as soon as she was on her own.'' Larry Smith settled in Antioch, Calif., where he ran a welding shop with his brother Dennis. Their parents visited Antioch several times and Smith's daughter spent a summer with her grandparents in Pekin, a central Illinois town of 34,000. Smith's surrender followed a week of festivities there at the home of his parents, Dolores and Lawrence E. Smith. ``He hadn't been back in 12 years and we had a big family reunion. ... He came back because my mom has been in bad health and he wanted to put all this behind him,'' Mrs. Sprinkle said. ``I told him this was something he just had to do,'' said Smith's father, 65. ``He's a good man. He's changed a lot in 12 years. He loves his family and wants to be with us. ``He's raised a beautiful girl and worked hard. Now he's decided he's going to face up to his mistakes. I hope he gets off pretty light. He deserves it.'' Larry Smith started thinking about returning to Pekin to join the family tarp business about five years ago when his brother Dennis was shot to death in a dispute over money, Richard Smith said. At about the same time, he said, Larry Smith separated from Gayla Kendrick, his live-in girlfriend and Penny's mother. Ms. Kendrick, a co-defendant in Smith's drug case, also jumped bail and is still at large. Smith was not available for an interview because he is in jail without bail. The family would not say where his Marine daughter is based.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Legislator Dies After Fainting at Riot
DOC.TEXT: An 82-year-old lawmaker of the ruling Nationalist Party died one day after fainting in the legislature building while rioters outside called for him and other elderly lawmakers to quit. Chiang Kung-liang died of a lung malfunction Wednesday evening at the National Taiwan University Hospital. Chiang, who had been hospitalized for a year with asthma, fainted Tuesday as the legislature convened to vote for a new speaker. A hospital statement did not say if Chiang's death was related to the rioting outside. But a doctor for the legislature, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the death may have been partly caused by shock over the violent protest. Chiang was among the more than 100 lawmakers who last faced election on the Chinese mainland more than four decades ago. They have been frozen in office in support of the Nationalist government's claim to still be the legitimate ruler of all China. The protesters demanded that the aging legislators be replaced by people elected in Taiwan. In the rioting, more than 100 people were injured, including five elderly politicians who were punched and kicked by the demonstrators.

DOC.HEAD: Broker Who Embezzled $2 Million In HUD Funds Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A man who embezzled $2 million in U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development funds to pay for a lavish lifestyle pleaded guilty to reduced charges Wednesday after helping the government win a cocaine case. Cy Walker, who spent at least $180,000 on cars and also bought a speedboat, furs and jewelry with some of the stolen HUD money, pleaded guilty to one count of embezzlement and one count of failing to file an income tax return for 1986. U.S. Attorney Jim Wilson said Walker faces maximum penalties of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on the embezzlement count and one year in prison and a $25,000 fine on the tax return count. Walker, who once held the HUD contract to handle closings of HUD property in the Montgomery area, is to be sentenced by U.S. District Judge Joel Dubina after a pre-sentence report is completed. No date was set immediately. After Walker's embezzlement scheme was spelled out in HUD audits and agency documents last year, Wilson initially declined to say if any charges against Walker were being considered. Later it was disclosed that Walker had arranged a deal with prosecutors to get a reduced prosecution in return for undercover work that led to the indictment of Freddie Hyatt on cocaine charges. Hyatt, a former Auburn University football star and racehorse trainer, was convicted last September on three cocaine distribution counts and was sentenced to four years and three months in federal prison. His defense attorney contended that Walker framed Hyatt in a series of calls seeking to buy cocaine. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles Niven, who prosecuted Hyatt at the trial in Opelika, defended the plea agreement made with Walker, saying that to catch a drug dealer ``you use people who are involved in criminal activities. You don't sell drugs to preachers or Sunday school teachers.'' It was brought out at the trial that Walker would be allowed to plead guilty to the two counts. Walker used a bank's wire transfer forms to embezzle the HUD money during a period of more than two years before HUD discovered the scheme in 1987. By the time HUD officials sought to get the money, Walker had depleted the bank account. Walker acknowledged from the witness stand at the Hyatt trial that he had used the money to buy sports cars and entertain women. Walker pleaded guilty to one count of embezzling $2,073,499 in HUD funds and a second count of failing to pay federal taxes on $711,821 for the 1986 tax year.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Call For Nationalization Make Business People Nervous
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's release may lead to talks between blacks and whites on South Africa's future, but many business leaders doubt his economic theories would make for sound management of the continent's strongest economy. Mandela, the African National Congress leader released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, favors state control of the country's gold mines, banks and monopoly industries to help redistribute the wealth that is disproportionately controlled by whites. Many economists and business executives say attempts to nationalize South Africa's economy will result in the stagnation that has plagued Eastern Europe and Africa's socialist-oriented economies. ``The ANC remains locked in the past ... its economics 35 years out of date,'' said Business Day, a financial daily opposed to apartheid. Raymond Parsons, head of the South African Chamber of Business, says if ``South Africa is to survive in the modern global economy, and if we are to serve the total population best, we are going to have to expand the private enterprise ethic.'' Mandela and most other senior ANC leaders are in their 60s or 70s and were imprisoned or fled into exile in the early 1960s, when ``scientific socialism'' was the favored economic system among Africa's newly independent states. Such systems have failed miserably. No more than five black African nations have per capita incomes in excess of $1,000 a year, and none of those are socialist oriented. Yet the ANC contends some degree of socialism is needed to help reduce the enormous gap between white wealth and black poverty. ``The nationalization of mines is a fundamental policy of the ANC,'' Mandela said after his release. ``I believe the ANC is quite correct in this attitude.'' Such talk sent the Johannesburg Stock Exchange falling. Mandela has since sought to reassure white businessmen by saying the ANC would consult business leaders before making any major economic changes and would expect both sides to compromise. The ANC is the main black group fighting the white-minority government and most observers believe it would win elections if blacks were allowed to vote. The organization was legalized Feb. 2 and plans to send a delegation from its headquarters in Zambia to meet President F.W. de Klerk and try to clear the way for talks on a new constitution that will include the country's 28 million blacks. South Africa is the world's largest gold producer, and a handful of mining conglomerates dominate the economy. Many blacks see apartheid and capitalism as intertwined, and feel both need to be eradicated. Many anti-apartheid groups, including the largest black labor federation, the Congress of South African Trade Unions, are avowedly socialist. ``South Africa seems to be one of the last places on earth where the display of the hammer and sickle at public rallies still evokes cheers,'' Herman Nickel, a former U.S. ambassador to South Africa, wrote recently in The Wall Street Journal. Per capita income for South African blacks is about $1,000 a year, but whites make at least five times more on average. Economic opportunity was virtually non-existent for blacks until recent years. Whites controlled private companies and dominated managerial posts in the large state-run industries, such as steel, transport and energy. The government recently has begun to sell off huge state operations, saying they will be more efficient as private companies. But some blacks, including Mandela, argue the moves are designed to keep wealth in white hands now that there is talk about the possibility of a black government. Blacks are now making some economic progress. Their incomes are rising faster than those of whites, and black-run businesses range from large construction firms to taxi fleets. Sam Motsuenyane, president of the black National African Chamber of Commerce, has earned the respect of many anti-apartheid leaders with his calls for black empowerment through economic success. Black Enterprise magazine, which features examples of thriving black-owned businesses and offers advice to aspiring entrepreneurs, has done well since its launch several years ago. The anti-apartheid City Press, the country's largest black-oriented newspaper, said in a recent editorial that ANC leaders have ``to seriously review their stand on nationalization.'' ``While we agree there has to be some form of redistribution of wealth beacuse the majority of the people in this country were disadvantaged by the system of apartheid, we tend to agree with ... Motsuenyane's assertion'' about black economic empowerment, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Crazy Eddie Once Again A Fugitive After Appellate Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: For the second time, ``Crazy Eddie'' founder Eddie Antar is wanted by federal marshals in connection with an order to turn over $52 million in overseas funds, officials said Wednesday. The arrest warrant was issued by U.S. Magistrate Ronald J. Hedges after the reclusive founder of the consumer-electronics store chain failed to appear at a court hearing Tuesday. ``He's a wanted fugitive. We have a lot of addresses, but we don't know where he is,'' said U.S. Marshal Arthur Borinsky. Antar, who is under investigation by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, had been ordered by U.S. District Judge Nicholas Politan to turn over $52 million the SEC alleges was obtained in insider trading. The SEC has been pursuing a civil securities fraud case against Antar and three other former officers of the 43-store empire, which collapsed last year. On Feb. 9, Politan issued an arrest warrant on civil contempt charges after Antar failed to show up at a hearing to explain why he did not obey the order to return the money. Antar appealed Politan's order to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and surrendered voluntarily on Feb. 13 to the U.S. marshal in Newark. His attorney, Jack Arseneault, has argued that to return the money would be self-incriminating because it would be tantamount to an admission that the money is there. Politan has rejected that argument. Last Friday, the appellate court in Philadelphia also struck down the argument, clearing the way for civil contempt proceedings if Antar fails to turn over the money. Hedges issued the arrest warrant after Antar's lawyers explained that their client was unavailable, court officials said. Antar's lawyers did not immediately return telephone calls to their office Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Hope Insurance, Federal Financial Help Will Keep Town Above Ground
DOC.TEXT: Residents of Cannelburg, built upon a labyrinth of abandoned coal mines, are not kidding when they say their town is slipping away. Amid reports of shaky foundations and dropped floors, state officials have warned them not to be surprised if the entire town eventually is swallowed up. Residents hope to be shored up by federal financial help or special mine insurance. ``The town is completely undermined,'' said Lisa Howard of Cannelburg's Citizens Helping Against Mine Subsidence. ``The town is suffering from mine subsidence and will eventually subside.'' At least 25 of the 60 homes in the community of 150 in southern Indiana already have been damaged, Mrs. Howard said. A federal emergency was declared last October when a 24-foot-wide and 4-foot-deep sinkhole developed under Cannelburg's main street. It was later repaired. But sinkholes and depressions have since materialized at an alarming rate. Mine and safety authorities believe miles of abandoned, slowly deteriorating mines underneath the city are causing the depressions. The Indiana Department of Natural Resources wants to conduct extensive tests to determine the exact cause of structural damage. Sue Beckett said her home has nearly twisted on its foundation. At first, she said, ``we noticed minor things. We had a door that swelled and wouldn't shut. But in the middle of November it started to progress.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note CHARLESTON, S.C.-dated Prince Charles item; PMs report also will have WASHINGTON-dated PM-Prince Charles, Bjt.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher put aside old political wounds and went to a lunch honoring former Prime Minister Edward Heath, whom she defeated for the Conservative Party leadership 15 years ago. Heath's bitterness has never waned. He refused to serve under Mrs. Thatcher and has kept up steady criticism of her policies. But he welcomed her in the Savoy Hotel Wednesday, and they chatted amiably among more than 500 guests marking Heath's 40 years in the House of Commons. Heath said he was ``very touched'' that Mrs. Thatcher had found the time to be there. But he found his old self quickly enough, criticizing the government for shuffling its feet on the reunification of Germany. Heath said he and other rank-and-file lawmakers had the duty to ``keep the government up to the mark.''

High school math teacher Jaime Escalante, whose life inspired the film ``Stand and Deliver,'' is among six people to be honored with a Common Wealth Award. Escalante, 59, took a substantial pay cut from his job with an electronics company to teach at Garfield High School in Los Angeles. Using teaching methods that stress hard work and self-confidence, Escalante helped turn Garfield into a model school. The othr winners who will be honored at an April 7 banquet were director and choreographer Jerome Robbins, sociologist Mirra Komarovsky, newspaper columnist David Broder, novelist Aharon Appelfeld and computer scientist J.C.R. Licklider. Each recipient will receive $20,000 and an engraved trophy. The awards have been given annually since 1979 for achievement in dramatic arts, literature, mass communications, public service, science and invention and sociology. The awards are part of the Common Wealth Trust established by Ralph Hayes, former U.S. secretary of war.

Long odds never bothered Sylvester Stallone's cinematic alter ego Rocky Balboa, but his fans have an uphill battle to keep Rocky's 8{-foot bronze likeness atop the steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. ``Would you like to buy a prizefighter 8 feet high?'' museum President Robert Montgomery Scott asked Wednesday. Scott wants the statue gone from the front of the museum when filming is done for ``Rocky V,'' but the prop-turned-tourist-attraction is gaining supporters, including Mayor W. Wilson Goode. ``There is a contract between the `Rocky V' production group and ourselves that it will be removed on Saturday but they've been pushing pretty hard to keep it there,'' Scott said. ``Rocky'' creator Sylvester Stallone had the statue made for the third movie in his series about a Philadelphia club fighter who makes it to the top. The statue, its arms and gloved fists held high, can appear towering from the right camera angles. But in the plaza surrounded on three sides by the museum and its tall columns, ``it looks like a toy,'' Scott said. Goode said the statue represents ``the struggle of so many people.''

Britain's Prince Charles urged business leaders from around the globe to take an active role in promoting free enterprise in Eastern Europe. ``Business leaders can be a real force for positive change throughout the world,'' Charles told more than 100 chief executives Wednesday. ``Clearly, you are operating in a changing world with all sorts of new market conditions.'' Business in the Community, a London-based charity founded by the prince, invited the corporate executives to Charleston for two days of discussions on the role of business in the coming decade. Earlier Wednesday, the prince planted a tree at a public housing complex, signifying the city's rebuilding after Hurricane Hugo. The hurricane came ashore at Charleston on Sept. 21 with 135 mph winds, leaving 29 dead and $5.9 billion in damage across the state. Charles was meeting with President Bush today.

Dustin Hoffman, Robert Goulet, Mary Martin and Ralph Bellamy were on the bill for the 75th anniversary of the Shubert Theater, once Broadway's premier tryout spot. The gala performance May 12 at the Shubert Performing Arts Center will include vignettes from some of the famous shows that appeared on the theater's stage and reminiscences by some of the stars who appeared in them. The Shubert's owners are hoping proceeds from the event _ tickets cost from $60 to $250 _ will enable them to conclude a two-year, $2 million endowment campaign. Judith Lisi, the theater's executive director, called the gala ``an opportunity to look back at the history of this illustrious theater,'' which was home to the world premieres of all of Rodgers' and Hammerstein's musicals.

DOC.HEAD: Opinions Mixed About Influence of Sanctions on Reform
With PM-Mandela's Economics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Economic sanctions have retarded growth, costing jobs and affecting social programs, but whether they have pushed the government to political reform is a matter of argument. ``We believe sanctions have been very helpful,'' Nelson Mandela said after President F.W. de Klerk freed the African National Congress leader from a life prison term Feb. 11. Mandela also credited ``mass struggles'' inside South Africa and changes in the thinking of government leaders for his release and the legalization of the ANC and other organizations. Government officials and white businessmen acknowledge the economy has been affected by withdrawal of investments, trade embargoes and punitive loan terms, but say political changes are being made simply because it's the right thing to do. Finance Minister Barend du Plessis stands by the government line that sanctions did not influence reform, although they cost the country wealth and jobs. He said this week the reforms de Klerk has made may ease the sanctions. That already has happened in Britain's case. On Wednesday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher lifted a ban on investments and urged the European Economic Community to end other punishments as an encouragement to de Klerk. Kent Durr, the South African trade minister, said the British action would encourage negotiations on an end to apartheid. When de Klerk returned from meetings with Mrs. Thatcher and other European leaders in June, he said international pressure and economic sanctions may ease ``as long as it is visible that we're really working to end apartheid and white domination of the government.'' He has since ended segregation of beaches, allowed huge anti-government demonstrations, legalized 60 organizations, freed some political prisoners, suspended all executions and partially lifted the state of emergency. De Klerk never said he was caving in to foreign pressure, as right-wing opponents claim, but he has clearly linked South Africa's internal economic and political problems with its international image. ``The time has come for South Africa to restore its pride and to lift itself out of the doldrums of growing international isolation, economic decline and increasing polarization,'' he said at his inauguration in September. ``We are going to open the door to prosperity and economic growth ... by breaking out of the international stranglehold which, for political reasons, has been applied to our growth potential.'' Nico Czypionka, chief economist of the Standard Bank, said: ``Sanctions did certainly undercut economic growth ... but I don't think that was the factor that triggered the political changes taking place.'' He said the black population boom and urbanization of hundreds of thousands of rural blacks probably contributed to the goverment's movement toward reform. Financial experts agree the most damaging sanctions were those by lenders. In 1985, creditor banks decided not to renew loans, and to impose strict credit policies. Economists at the Trust Bank estimate South Africa would have had $14 billion more in loans and investment in the past five years _ and $4 billion more in export earnings _ had it not been for sanctions and political turmoil. Sanctions also forced businesses to increase efficiency, showed consumers they could do without many imported luxuries and caused the government to change its financial policy. Most of the nearly 200 foreign companies that left South Africa sold their local operations to domestic owners for low prices to be paid over long terms. Few jobs were lost, but many social, educational, housing and training programs begun by foreigners were dropped.

DOC.HEAD: Sculptor Argues against Grounding of His Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Kansa in 2nd graf is correct.
DOC.TEXT: A sculptor told lawmakers he would never have entered a competition to design a major state statue if he knew they were going put it on the ground instead of on top of the Statehouse dome. The proposed 20-foot statue, named Ad Astra from the state's motto, ``ad astra per aspera'' or ``to the stars through difficulty,'' was designed by Richard Bergen of Salina. It depicts a male Kansa Indian pointing a bow and arrow toward the sky. After years of debate about a plan to put a statue of Ceres, the goddess of agriculture and fertility, atop the Capitol dome, the 1984 Legislature authorized the Kansas Arts Commission to conduct a competition and choose an alternative statue. Bergen's design was named the winner in 1988, and he was awarded a $1,500 prize, plus the promise of a contract to produce the full-sized work for $50,000. He told the House Economic Development Committee on Tuesday he could have it done in one year. However, the project ran into a major problem: an assessment of the dome's structural condition produced an estimate that it could cost as much as $400,000 to shore it up so it could hold the two-ton statue. The 1989 Legislature declined to appropriate the money. A bill introduced this year would place Ad Astra on a pedestal base on the Statehouse grounds, rather than on the dome, at a cost of only $25,000. Bergen strenuously objected. ``I designed this originally to go up on the dome,'' he told lawmakers Tuesday. ``I don't want it on the ground. If they had said they wanted it on the ground, I wouldn't have been in the competition.'' ``That's not the way Kansans work. We complete our tasks,'' he said. ``If I have to go out and raise the money to put it up there, I'll do it.'' Bergen argued the dome is sound enough to hold his statue if the state would just perform normal maintenance and spend a nominal amount to shore it up. He also said the $400,000 estimated cost is inflated, because it contains $100,000 in contingency fees in case costs wind up higher than expected. He said he can get a helicopter on loan to do hoist work, eliminating a $78,000 expense. ``I think we ought to go ahead and put the thing up there,'' he told the committee. Lucinda Foster, chairwoman of the Arts Commission, said the statue is shaped to be viewed from 300 feet away, and putting it on the ground would detract from its esthetic value. ``This proposal unfortunately, raises more problems than it solves ... unless it is a temporary plan,'' Mrs. Foster said.

DOC.HEAD: Even Tax Accountants Can't Get it Right
DOC.TEXT: Ask 50 tax experts to calculate the federal taxes of a make-believe family and you'll get 50 different answers _ most of them wrong. ``Money'' magazine tried it and discovered: _The 50 pros figured the $130,000-a-year family owed somewhere between $9,806 and $21,315. The correct answer, ``Money'' said, was $12,038. _Although the family had some tax problems that most Americans will never face, some of the experts fumbled such basic items as the credit for child care expenses, the deduction for moving expenses and the Social Security tax owed by a self-employed person. _The 35 certified public accountants, eight independent enrolled agents, two non-CPAs and five preparers from such chains as H&R Block charged fees ranging from $271 to $4,000. _There was no logical connection between fees charged and performance. ``Of the two preparers who fared best, one charged about $275 above average; the other around $260 below,'' the magazine said. Over the past three years, the average preparation fee for an upper-income return has risen by 30 percent, to $1,012 this year. While the pros are still having their problems with the 1986 tax overhaul, ``Money'' found the people who answer questions by phone at the Internal Revenue Service are doing a little better this year. IRS personnel correctly answered the magazine's questions 72 percent of the time, compared with 59 percent a year ago. Should the news about the tax experts scare you into preparing your own return, as only about one-half of taxpayers still do? The magazine offers this advice: ``If our insanely complicated tax code can trip up even highly trained CPAs, what hope would a mere layman have unless his return was relatively simple or he was an avid amateur accountant willing to put in long hours of study?'' This is the third straight year that ``Money'' has handed tax professionals the records of a hypothetical family and asked them to calculate what the family owes under the new tax law. The first year, no two preparers computed the same tax due, and their answers ranged from $7,202 to $11,881. The second year, the range was from $12,539 to $35,812; only 10 experts managed to avoid significant errors. ``This year's results were even more depressing: our test stumped all but two of the 50 tax pros who were willing to grapple with it,'' the magazine reports in its March issue. This year's test involved John and Jane, who had two preschool children and income of $132,000. Their finances put them in the top 2 percent of earners, and although some of their tax problems will never be encountered by most Americans, they should not pose a major problem for professional tax preparers. In addition to several errors on the child care credit and self-employment tax, ``Money'' said, other major mistakes involved calculation of taxes on mutual fund shares; tax consequences of Jane's $8,000 loss on worthless stock; the handling of the couple's retirement accounts and treatment of moving expenses. In testing the IRS personnel who take tax questions by phone, ``Money'' found the answers were correct 90 percent of the time if they were to be found in the Form 1040 instruction booklet or in basic IRS information publications. But if the question-takers had to dig, the magazine said, they tended toward misleading advice. ``Money'' said taxpayers who have to use professional preparers should invest in a commercial tax guide so they can take as much knowledge as possible to their tax lawyer or accountant. The magazine's closing advice has been echoed in the past by the IRS: ``keep asking your preparer questions about any items on your return that you don't understand. The more questions you ask, the more you'll force your pro to think again about the issues _ and maybe even spot an error that might otherwise bring down the wrath of the revenuers.'' None of the nation's six largest accounting firms would calculate the taxes for the hypothetical family. The magazine quotes a spokesman for the Arthur Andersen firm as saying ``his firm had a lot to lose by performing poorly and little to gain by doing well.''

DOC.HEAD: Barbecue Restaurant Owner Claims Employee Stole Sauce Recipe
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a barbecue restaurant who claims a former employee absconded with a secret sauce has taken his beef to court. Chris Carroll, owner of Spring Creek Barbecue in Arlington, has filed a lawsuit against Londell Fisher, co-manager of the nearby Stage Coach Bar-B-Que. Carroll contends that when Fisher left Spring Creek in December, he took the secret barbecue sauce recipe with him. Carroll's suit claims only three employees knew Spring Creek's sauce recipe and that Fisher continues ``to serve barbecue sauce which is made from the same confidential recipe.'' Fisher says there's no secret to Carroll's sauce. ``How can you call it a secret when everyone in the kitchen who had to prepare the sauce knew the recipe?'' he asked, estimating that eight or nine workers were privy to the recipe. Fisher also said Stage Coach uses a different secret sauce. ``I think it's a little spicier.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Career Officers May be Forced Out in Army Cutbacks
DOC.TEXT: The Army says some career officers may be forced out as the service shrinks in the next few years to adapt to a fading Soviet military threat. The service's top military and civilian officials told Congress on Wednesday that career officers would be eliminated only as a last resort, but such cuts may be needed as part of a reduction in overall U.S. military strength. ``The Army will not dismiss them lightly and break faith,'' said an Army ``posture statement'' presented to the House Appropriations defense subcommittee by Army Secretary Michael P.W. Stone and Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the Army chief of staff. The report said the Army would continue to try to keep high-quality soldiers and military leaders even as defense spending declines and troop levels are cut. ``We must continue to attract and retain the best educated, motivated and ambitious young men and women our nation has to offer,'' Stone told the subcommittee. The subcommittee hearing was closed to the public. Copies of the Army report and the prepared testimony of Stone and Vuono were released at the Pentagon. The report gave no estimate of how many of the 375,000 career Army officers and noncommissioned officers might be dismissed. Such reductions would be highly unusual for the U.S. military, which following World War II, the Korean War and Vietnam was able to slim its ranks by turning loose thousands of draftees eager to re-enter the civilian economy. Today's soldiers and officers, however, are all volunteers, and for many the service is a career. In a joint introductory passage in the Army report, Stone and Vuono said movements away from totalitarian rule in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe had opened the way to ``what may be a significant reduction in the possibility of war between major industrialized nations.'' But they added, ``Soviet and Soviet-supported military action in Europe and Asia will remain a demanding challenge'' for the U.S. military, requiring that the Army remain ready for high-intensity warfare even as it shrinks in size. The Army is planning to trim its ranks by more than 100,000 over the next few years, to a total of about 770,000. The report also spelled out the changing nature of the Army's mission. It said that although the Army would try to remain prepared for a large-scale, high-intensity war on the European continent, it would put increasing emphasis on the risk of low-intensity conflicts such as Third World skirmishes and strikes at terrorists. ``Clearly, low-intensity conflict is the security challenge most likely to demand a ... U.S. military response in the future,'' the report said, adding that more than 800 soldiers currently are involved in counter-narcotics missions. The report said Army forces have been providing ``training and support'' to anti-narcotics units in Latin America ``for some time.'' It cited Bolivia and Colombia as examples. No other details were provided. ``Involvement in the national campaign against illegal drugs is consistent with the Army's role as a strategic force, fulfilling the overall mission of safeguarding the national security of the United States both at home and abroad,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Avianca Recommendations
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of communications between pilots of Avianca Flight 52 and air traffic controllers prior to the Jan. 25 crash that killed 73 people at Cove Neck, N.Y., as disclosed in National Transportation Safety Board urgent recommendations on the crash: 8:44 p.m. _ Air traffic controllers tell the plane to expect clearance to continue on at 9:05 p.m. The response is: ``Ah, well, I think we need priority; we're passing out of (garbled).'' The controller: ``Roger, how long can you hold and what is your alternative (airport)?'' The plane crew replies, ``Yes, sir, we'll be able to hold about five minutes, that's all we can do.'' 8:46 p.m. _ A controller at New York Air Traffic Control Center advises another control center, New York TRACON, that Avianca 52 ``can only do five more minutes in the hold. Do you think you can take him or should I offer him his alternate?'' The second controller says, ``Slow him to one eight zero knots and I will take him'' into Kennedy Airport. At the same time, the flight crew advises the first controller, who has asked for his alternate airport, ``It was Boston but we can't do it now. We, ah, we will run out of fuel now.'' 8:56 p.m. _ The plane is instructed by a controller to ``turn right, right turn heading two twenty. I'm going to have to spin you (make a 360-degree turn), sir.'' 9:03 p.m. _ During the next seven minutes, Avianca 52 receives routine radar service, including several heading changes and further clearances in its descent into Kennedy. 9:11 p.m. _ The final controller: ``You're on five miles from the marker. Maintain two thousands till established on localizer cleared (runway) 22 left.'' 9:15 p.m. _ The flight crew is instructed to contact Kennedy Airport tower. The tower tells Avianca it was No. 3 to land. 9:23 p.m. _ Avianca 52 advises the Kennedy tower it is executing a missed approached. 9:24 p.m. _ The flight crew: ``Ah, we'll try once again, we're running out of fuel.'' Controller: ``Okay.'' 9:25 p.m. _ Avianca, acknowledging instructions from the final controller: ``Climb and maintain three thousand and, uh, we're running out of fuel, sir.'' Controller: ``Okay, ah, fly a heading of zero eight zero. I'm going to bring you about fifteen miles northeast and then turn you back on for the approach. Is that fine with you and your fuel?'' The response: ``I guess so. Thank you very much.'' 9:29 p.m. _ ``When can you give us a final?'' asks Avianca. The final controller responds: ``Affirmative, turn left heading zero four zero.'' 9:30 p.m. _ After the controller clears the plane to maintain 3,000 feet, the flight crew says, ``Ah, negative, sir, we just running out of fuel. We okay three thousand...'' 9:32 p.m. _ From Avianca: ``We just lost two engines and we need priority please.'' The controller advises the plane that it is 15 miles from the airport outer marker and clears it for approach to runway 22 left. 9:34 p.m. _ The controller: ``You have, ah, you have enough fuel to make it to the airport?'' Avianca 52 did not respond.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Promises Measures To Protect Americans From Guerrilla Threat
DOC.TEXT: The government is promising special measures to protect Americans threatened with death by a leftist guerrilla group, and U.S. nationals are hiring extra security guards. Americans on the U.S. Embassy staff were told Wednesday to stay home except for necessary trips and were being escorted to and from work by armed guards, an embassy employee said. A U.S. oil executive said his company had canceled all trips outside Bogota by American employees. ``Every American client I've got was on the telephone this morning asking for more guards,'' the owner of a security company that protects several U.S. companies told The Associated Press. The National Liberation Army declared Tuesday that all U.S. interests in Colombia were its military targets. It has kidnapped three Americans in a week. James Donnelly of Detroit and David Kent of Indianapolis still were beomg held, but the guerrillas freed the Rev. Francis Amico Ferarri of Rochester, N.Y., a Roman Catholic priest. Minister of Government Carlos Lemos, a member of the National Security Council, said after a council meeting Tuesday night that the government was making special arrangements to protect Americans and U.S. business interests. He said it appeared recent attacks by the guerrillas also were meant to discourage people from voting in congressional and mayoral elections March 11. The National Liberation Army has become the most anti-American and violent of Colombia's six guerrilla groups. Manuel Perez, a former Catholic priest, commands the pro-Cuba guerrilla group. Two years ago, his guerrillas began blowing up sections of Colombia's largest oil pipeline an average of almost once a week. The line, which carries 240,000 barrels of crude a day from northeastern Cano Limon field 500 miles to the Caribbean coast, has been attacked twice this week and seven times in 1990. Ecopetrol, the state oil company, said the pipeline had been shut down since Monday because of the damage. A spokesman, who insisted on anonymity for fear of becoming a guerrilla target, said it should reopen in a few days. The guerrillas have made their threat against Americans three times, first in a letter addressed to the families of Kent and Donnelly. It was published by the daily El Colombiano of Medellin, headquarters of the most powerful cocaine cartel, where the men were kidnapped Feb. 13. Amico told the Bogota daily El Tiempo that he carried another copy of the threat when he was released, in the form of a statement from the National Liberation Army. On Wednesday, the Spanish news agency EFE said it had received a threatening guerrilla statement that singled out Thomas McNamara, the U.S. ambassador. No firm figures are available on the number of Americans in Colombia, but past U.S. Embassy estimates have been about 20,000. The State Department already had considered Colombia so dangerous it would send only people who were single or married and willing to live apart from their families. Diplomats get hazard pay for service in Colombia. U.S. oil companies operating in the country include Occidental, Exxon, Texaco, Houston Oil, Amoco and Chevron. Among the dozens of other U.S. firms are IBM, Xerox, General Motors, Colgate-Palmolive, Borden, Johnson & Johnson, Squibb and Kodak. The most serious attack on a U.S. company by the guerrilla group occurred two years ago when a car bomb exploded outside Occidental headquarters in Bogota, wounding two guards and breaking most windows in the 10-story building.

DOC.HEAD: Some Chinese Students Want to Return to Homeland
DOC.TEXT: An organizer hopes to lead the first announced delegation of Chinese students to return home since the killing of scores of people in Tiananmen Square. ``I believe that this is the right cause. We have to open the door to interaction. Without interaction we can do nothing with the movement back home,'' said Matthew Huang, the leader of the proposed delegation by the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars in the United States. The federation recently voted to seek permission for a visiting delegation. Letters have been sent to the Chinese Embassy in Washington, D.C., but there has been no response so far. Huang, a student at the University of Massachusetts, said it's possible the government will refuse to allow the students to return. ``We do want to go back and we think someone should take the risk,'' said Shen Tong, one of the leaders in the pro-democracy movement in Beijing who eluded capture and is now studying at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass. He said Wednesday he was willing to take that risk. ``This kind of open attitude can basically challenge the Chinese government's closed-door policy,'' he said. ``It's also for the American government. We want to show the Bush administration we didn't give up our struggle.'' The administration, asserting that it is important to maintain a dialogue with China to encourage liberalization, last month vetoed a bill protecting Chinese students against deportation. Bush has twice sent high-level emissaries to China since last summer's bloody suppression. A statement by the student federation said reasons for its visit include investigating what happened to those killed when soldiers moved into Beijing's Tiananmen Square on June 4, as well as seeing ``the real China, normal or not.'' Huang, a 27-year-old biology student, said he's scared about what may happen on a trip home. ``We will try our best to go back and maybe we will face some danger,'' Huang said. ``One thing is for certain is we won't trade our principles.' Officials at the Chinese Embassy in Washington did not return a telephone call on Wednesday. The crackdown of the pro-democracy movement was followed by an outcry by Chinese students studying in the United States. Many were colleagues of the students leading the movement in China.

DOC.HEAD: Electricity Rationed After Rebels Blow Up Utility Poles
DOC.TEXT: Rebel sabotage has forced rationing of electricity in San Salvador and the eastern part of the country, the state-owned electrical company said. Leftist guerrillas dynamited 10 utility poles 70 miles east of San Salvador on Tuesday, the armed forces press office said, and the power company said the sabotage put seven major power transmission lines out of service. A company spokesman said the power supply in the capital was 42 percent below normal and the eastern provinces of Usulutan, San Miguel, La Union and Morazan were also receiving only partial service. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The outages affected large residential, industrial and commercial zones of the capital. Blowing up utility poles and other electrical installations is a tactic frequently used by the guerrillas to damage the economy. In 1989, there were 657 such rebel attacks, according to the power company. Four employees were killed while trying to repair the damage. More than 70,000 people have died in the 10-year-old civil war, the majority of them civilians.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The beautiful homes and narrow, winding streets of this exclusive enclave south of Kansas City are attracting a less-appealing element: diesel-spewing buses full of gawking tourists. Irked residents want to ban the tour buses. They complain of traffic jams, street deterioration, bus fumes and flashing cameras. In July, Mission Hills Mayor Betty Lu Duncan asked large Kansas City-based tour companies to stop sending buses down the city's streets. Most local companies have complied with Duncan's request. But out-of-town companies still send large buses into the city. Next month, the city council will consider banning large tour buses from sightseeing operations. ``If you lived on Mission Drive and tour buses kept coming by your home would you like it?'' asked Phil Carrott, a Mission Hills resident. ``I don't think the regular guy would want somebody driving by his house time after time after time.''

Lifelong Republican Karl Hilli says sending best wishes to a Democrat he respects may have cost him a spot in the town delegation. The state Republican Party stripped Hilli of his membership in the delegation after learning he wrote to newspaper editors extending his ``best wishes'' to state representative candidate William King, a Democrat. ``The times are too tough to be too narrow-minded,'' Hilli said. ``I can't just hammer somebody because he has a `D' next to his name.'' Hilli worked last year to revive the town Republican committee and was chairman of the local GOP delegation. He said he hopes to clear up the situation so he can still serve as a delegate at the state party convention in Boston next month. Alexander Tennant, executive director of the Republican State Committee, wrote Hilli that party rules clearly state endorsing anyone other than a Republican in a partisan election equals automatic resignation. ``I think he's a nice guy,'' Hilli said of King in an interview Tuesday. ``Because I say `Good luck' to someone doesn't mean I support him. I think he'd be a good candidate, but it does not mean I'm endorsing him over a Republican that might run.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 35,826.84, up 92.51 points, or 0.26 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Finding February May Not Be a Dry Month
DOC.TEXT: Colder weather in the Great Plains winter wheat area after two months of relatively balmy temperatures is reminding farmers that it is still February, after all. ``Winter returned to the northern and central plains as Arctic air plunged south and reversed the warm spell of the last two months,'' the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Wednesday. ``Rain benefited winter wheat in portions of the central and southern Great Plains,'' in the week of Feb. 11-17, the report said, although ``additional moisture was needed in Kansas.'' The facility is operated by the departments of Agriculture and Commerce. The weekly reports cover weather and crop conditions but do not include crop production forecasts. Also, the period covered did not include more recent precipitation in the plains area, including up to a foot of snow in the Oklahoma Panhandle and parts of Western Kansas. In a related report, the USDA said wheat inventories may drop to 443 million bushels by the beginning of the next marketing year on June 1, the lowest in 15 years and down from 702 million bushels a year ago. ``However, increases in planted area and a return to normal yields in 1990 will likely allow modest stock rebuilding if use is similar to the previous two years,'' the department's Economic Research Service said. The U.S. area planted to winter wheat last fall is up 3 percent, even though an additional 1.9 million acres of wheat base were enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program during 1989. ``While the winter wheat crop in the southern plains was stressed by dryness in the fall and early winter, precipitation and relatively mild temperatures in January and February have raised crop prospects,'' the report said. ``Nonetheless, timely rains will be needed in coming months.'' Looking at the global situation, the report said wheat export prices in recent weeks have declined to below year-earlier levels. ``Rising foreign stocks, relatively slow sales in the first half of the (1989-90) marketing year, a larger-than-anticipated Southern Hemisphere harvest, and prospects for a large 1990-91 Northern Hemisphere crop have translated into the declining export prices,'' the report said. Overall, global wheat production in 1989-90 is up about 7 percent from a year earlier but consumption will exceed production for the third straight year. That will drain world wheat stockpiles to their lowest level since 1981-82. But all of the decline in global wheat inventories will be in the United States. The report said stocks held by foreign exporters are up 12 percent from the 1989-89 marketing year.

Scientists conducting genetic experiments with ordinary pond scum say it may one day be an automatic dispenser of fertilizer in rice fields. But the scientists, who work for the Agricultural Research Service in the Agriculture Department, said Wednesday it may be another 15 years before rice growers are able to use the pond scum, or blue-green algae, as a fertilizer source. If the procedure can be developed, the natural fertilizer dispensed by the special algae could have a significant effect on rice production around the world, including many Third World countries that rely on the crop as a food staple. Stephen Albrecht, a plant physiologist at the agency's laboratory in Gainesville, Fla., said greenhouse tests with the altered algae boosted rice production eightfold. However, he said it didn't do well in the field, probably because the algae had not been adapted to field conditions. Normally, pond algae produces just enough nutrient-rich ammonia from nitrogen in the atmosphere to take care of its own needs. The genetically engineered strains keep producing as long as nearby plants need the nutrients. When rice plants stop taking in ammonia, the algae stops production before excess amounts spill over into the environment. Albrecht said the on-and-off fertilizing system could mean less groundwater contamination. Tests showed that while rice with algae at its roots had some ammonia, there was none in the environment. If the algae can be adapted to rice fields, Albrecht said growers could grow algae alongside rice fields and flood it into the rice areas at irrigation time. He said it would be cheaper and require less work than with commercial fertilizers.

DOC.HEAD: Broadway's Longest-Running Show To Close
DOC.TEXT: In the summer of 1975, Gerald Ford was in the White House and Leonid Brezhnev was in the Kremlin, Toni Tennille cooed ``Love Will Keep Us Together,'' and ``A Chorus Line'' opened on Broadway. But no show runs forever. Producer Joseph Papp announced Wednesday that the musical celebration of Broadway dancers probably will close March 31 after its 6,104th performance _ the longest run in Broadway history. When ``A Chorus Line'' moved to the Shubert Theater from off-Broadway on July 25, 1975, Broadway was coming off its worst musical season in years. There had been a series of expensive flops like ``Mack and Mabel,'' ``Goodtime Charley,'' ``Doctor Jazz,'' and a revival of ``Good News.'' The only crowd-pleasers were pleasant if undistinguished musicals like ``Shenandoah'' and ``The Wiz.'' ``A Chorus Line'' changed all that. It quickly became the hottest ticket in town. Now, some of its original performers still want it to stay around. ``What I had always hoped would happen, it would go back off-Broadway and go on forever like `The Fantasticks,''' said Kelly Bishop _ Sheila in the original production _ during a news conference. ``Maybe that could happen?'' Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, where Michael Bennett and some cohorts first opened it to the public on April 15, 1975, discounted the possibility. ``Why go back?'' he said. ``We're a symbol of Broadway and should stay there in symbol as well as fact.'' Bob Avian, who choreographed the show with Bennett, predicted that ``A Chorus Line'' will be revived on Broadway in five to 10 years. ``It'll be on the road forever and we can all feel a part of that. You know, classics never die,'' he said. The musical, performed on a nearly bare stage without intermission, tells the stories of 18 dancers auditioning for a big Broadway musical. They are put through their paces by an unseen director who questions them about why they want to dance. Among the hopefuls are Cassie, a featured dancer once linked romantically to the director and now trying to get back into the chorus; Sheila, an insecure, wise-cracking older dancer who discovered as a child ``Everything Was Beautiful at the Ballet''; and Diana, who explains her passion for dance in what became the show's best known song, ``What I Did For Love.'' Papp said that ``A Chorus Line'' has had weeks when it lost money, but so far this year it has steadily incurred losses. He said that weekly operating costs are $160,000 and, since Jan. 1, average weekly income has been $122,825. He hopes that people will rush to see ``A Chorus Line'' before March 31. If box-office lines are long enough, he said, ``A Chorus Line'' might run through Easter week. If ticket sales don't pick up, the show will close before March 31. On Sept. 19, 1983, when the musical logged its 3,389th performance, it became the longest-running show in Broadway history, overtaking ``Grease.'' The second longest-running Broadway show was the revival of ``Oh! Calcutta!'' which closed Sept. 24 after 5,959 performances. It is followed by ``42nd Street,'' 3,486; ``Grease,'' 3,388; and ``Fiddler on the Roof,'' 3,242.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Chief Urges Careful Pace on Insurance Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Attempts to reform deposit insurance could do more harm than good to the nation's financial system, says a top regulator who warns that many proposals circulating would cause negative side effects. Injecting more market discipline into the banking system, although desirable, would involve tradeoffs that include greater financial instability and less protection for consumers, said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``This is a dangerous subject,'' he said Wednesday. ``Don't grab for easy, quick solutions or you're liable to blow yourself out of the water.'' The House Banking Committee hearing, which also featured General Accounting Office head Charles A. Bowsher, opened what promises to be the most explosive financial industry issue before Congress in the next few years. Many private analysts believe deposit insurance helped encourage the risky behavior that led to mammoth S&L losses. Depositors have little or no reason to care whether they were placing their money in a sound institution, they argue. Congress considered the question too hot to handle in last year's S&L bill and ordered the Treasury Department and Bowsher's agency _ Congress' auditing and investigative arm _ to study the mattter and make recommendations by next February. Bowsher gave little hint of the GAO's ultimate stance, but urged legislators not to lose sight of the benefits of the system. ``Deposit insurance deserves much of the credit for the fact that ... there was no serious loss of confidence in the ... banking system'' during the 1970s and 1980s when ``the nation experienced oil shocks, inflation, ... the worst recession since the Great Depression ... (and) a stock market crash,'' he said. On other matters, Seidman: _said the FDIC was investigating whether it had the authority to curb so-called ``golden parachute'' contracts that provide bank and S&L executives with lucrative severance benefits if their institution fails. Perversely, sometimes executives benefit more from an institutions' failure than its success, he said. _issued a new more pessimistic assessment of the commercial bank insurance fund's condition. The fund, which lost $4 billion in 1988 and declined again in 1989, likely will ``about break even'' in 1990, he said, ending the year around $14 billion. ``The reason is we've developed some real problems (in real estate) in the Northeast and down the East Coast and we don't know how much, if anything, that's going to cost us,'' he said. He said ``at this time'' the agency does not expect any major bank failures among institutions currently reporting increased losses. Both Bowsher and Seidman conceded the failure of hundreds of banks and S&Ls in recent years make it clear the government's exposure to loss must be limited. However, Seidman warned, ``depositors must experience real losses to develop real market discipline.'' He added, ``no one really knows what would happen if a large bank were allowed to default on deposit obligations.'' So far, regulators have been unwilling to risk the chance that a failure of a big bank would bring down the entire financial system He said one of the most common reform proposals _ reducing the $100,000 insurance limit _ would probably be ineffective. Most depositors would simply divide their money into smaller chunks and spread it among more institutions. A rule limiting depositors to just one insured account among all banks and S&Ls would be difficult to administer, he said. Nevertheless, Reps. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, the chairman of the committee, said Congress must consider reducing the $100,000 deposit insurance limit, arguing it ``is too broad and has gotten away from its original purpose _ protection of the small depositor.'' But he said legislation was unlikely until next year, after completion of the GAO and Treasury studies. Both Gonzalez and Rep. Chalmers Wylie of Ohio, the panel's senior Republican, said expansion of bank investment powers, long sought by the industry, will not be considered separately from deposit insurance reform.

DOC.HEAD: Divers Retrieve More Bodies from Icy Lake Bottom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with five more bodies recovered, names of victims, search called off for the night; picks up 6th graf pvs, `A preliminary...
DOC.TEXT: Divers pulled five bodies out of frigid Convict Lake Wednesday, but officials said the effort to recover the last of seven people who fell through thin ice would be suspended indefinitely. ``Search efforts have been suspended tomorrow, due to loss of resources and safety factors,'' Mono County Sheriff Martin A. Strelneck said late Wednesday. ``The divers are getting tired and cold, and it's getting dangerous out there for them'' Rescue divers planned to rest and regroup before resuming the search for the body of Dave Meyers, 53, of Bishop, Strelneck said. Two bodies were brought to shore wrapped in yellow plastic bags moments before two more bodies were found at a depth of 100 feet by an underwater video camera used in the search, said Mono County sheriff's spokeswoman Gail Merritt. A fifth body was hauled out before the search and recovery operation was called off for the night. On Tuesday, the body of Forest Service ranger Clayton Cutter, 31, was pulled from the water by searchers pulling on a rope still clutched in the victim's frozen hands. Sixteen teen-agers and two adults from Camp O'Neal, a residential facility for troubled youths, were on a Presidents Day outing Monday when four of the youths plunged through the ice on the lake at the 7,500-foot level in the eastern Sierra Nevada. A 15-year-old managed to pull himself out of the water, but four adults died when they attempted to rescue the others. The five victims whose remains were recovered Wednesday were identified as: Randy Porter, 39, of June Lake; Vidar Anderson, 58, of Long Valley; David Christopher Sellers, 15, of Tulare; Shawn Rayne Diaz, 15, of Dinuba; and Ryan Charles McCanless, 13, of Redlands. A preliminary sheriff's department investigation, completed Wednesday, said the teen-agers were playing, not skating, on the ice-covered lake, which is a mile long and a quarter-mile wide. Sheriff's investigator John Rutkowski said he was trying to determine whether the teen-agers were properly supervised. ``These are the things we're trying to find out: How much supervision did they have? Were they out on the ice alone? How many were out on the ice at one time?'' Judging ice thickness is left to individual common sense at the hundreds of lakes in the rugged Sierra Nevada Range, said Fred Richter, nordic supervisor for the local U.S. Forest Service office. But Tracey Wood, a friend of Clayton Cutter, the Forest Service ranger whose body was recovered from the lake Tuesday, argued: ``They definitely need signs out there.'' ``I know people are going to be rebellious, but before they advertise a lake for ice skating they better let people know how thin the ice is,'' she said. Ice skating is encouraged in Convict Lake brochures. The six-member Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department deep-sea diving team joined 11 divers from Washoe County, Nev., in the retrieval operation Wednesday, Merritt said. ``We've got state-of-the-art stuff up here now. We're sure we will find them all now,'' Merritt said. The Los Angeles dive team, wearing helmets and outfitted with surface air equipment that allows them to stay down for up to 30 minutes, used the video camera to guide them on the bottom of the 140-foot-deep lake. ``We really welcome this help,'' said Merritt. The Nevada divers could dive no deeper than 50 feet and withstand only 10 minutes in the icy water. Camp O'Neal is a private, non-profit residential camp that usually provides education and vocational training for troubled youth, who are referred from throughout the state. Convict Lake, just south of the Mammoth ski resort about 250 miles north of Los Angeles, got its name from a shootout between a posse and escaped convicts in the late 1800s. Twenty-nine convicts escaped from a Carson City, Nev., prison and six of them fled south and killed a mail rider. A local posse caught up with the convicts at Monte Diablo Creek, now Convict Lake, and posse leader Robert Morrison was killed in a gunfight. The convicts escaped, but three of them were captured a few days later. Two of the recaptured convicts were lynched en route to jail at Carson City.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EST; time by source
Government Weather Map Includes ``Microclimates'' for Gardeners
DOC.TEXT: A new map unveiled by the Agriculture Department today shows detailed temperature zones across the nation to aid home gardeners and nursery operators. The new Plant Hardiness Zone Map, updated for the first time in 25 years, shows detailed markings and information for all 50 states, including Alaska and Hawaii for the first time. Also, for the first time, small areas of ``microclimates'' are indicated, said H. Marc Cathey, director of the department's National Arboretum, who oversaw revision of the map. These are cool pockets caused by mountaintop elevations and hot spots in cities or protected valleys, he said. For example, the map shows tiny microclimates scattered throughout the Rocky Mountain area and the Northeast. Although less concentrated, the microclimates also are shown in the Great Plains, Corn Belt and other regions of the country. Some of them cover parts of several counties, while others are confined to small portions of single counties. Commercial nurseries use the average minimum temperatures designated by the map's zones to determine when plants should be shipped to different parts of the country. Plant varieties are often catalogued by the zones in which they will survive and thrive. Cathey said the map also includes Canada and Mexico. ``Our borders are contiguous and we share many plants, both native and introduced,'' he said in a statement issued by the department's Agricultural Research Service. ``It is appropriate not to isolate the U.S. when talking about climate.'' The map unfolds to four feet by four feet and has 11 color-coded zones based on 10-degree Fahrenheit differences in average annual minimum temperatures. Each zone is divided into A and B regions based on 5-degree differences. Zone 11 is new, representing an almost frost-free zone on the southern tip of Florida, southern California, all but the mountainous areas of Hawaii, most of the coastline of the Yucatan in Mexico, the southern Baja peninsula and the Gulf of Mexico. Information from 14,500 weather stations went into the project, more than twice as many stations used for maps produced in 1960 and 1965. Cathey said there are no signs that might represent global warming. But on both coasts, particularly in the Southeast, temperatures are 5 to 10 degrees cooler in the winter than indicated on the previous map. The new information used to create the map allowed the borders of the zones to be drawn in much more detail than before and are more precise, with intricate edges where the zones interweave. Cathey said the new map ``should eliminate some of the inconsistencies between gardeners' experiences with local weather and the previous map.'' Meteorologist Mark Kramer of Meteorological Evaluation Services, Amityville, N.Y., a private firm which analyzed the data for the department, said the new map ``tells us the weather has changed, but we don't know whether the climate is changing.'' Weather, he said, is day-to-day, month-to-month and year-to-year, while climate represents a longer term, starting with about 30 years. Copies of the map are available for $6.50 each from the Government Printing Office, miscellaneous publication 1475, stock number 001-00004550-04, the agency said. The Washington phone number is (202) 783-3238.

DOC.HEAD: Government May Seek Recall of GM Cars
DOC.TEXT: Faulty brakes that consumers blame for more than 100 accidents may lead to a recall of some General Motors cars, although the company is resisting, the government says. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Wednesday that GM rejected the agency's request to issue a voluntary recall. The agency said it was opening a formal safety defect investigation ``to prepare for a possible government-ordered recall.'' The probe covers 175,000 Chevrolet Camaros and Pontiac Firebirds from the 1982 through 1986 model years. It also covers 273,000 Pontiac Fieros from the 1984 through 1986 model years. Rear disc brakes on many of the vehicles do not adjust automatically as the brake pads wear, the agency said in a statement. ``As a result, the rear brakes may become less effective in stopping a moving car, and the parking brake may be unable to hold a parked car on a slope,'' it said. ``There are no warning signs of the parking brake problem.'' The brake warning light might be activated, depending on the extent of brake pad wear and how hard the driver presses the pedal. But it sometimes illuminates only during emergency stops when the driver is exerting full force on the brake, the statement said. A vehicle typically develops the problem after about 18,600 miles on the road. The agency said it received 42 complaints from owners, including 14 reported crashes and five injuries. General Motors has reported 129 accidents, 13 injuries and two deaths that owners blame on the brake problem. ``We will continue to cooperate'' with the agency, GM spokesman Tom Pyden said. ``The investigation will offer both parties the opportunity to exchange and review additional technical data on this subject. From there, we can work together toward a resolution of this matter.''

DOC.HEAD: TV Program Shows Reconstructive Skull Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Viewers in 12 cities watched as doctors reconstructed a 15-month-old girl's skull on live television, but the infant's parents chose to watch ``The Wizard of Oz'' instead. Surgeons successfully reshaped the infant's skull Tuesday night to correct a rare disorder, plagiocephaly, which causes the seams in the skull to close prematurely. The result is facial deformity and the threat of serious vision problems. The patient, Michele Miller, daughter of Lynn and Paul Miller of the Princeton, N.J., area, was born with the condition. Michele's parents sat out the two-hour procedure in a hospital waiting room watching the classic movie starring Judy Garland as a young girl who dreams of visiting the mythical land of Oz. The operation was televized live by WHYY in Philadelphia and carried by 11 other public television stations, including WQED in Pittsburgh, WGBX in Boston and KERA in Dallas. Fifteen other stations taped the program for later broadcast. WHYY's first live broadcast of an operation, spinal surgery conducted June 19, gave the station at that time its highest ratings ever for a local production and prompted WHYY to plan Tuesday's program. ``We felt this one had an educational mission,'' said WHYY director Mike Quattrone. ``This is something that can be corrected. ... What we want to do is de-mystify something, take away the fears.'' At the end of the program, viewers were invited to call the Philadelphia television station with their comments. Tina Brock of WHYY said at least 100 calls came in within the first 25 minutes. One man said, ``This is the most amazing thing I've ever seen on television,'' according to Brock. A boy called long distance from New York to say the program was ``awesome,'' Brock said. Some callers said at first they found the operation difficult to watch, but were drawn into the medical procedures by the surgeons' clear explanations. ``It went really well,'' plastic surgeon Linton A. Whitaker said. ``There were no great problems, although the child was a little older than the ideal (of six to nine months). It still works very well up to about 18 months, but the bone's a little thicker, a little harder to cut.'' During the operation, the surgeons reshaped Michele's skull and reconstructed the area around her left eye. ``She might have been OK as far as vision, but the side of the head was definitely abnormal,'' Whitaker said. ``Her parents recognized it at birth.'' Prior to the surgery, the left side of her face was slightly flattened. Michele's parents agreed to allow the operation to be televised in hopes of reaching others who have children with plagiocephaly and may not realize it or know that corrective surgery is available. ``Maybe you think something is wrong, but you don't say anything,'' Lynn Miller said. ``... Had I known that surgery was an option, I would have taken her sooner.'' Whitaker said Michele should be discharged from the hospital within a week. The only scar will be on top of her head. Public televisions stations that plan to show the program at a later date are: WLVT in Allentown, Pa.; KQEC in San Francisco; KTCA in St. Paul, Minn.; WCFE in Plattsburgh, N.Y.; South Dakota Public Television; KNPB in Reno, Nev.; WMVT in Milwaukee; KNME in Albuquerque, N.M.; WGVU in Grand Rapids, Mich.; WSKG in Binghamton, N.Y.; KCWC in Riverton, N.Y.; WENH in New Hampshire; KTEH in San Jose, Calif.; WFYI in Indianapolis; and KYIE in Sacramento, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Indicted Mayor Holds Core Support
DOC.TEXT: Beleaguered Mayor Marion Barry would lead a mayoral primary race against all other candidates, including Jesse Jackson, with support from 25 percent of registered Democratic voters, according to a Washington Post poll released today. The Post poll, the latest taken since Barry's Jan. 18 arrest on a cocaine possession charge, found seven of 10 city Democrats believe the mayor should not seek a fourth term and 40 percent think he should resign immediately. But the survey also showed Barry still holds a solid core of support, giving him the edge over other candidates in the crowded field of declared and potential Democratic contenders. Jackson, who has been reportedly weighing a run on the mayor's office but says he won't oppose Barry, was second with 19 percent. Jackson was supported by 26 percent of the respondents when Barry was removed from the field in the poll. City Councilman John Ray was supported by 14 percent of the full Democratic field; Council Chairman David Clarke had 12 percent; congressional Del.
