Walter Fauntroy, D-D.C., had 11 percent; and other candidates had less than 10 percent each. Fauntroy has said only that he is considering the mayor's race. Barry, who was indicted last week on perjury and drug charges, is in a Florida clinic for treatment of what he says is an alcohol problem. He plans to move to Fenwick Hall, a treatment center outside Charleston, S.C., later this week. The mayor has not said whether he will run again. The telephone survey of 800 self-described registered Democrats was conducted Feb. 16-19. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Oblong Turned Out To Be Modern Stomach Stone, Not Fossilized Egg
DOC.TEXT: An oblong object that officials last year proclaimed to be a fossilized egg up to 16 million years old has turned out to be a stomach stone from a modern mammal, possibly a cow. ``Mother Nature fooled us,'' said Mike O'Neill, a U.S. Bureau of Land Management fossil expert. O'Neill said he concluded after two months of study that the surface of the egg-shaped object was made up of calcium phosphate rather than the calcium carbonate it should have contained had it been an ancient fossil. Denver paleontologist Karl Hirsch, when consulted, suggested the object might be a stomach stone, O'Neill said. ``He told me about some papers that had been written on those, so I went to the library and did research, and it matched up,'' O'Neill said. Stomach stones are formed in ruminants, such as cattle, deer or goats, when foreign objects enter their digestive tracts, O'Neill said. The object becomes chemically coated. The stone, found by a Forest Service wildlife specialists last fall in Carson National Forest, probably had been on the ground for three to five years, O'Neill said.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Rejects Communism, Capitalism in Huge Campaign-Closing Rally
LaserPhotos MGA1,2
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega rejected communism and capitalism and asked God for ``wisdom to govern'' in a rousing speech before 300,000 people that closed the Sandinista party's election campaign. He told the crowd that he expects a Sandinista victory over the U.S.-backed opposition coalition in Sunday's elections to finally bring ``respectful'' relations with the United States after a decade of contempt. Members of the wildly cheering crowd waved waving black-and-red Sandinista flags and chanting ``Daniel! Daniel!'' Behind Ortega on a terraced reviewing stand on the shores of Lake Managua were other leaders of the leftist Sandinistas, international election observers, journalists and Bianca Jagger, ex-wife of rock star Mick Jagger. Wednesday's rally was the second largest in Nicaraguan history, surpassed only by one during Pope John Paul II's 1983 visit. Streams of people flowed through town, dancing to rock, reggae and brass bands along the streets. In his speech, Ortega equated his main rival in Sunday's voting, the United National Opposition, with the U.S.-supported Contra rebels who have hounded his government since 1981 but not posed a serious threat for months. He said the rebel force and the opposition coalition, which Ortega grouped as the heirs of ousted dictator Anastasio Somoza, had caused harm to Nicaragua. ``But on February 26, once we win the elections, I'm going to send them the bill and I'll tell them that since the debt is so large and unpayable, we are going to forgive it,'' Ortega told supporters. The rally marked the official end of campaigning; a three-day cooling off period begins today. The election is seen as a referendum on 10 years of Sandinista rule. Voters will choose among 10 presidential candidates, although only Ortega and the opposition coalition candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, have a chance to win. The 1.75 million registered voters will also select a vice-president, 90 National Assembly delegates, representatives for 144 town and city councils and two regional councils for the Atlantic Coast. The Organization of American States, the United Nations and a host of other groups will field 1,500 election observers to ensure the balloting is fair. In a speech sprinkled with religious allusions, Ortega told the crowd Wednesday night that the Sandinista Front has its roots in Christianity because it chooses to side with the poor of this predominantly Roman Catholic country. He quoted a passage from the Bible in which Solomon asks God for wisdom. ``I say: Lord, give me wisdom to govern, give me wisdom to be just, give me wisdom to forgive,'' Ortega said. He called the Sandinista revolution unique and said he hoped it would become ``an example to the people of Latin America and the world.'' ``Here neither the communist model nor the capitalist model is any good. The Sandinista model is the one that belongs to Nicaraguans,'' Ortega said. ``That's what revolutionary knowledge and experience tell us, that we don't have to copy anybody.'' In the past, the Sandinistas have expropriated land and major industries from private owners and nationalized them. Most recently, in June, they seized three major sugar refining plants and three coffee plantations. The Sandinista rally drew truck- and busloads of supporters from as far away as Boaco, 60 miles to the east. Richard Boldan, a farmer from the Boaco area, agreed the economy had been bad _ inflation was 1,700 percent last year _ but said his lot had improved under the Sandinistas. ``If the situation has been difficult, it is because of the war,'' said Boldan, referring to the long guerrilla war waged by the Contras. Ortega said the Sandinista victory would make the United States respect Nicaragua after a decade of hostility. The U.S. Congress cut off military aid to the rebels in February 1988 but kept up non-lethal aid to put pressure on the Sandinistas to hold free elections. ``We want the peace of the man who is respected,'' Ortega said. ``And that is what we always have demanded from the North American government _ respect.'' The Sandinistas put on a lively show, with dance troupes, rock singers, fireworks and bands. Nearly everyone in the crowd had a Sandinista campaign memento _ T-shirts in bright colors with ``Daniel Presidente'' or pictures of other candidates; baseball caps, keychains, belt buckles or headbands. Ortega claimed a crowd of 500,000, but experienced observers estimated it at about 300,000 _ still almost five times what Mrs. Chamorro drew at her closing rally Sunday. Despite a huge campaign effort and opinion polls that generally give Ortega the lead, uncertainty about the outcome lingered. Many Nicaraguans are reluctant to speak their minds to strangers and the large Sandinista rallies appeared padded by public employees and others pressured to attend. In Washington, the State Department said Wednesday that Nicaraguan authorities have been routinely threatening opposition party activists as part of a campaign to influence the elections. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that opposition sympathizers have told the U.S. Embassy in Managua that government security agents have threatened them with ``loss of job or land, bodily harm or even death.'' Mrs. Tutwiler said supporters of Mrs. Chamorro in the military have had their voter registration cards confiscated and opposition poll watchers ``have been threatened not to show up on election day.''

DOC.HEAD: Thomas Judicial Nomination Set for Action in Senate Panel
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Committee meeting begins 10 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Judiciary Committee appears set to approve the nomination of conservative civil rights official Clarence Thomas to become a federal appeals judge, despite sharp last-minute criticism from a member of the panel. Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, circulated a letter among Judiciary Committee members on Tuesday, declaring that he was unsatisfied with answers provided by Thomas to the committee last week. As chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Thomas has been one of the most visible blacks in the Reagan and Bush administrations. And his opposition to affirmative action programs and quotas along with his other conservative views have drawn sharp criticism from civil rights forces. At his confirmation hearing last week, Thomas said state and local agencies were primarily to blame for the lapse without action of more than 900 cases of alleged job discrimination in recent years. Critics from women's and senior citizens groups said at the time that the number of lapsed cases actually ran into the thousands. And Metzenbaum said in his letter Tuesday that the responsibility rested with the commission itself. Metzenbaum said he was not opposing Thomas because of the chairman's political beliefs but because of his remarks on the law at the hearing. As the committee vote approached, however, civil rights forces appeared resigned to Senate approval of Thomas. Some of the steam went out of the drive to block confirmation when Benjamin Hooks, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, announced a day before the hearing that he would not stand in the way of placing Thomas on the court. If confirmed he would take the place of Robert Bork on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, often described as the nation's second highest court. Because it is located in the nation's capital it frequently is called on to decide major governmental cases and it has often been a springboard to the U.S. Supreme Court. Bork resigned after being rejected by the Senate for elevation to the Supreme Court in the most bitter judicial fight of recent years. Thomas, born in poverty in rural Georgia, is a graduate of Yale Law School and his career has been aided by close ties to Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo. He worked for Danforth both in his Senate office and when Danforth was attorney general of the State of Missouri. Thomas was recommended to the panel at his confirmation hearing by Danforth and by Sens. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and Charles Robb, D-Va.

DOC.HEAD: Grammy Winners Agree the Trophy is Important
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: The excitement backstage _ even among the older folks _ showed the six-inch Grammy trophy was something more than just another piece for the mantel. ``If you stick around long enough, you get your just desserts,'' said Don Henley, 42, one of several older rockers who shone at Wednesday night's 32nd annual Grammy Awards. ``I thought you'd only get this at 75,'' said former Beatle Paul McCartney, winner of the lifetime achievement award. ``But in this business they're getting younger and younger. I think Debbie Gibson is getting one next year.'' After taking their trophies on the stage of the Shrine Auditorium, some of the victorious musicians swept through the cavernous backstage area to answer an onslaught of questions from reporters gathered at five different media stages, divided by blue curtains. Bonnie Raitt, the big winner with four Grammys, was ecstatic. ``I feel like the guy that just beat Mike Tyson,'' said Raitt, whose awards included best female rock vocal performance and best album for her ``Nick of Time'' LP. Miss Raitt, known for her mixture of blues, ballads and rock, said she finally feels she is getting recognition since her album recording debut in 1971. ``The critics and peers said finally she made a great record,'' Raitt said, shaking one of her statues. The 40-year-old Raitt said she applauded the nominations this year of many veteran rockers, such as the ``Rolling Stones,'' and ``Traveling Wilburys.'' ``A lot of people over 40 got nominated, so I guess we haven't been put out to pasture,'' Raitt said. Some of the musicians were asked what they might have become if not for their musical careers. The Texas-born Henley, sporting a gray suit, bolo tie and black boots, said he would have been a rancher. Henley was nominated four times and won for male rock vocal performance for his ``End of the Innocence'' album. Actress and singer Bette Midler stoutly said she wouldn't have any career if not for music. ``I like to sing more than anything, it's transporting,'' Midler said. ``I feel at my most creative, when I'm singing.'' Midler and producer Arif Mardin captured the song of the year for ``Wind Beneath My Wings,'' a ballad featured in Midler's movie ``Beaches.'' Rap singer Young M.C., who graduated from the University of Southern California last year with an economics degree, said accounting would be his profession, if not for music. Young M.C. garnered an award for his ``Bust A Move,'' rap song, and said the music industry is gradually realizing the significance of rap music. ``You've got to crawl, before you walk,'' said the rapper. Anita Baker said she was amazed at her triumph in the heavily competitive rhythm and blues female performance. ``Janet deserves it more than me,'' said Baker, who won for her ballad, ``Giving You the Best that I Got,'' which was pitted against Janet Jackson's ``Miss You Much,'' and Aretha Franklin's ``Through the Storm.''

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Says Germanys Should Guarantee Western Border Before Uniting
DOC.TEXT: Before the two Germanys unite they owe it to Poland to agree to a ``peace treaty'' guaranteeing this country's western border, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki insisted. At a rare news conference Wednesday, Mazowiecki also reiterated the Polish position that Soviet troops should remain in their country as insurance. ``We believe that a new stage of history created by the reunification of Germany ... must not be entered with any ambiguity concerning Poland's western border,'' he said, emphasizing his demand that decisions affecting Poland's security not be made without its participation. ``We are demanding that before the reunification, the total removal of these ambiguities must take place.'' Mazowiecki proposed that after East German elections in March, the two Germanys and Poland initial a treaty, ``corresponding with a peace treaty,'' recognizing the post-World War II borders, and that it be signed finally by the government of a unified Germany. He said such an agreement could be negotiated, with Poland's participation, at the reunification talks planned by the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II Allies: the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. A third of present-day Poland was territory forfeited by Germany after World War II, compensating for an even larger eastern Polish territory annexed by the Soviet Union. East Germany and West Germany have individually signed agreements recognizing the Poland's western border. But West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, some of whose political supporters still consider the lands part of Germany, has said he cannot make promises about the border on behalf of a unified Germany. Mazowiecki has demanded a seat at the six-party unification talks when the security of Germany's neighbors is discussed, and he said Wednesday that Poland's ambassadors are delivering letters to the four Allies outlining its position. ``It is unthinkable in today's democratic world to have this form of Yalta when one group of countries could decide about another,'' he said, referring to the 1945 conference when the Allied leaders reworked Poland's borders and ceded Eastern Europe to Soviet hegemony. West Germany has rejected a role for Poland at the talks, saying the unification proposal concerns only the territory of the two Germanys. The United States also has indicated opposition, but Mazowiecki said he would not consider the position final. East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow has expressed ``full understanding'' for Poland's position and his foreign minister, Oskar Fischer, said Wednesday that a united Germany must give full legal recognition to Poland's western border. Fischer also warned of rapid unification, adding his voice to those of other Warsaw Pact officials who say the process is moving too quickly. There have been expressions of support from Great Britian, Mazowiecki said, while France has not made an official statement. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in an interview published Wednesday that a united Germany must guarantee the postwar borders of Poland, which Nazi Germany invaded in 1939 to touch off World War II. Unlike Czechoslovakia and Hungary, Poland has not pushed for the removal of Soviet troops. Mazowiecki's Solidarity-dominated government has said the Soviet troops should remain as insurance against Germany. Mazowiecki said he is aware that the public favors the withdrawal of Soviet troops, ``but we assess this situation realistically, in the perspective of the Germany problem, and thus at the moment do not put this issue in such a category.''

DOC.HEAD: FBI Won't Have to Cut 400 Agents, Justice Department Says
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department says the FBI won't have to cut 400 agents from its payroll next year because it has found new ways to save money under President Bush's proposed budget for fiscal 1991. The cost-cutting measures were worked out in the last few weeks since Bush's budget proposal was sent to Congress, Justice spokesman David Runkel said Wednesday. The proposed budget would have forced the FBI to cut more than 400 agents from its workforce of more than 10,000, probably through attrition, to finance an estimated $42 million in additional overtime expenses. A new law passed by Congress last year increases the overtime pay for federal law enforcement officers, including FBI agents. Under the new plan to pay for the overtime costs, the FBI will stagger the hiring of 338 new agents provided in the 1991 budget to investigate organized crime, drugs and white-collar fraud, said an FBI official. Their hiring will be spread out over the 1991 fiscal year to save money, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The FBI also will postpone the purchase of some new equipment, the official said.
DOC.HEAD: Cavazos Sticks With Troubled Loan Program
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos says he will continue supporting federally guaranteed loans for students in private vocational and technical schools even though their default rate is 37 percent. ``I want to make it clear that in no way does the Secretary of Education advocate stepping away from support of guaranteed student loan programs for proprietary schools,'' Cavazos told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee Wednesday. However, Cavazos said the administration was determined to crack down on institutions with high rates of default. Proprietary schools are privately owned institutions that teach trades such as electronics or auto repair. Overall, counting loans for regular college attendance, there were 1.9 million defaults in the guaranteed student loan program in 1989, and the projected number this year is 2 million. Cavazos was testifying on President Bush's educational budget request of $25 billion, up more than $500 million from the 1990 budget. He noted the federal contribution is about 6 percent of the nation's total expenditure of $353 billion for the current school year.
DOC.HEAD: Official Says Nuclear Arms Plant to Remain Idle Until Summer
DOC.TEXT: The Rocky Flats weapons plant in Colorado, closed indefinitely late last year for safety and management improvements, is unlikely to resume full production until at least July, a senior Energy Department official says. The plant, situated about 16 miles northwest of Denver, is the sole supplier of plutonium triggers for U.S. nuclear warheads, which are vital to maintaining the nuclear weapons stockpile. Neither the Energy Department nor the Pentagon has said how long Rocky Flats could remain out of service before the arms stockpile would be jeopardized. The plant also was closed for a few months in 1988 after a worker was contaminated by radioactivity. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins had said shortly after the latest shutdown that he hoped Rocky Flats would resume production by February, but the contractor that runs the facility says it needs more time to install new safety procedures and retrain workers. Adm. J.M. Barr, the deputy assistant energy secretary for military application, said Wednesday that one of the key plutonium processing facilities could be ready to resume operation by the end of June. Barr said current plans called for the full resumption of Rocky Flats production sometime between July and September, although that was subject to revision. Barr told the Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety, which is monitoring progress toward resuming operations, that he would have a more specific target date ``very early in April.'' Barr stressed that the final decision to resume production rested with Watkins, who in recent weeks has pledged to subject the plant overhaul to a full review by independent observers. Rocky Flats has been plagued by a variety of operating and waste-handling problems in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: High School Graduate Objects to Heavy Metal Song
DOC.TEXT: The selection of a heavy metal rock song for graduation ceremonies at a high school has created a dilemna for the student council president. Instead of Edward Elgar's ``Pomp and Circumstance,'' seniors at Harmony Grove High School picked ``I Remember You'' by Skid Row for their traditional exit walk after the awarding of diplomas. The council president, 17-year-old Jennifer Miller, said this week that her Baptist beliefs ``don't allow me to listen to that type of music.'' Her mother, Janet Miller, said Jennifer has never been allowed to listen to heavy metal music because of what she called its drug messages and anti-religion overtones. Ms. Miller said the song and group were inappropriate for the spring graduation. ``I believe the reputations of groups like Skid Row suggests their own nature.'' ``I support her 100 percent,'' Mrs. Miller said. Superintendent Dan Henley and high school principal Billy Gibbs reviewed the song, and declined to intervene. ``If the song had contained any reference to drugs or anything that could be considered immoral, we would have rejected it,'' Henley said. Ms. Miller said she wanted to attend the ceremony, but would not walk in the seniors walk. ``I have the right to have my diploma handed to me during the ceremony and not sent to me through the mail,'' she said. But Henley disagreed. If Ms. Miller refuses to take part in the senior walk, he said, she will not be permitted to receive the diploma on stage and it will be mailed to her. Gibbs said parents of other students in this town 25 miles southwest of Little Rock would be embarassed if Ms. Miller left early or stayed seated during the song. ``It would look like a visible protest,'' he said. ``Parents should not be put through that.'' Henley said Ms. Miller could appeal his decision to the district school board.

DOC.HEAD: Bolivia, Peru Say No To Coca-Eating Bugs
DOC.TEXT: The world's two largest cocaine-growing countries have rejected a U.S. idea to put coca-chewing caterpillars in their fields, saying the insects might also ravage other crops. The U.S. Agriculture Department is studying the potential for using such insects to kill coca plants in Bolivia and Peru. President Bush has asked for $6.5 million for the program involving the Malumbia moth, whose larvae eat coca leaves. The moth is native to Peru's Huallaga Valley, where more coca grows than anywhere else in the world. But Bolivian and Peruvian officials said Wednesday that Washington should instead spend its time and money helping their farmers switch from coca to other crops. ``The worm is not needed here,'' said Carlos Guillen, a Peruvian government spokesman in Lima. ``What the government wants is to replace the coca crop with other crops, such as coffee, cacao (and) palm oil trees.'' ``Many studies have been made in Peru concerning this worm as a means of eradicating the coca crop,'' Guillen said, and the government views crop substitution as a better solution than eradication. He said use of the worms could endanger citrus trees and other crops. Osvaldo Antezana of Bolivia's Interior Department said Wednesday: ``The government rejects any such ideas because the plan presented in the Cartagena drug summit ... calls for alternative development that would take place with the participation of farmers.'' Bolivian farmers supported their government's position. ``By using bugs, the Americans would be confirming that they do not have any political will to solve the social and economic problems in Bolivia,'' said Segundino Montevilla of the Confederation of Bolivian Peasants. ``If it is true, this would mean that the famous Cartagena drug summit made no sense.'' Antezana, the undersecretary for alternative development, said Bolivia's policies ``are clear and concrete. They are based on the voluntary reduction of coca plants with economic compensation ... without the use of chemical products or biological agents.'' Mauro Bertero, the agriculture minister, said: ``I do not believe the United States would attempt something like this without the approval of the government of Bolivia. That would not fit in with the dialogue and agreements reached at Cartagena.'' At the summit a week ago between Bush and the leaders of Colombia, Peru, and Bolivia, U.S. officials agreed to provide aid in developing other crops. Peru produces most of the world's coca, which is processed into cocaine, and Bolivia grows about one-third of it. The Agriculture Department research program was reported Tuesday by The Washington Post, and White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said later: ``We are not undertaking any biological war. Neither troops nor caterpillars will go in without prior request and consultation.'' More than 300,000 farmers in Bolivia and 200,000 in Peru depend on coca for their livelihood. Peru estimates sales of the leaves bring $1 billion into the country each year, and Bolivia earns up to $500 million a year from coca. Bolivian farmers have destroyed 4,940 acres of coca plants since Jan. 1 in return for payments of about $800 per acre. Antezana said the voluntary eradication program had gotten bigger since December because of a sharp drop in coca prices resulting from Colombia's crackdown on cocaine traffickers and increased interdiction within Bolivia.

DOC.HEAD: Global Warming Linked to Carbon Dioxide in Atmosphere
DOC.TEXT: A worldwide warming over the past 30 years is almost certainly related to increases in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, according to a statistical study published today. Detailed analysis found that there is only about two chances in a million that the two trends are not linked, researchers said. But that does not prove that the carbon dioxide was triggering the global warming, they said. Many scientists are concerned that continued buildup of carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere may lead to global warming that could alter climates through an atmospheric process called the greenhouse effect. But researchers disagree over whether gas buildup has caused any detectable warming yet. The statistical analysis is presented in today's issue of the British journal Nature by Cynthia Kuo, Craig Lindberg and David Thomson of AT&T Bell Labs in Murray Hill, N.J. Their work used observations of atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations taken monthly since March 1958 at the summit of Mauna Loa in Hawaii. The values are typical of measurements made at several sites, the researchers said. They compared the concentrations to monthly averages of global temperature from 1958 to 1988 and found a strong statistical relationship between short-term fluctuations in the two trends. That means ``there is probably some physical link'' between the two trends but ``there's no way to say which is causing which,'' Lindberg said in a recent interview. Some third factor, such as increased energy output from the sun, may be causing both observed trends, he said. The analysis found that changes in carbon dioxide concentrations lagged behind those in temperature by five months. That might occur if warmer temperatures cause carbon dioxide to emerge from oceans or elsewhere in the environment, Lindberg and Thomson said in telephone interviews. In a Nature editorial, researcher T.P. Barnett of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif., also said that the study's limitations mean it cannot be taken as proof of warming due to carbon dioxide.

DOC.HEAD: Four U.S. Lawmakers Denied Permission to Observe Lithuania Elections
DOC.TEXT: Four U.S. congressmen have been denied permission to travel to the independence-minded Soviet republic of Lithuania for this weekend's elections, the legislators said. The lawmakers had hoped to pick up visas at the Soviet consulate in East Berlin but the Soviets sent them a cable ``advising us that we would not be allowed to witness the Lithuanian elections,'' Rep. Richard Durbin said Wednesday. The Illinois Democrat and three colleagues were selected by Congress to observe the local elections Saturday after an invitation was received from the Lithuanian national movement Sajudis. ``It's very frustrating. We're running into the limits of glasnost, apparently,'' said John Miller, R-Wash. The members of the party were Reps. Christopher Cox, R-Calif.; and Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas. Lithuania and the other Soviet Baltic republics _ Latvia and Estonia _ want more freedom from Moscow, and the elections will test the strength of nationalists in Lithuania. In December, Lithuania's Communist Party became the first regional party in the country to break with Moscow and declare itself independent. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev later visited the republic in an attempt to dissuade the secessionits but met with little success. Durbin was asked if the Soviets had specified reasons for the visa denial. He said they were told they hadn't gone through the appropriate procedures. ``But frankly that conflicts with the fact that other parliamentarians from Canada and Austria are presently in Lithuania. It appears that they have made some special ruling, as (the denial) relates only to members of Congress from the United States.'' In Moscow, Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said the congressmen had not been invited by any officially recognized groups and said their trip was not coordinated or discussed through diplomatic channels. ``Taking all these facts into account, the congressmen were informed that their trip to the U.S.S.R. at present would be incorrect,'' he said. ``This decision of course is in no connection with the personalities of the congressmen. They are welcome in the U.S.S.R. at any convenient date which could be mutually agreed upon.'' Durbin said the delegation would continue to press for permission to go to Lithuania and would contact Washington ``to rally some support'' to pressure the Soviets. ``We still have time to make it to Lithuania before the election,'' Durbin said. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were independent states between World War I and 1940, when they were annexed by the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Galaxies Clumped in Regular Pattern on Vast Scale, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Researchers said today they had found clumps of galaxies occurring in an apparently regular pattern over a vast distance, a finding that clashes with current understanding of the universe. It was surprising enough to find clumps of galaxies rather than a more uniform distribution over such a large scale, but ``to find the regularity is just mind-boggling,'' said study co-author David Koo. Gravity would not have enough time since the birth of the universe to produce the pattern over such a huge scale, so the find may be a ``fossil imprint'' from the very early universe, he said. But another scientist familiar with the study said he believes the findings are merely a statistical fluke, rather than a real pattern. ``This is so counter to our other notions (about the universe) that I'm going to treat it skeptically unless it's really proven conclusively,'' said Marc Davis of the University of California, Berkeley. The new work is presented in today's issue of the British journal Nature by Koo of the University of California, Santa Cruz, Alexander Szalay of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore and researchers in England. They surveyed galaxies in two opposite directions from the Milky Way galaxy, which includes Earth. Within these narrow lines of sight, researchers found about a dozen clumps of galaxies separated by approximately evenly spaced gaps of 400 million to 800 million light-years, Koo said Wednesday. A light-year is the distance light travels in a year, about 5.88 trillion miles. The calculated distance between clumps depends on one's assumptions about how fast the universe is expanding. The gaps were not completely empty of galaxies. The Milky Way, for example, resides between two clumps in about the middle of the overall series the researchers observed, Koo said. Koo said researchers are now looking elsewhere to see if the regularity shows up again. If the pattern is proven, it would force a revamping or abandonment of currently popular theories about the development of the universe, he said. Davis agreed that the proven existence of such a pattern would require a ``fundamental rethinking'' of theories about the very early universe. ``It is totally outside the domain of any physics we have thought of,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound In Tokyo, Dollar Inches Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's main index fluctuated wildly today but ended up rebounding moderately from its plunge of more than 3 percent the previous day, while the dollar inched up against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which fell 1,161.19 points Wednesday in its third biggest single-day decline, gained back 92.51 points, or 0.25 percent, on Thursday, closing at 35,826.84. The index rose more than 400 points in today's early trading, but then plunged on a wave of computer-guided selling by foreign institutions seeking to capitalize on price differences between shares for immediate delivery and those for future delivery. At the end of the morning session, it was 405.97 points below the previous day's close. But it recovered as investors, who had been waiting uncertainly on the sidelines, gradually returned to the market in the afternoon. Mike Morizumi, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, said these investors thought the market had hit bottom when the index fell to 35,000. But he said a real upward push for stock prices was unlikely before the central bank acts on its official discount rate, the interest charged for loans to commercial banks. The market has been speculating on a discount rate increase following last Sunday's parliamentary elections. Higher interest rates tend to discourage stock investment, and dealers said investors hesitated to make major purchases now. Central bank officials have said they still are watching economic conditions. Dealers and analysts said a wave of computer-guided selling by foreign institutional investors has been a major causes of the Nikkei index's recent decline. ``Because only a small volume of shares is being traded, such massive selling by computer can easily send the entire market falling,'' said Keiichi Nishida of Kidder Peabody Securities. Volume traded on the exchange's first section was estimated at 550 million shares, up from 450 million Wednesday. In the foreign exchange market, the dollar closed at 145.23 yen, up 0.08 yen from Wednesday's close of 145.15 yen. It opened at 145.45 yen and ranged between 145.15 yen and 145.48 yen. In the last three days, the dollar has edged up a total of 0.71 yen. ``Market players cannot figure out the market direction, and they are just taking a wait-and-see stance so far,'' said Akiko Kobayashi, a Bank of Tokyo trader.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Law Allowing Old Rail Lines To Be Used as Paths
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court may have paved the way for thousands of miles of hiking and biking paths by rejecting a couple's appeal of a law allowing unused railway lines to be converted into nature trails. The justices Wednesday unanimously rejected an appeal by J. Paul Preseault and his wife, Patricia, who said a 1983 federal law known as the ``rails-to-trails'' act trampled their property rights to satisfy the nation's back-to-nature and physical-fitness boom. ``I guess at this point I'm stunned,'' J. Paul Preseault said. ``I didn't do this, go all the way to the Supreme Court, to have them tell me to file my case in another court. I wasn't looking for money. I wanted my property rights honored.'' The ruling could affect a large number of property owners. The nation's railway system, at its peak in 1920 with 272,000 miles of track, is now down to 141,000 miles and 3,000 more miles are abandoned each year. Justice William J. Brennan said the rails-to-trails law is a legitimate exercise of congressional power aimed at ``encouraging the development of additional recreational trails.'' But Preseault said the public recreation path that runs through his lakefront property in Burlington violates the U.S. Constitution's Fifth Amendment, which bars the taking of private property without just compensation, and also said it interferes unlawfully with interstate commerce. Brennan said Preseault still can file a claim for compensation against the federal government under a separate law. Preseault said Wednesday he intends to fight for compensation. ``The opinion is a strong reaffirmation of the requirement that government can be asked for compensation,'' said Presault's attorney, Michael Berger of Los Angeles. ``The Supreme Court is saying the federal claims court is there for compensation for this kind of taking of property.'' Ownership of the land claimed by the Preseaults is in dispute. Vermont officials say the property belongs to the state. But if the Preseaults own the property, they say they have a right under Vermont law to use the land once the rail line is abandoned. The 1983 federal law _ an amended version of the earlier National Trails System Act _ allows for railroad rights-of-way to be maintained for possible future railroad use while the land is converted at least temporarily to nature trails. This practice, known as rail banking, is at the heart of Wednesday's ruling. Vermont entered into a lease with the city of Burlington that allows the city to maintain the right-of-way as a trail while preserving it for possible rail use. The Preseaults said the rail-banking provisions are a sham to conceal the true purpose of the federal law _ preventing railroad rights-of-way from being returned to their rightful owners after abandonment. The couple said the rail-banking procedure disguises the fact that the rail lines have been abandoned. Brennan rejected that argument. The law is not invalid ``merely because more Draconian measures _ such as a program of mandatory conversions or a prohibition of all abandonments _ might advance more completely the rail-banking purpose,'' he said. ``The history of congressional attempts to address the problem of rail abandonments provides sufficient reason to defer'' to Congress, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan, South Carolina Legislatures Approve Teen Abortion Bills
DOC.TEXT: Legislatures in South Carolina and Michigan gave their final approval to bills requiring parental consent for teen-agers seeking abortions. The bill passed Wednesday by the South Carolina House requires consent by a parent or other guardian for girls under 17. A spokesman said Gov. Carroll Campbell backed the bill but wanted to ``read the fine print'' before signing it. In Michigan, Gov. James Blanchard said he would veto the bill, which passed the House by a 65-42 vote. The bill's supporters acknowleged they lacked the necessary 74 votes for an override in the 110-member House. The bill earlier had passed in the Michigan Senate. Barbara Listing, president of Right to Life of Michigan, said backers of the bill will try to mount a petition drive to put the issue on a statewide ballot. The group used that approach when it successfully sought to ban state-funded abortions for poor women. ``We're pleased, the parents will be pleased. It will be the abortion clinics that won't be pleased because it will cut into their business,'' Listing said. But abortion rights advocates interpreted the vote's margin as a victory for their movement. ``We won. It's over. They lost,'' said Rep. Maxine Berman, a Democrat. ``What this bill is all about is intimidating women into motherhood.'' Blanchard said the abortion consent bill is unreasonable. ``I would veto it for a lot of reasons, first of which is it would deny any help to women victimized by sex crimes, rape and incest, other abuse,'' Blanchard said. ``I think that's unreasonable.'' The bill would allow pregnant girls under 18 who felt they couldn't approach one of their parents about an abortion, or were denied permission, to seek a waiver from a judge. The South Carolina bill requires girls under 17 to get the permission of a parent, grandparent, guardian or judge before obtaining an abortion. It offers no exception for girls who have been raped. Parents who deny their daughter's request for an abortion would have to share legal and financial responsibility for their daughter's offspring until their daughter reaches the age of 18. The South Carolina Senate already approved the bill. ``The governor endorses the concept of parental consent but wants to read the fine print'' before he signs the bill into law, said Tucker Eskew, Campbell's spokesman. Rep. Wes Hayes, the bill's sponsor, hailed the passage and termed the measure ``pro-family legislation.'' ``It says that we want to have somebody else involved in the decision process other than just that 16-year-old and the abortion clinic,'' said Hayes, a Democrat. South Carolina law now requires a girl under 16 to obtain a parent's consent for an abortion, but the law has not been enforced.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Ministry Strongly Protests U.S. Rights Report
DOC.TEXT: China today strongly protested a U.S. State Department report that accuses it of widespread human rights abuses, insisting the report's contents are based on lies and hearsay. However, a Foreign Ministry spokesman refused to say if his government planned to retaliate in any way. Past responses to foreign criticism often have contained warnings that relations would be damaged. ``The Chinese government and people express their utmost indignation at this (report), which violates the basic norms governing international relations,'' said the spokesman, Li Zhaoxing, reading a prepared statement at the ministry's weekly news conference. ``The Foreign Ministry ... hereby lodges a strong protest with the U.S. Government,'' Li said. The State Department report, issued Wednesday, contained Washington's strongest public criticism ever of China under senior leader Deng Xiaoping, a man whom three American presidents have toasted as a friend. Its comprehensive listing of abuses, from torture and secret executions to pervasive surveillance of daily life, was expected to halt the slight warming of U.S.-Chinese relations that followed the December visit of National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. A Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, predicted that official Chinese contacts with the U.S. Embassy in Beijing would drop off sharply. The embassy experienced similarly chilly relations with many Chinese government units in the first months after the army's June 3-4 crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing. Official newspapers then carried daily attacks on the United States for criticizing the army's killing of hundreds of protesters, and for sheltering dissidents Fang Lizhi and his wife. However, relations began improving in the last months of 1989, following visits of former President Richard Nixon and Scowcroft. The official response to the State Department report said the report was based on ``guesses and rumors''. ``The repeated acts of grossly interfering in China's internal affairs ... are but expressions of out-and-out hegemonism and power politics,'' it said. It also accused the United States of failing to solve its own ``extremely serious human rights problems'' and of violating the rights of Panamanians when it invaded their country in December to oust Manuel Antonio Noriega. Asked to give examples of material in the report that is based on rumor or lies, Li told journalists to read the Chinese press for the truth, and added, ``You might also find answers to your question by resorting to what we in China call a self-examination.'' Li refused to say how many people are being held without trial in connection with the protests. Thousands were arrested in Beijing alone after the crackdown began, and many have not yet been formally charged. The State Department report criticized Chinese judicial procedure and called prison conditions ``invariably harsh and frequently degrading.'' It noted an official Chinese report last year said about 2 million Chinese were sent to labor camps in the past decade. It also noted close monitoring and control of personal life in China, including surveillance by neighborhood watch committees, opening of mail, tapping of telephones and stationing of cameras on roads and in buildings.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President's Brother Named Publisher of Indiana Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Michael E. Quayle, younger brother of Vice President Dan Quayle, has been named publisher of the Vincennes (Ind.) Sun-Commercial, the newspaper's parent company has announced. Quayle will assume his new job on March 1, replacing W.E. Brooks Jr., who is retiring after 26 years as publisher, Central Newspapers Inc. announced Wednesday in Indianapolis. Besides the Sun-Commercial, Central Newspapers owns newspapers in Indianapolis, Muncie, Ind., and Phoenix. Quayle, 33, has held newspaper jobs in Huntington, Ind., Muncie and Phoenix. He is publisher of The Wickenburg Sun, a weekly which he bought from his father in 1986. His father, James C. Quayle, is publisher of the Huntington Herald-Press. He worked for Phoenix Newspapers Inc., which is a subsidiary of Central Newspapers, and the brothers are nephews of Eugene S. Pulliam, head of Central Newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Fog in Northwest; Rain Soaks Gulf to Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Rain soaked the nation today from Oklahoma City to the mid-Atlantic and from the Gulf of Mexico to the Great Lakes. Up to 4 inches were expected by tonight along an area 100 miles inland from the Gulf stretching from Texas to Florida's panhandle. Flood watches continued in Mississippi, Alabama, northern Georgia, northwestern Florida and Louisiana, dampening New Orleans' pre-Mardi Gras festivities. Thunderstorms moved east from Texas into the lower Mississippi Valley after leaving locally heavy rain including 4.01 inches at Rosenberg, 2.80 inches at Fulsher and 2.50 inches at Satsuma. In the Beaumont-Port Arthur, Texas, area, 2.18 inches fell between 1 p.m. and 7 p.m. EST Wednesday. The rain canceled or postponed some of the parades preceding Tuesday's Mardi Gras celebration. Heavy rain and snow disappeared from the fog-shrouded Pacific Northwest today. The Northeast Seaboard looked for low pressure and rain by tonight, some arctic air on Friday and frigid temperatures and a chance of snow by the weekend. Flood watches for tonight were posted in southern Vermont, where falling temperatures were changing rain to snow. Northern Wisconsin and Michigan's Upper Peninsula looked for flurries off Lake Superior today. High winds buffeted Alaska and calmed Hawaii. Temperatures of 28 below and gusts to 30 mph spawned wind chills of minus 75 and colder near Bethel, Alaska. Today's high should be 18 degrees below, with a wind chill of nearly 70 below. The mercury was expected to dive tonight, perhaps to record lows. Chandalar, Alaska, recorded the nation's low of minus 56 Wednesday. Caribou, Maine, was the cold spot in the lower 48 with a reading of 14 below. Gale-force winds abated on Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa today as a Pacific low-pressure system churned northeast toward the mainland. On Wednesday, the Upper Peninsula towns of Sault Ste. Marie and Marquette, Mich., enjoyed record highs for the date with readings of 42 and 46 degrees, respectively. Wednesday's high temperature for the nation was 88 degrees at Fort Myers and Naples, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Bonnie Raitt Triumphs Over Past at Grammys
LaserPhoto LA5
DOC.TEXT: Veteran performer Bonnie Raitt bounced back from a tough decade including a battle against drugs and alcohol and switch of record labels with a high-powered comeback capped by four Grammys. The Grammys were the 40-year-old, rebellious redhead's first in a career spanning 20 years. Her ``Nick of Time'' LP, expressing doubts about love and growing older, won Miss Raitt album of the year and female rock vocal trophies Wednesday. The single ``Nick of Time'' won for female pop vocal performance. Miss Raitt, whose influences include country and blues, also shared the best traditional blues performance Grammy with John Lee Hooker for their ``I'm In The Mood'' track on Hooker's ``The Healer'' album. ``I can only take so much of this. Wake me up when this is over,'' said Miss Raitt, whose previous album, ``Nine Lives,'' was ignored by both critics and her record label, which refused to release it on compact disc. The daughter of Broadway musical star John Raitt (``Carousel'' and ``Oklahoma'') and piano accompanist Marjorie Haydock, Miss Raitt taught herself guitar at age 9. Her early influences included blues master Junior Wells, who contributed to Miss Raitt's first album, ``Bonnie Raitt,'' in 1971. ``Nick of Time'' is her ninth album. One of her best known singles was Miss Raitt's 1977 cover of the late Del Shannon's ``Runaway.'' But in the interim, her work has been uneven as she fought drug and alcohol abuse. Three years ago, she began psychotherapy and a year later she joined Alcoholics Anonymous. The singer said during her recent concert tour, which played to packed houses across the nation, that vanity led to her rebirth as an artist. ``I was going to make an album with Prince,'' she said in 1988. ``It's one thing to go on stage if you're a little chunky, it's another to make a video with a guy who's known for looking foxy. I decided to lose weight, which you can't do if you're drinking all the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Paul McCartney Thanks Beatles Buddies in Accepting Lifetime Award
With PM-Grammys, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Paul McCartney, honored with a lifetime achievement Grammy, said he had a little help from his friends. ``I've got to take this opportunity now that I've got this award here to thank John, George and Ringo for being beautiful people,'' McCartney said Wednesday at the 32nd annual Grammy Awards. McCartney, a five-time Grammy award winner who recorded hits with the Beatles, Wings and as a solo artist, was hailed by actress Meryl Streep for his ``anthems of the spirit'' and honored by Ray Charles and Stevie Wonder, who performed Beatles songs. McCartney in turn paid tribute to those artists who influenced him. ``When I was just child in Liverpool, I was listening to the radio and this record came on called `What'd I Say,' by a guy named Ray Charles. ... A little later there was this guy called little Stevie Wonder and a record called, `Fingertips.' And it had the same effect on me,'' McCartney said. Backstage, McCartney expressed amazement at getting the lifetime achievement award at age 47. ``I thought you'd only get this at 75,'' McCartney said. ``But in this business they're getting younger and younger. I think Debbie Gibson is getting one next year.''

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff's Office Says No Laws Violated When Asthmatic Student's Mouth Taped
DOC.TEXT: The sheriff's office said no laws were violated when a teacher taped shut the mouth of an asthmatic fifth-grader for talking in class. But the school district placed Kenneth Roberts, 20, on administrative leave and started its own investigation into the episode. ``I will delay any judgment about Mr. Roberts until the facts are in,'' said Adams County schools superintendent Michael Massarotti. ``Regardless of whether the child had been asthmatic or not, we would have taken the same course of action.'' Roberts said he put tape over the Berkeley Gardens Elementary School student's mouth after the boy yelled across the room and ignored his requests to quiet down. He said the boy was not hurt, and he learned the student had a history of asthma only after the incident. The sheriff's office began investigating last Thursday after principal Kathleen Bassett reported the student's mouth was shut with masking tape for about 20 minutes. ``This matter was investigated by detectives ... it was determined there was no violation of criminal law,'' said Robert Neiman, a sheriff's office spokesman. The boy's name was not released. His mother, Sherrie Rivera, said she was ``real disappointed'' with Roberts. ``We've discussed his talking problems, and the teacher has been patient. We just wish he hadn't gone this far.'' She said the boy's asthma requires constant medication. ``We always carry an inhaler with him. ... This could have been really bad.''

DOC.HEAD: Children's Programming Draws Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The happy land of kids' TV has turned nasty with an antitrust suit brought by the Walt Disney Co. against the Fox Broadcasting Co. and its affiliates over Fox's planned children's programming. Disney alleged in the suit filed in U.S. District Court Wednesday that Fox has attempted to prevent its 129 affiliated stations from carrying ``The Disney Afternoon,'' a two-hour daily lineup of children's programming in syndication. Fox soon will introduce its own children's network of daily shows, with the first program set to debut in September. Both Disney and Fox are selling their children's shows on condition that they be broadcast from 3 p.m. and 5 p.m. The suit seeks unspecified compensatory damages, punitive damages and a permanent injunction. Disney claimed in the suit that Fox has intimidated its affiliate stations with threats that the stations will be dropped by Fox if they take the Disney lineup. ``American kids have voted through their viewing habits and have consistently and unarguably determined that Disney animated programming is their No. 1 choice for afternoon viewing,'' Richard Frank, president of the Disney studio, said in a statement. ``Having lost this battle, Fox now wants to deprive children of these shows by coercing its affiliates to buy Fox's programming rather than Disney's,'' Frank said. But Kevin O'Brien, president of the oversight committee for the Fox Children's Network, said that the Disney suit ``reeks of absurdity and it's nothing more than a scare tactic.'' He said that Fox has made it ``repeatedly clear'' that Fox would allow its stations the ``flexibility'' they need to show Disney's kids' lineup. The Fox children's lineup starts with a daily half hour and three hours each Saturday this September. Additional half hours to the daily schedule are set to be added later.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders All Proceedings Closed in Moody Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered all proceedings sealed in relation to a man under investigation in the recent mail bombings that killed a judge and a civil rights lawyer. Attorneys for Walter LeRoy Moody had asked U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman to issue a gag order, seal all documents in the case and order the return of items confiscated from searches of Moody's home, storage area and vehicles. Freeman said Wednesday the public's interest in seeing the arrest of the person or persons responsible for the mid-December bombings outweighed interest in day-to-day developments. Peter Canfield and Terry Adamson, attorneys representing The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and WSB-TV, said they planned to file an appeal with the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals today. Adamson said the appeals court could overturn Freeman's entire ruling or find that portions of the proceedings could be released to the press _ just as portions of the videotaped testimony of former President Ronald Reagan in the Iran-contra case were released this week. Moody's attorneys, Michael Hauptman and Bruce Harvey, said they could not comment on any aspect of the proceedings. Moody did not respond to questions. Freeman said public access into Moody-related documents could jeopardize the investigation if a conspiracy is involved. Agents investigating the mail bombs have extensively searched the homes and businesses of three men in Alabama and Georgia, including Moody's Clayton County home two weeks ago. No one has been charged in the attacks, which killed Judge Robert S. Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and Robert Robinson, a Savannah attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``In order for the flag to endure as a symbol of freedom in this nation, we must protect with equal vigor the right to destroy it and the right to wave it.'' _ U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein in dismissing flag burning charges against four people and ruling that the new federal law passed by Congress to prohibit desecration of the flag is unconstitutional.

``I'm overwhelmed. I'm so honored I can barely stand it.'' _ Bonnie Raitt, 40, whose whiskey voice and wicked guitar chops won her a loyal following but little fame over 20 years of entertaining, after winning her first four Grammy awards.

``It'll be on the road forever and we can all feel a part of that. You know, classics never die.'' _ Bob Avian, who helped choreograph ``A Chorus Line,'' after it was announced that the musical probably will close March 31 after its 6,104th performance _ the longest run in Broadway history. Avian predicted that ``A Chorus Line'' will be revived on Broadway in five to 10 years.

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP on TV-Grammys, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0465,0559
DOC.HEAD: Grammy Awards: The 31st Sequel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `True, Wednesday...' to CORRECT spelling to Garry sted Gary, changes category code to `e'; picks up 3rd graf `But you...'
DOC.TEXT: Once there were 28 categories of Grammy awards. Now there are 76. But unlike TV's Emmy Awards show, which has become an epic in bloat, CBS' telecast of the Grammy awards moved along right smartly. True, Wednesday night's 32nd annual Grammy Awards show from Los Angeles, aired live only on the East Coast, ran 37 minutes over its three-hour schedule. True, host Garry Shandling was a tad less than exuberant. But you rarely had the feeling, as one often does on Emmy night, that every single winner would get to say thanks to everyone the winner knew, be it mother, agent, or third assistant cousin. There was a whole lot of thankin' going on, make no mistake. The laconic jazz great, Miles Davis, did it in two short bursts, saying ``Thank you,'' and, upon sighting a standing ovation for him, saying ``Thank you again.'' Two other winners were even moved to thank their lawyers. But executive producer Pierre Cossette, who has been doing Grammy shows almost since the golden age of silent television, fashioned a well-paced evening. He gave a representative sampling of tunes and music forms, presenters who got to the point fast, and surprisingly few overly grateful winners. The music world's annual salaam to itself only really sagged when it spent about 20 minutes hailing the thoughts, words, music and video clips of Paul McCartney, whose name often is prefaced with the phrase ``Former Beatle.'' All this salute lacked was the intelligence that Fellow Former Beatle George Harrison had his tonsils taken out on Feb. 8, 1969. McCartney proved a gracious visitor, though. He didn't even wince at the preliminaries, a solemn speech by Beatles fan Meryl Streep. She or her speechwriter left the impression that he could make the the lame walk and the tone-deaf hear, noting that his fine music not only had an impact on rock 'n' roll but ``also on Western culture.'' The McCartney hoopla was due to his Grammy-knighting for a lifetime of musical achievement. Davis was similarly honored, although late in the show, when it was in overtime. But he played his horn and sounded fine. Wednesday's show, which among other things featured the first televised Grammy award for rap music, served as a reminder that rock no longer is for and by the young. There were a few sprouts about on stage, notably the distinguished new rock group Milli Vanilli, which has one recent hit with lyrics that go ``girl, you know it's true, ooo, ooo, ooo ...'' But you also saw that rock 'n' roll is here to gray. There was McCartney, youthful-looking, but 47. And Grammy winner Bette Midler, only three years younger. And four-time winner Bonnie Raitt, 40. We all get ancient. It's part of life's rich pageant. But you just don't think of rock stars getting ancient, too. The Grammy show, however, disproved this notion. It left a distinct feeling that if someone ever makes a TV series about today's rock stars, it probably will be called ``fortysomething.''

DOC.HEAD: Bureau of Prisons Will Take Over Leper Colony
DOC.TEXT: The only leper colony in the continental United States will be converted to a health care center for elderly and crippled federal prisoners, officials said. U.S. Rep. Clyde Holloway, R-La., said Wednesday that the agreement between the Bureau of Prisons and the Public Health Service should be signed early next week. The 130 leprosy patients who live at the Gillis W. Long Hansen's Disease Center in Carville about 70 miles west of New Orleans would be allowed to remain, Holloway said. ``It's a win-win situation,'' Holloway said. The 340-acre facility, in an isolated curve of river, will be able to hold about 1,000 prisoners, he said. It was the last U.S. Public Health Service hospital in the country. The federal research project on leprosy, now known as Hansen's disease, will be moved from the center 20 miles up the Mississippi River to Baton Rouge. The colony opened in 1894 on an old plantation. The federal government took control in 1921 and as many as 500 residents lived there during the 1930s. The center has treated nearly 3,000 patients and survived the 1984 Reagan administration budget cuts when seven other Public Health Service hospitals closed. All major advances in leprosy treatment _ drugs, armadillo-related discoveries and two generations of vaccines with limited effectiveness _ came from Carville's researchers, said center Director John Duffy. Leprosy, a bacterial infection, causes nerve damage that can result in loss of muscle control, crippling of the hands and feet and blindness. Most cases can be treated before complications set in and treatment makes the disease non-contagious. Two hundred to 300 new cases are diagnosed every year, with an estimated 10,000 U.S. victims and 20 million worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: American, Two Filipinos Killed in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen ambushed a jeep in the central Philippines, killing an American, his Filipino wife and father-in-law, the military and U.S. officials said today. A report by the Philippine Constabulary said the killings took place Wednesday along a highway on Bohol island, 400 miles southeast of Manila. The American was identified as John Robert Mitchell, 42, of Fairbanks, Alaska. U.S. Consul Franklin Huddle confirmed the American victim's identity, but said he did not know what Mitchell did in the Philippines or how long he has been in the country. The constabulary report said assailants fled after firing M-16s and rifles at the jeep that Mitchell drove. Mitchell was fatally shot, as was his wife, Marilou Chatoo, 24, and her father, Silvino. The military said it was investigating whether the attack was carried out by Communist rebels, who operate in the area.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS to UPDATE with Hampson obit; picks up with Brandon obit. No separates moved for PMs cycle. Anderson also moved on sports wires; Henske also moved on business wires
DOC.TEXT: Albert W. Hampson, an artist whose work appeared in The Saturday Evening Post and Look magazine, died Monday of an apparent heart attack. He was 79. Hampson painted his first cover for the Post at age 25. The 1935 illustration shows two disgusted Naval Academy cadets carrying a can of paint thinner while escorting their mascot Navy goat, on which an opposing football team had brushed in red paint ``Sink the Navy.'' Hampson's 1974 portrait of Philadelphia mayor James H. Tate hangs in the City Hall Annex in Philadelphia. He was an art director and freelance commercial artist for various advertising agencies in New York and Philadelphia.

Henry Brandon, a Hollywood character actor whose roles ranged from Indian chiefs to the comic foil for Laurel and Hardy and who was the model for Captain Hook in Walt Disney's animated ``Peter Pan,'' died of a heart attack Feb. 15. He was 77. Brandon caught the attention of Hal Roach, the producer of the Laurel and Hardy comedies, and was cast under his real name, Henry Kleinbach. He played Old Barnaby in the 1934 classic ``Babes in Toyland.'' Brandon played Indian chiefs 26 times, including in ``The Searchers'' and ``Two Rode Together.'' His film work extended to the mid-1970s. His other film credits include ``Beau Geste,'' ``Nurse Edith Cavell,'' ``Underground,'' ``Joan of Arc,'' ``Pony Express,'' ``The War of the Worlds,'' and ``Auntie Mame.'' Brandon later did voice-overs for commercials.

Denise Anderson, the 24-year-old sister of former world heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson, died Wednesday of a heart attack. Roger Anderson found his 423-pound wife unconscious in their home in the New York City borough of Queens, police said. Tyson, 23, lost his boxing title Feb. 11, when he was knocked out in the 10th round by James ``Buster'' Douglas in Tokyo, in one of boxing's greatest upsets.

John M. Henske, former chairman of Olin Corp. and the Chemical Manufacturers Association, died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 66. Henske began his career with Stamford-based Olin in 1969 as vice president of the chemicals group. He was elected president in 1973 and named to the additional post of chairman in 1980. He retired July 1, 1988. The Omaha, Neb., native came to Olin from Dow Chemical Co., where he had served on the board of directors and as a vice president.

Marc Ray Clement, 39, an actor who played Southern characters in the films ``Mississippi Burning'' and ``Murder in Coweta County,'' was killed Sunday in a traffic accident. Clement toured with the National Shakespeare Company, then became a member of and spokesman for the New Christy Minstrels singing group. He played one of the conspirators in the film ``Mississippi Burning.'' Clement also had roles in the films ``The Slugger's Wife,'' `Night Shadows,'' ``Blue Heaven,'' ``Old Boyfriends,'' ``Hooper,'' and the yet-to-be-released ``Chattahoochee'' and ``Career Opportunities.'' Clement was killed when he apparently lost control of his truck and hit a tree.

Frank Ross, the movie producer who helped put ``The Robe'' and ``Of Mice and Men'' on screen, died Sunday of complications from brain surgery. He was 85. Ross worked in the 1920s as a contract player for Paramount, appearing with such stars as Clara Bow and Jean Arthur, who became his wife. He married actress Joan Caulfield after his divorce from Miss Arthur in 1949. After turning to production, he shared a special Academy Award in 1945 with Melvyn LeRoy for ``The House I Live In,'' a short film on intolerance. ``The Robe,'' in 1953, was the first CinemaScope feature film and starred Richard Burton. Ross served as associate producer for ``Of Mice and Men'' in 1939. Other film credits include ``The Devil and Miss Jones,'' ``The Rains of Ranchipur'' and ``Demetrius and the Gladiators.''

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Make Off With 2,500 Watches
DOC.TEXT: Five men hijacked a van at Hong Kong airport today and escaped with 2,500 watches worth $3.8 million, police reported. Police said the robbers, two of whom appeared to be armed with pistols, committed the robbery after the vehicle had been been loaded with 40 boxes of watches at the cargo handling area. Police gave the following report: The robbers tied up two security guards and the driver and drove the van to an open area where they transferred the boxes to another vehicle. They then drove off. The security guards managed to untie themselves and reported the robbery to police. No one was injured, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting Between de Klerk, African Leaders Postponed
DOC.TEXT: A meeting between President F.W. de Klerk and leaders of five black African nations has been postponed following protests from opposition groups and other nations, government officials said today. In a statement, the government said de Klerk would not be attending a meeting Saturday in Zaire to discuss regional problems and recent developments in South Africa. It said the meeting would be held later, but gave no date. In another development, the Foreign Ministry said Foreign Minister Pik Botha's visit to Angola and Kenya this week had been postponed. The ministry gave no reasons for the postponement, beyond citing fighting in Angola. The apparent setbacks came at a time when South African officials had been predicting recent internal reforms would clear the way for diplomatic and trade ties with black African nations after years of isolation. South African officials said earlier this week that de Klerk would meet the leaders of Burundi, the Central African Republic, Chad, Rwanda and Zaire in the first summit between South Africa and black African nations. The meeting was presented as a major breakthrough. It reportedly was arranged by Zaire's president, Mobutu Sese Seko. But the African National Congress, the main South African anti-apartheid group, protested and urged the Organization of African Unity to block the meeting. The ANC said the South African government still supported apartheid and any contacts by black African nations would be premature. Several other black states condemned the meeting with de Klerk and urged the participants not to take part. Chad denied it had been been invited. De Klerk legalized the ANC and released top black leader Nelson Mandela from prison this month to try and clear the way for talks on ending white minority rule and sharing political power with blacks. The ANC has said it will send a delegation to meet with de Klerk on trying to clear the way for talks on a new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Grammy Crowd: They Came, They Shrieked, They Took Snapshots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Robirt in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Grammys-Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Recording stars arriving at the Grammy awards came face to face with hundreds of squealing, photo-snapping fans, including two surprised with free tickets. One performer had a hard time getting in. Singer Robirt Pilatus of Milli Vanilli scuffled with a guard when the long-haired performer was denied entry to the show staged at the Shrine Auditorium. ``Yeah, I had some problems out there. I wanted to get in and I couldn't. I didn't know this gentleman was a police officer,'' said Pilatus. ``He wanted to arrest me. They found out I was innocent.'' A mysterious benefactor approached the ogling fans, asked if anyone wanted tickets and handed a pair to Carrie Palmer, 19. ``I'd like to thank the lady, but I don't know who she is,'' said Miss Palmer, who gave the other ticket to a friend. Ticket brokers were fetching prices as high as $1,000 per ticket. Limousines, Porsches and Jaguars pulled up three-deep outside the auditorium and recording artists emerged in the hottest fashions, mostly rock 'n' roll black and chic metallics. Elva Torres said that Donny Osmond, staging a musical comeback, seemed to her to be the nicest and most sincere celebrity. ``He rolled down the window and let the girls shake his hand. He also gave them autographs,'' she said. ``I thought that was really nice.'' Screams broke out when George Michael arrived. ``Oh my God. He is, like, the sexiest man alive,'' said 17-year-old Jennifer DeLadurantey. Miss DeLadurantey's friend, Jill Dunleavy, 17, said, ``He turned around and all I could do is take a snapshot.'' Dianne Rendon of Whittier was hoping to see Paula Abdul or Paul McCartney, but never got the opportunity. Still, she said that waiting eight hours was not all in vain. ``It was worth it for my daughter, who saw the New Kids on the Block,'' said Ms. Rendon. Nearby, about 20 members of the Guardian Angels, a self-styled crime patrol, set up a picket line to denounce nominations for the hard rock group Guns N' Roses and the rap group Public Enemy. ``They've singled out two groups that are promoting hate and violence in their records,'' said Angel leader Paul Barrera. Guns N' Roses, nominated for best hard rock performance for the album ``GN'R Lies,'' offends blacks, immigrants, and homosexuals, Barrera said. Public Enemy, nominated for best rap performance with the single ``Fight the Power,'' is ``going after the Jewish community,'' Barrera claimed.

DOC.HEAD: South African Generals Tied To Secret Death Squads: Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th pvs, `Malan had...' to UPDATE with newspaper report that unit had misused hundreds of thousands of dollars, secret investigation started. Picks up 10th pvs, `President F.W. ...'
DOC.HEAD: By BARRY RENFREW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The defense minister says the army won't block an inquiry into charges that he and other top generals were linked to a secret unit that killed anti-apartheid activists, according to reports today. The opposition Democratic Party called for Defense Minister Gen. Magnus Malan's dismissal. The liberal party's leader, Wynand Malan, said the government must remove the minister immediately or it will be seen as supporting death squads. Gen. Malan denied he had ordered any killings or been involved in any illegal activities, the state South African Broadcasting Corp. reported. He said an investigation would exonerate the defense forces. Malan made the statement pledging no army interference in the investigation after The Star newspaper reported Wednesday that it had uncovered evidence that Malan and senior generals were linked to ``the activities of a secret South African Defense Force unit allegedly linked to death squad operations.'' The Star, citing unidentified sources, reported that Malan and other senior officials were linked to a secret unit called the Civil Cooperation Bureau, which used civilian personnel to conceal the army's attempts to manipulate political affairs. The newspaper reported the chain of command for the unit ran from Malan's office to Gen. Jannie Geldenhuys, chief of the South African Defense Forces; to Gen. Witkop Badenhorst, chief of military intelligence; and to Maj. Gen. Eddie Webb. The unit, funded by the military, was commanded by Col. Johan Verster, who reported directly to Webb, the newspaper said. The report was the first to directly link death squad allegations to senior military figures. The unit ran up to 16 ``cells'' across South Africa and its activities were controlled by a special ``operations committee'' composed of Defense Force generals, the newspaper said. The unit also monitored black trade unions and helped coordinate action against activists based in other nations, it said. Malan had been aware of the secret unit since it was set up in 1987, the newspaper reported. In a report today, The Star said hundreds of thousands of dollars in military funds had been misused by the secret unit to buy BMWs and other luxury cars, pay for houses and underwrite agents' lavish lifestyles. The lavish spending alarmed senior generals who began a secret inquiry to try and stop the abuses, the newspaper reported. President F.W. de Klerk last month ordered an investigation into charges that military and police squads killed government opponents. The commission is expected to investigate the unexplained deaths of at least 60 anti-apartheid activists over the past decade. Three former police officers have confessed publicly to being involved in death squad activities and several police officers are under investigation for alleged involvement in death squad kilings. No military officers have been charged or suspended in connection with the allegations. Malan said the attention focused on the death squad claims was diverting attention from anti-government groups that had killed hundreds of people. ``The actions of terrorists and aggressors who have claimed hundreds of innocent lives are being pushed into the background,'' Malan was quoted as saying today by Johannesburg newspapers. The president has legalized the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups as part of efforts to start talks on ending white-minority rule and sharing political power with blacks. De Klerk has curbed the power of the security forces since taking office in August.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Murderer Barred from Mother's Funeral Because of Horton Law
DOC.TEXT: A convicted murderer lost his bid to attend his mother's funeral after a judge upheld a state statute passed in response to the Willie Horton case. Superior Court Judge Robert Prince on Wednesday refused to grant an appeal by the American Civil Liberties Union to allow Philip Pennellatore to pay his respects on Friday to the woman he called his ``best friend.'' The ruling upheld a state law barring the temporary release of inmates serving life sentences for first-degree murder. The law was passed because of the furor over Horton's assault on a Maryland couple while on furlough _ a key issue used by President Bush to cast doubt on Gov. Michael S. Dukakis during the 1988 presidential race. Pennellatore, 29, was convicted of first-degree murder in 1982 for the 1981 killing of an 80-year-old retired librarian. He is serving a life sentence at the Old Colony Correctional Institute in Bridgewater. Pennellatore originally asked for a court injunction to see his mother, dying of pancreatic cancer, on Feb. 5. Then he sought to attend her funeral. Nettie Pennellatore, 61, died Tuesday. ``It's good prison management. It's humane,'' said John Reinstein, an American Civil Liberties Union attorney who represented Pennellatore. Reinstein said Pennellatore and other inmates who have filed separate suits against the state Department of Correction argue that the Willie Horton law is an ex post facto law. ``It basically went back and imposed additional punishment on prisoners already convicted of crimes,' Reinstein said. Corrections Department spokeswoman Kathy Robertson said it would take a court order or special legislation to allow a convicted lifer out for any occasion. Only three other states in the United States have no furlough system, she said. But the sponsor of the so-called ``Willie Horton statute,'' Rep. Larry Giordano, a Democrat, said he was not aware the bill banned prisoners from attending family funerals. ``I would have no problem with that,'' Giordano said. ``You only have one mother and father. Keeping first-degree murderers behind bars is important to me, but I have a little compassion.'' Maureen Donovan, who spearheaded the anti-furlough campaign, said she agreed with the policy. ``He was the cause of a funeral himself,'' said Donovan. ``If they let him out, they are breaking the law.''

DOC.HEAD: Tehran Newspaper: Hostages in Lebanon Should Go Free
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th pvs, `Most of...' to UPDATE with reax from Peggy Say. Picks up 6th pvs, `The hostages...'
DOC.TEXT: A Tehran newspaper said today that the foreign hostages held in Lebanon should be freed because they are being used as a propaganda tool against Iran. It was the first known statement by an Iranian newspaper advocating the release of all the captives.
