The English-language Tehran Times said in an editorial that freeing the hostages was in line with Islamic and humanitarian principles, according to excerpts carried by the official Islamic Republic News Agency. ``Regardless of the West's propaganda ploys, Moslem forces, out of Islamic and humanitarian considerations, should work to get the hostages free with no precondition,'' IRNA quoted the editorial as saying. Most of the 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon are believed in the hands of extremist Shiite Moslem factions loyal to Tehran. Eight are Americans; the longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Asked about the Tehran Times editorial, Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, said: ``I am deeply grateful. It is encouraging. I consider that Iran is not part of the problem, but part of the solution.'' The hostages' fate is believed linked to a power struggle within the Iranian government. The Times is close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, who has offered to help free the hostages before but has been criticized for such moves by hard-line government factions. The editorial said the fight against Western influence in the Middle East was a legitimate one and should continue, but that all the forces in Lebanon should work to free the hostages regardless of their nationality. ``They should regard the hostages as victims of imperialist policies of the West and make attempts to get them all freed,'' the newspaper said. ``Maybe 1990 will be the year for the release of all the hostages,'' the newspaper said. The IRNA report, monitored in Nicosia, said the West did not attach practical value to the hostage issue, assigning more importance to Westerners missing than those from other countries. The newspaper repeated Rafsanjani's demand for the release of Iran's charge d'affaires in Beirut, Mohsen Musavi, and three other embassy staff members missing for nearly eight years. The four were kidnapped by Christian Lebanese Forces militiamen in north Lebanon in July 1982 and are believed to have been killed. Lebanese Forces commander Samir Geagea, who took over the militia in 1986, has said he found no trace of the men. He blamed his predecessor, Elie Hobeika, for their disappearance and apparent slaying. Geagea's disclosure in 1988 was the first formal comment by the militia that it had been involved in seizing the Iranians. The Westerners missing in Lebanon include eight Americans, four Britons, an Italian, an Irishman, two West Germans and two Swiss. Mrs. Say, of Cadiz, Ky., and an Associated Press delegation are currently on a trip to discuss with world leaders her campaign to free her brother. Now in Damascus, Syria, she has already met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Pope John Paul II and Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Attempts to meet with Iranian leaders have not succeeded. During her meeting with Arafat last week, Mrs. Say was told that Rafsanjani had the greatest influence over the hostages but his room to maneuver was limited by hard-liners in the government. Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a former interior minister and Rafsanjani's staunchest rival, regularly encourages the groups holding hostages in Lebanon. The hostage-takers are believed linked to the Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God, which Mohtashemi helped organize.

DOC.HEAD: Divers Retrieve More Bodies from Icy Lake Bottom
LaserPhoto XMLK3
DOC.TEXT: Divers wearing iron helmets used sophisticated underwater camera gear to help them recover five more bodies from iced-over Convict Lake, including two victims who were at lake bottom. After pulling what was the sixth of seven drowning victims from the lake late Wednesday, authorities halted the recovery effort to give exhausted divers a chance to recuperate. ``Search efforts have been suspended, due to loss of resources and safety factors,'' Mono County Sheriff Martin A. Strelneck said in a statement. ``The divers are getting tired and cold, and it's getting dangerous out there for them.'' Divers from Los Angeles County and Washoe County, Nev., will resume searching for the lone body still under the ice, but no time was set to continue the effort, he said. The remaining body is that of Dave Meyers, 53, of Bishop. The deaths caused by thin ice came Monday, Meyers' first day as a counselor at Camp O'Neal, a facility for troubled youths. Three teen-agers from the camp were the first to plunge into the bone-chilling waters of the high-altitude lake. Two bodies wrapped in yellow plastic bags were brought to shore about 3:20 p.m. Wednesday, moments before an underwater video camera found two more bodies at 100 feet. A fifth body was recovered before the operation ended for the night. Divers on Tuesday recovered the body of Forest Service Ranger Clayton Cutter, 31, one of four adults who died trying to save the three floundering teen-agers. Recovered from the lake Wednesday were the bodies of camp counselor Randy Porter, 39, of June Lake; volunteer firefighter Vidar Anderson, 58, of Long Valley; and camp residents David Christopher Sellers, 15, of Tulare; Shawn Rayne Diaz, 15, of Dinuba; and Ryan Charles McCandless, 13, of Redlands. The victims' friends and relatives on Wednesday questioned U.S. Forest Service policies that leave judging ice thickness up to individual common sense at the hundreds of lakes in the rugged Sierra Nevada range. ``They definitely need signs out there,'' said Tracey Wood, a friend of Cutter. ``I know people are going to be rebellious, but before they advertise a lake for ice skating they better let people know how thin the ice is,'' she said. Convict Lake brochures tout its ice skating. A remote-controlled underwater camera lowered into the 32-degree water helped divers locate two bodies on the lake bottom, 117 feet below the surface, said Mono County sheriff's spokeswoman Gail Merritt. The operation included a six-member Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department deep-diving team and 11 divers from Washoe County, Nev. The Los Angeles dive team had iron helmets and surface air equipment allowing them to go deeper and stay down for up to 30 minutes. The camera guided them on the bottom of the 140-foot deep lake. The tragedy struck while 16 teen-agers and two adults from Camp O'Neal were on an outing at the lake at the 7,500-foot level in the eastern Sierra Nevada. A preliminary sheriff's department investigation completed Wednesday said the teen-agers were ``playing,'' not skating, on the mile-long, quarter-mile wide lake. The investigation will be passed to the Mono County district attorney's office and the state Department of Social Services, the report said. Sheriff's investigator John Rutkowski said he was trying to determine whether the teen-agers were properly supervised. Convict Lake, just south of the Mammoth ski resort about 250 miles north of Los Angeles, got its name from a shootout between a posse and escaped convicts in the late 1800s.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Assures Japanese On Troop Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 19th graf to correct prime minister to foreign minister.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney assured Japanese officials today that no U.S. combat troops would be removed from Japan if reductions in American military forces here are ordered, a Pentagon spokesman said. The pledge came as Cheney met for more than two hours with his Japanese counterpart, Defense Minister Juro Matsumoto, according to Cheney spokesman Pete Williams. Cheney also met with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, congratulating him on his conservative party's re-election victory in Sunday's election, and separately with Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama. Cheney was in Japan on the final leg of his two-week Asian tour, in which he has been consulting with allied nations about Pentagon proposals to reduce the 120,000 U.S. troops stationed in the Pacific Rim by 10 to 12 percent. That would amount to a possible cut of 5,000 military personnel from Japan alone. About 50,000 U.S. Marines, sailors, soldiers and Air Force personnel are based in Japan and Okinawa. Cheney ``did discuss numbers'' about a possible troop withdrawal with Matsumoto, Williams said, but he provided no details. The Pentagon chief told his Japanese counterpart that ``if we do reduce our forces in the region, it will be done without affecting our combat capabilities,'' Williams said. Assuring Matsumoto the United States remains committed to helping maintain peace in the Pacific, Cheney said America ``will continue to modernize and upgrade'' the forces and military hardware based in the region. Cheney is due to report to Congress by April 1 with a reassessment of the U.S. military role in the Pacific. Some lawmakers have called for severe drawdowns in troops levels based in economically robust nations overseas, given the reduced superpower tensions and budget deficit worries at home. Cheney told the Japanese that no final decision has been made on manpower cuts, nor which units in Japan might be affected. Such decisions will be made by Adm. Huntington Hardisty, the U.S. Commander in Chief of the Pacific, and U.S. military commanders in Japan, in consultation with the allies, Williams said. Williams said the two officials had a ``very broad discussion'' about a possible increase in Japanese financial support for Americans based here, but ``no figures, no specifics'' were mentioned. U.S. officials have said in the past that Cheney is looking for a ``sizeable increase'' in the $2.4 billion the Japanese contribute to the $7 billion cost of maintaining U.S. forces here. The lack of specifics about numbers is a negotiating tactic, one U.S. official said, noting that the Japanese ``understand our requirements'' and are willing to increase their financial support for such things as recreational facilities and hospitals to help U.S. troops and their families. In South Korea and Asia, the Americans are looking to the host governments to pick up more of the tab for such things as utility costs and local wages for their own citizens working on the bases. Earlier in Cheney's travels, one U.S. official said a doubling of host nations' contributions would be a desirable goal. Because this is Cheney's first visit to the region as defense secretary, the sessions were primarily ``get-acquainted'' talks, with each side laying out for the other their global views in light of the revolutionary changes that have swept Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, Williams said. The officials found that they shared ``very similar views,'' Williams said, both taking ``a very cautious approach'' to events in the Soviet Union. ``Both sides expressed the view that whatever changes may be going on in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, the fundamental picture in Asia and the Pacific hasn't changed. Nor should either country's strategy in the region change,'' Williams said. Later, Foreign Minister Nakayama told Cheney it was important to continue enhancing U.S.-Japan cooperation, said a Foreign Ministry official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity. Nakayama said Japan hopes the United States will remain a Pacific power and keep forward-deployed forces in the region despite the possible cuts, according to the official. The official said Kaifu told Cheney that Japan was willing to work closely with the United States on ensuring cuts would not affect basic combat strength. Regarding Japan's share of the cost of maintaining U.S. troops, Kaifu said Japan had already substantially increased its share and would build in the future, the official said. Cheney has stressed throughout his travels that despite some reductions in the Soviet Navy, it still retains its largest fleet in the Pacific and has more than 500,000 troops based in Asia. And in spite of Soviet moves to lessen tensions with the West, nations such as South Korea still feel threatened by such militaristic powers as Communist North Korea. Cheney delivers a major policy speech on Friday before the National Press Club here, and then travels to Kyoto as a guest of the Japanese Defense Agency. He returns to Washington on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Report Former East German Spy Chief Flees to Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with East German officials saying Wolf on vacation, not under investigation; picks up 4th pvs, `East German ...' EDITS thereafter to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: East German officials today disputed a report that former spymaster Markus Wolf fled East Germany for Moscow, saying he was only taking a vacation in the Soviet Union and was not under investigation for illegal arms deals. The Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper of Munich reported that Wolf had taken refuge in the Soviet Union to avoid possible arrest in connection with a weapons scandal that occurred under the ousted hard-line Communist regime. Wolf, who led East Germany's espionage operations for 20 years, is believed to have had close ties to the KGB and once called the Soviet Union his ``second home.'' The official East German news agency ADN said Wolf and his family went on vacation in the Soviet Union on Feb. 12 and would return soon. Eberhard Meier, a personal assistant to Wolf, told the news agency the former spy was also working on the Russian-language version of a book published after his retirement from the intelligence service. Meier denied that Wolf fled to the Soviet Union to avoid possible prosecution in connection with an arms exporting operation. Hans-Juergen Joseph, East Germany's chief prosecutor, was quoted by West German newspaper Bild as saying: ``There is no investigation against Markus Wolf.'' Bild quoted Gregor Gysi, chairman of the former Communist Party, as saying Wolf was expected back ``next week.'' The party is now renamed the Party of Democratic Socialism. Gysi called everything else in the Sueddeutsche Zeitung report ``pure nonsense.'' The Munich newspaper reported that East German prosecutors believe Wolf was involved in the illegal arms operation and may even have directed it. East German authorities have said the exports were handled by Alexander Schalck-Golodkowski, chief foreign trader for the ousted Communist government. He fled to West Berlin when the operation was discovered in December and spent several days in jail, but a judge said there were no grounds in West Germany for holding Schalck-Golodkowski and released him in January. Wolf, 67, retired in February 1987 from the State Security Ministry, where he was in charge of the espionage section and directed such agents as Guenter Guillaume, whose unmasking led to the resignation of Willy Brandt as West German chancellor in 1974. Guillaume had been one of Brandt's closest aides. In the October turmoil that brought down hard-line Communist Party chief Erich Honecker, he supported the type of political and economic reforms championed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet president. Wolf joined the State Security Ministry in 1951, became espionage chief in 1957 and retired with the rank of general. His career was said to have inspired spy novelist John Le Carre's character Karla, a fictional Soviet spymaster who finally is forced to defect to the West by an elaborate plot devised by British agent George Smiley. After decades of virtual invisibility, Wolf spoke at rallies in the early days of East Germany's peaceful street revolution and appeared in several discussions on East and West German TV. There is an arrest warrant out for him in West Germany because of his espionage activities.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire Tear Gas and Beat Singing Students
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers wielding truncheons fired tear gas and charged more than 300 demonstrating students today, beating dozens as they sang the national anthem in an anti-government protest at a university. Armed police wearing riot helmets sealed off the campus in the Cocody section of Abidjan, where the state university, presidential palace and many embassies and ambassadorial residences are located. One resident said police and soldiers also fired tear gas at students who fled the campus and tried to continue the protest. ``One canister exploded just a couple of meters from my car as I drove toward my home near the Austrian Embassy. I dare not leave my house,'' one resident said on condition of anonymity. About 200 students gathered later outside the walled offices of state-run Radio Abidjan yelling: ``Tell the truth! Tell the truth!'' as soldiers and police attacked them with batons. State newspapers, television and radio have remained silent about unrest, which began late Monday when students angered by cuts in water and power demanded the resignation of conservative President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. The Ivorian League of Human Rights appealed today to judges to intercede on behalf of 23 students it said were detained Monday night. Trucks of police and soldiers patrolled residential areas and shopping centers surrounding the state university. It was the most serious unrest in years in Ivory Coast, where the pro-Western government is struggling against a recession that brought unemployment, salary cuts and declining living standards to one of Africa's richest countries. Houphouet-Boigny, officially stated as 84 years old but believed in his 90s, has ruled Ivory Coast as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960. Students said many of protesters were hurt in protests this week but only a few seriously enough to warrant treatment at the hospital. Hospital officials said they were not authorized to comment. On Monday night, police beat students who set two cars ablaze outside a university residence in the poor suburb of Yopougon, three miles from the main campus. Protesters said one student was beaten to death Monday night, but it was not possible to verify the claim. On Tuesday, students smashed windows of two buses after bus service was suspended between the main campus and the many university residences sprawled across Abidjan, the capital. Today, more than 300 students protested peacefully outside the rector's office at the university singing: ``Greetings, land of hope,'' the national anthem. Police charged them with truncheons. Earlier, some students tried to attend classes but were disturbed by about 20 militant students demanding, ``Come out! Come out!'' Soldiers and police marched in, and beat both protesters and students trying to study. ``Not all the students are protesting, but we all agree that there have to be changes in Ivory Coast,'' a chemistry student said. He said there are no apparent leaders among the 20,000 students because the government prevents students from forming independent groups. Among demands the protesters presented Wednesday to rector Toure Bakary is dissolution of a students' union that serves as a youth league of the ruling Democratic Party. On Wednesday the students tore up the red, green and orange party flag that flew over the university.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Optimistic About Transplant Recovery Despite Setback
DOC.TEXT: Doctors stopped the bleeding from 12-year-old Stormie Jones' newest liver and remained optimistic the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient would recover. Stormie, from the Fort Worth, Texas, suburb of White Settlement, remained in critical condition today at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Doctors on Wednesday reconstructed a connection between the donor liver and the hepatic artery, a blood vessel that supplies the liver, Dr. Andreas Tzakis said. ``The liver looks good and we expect her to recover promptly,'' said Tzakis, who headed a team that operated for nine hours to stop bleeding from sutures that had given way and to check all other sutures. Internal bleeding occurs in about 10 percent of all patients receiving a second transplant, he said. Stormie, who was given a new heart and liver six years ago, received her second liver during a 10-hour procedure Tuesday. Stormie did not appear upset that she required more surgery, Tzakis said. ``She's determined to make it, no matter what,'' he said. Stormie's stepfather, Alan Purcell, 27, said the girl's feisty attitude has helped family members. ``How can we get down when she stays up?'' he said. Stormie's first transplant was needed to control effects of a rare disease that left her with cholesterol levels 10 times normal. The second operation resulted from permanent liver damage due to hepatitis caused by an unknown virus. Her donor heart has remained healthy.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Skinheads Didn't Plot Against Minorities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to delete reference to attorney's race. SUBS 14th graf, `Attorney General...', to change Thornburgh's first name to Dick sted Richard, per his preference. Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: An attorney representing one of five white supremacists on trial for hate crimes told the jury the men were falsely accused of plotting against minorities. ``There will be fliers, writings on the wall and other things that will get your emotions up,'' attorney Leon Carter said Wednesday in his opening statement. ``You will find that these men are not guilty of the conspiracy that is alleged.'' Carter has declined to comment about the case outside the U.S. District courtroom. He is representing Jon Lance Jordan, 19, of Garland, who is on trial with Sean Christian Tarrant, 20, and Daniel Alvis Wood, 20, of Dallas; Michael Lewis Lawrence, 22, of Tulsa, Okla.; and Christopher Barry Greer, 25, of Irving. All are charged with violating the civil rights of Jews by defacing a synagogue in 1988. Greer, Tarrant and Jordan are also accused of civil rights violations by allegedly chasing blacks and Hispanics from a Dallas park, also in 1988. The defendants are members of a skinhead faction called the Confederate Hammerskins. The skinhead subculture, so-called because its members sport severely short haircuts, originated in London in the 1960s. Segments of the movement have taken on Nazi beliefs in recent years, and since have been supported by and associated with white-supremacist groups. Wood talked about putting cyanide gas into the air conditioning system of Temple Shalom, a north Dallas synagogue, said Gordon Gene Buchanan, a former Hammerskin member. Buchanan said he accompanied Jordan, Tarrant and Wood to the synagogue on an August night in 1988 and that he saw Jordan and Wood near the outside air conditioner units, but he couldn't see what they were doing. Dan L. Kraus of Temple Shalom testified that a number of the synagogue's members discussed leaving the congregation after vandalism that included anti-Semitic graffiti, gunshots into walls and windows and damage to the air conditioning system. One piece of graffiti said, ``6 million more,'' referring to the Holocaust, in which millions of Jews were killed in concentration camps. Buchanan also testified that Tarrant attacked a black man and a white woman who was with an Hispanic man in separate incidents at Robert E. Lee Park, which prosecutors say the skinheads believed should not be visited by non-whites. Alexis Charles Newton of Dallas, who is black, testified that he was chased from the park by white youngsters, some with closely shaven heads. ``I was scared. I knew what could happen if they caught me,'' Newton said. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said after the indictments were issued in September that prosecution of racial hate crimes is a priority of the Justice Department. Each of the federal charges carries up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Wood already has been sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $5,000 by a state judge for spraying swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans on the synagogue. Eleven other Hammerskins have been charged; three out of five adults and four of six juveniles pleaded guilty.

DOC.HEAD: Ivana Trump's Lawyer Tells All About First Hubby
DOC.TEXT: Before The Donald, there was Herr Winklmayr. Ivana Trump, the wife of billionaire developer Donald Trump, was married briefly in the early 1970s to an Austrian skier, according to her lawyer, Michael Kennedy. Kennedy called Mrs. Trump's 1971 marriage to Alfred Winklmayr a ``Cold War marriage'' that allowed her to travel under an Austrian passport out of Communist Czechoslovakia, her homeland. They were divorced in 1973. ``They never slept together,'' Kennedy said. ``They never lived together.'' Winklmayr, a ski instructor, and Mrs. Trump, who was a world-class skier, were friends and remain friends, Kennedy said at a news conference Wednesday. The latest revelation since Trump announced he was leaving his wife of 12 years came in response to ``inaccurate'' reports published in the British tabloids, Kennedy said. He would not say what the inaccuracies were. But a report in the London Sun said Winklmayr was 60 when he wed Mrs. Trump and died within two years of the marriage, leaving her enough money to finance ``a new life in Canada,'' where she moved in 1972. Kennedy said Winklmayr was 25 and Mrs. Trump was 22 when they married. Trump knew about the marriage but her children, ages 12, 8 and 6, did not, Kennedy said. The Sun never used his first name, referring to him as ``Herr Winklmayr.'' Herr is German for mister. Kennedy declined to answer questions about the Trumps' prenuptial agreement, which reportedly would give Mrs. Trump $25 million, the house in Connecticut and custody of the three Trump children, nor would he comment on a possible out-of-court settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Malcolm X Remembered on 25th Anniversary of Assassination
DOC.TEXT: Poets and politicians joined to praise black nationalist Malcolm X on the 25th anniversary of his assassination, and one group circulated petitions calling for a holiday in his honor. ``I couldn't believe it that everyone was calling out his name,'' Malcolm's widow, Betty Shabazz, said after the commemoration. Her husband had not been honored as vociferously in the past, she said. ``I say time brings about a change,'' Mrs. Shabazz said. More than 1,000 gathered Wednesday at Abyssinian Baptist Church to remember Malcolm X, and an additional 600 people were turned away. Malcolm X was killed Feb. 21, 1965, while speaking at a ballroom in Manhattan. He was 39. Three members of the Nation of Islam were convicted of the murder; Malcolm X had broken with the group in the year before his death. Haki Madhubuti, a poet and publisher of Third World Press in Chicago, said he thinks of the slain leader every day and displays his picture over his desk. ``He was the man who gave my generation a voice,'' Madhubuti said. While the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. preached civil disobedience and non-violence, Malcolm X emphasized separatism and self-defense. Percy Sutton, a former state lawmaker and Manhattan borough president, remembered his first meeting with the activist minister. Sutton said Malcolm X told him: ``People like you don't want to be associated with people like me.'' But Sutton became Malcolm X's attorney, and his client went on to help him gain ``access to the corridors of power,'' he said. The National Malcolm X Commemoration Commission produced Wednesday's event and proclaimed 1990 to be the Year of Malcolm X. The commission circulated petitions to make his birthday, May 19, an African-American day of commemoration. Also Wednesday, about 400 people met at the Audubon Ballroom where Malcolm X was assassinated, and protested plans to demolish the building. An observance was also held in Omaha, Neb., birthplace of Malcolm X.

DOC.HEAD: FAA to Issue New Warnings to Airlines and Controllers on Words to Use
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with minor editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Federal aviation officials said today they would issue new warnings to airlines and controllers about the proper words to use in dealing with a plane that is running out of gas. The Federal Aviation Administration responded to urgent recommendations Wednesday from the National Transportation Safety Board in its investigation of the Avianca crash that killed 73 people in New York last month. Avianca pilots told controllers four times that they were running out of fuel before their jetliner crashed, but the NTSB said that wasn't enough. They should have declared a ``fuel emergency,'' the safety board said. Pilots of the Colombian airliner apparently tried to tell controllers of an emergency situation but failed to use the language required by the FAA, the board said. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar said the agency would pass along the safety board's concerns to all carriers and to its air traffic controllers. ``We'll implement the recommendations as soon as possible,'' he said. The board asked the FAA to notify all airliners using U.S. skies that their pilots must be ``thoroughly knowledgeable'' about required communications when fuel emergencies and other critical problems occur. The four-member board, with one dissenting vote, also urged the FAA to advise its own controllers of ``the need to request from flight crews clarification of unclear or ambiguous transmissions that convey a possible emergency.'' Board member Jim Burnett said he did not sign on to the recommendations because language in a letter to FAA Administrator James Busey was toned down to be less critical of FAA controllers. The letter said the board was still investigating the crash and ``has not concluded that any specific communication or coordination problems'' caused the accident. It said, however, that Flight 52 pilots should have declared a ``fuel emergency'' and air controllers should have asked them to clarify their condition when they repeatedly said they were ``running out of fuel,'' the board said. Although transcripts of the flight recorder have not been made public, the letter to Busey provided some details of the Avianca pilots' appeals to controllers who were handling their flight. The Boeing 707 airliner was delayed three different times for a total of 77 minutes because of heavy traffic over the East Coast. The letter said the crew used ``non-standard phraseology'' in telling controllers that the plane was low on fuel. Among statements quoted were: ``We'll try once again, we're running out of fuel,'' ``We just running out of fuel,'' and ``We just lost two engines and we need priority please.'' Fifty minutes before the crash, Avianca pilots told one controller they could only ``hold about five minutes'' and two minutes later they said they could not make it to an alternative airport, Boston, because the jetliner ``will run out of fuel now.'' The last question from the controller just before the crash was: ``You have, ah, you have enough fuel to make it to the airport?'' The board said there was no response from the flight crew. FAA rules call for pilots to declare ``minimum fuel status'' when they need to land without undue delay and a ``fuel emergency'' when they should be given first priority for landing. The next step would be a ``mayday'' call in the event of a ``distress condition.'' None of the declarations was heard from Avianca 52 before it crashed. The board said it was investigating three other incidents involving problems in communications since the Avianca crash. Two of these involved U.S. carriers and the third involved a foreign carrier, officials said. The board said preliminary evidence in its investigation, which is to be concluded in several months, indicates there may have been ``incomplete communication'' between the flight crew and controllers at the New York Air Route Traffic Control Center, the New York TRACON Control Center and the Kennedy tower. The board quoted one air traffic controller, whose identity was not disclosed, as saying that had the flight crew advised that they were ``fuel critical, (with) minimum fuel or in an emergency situation,'' he would have provided them with emergency service. The FAA is not required to follow safety board recommendations.

DOC.HEAD: Pasadena Police Track Copters Medfly Sprayers, Order `Cease and Desist'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to move up that choppers are state-chartered, CORRECT that ban was enacted Wednesday sted Tuesday, ADD detail on communities sprayed. Picks up 14th graf, `Pasadena's ban...'. ADDS one graf on end with background on proposed anti-pesticide initiatives.
DOC.TEXT: Pasadena police tracked state-chartered helicopters spraying Medfly-killing pesticide today and ordered them to halt under a law that provides criminal penalties to challenge the urban crop-dusting. The helicopter squadron was tracked within city air space flying at 500 feet, a day after Pasadena's governing board adopted a minimum altitude of 700 feet for nighttime helicopter formations, said city director Rick Cole. Police contacted the helicopter group and issued a 1 a.m. warning followed by an order to ``cease and desist'' the overflight aimed at Mediterranean fruit flies, said Pasadena police Officer Pat Carnighan. The measure enacted early Wednesday provides maximum penalties of $1,000 and a year in jail. Pasadena police in their two helicopters did not write citations. But when the choppers landed at El Monte Airport for refueling this morning, Jim Josephson, the lead pilot for San Joaquin Helicopters, was told the city would seek criminal misdemeanor complaints, Carnighan said. The state hired El Monte-based San Joaquin Helicopters to carry out its malathion spraying program. The Los Angeles County district attorney's office will have final say over whether complaints might be filed. Police met with Josephson before the overnight spraying to discuss the new ordinance and their planned enforcement action, said Pasadena police Sgt. Tom Oldfield. ``I wouldn't want to make it like this was a play arranged for everybody's benefit ... but we have gone down to talk to them and we know what they're going to do and how they're going to do it, and they know what we're going to do,'' Oldfield said. ``It's not like we're dealing with criminals,'' he said. The helicopters lifted off late Wednesday to spray a 53-square-mile area with the pesticide as part of the state's $30 million Medfly eradication campaign. The area sprayed in the operation that ended about 3 a.m. today included 10 square miles in southeast Pasadena, a city of about 135,000 people. It also part or all of Rosemead, San Gabriel, Monrovia, Monterey Park, South San Gabriel, northern Montebello, South El Monte, El Monte, Norwood Village, parts of Alhambra, Temple City, Arcadia and San Marino. The white Bell 204 helicopters flying in formation resembled a nighttime military assault. Pasadena's ban was the most aggressive of local efforts to halt spraying of malathion. Other cities have gone to court in hopes of doing the same. Opponents say too little is known about the health effects of the insecticide. However, the ban faces an uphill battle because Gov. George Deukmejian has declared a state of emergency in response to the Mediterranean fruit fly, and the declaration supersedes local ordinances, said Dr. Isi Siddiqui, assistant director of the state Department of Food and Agriculture. ``If Pasadena wants to stop it, they'll have to use available legal processes,'' Siddiqui said. ``They should exhaust legal remedies instead of (this) showdown in the air.'' Oldfield acknowledged that the swarm of state helicopters, joined by city helicopters and probably by news helicopters as well, pose a potentially hazardous situation in the air. But he said the city's brand of aerial warfare was expected to serve as another route to court. The state is spraying 400 square miles of Los Angeles and Orange counties to wipe out the worst infestation of Mediterranean fruit flies since 1981-82. Agriculture officials have called the spraying a safe and necessary step to prevent the Medfly from harming the state's multibillion-dollar farm economy. The Medfly lays its eggs in more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts grown in California. The crops are destroyed when the larvae hatch and growing maggots eat their way out. The Los Angeles City Council voted unanimously Tuesday to take the state to court over spraying. The cities of Pasadena, Glendale and Burbank will join the lawsuit. The Los Angeles city attorney was expected to file the suit today. Last month, the Orange County cities of Garden Grove, Huntington Beach and Westminster filed suit in Superior Court. A judge refused their request to stop spraying immediately. The Legal Aid Society of Orange County filed suit in federal court, arguing the spraying violates the civil rights of homeless people. Public concerns about pesticides in California also have prompted campaigns to put voter initiatives on the November ballot regulating their use. A proposed measure backed by environmentalists would phase out the use of some chemicals linked to cancer; a counterproposal from agriculture groups would give farmers more flexibility.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Leaders Threaten to Quit Over Peace Talks Compromise
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the left-leaning Labor Party said today they will quit the coalition Cabinet unless the right-wing Likud bloc accepts a compromise plan to clear the way for preliminary peace talks with Palestinians. Labor Party members said they wanted a Cabinet vote on the plan in two weeks. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, the No. 2 official in the Labor Party, had been a staunch defender of retaining the coalition but said today he changed his mind after Egypt approved a compromise package on the makeup of a Palestinian delegation to the proposed talks. ``Reasonable answers were given by the Egyptians to the United States on everything that is linked to the composition of the Palestinian delegation,'' Rabin said in an interview with Israel army radio. ``If it becomes clear that the answers from the other (Arab) side ... are positive, and ... if the delay comes from here, there is doubt whether there is a point in the continuation of the government,'' said Rabin. Egypt represents Palestinian positions in U.S.-brokered Middle East peace efforts because Israel refuses to negotiate directly with the Palestine Liberation Organization. The 107-member Labor Bureau, which runs the party's day-to-day affairs, met today to vote on a resolution calling for a Cabinet decision by March 7 on the compromise. That would require acceptance from Likud, which has opposed the compromise. The compromise calls for the Palestinian delegation to include six residents of the occupied lands; two deportees brought back from exile; and two residents of Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem who have other homes in the territories. Egypt would announce the composition of the delegation. The compromise, which has U.S. backing, is intended to satisfy PLO demands while recognizing Israel's formal insistence that it will only negotiate with residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Environment Minister Ronnie Milo, a confidant of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, today reiterated Likud's opposition to the compromise package. ``Deportees and east Jerusalem Arabs, this is something that is not included in the initiative of the Israeli government,'' Milo said on army radio. The government's initiative calls for Palestinian elections leading to limited self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, with their final status to be decided in later talks. Shamir has rejected the participation of east Jerusalem Palestinians but has not ruled out including deportees in a Palestinian delegation. Labor's ultimatum increases pressure on Shamir, who is battling hard-line Likud rebels trying to oust him as party leader. The hard-liners object to deportees or east Jerusalem Arabs taking part in the talks. Israel annexed Arab east Jerusalem after it was captured from Jordan along with the West Bank in the 1967 Middle East war.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle to Lead Delegation to Inaugurations in Chile and Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will lead a U.S. delegation to presidential inaugurations in Chile and Brazil next month, and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy will accompany him to Chile, it was announced today. Kennedy, D-Mass., who joined Quayle in the vice president's office for the announcement, will be part of the official U.S. delegation at the inauguration March 11 of Patricio Aylwin as president of Chile. He was elected Dec. 14. Fernando Collor de Mello, who was elected Dec. 20, will be inaugurated as president of Brazil on March 15. He recently met with Quayle and President Bush in Washington. Quayle also is expected to make stops in Argentina, Paraguay and Barbados. ``The restoration of democracy in Chile has been something which the American people have felt extremely deeply about for a long period of time. This has been an extremely painful process,'' Kennedy said, referring to that country's history of repressive governments and human rights violations. ``This is another indication of the winds of change that are taking place in the world.'' Kennedy said his participation in the U.S. delegation ``will be an indication to the Chilean people of the strong support for the restoration of democracy in Chile.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Attacks ANC's Guerrilla Campaign
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk today welcomed an African National Congress proposal to send a delegation for talks but criticized the group's adherence to guerrilla violence. The ANC, which de Klerk legalized Feb. 2, says its armed struggle remains a strategy to pressure the white-dominated government to share power with the nation's black majority of 28 million. Last week, the ANC announced it would send a delegation from its exile headquarters in Zambia to confer with de Klerk on how to clear the way for negotiations on a new constitution. No date for the meeting has been set, and de Klerk said the government would first have to address ``legal uncertainties'' in regard to exiled ANC leaders who might be liable for prosecution in South Africa. Although welcoming the ANC's decision to pursue talks, De Klerk said it was ``disappointing that the ANC leadership continues to talk about an armed struggle and hostilities at a time when most South Africans, supported by the rest of the world, want peace.'' ``The South African government is committed to a new dispensation which offers peace and justice for all,'' de Klerk said. ``An armed struggle and hostilities do not fit into this pattern.'' Recently released ANC leader Nelson Mandela helped launch the ANC's guerrilla campaign in 1961, a year after the group was outlawed. The bombing and sabotage campaign, however, has been largely ineffective in the past year and poses no serious threat to the government. De Klerk criticized the ANC for setting preconditions for the start of formal negotiations. The ANC has said de Klerk must lift the state of emergency and release all political prisoners before formal talks can begin. De Klerk says he plans to lift the 3{-year-old state of emergency soon and already has freed some political prisoners. The ANC seeks a one-man, one-vote democracy, which de Klerk opposes, saying it will lead to black domination of the country's 5 million whites. De Klerk envisions some mechanism that would give whites veto power on major policy decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Explosive Material Found in Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to recast lead, UPDATE with officials uncertain whether chemicals are still in school, picking up 6th graf, `The portable ...; SUBS 11th graf, `Superintendant Gary ..., to conform; pick up 12th graf, `Brader said ...
DOC.TEXT: Two elementary schools were closed after officials stumbled onto potentially explosive medical supplies that could have blown a hole the size of a ``decent-sized swimming pool'' if they were mishandled. ``My wife's scared to death because we're living right here,'' said Dennis Jarrell, who has three children at Gasport Elementary School, across the street from his house. Emergency hospital kits that were equipped with oxygen, nitrous oxide and ether in the late 1950s and early 1960s were discovered in the Gasport school and one in nearby Middleport by officials looking to create more storage space. ``There's no set way to compare ... but you can probably compare a container (of ether) to a stick of dynamite,'' said Fire Chief Doug Winner. There were at least a dozen containers in the Gasport school. A federal Environmental Protection Agency official today was to inspect the basement storage room where officials stumbled across the material Monday. It was not immediately clear whether the original cache of chemicals was intact. Michael Shanley, head of Niagara County's Emergency Management Office, said all ether in the county's schools had been removed in 1974 and none could be left in Gasport or Middleport. But Gary Brader, Royalton-Hartland school superintendent, said there was no record that ether had been removed from either school. He said the cases containing the emergency medical supplies did not appear to have been opened. The portable operating rooms, which were stored in many public buildings during the beginning of the Cold War, were established by the federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare, now known as the Department of Health and Human Services. The emergency medical facilities were to serve as a civilian version of a mobile army surgical hospital, or MASH unit, to be available in case of a national emergency, said Bill Clark, regional director for the state Emergency Management Office. A directive issued by the federal Office of Disaster Preparedness in 1974 warned county emergency agencies about the danger of dated ether and ordered the ``packaged disaster hospitals'' be removed. Niagara County in western New York near the Canadian border had seven such hospitals, according to Clark. ``Five were dismantled. For some reason, these two weren't,'' he said. While no one's sure exactly how much of the material is stored in the two schools, Gasport Fire Chief Doug Winner said there's enough so that, if it exploded, ``You could probably make a decent-sized swimming pool.'' Brader said the school district had been trying to have emergency officials remove the supplies from the school for years ``simply because we felt we needed space for storage.'' Brader said it wasn't until Winner toured the basement storage room Monday that he found out the material probably would have exploded had it been moved. ``We're not dealing with canisters sitting in a shelf where you'd walk in and see them,'' he said. ``We're talking about large boxes and wooden crates that are sealed, that have signs from the FBI saying they're not be touched.'' Brader closed school for the 500 Gasport pupils Monday. Another 470 pupils at the Middleport school, five miles east, were sent home Tuesday after officials learned of a similar portable hospital in that building's basement. If the schools can't be reopened by next week, Brader said, the district will set up double sessions at a nearby high school. Officials said an area up to a half-mile around the schools might have to be cleared as a precaution, meaning several hundred people might be displaced.

DOC.HEAD: Law Against Flag-Burning Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to reflect that law is not overturned nationally by a district judge's ruling. SUBS grafs 16-18 bgng `House Speaker' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Sen. Mitchell commenting, adds background on charges of destruction of government property.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge declared unconstitutional a law passed by Congress to prohibit flag desecration, ruling that Americans' right to burn their flag must be protected as energetically as their right to wave it. Prosecutors said the challenge to the Flag Protection Act of 1989 may be appealed directly to the U.S. Supreme Court. In dismissing flag burning charges against four people, U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein on Wednesday ruled that the new federal law is unconstitutional. ``In order for the flag to endure as a symbol of freedom in this nation, we must protect with equal vigor the right to destroy it and the right to wave it,'' she said. Mark Haggerty, Jennifer Campbell, Darius Strong and Carlos Garza were charged with burning a U.S. flag outside a Seattle post office shortly after midnight on Oct. 28, the day the flag protection law went into effect. After the ruling, Strong set a flag on fire on the steps of the U.S. Courthouse and spat on it as it burned. He released a statement, with Garza and Campbell, that called the ruling a ``real victory for righteous people everywhere.'' The case is the first constitutional challenge to the law, according to David Cole of the Center for Constitutional Rights in New York, which represented the four defendants. Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Bartlett said the U.S. Attorney's office, the Department of Justice and the Solicitor General will decide whether to appeal directly to the Supreme Court, an avenue provided for in the law, or to try the four demonstrators on another charge. The center planned to argue the same issue today in a district court in Washington, D.C., in a case involving three people who burned flags on the steps of the Capitol, Cole said. He predicted both cases would end up before the Supreme Court. Congress passed the new law after the Supreme Court last June overturned a Texas flag-burning conviction against Gregory Lee Johnson. Johnson, who burned a flag at the 1984 Republican National Convention, was among the spectators at a Feb. 14 hearing before Rothstein. Rothstein cited the Johnson case in her decision, saying it supported the conclusion that Congress is outlawing certain forms of expression under the Flag Protection Act. ``The principle underlying the Supreme Court's decision last summer was that the government can't compel people under penalty of imprisonment to be patriotic and Rothstein's decision recognizes that Congress' new law does exactly that,'' said Cole, who called the decision ``wonderful.'' The legislation prohibiting flag desecration was pushed by Democratic congressional leadership in opposition to a Republican plan for a constitutional amendment. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said in Washington today, ``I wouldn't get too worked up about a district court ruling. It's what we all exprected.'' The only significance to the ruling, he added, is ``getting it (the issue) in a posture where it now will go ... directly to the Supreme Court.'' The four defendants had pleaded innocent and moved to have the flag desecration charges dismissed on grounds the act violates the First Amendment. Each of the four also was charged with one count of destruction of U.S. government property, as the demonstration escalated from the burning of small paper flags to burning a flag on the post office flagpole. Rothstein was asked only to dismiss the desecration charges and that is what she did in holding the law unconstitutional. The flag desecration and destruction of property counts each carry a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. Prosecutors were meeting to decide whether to take the remaining count of property destruction to trial or take the issue directly to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines Change Position On Infant Safety Seats, Call For A Rule
DOC.TEXT: The nation's airline industry is asking the Federal Aviation Administration to require that all infants be fastened into approved safety seats when they fly aboard airliners. The Air Transport Association, which represents major carriers, was filing a petition today urging the FAA to adopt new rules affecting children under 2 years old, said ATA spokesman Steve Hayes. The law currently allows infants to be held in the arms of adult passengers. A rule requiring the seats would mean that infant passengers would have to be ticketed. They currently fly free, and most airlines allow safety seats to be used if empty seats are available. Most car safety seats are also approved for airline use. The ATA previously recommended the use of safety seats for passengers under 2 years old but, until today, did not favor a federal rule requiring such use.

DOC.HEAD: Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Sponsors Nationwide Anti-Drug Program
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen cities around the country will share $27 million for programs to deter alcohol and drug abuse, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation announced. The amount, to be spent over five years, is the largest sum from a single private source to combat substance abuse. Urban cities and rural communities were selected, including an area of northwestern New Mexico that covers portions of the Navajo and Zuni reservations. Foundation president Dr. Leighton E. Cluff said Wednesday that the program is aimed at developing successful models that can be copied elsewhere. Each of the 15 communities, selected from 331 applicants, must develop a program to reduce alcohol and illegal drug abuse among residents. Planning would be done in each city by a coalition of educators, health officials, law enforcement authorities and representatives of labor, business, religious organizations and government agencies. Each municipality will receive $100,000 a year for at least two years for planning and will be encouraged to seek additional funding from outside sources. Eight of the 15 will then be chosen to receive $3 million each to continue developing their models. The cities include Newark; Washington, D.C.; New Haven, Conn.; Worcester, Mass.; West Charlotte, N.C.; San Antonio; Little Rock, Ark.; Milwaukee; Kansas City, Mo.; Columbia, S.C.; and the California cities of Vallejo, East Oakland, San Jose and Santa Barbara. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation describes itself as the nation's largest private health care philanthrophy, with $2 billion in assets and $100 million annually in grants. It is named for the late son of one of the founders of the Johnson & Johnson health care products company.

DOC.HEAD: State Faces Deadline to Accept Federal Plea Bargain with Exxon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 8th graf, `The state...' to add Exxon setting tentative date for resuming cleanup. Picks up 9th graf, `The March...'
DOC.TEXT: Alaska could lose federal aid for cleaning up the state's oil-fouled shores if it refuses to accept a plea bargain with Exxon Corp., the state's top prosecutor said. Attorney General Douglas Baily said he doesn't like the pending plea bargain over criminal charges for environmental damage from the nation's largest oil spill. But if Alaska declines to be a party to the agreement, he said, it could find itself stuck with the cleanup bills. At a briefing for state senators Wednesday, Baily said the state also could lose control over any federal money that is spent. The U.S. Justice Department has refused to inform the state of all the points contained in the agreement, making a decision extremely difficult, he said. ``I feel the state is being overrun by the federal government,'' said Sen. Bettye Fahrenkamp of Fairbanks. ``I feel that somewhere along the line we have to roar even when we're getting hit over the head.'' Justice Department and Exxon attorneys are expected to file the plea bargain in federal court Friday, according to Baily. Today was the deadline for the state to accept or reject it. Baily was to make his recommendation today to Gov. Steve Cowper. The state has worked with Justice Department lawyers on the case over the past five months, Baily said. But he said he doesn't know if the state's suggestions have been followed. Meanwhile, the Coast Guard and Exxon announced that the oil company will resume its cleanup of Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska on May 1, weather permitting. Exxon suspended its cleanup in September for the winter and had not set a date for further work. The extent of the work will not be determined until April, spokesman Joe Tucker said, adding it would be ``substantially smaller'' than efforts last year. The company found serious problems along about 10 of the 90 miles of shore its crews surveyed, said Hann Jahns, an Exxon scientist. The March 24 spill occurred when the Exxon Valdez ran aground on a reef in Prince William Sound. The tanker leaked nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in the clear waters of the sound, killing countless birds and other wildlife. No criminal charges have been filed against Exxon in federal court. The state had decided early in the legal process to concentrate on civil litigation and allow the federal government to handle criminal charges against Exxon. Justice spokeswoman Amy Casner said negotiations were under way, but provided no details on the settlement, which could resolve criminal charges against the company. Exxon spokesman Les Rogers in Houston also declined to comment. The Wall Street Journal reported a week ago that Exxon's plea bargain included a $500 million fund for cleanup and restoration expenses. The account was criticized by an attorney designated by state and federal courts to help direct the dozens of civil lawsuits filed against Exxon and Alyeska Pipeline Service Co. Attorney Kenneth Adams of Washington, D.C., said it would allow Exxon to say, ``Hey, we already paid for the damage to natural resources,'' and possibly use it as an excuse to avoid civil penalties. Adams said he plans to seek court postponement of any plea bargain until parties in the civil cases are allowed a chance to study it. Baily said, however, he believed the plea bargain would not take away any rights from the state or other civil litigants seeking damages from Exxon.
