DOC.HEAD: Soviets Confirm No Direct Flights To Israel in Offing
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union announced today it will not allow direct air flights to Israel, bowing to Arab concerns that some Soviet Jewish emigrants might be settled in the Israeli-occupied territories. The decision followed weeks of campaigning by Arab countries against the direct flights, despite Israeli claims that it has no policy of settling Soviet Jews in the occupied lands. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim P. Perfiliev told a news briefing, ``We do not exclude completely the development of relations with Israel, including international flights, but we think a direct air link presupposes a certain level and character of relations between the U.S.S.R. and Israel. ``And at present it is completely out of the question to have such an air bridge, an air link, in order to take emigrants to Israel,'' Perfiliev said. The Soviet Union broke diplomatic relations with Israel after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, in which Israel seized the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Moscow has made Israel's withdrawal from the territories a condition for restoring ties. But the Soviet state-run airline Aeroflot began negotiations last year with Israel's El Al airlines for direct flights between Tel Aviv and Moscow. They signed an agreement that would have started the flights Jan. 1. The Soviets came under pressure from Arab countries and Palestinian groups concerned about possible settlement of emigrants in the occupied lands. U.S. officials said Tuesday they learned of the Soviet ban on direct flights during Secretary of State James A. Baker III's talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow in early February. Asked why the Soviets began negotiations on direct flights to Israel in the first place, Perfiliev told reporters: ``It is difficult for me to answer questions that should be answered by the representative of Aeroflot. Many Soviet organizations have an independent character for their international relations.'' He hinted that recent developments soured the Soviets on the deal. ``The issue of mass resettlement in the occupied territories was raised ... quite recently,'' the spokesman said. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir caused widespread concern last month when he suggested Israel needs to keep the West Bank and Gaza to handle the influx of Soviet Jews. The continued ban on direct flights will hinder Soviet efforts to transport the emigrants, who are leaving in record numbers under relaxed rules. Last year a record 60,000 Jews left the Soviet Union, and the high rate of departure has continued in 1990. Only about 200 out of the 12,000 Soviet Jews who went to Israel last year decided to settle in the occupied lands, according to Israeli figures. The top political adviser to PLO chief Yasser Arafat said any settlement of Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied territories would be an ``act of war'' that would require reprisals. Bassam Abu Sharif told reporters on Wednesday at the PLO headquarters in Tunis, ``This is very dangerous. We will continue to work in favor of peace, but if no concrete measure is taken by the big powers, we must think of means allowing us to defend our land.''

DOC.HEAD: Testimony: Top Commanders Beat Arabs In Violation Of Orders
DOC.TEXT: A top Israeli army officer said in military court today troops often ignored orders barring the beating of Palestinian detainees and that he once slapped an Arab whose hands and feet were bound, Israel radio reported. Lt. Col. Ephraim Fein, former commander of the elite Givati Brigade, testified in the trial of four Givati reserve soldiers accused of brutally beating two Palestinian detainees in the occupied Gaza Strip in February 1988. One detainee later died. During today's hearing, a defense attorney also cited previous testimony saying that Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, then army chief in the Gaza Strip, beat a Palestinian who refused orders to clear a stone roadblock. Mordechai is now head of the army's Central Command, which includes the occupied West Bank. The testimony came a day after the release of a U.S. State Department report saying Israeli soldiers often ignored regulations and that many unjust killings by soldiers went unpunished. Also today, six Palestinian teen-agers were wounded by army gunfire in scattered clashes in the Gaza Strip, Arab hospital officials said. The army said it was checking the reports. The army declared curfews in villages across the West Bank to prevent violence on the 21st anniversary of the founding of the Democratic Front of the Liberation of Palestine, a Syrian-backed radical PLO faction, Israel radio reported. The Givati trial revived debate in Israel over the army's beating policy. Beatings became widespread after Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin in January 1988 authorized soldiers to beat Palestinians during violent demonstrations. The four defendants allegedly beat Palestinians severely in a grove in Gaza's Bureij refugee camp. One of the men, Iyad Akal, 21, fell unconscious and later died in Gaza hospital. Fein, who testified for the prosecution, told the court that at the time his soldiers were ``in a situation close to war.... The orders were changed and eroded to keep up with the fast pace of events.'' Fein also recalled an incident in which he himself violated orders. ``When they (soldiers) arrested an Arab, they bound his hands and feet and blindfolded him. One soldier helped him get down from the jeep, and he spit at the soldier. I slapped the Arab in an instinctive reaction,'' the radio quoted Fein as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Cautious About Normalizing Relations With Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today set stiffer conditions for normalizing relations with Nicaragua if the leftist Sandinistas win Sunday's elections. Baker told the House Foreign Affairs committee that the Bush administration will not automatically accept the judgments of international observers as to whether the elections are free and fair. If that condition is met, he said, there will be no normalization until ``we see a substantial period of good behavior'' by the government, including a halt to support for leftist rebels in neighboring El Salvador and political freedom for the opposition in Nicaragua. ``It seems to me that if you believe in democracy, you believe in respecting the results of a free and fair election,'' Baker said in response to a question from Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass. ``But the United States must reserve the right to make the judgment whether the election is free and fair,'' he added. Observer groups like one sent by the United Nations and one led by former President Carter will assess the elections in good faith and ``arrive at reasoned judgments,'' he said. ``But in light of experience, the United States needs to make its own judgment.'' He reminded the panel that a large delegation of congressional observers that had been appointed by President Bush was denied visas. At the time, the Nicaraguan government argued that any official U.S. group could not be objective, since the United States is providing money to the election campaign of opposition coalition candidate Violeta Chamorro. Some of the members of that group are traveling to Nicaragua this weekend as members of other observer teams. If Sandinista President Daniel Ortega is re-elected _ ``and we shouldn't assume this,'' Baker said _ ``Before we talk about normalizing relations ... we must see a sustained period of good behavior'' by the government. ``The government of the United States must be satisfied that there will continue to be open political space in Nicaragua,'' he said. ``Then we can consider beginning to look at how we might normalize'' relations, including lifting trade sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Says He Didn't Know of Contra Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 4th graf, A transcript, to insert dropped word `not'
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan testified in a videotaped deposition released today that he ``never ... had any inkling'' that White House aides were secretly helping arm and advise the Nicaraguan Contras at a time when Congress had banned such aid. And he said, ``No one has proven to me'' that profits from secret arms sales to Iran were diverted to the rebels fighting the leftist Sandinista government in Nicaragua. Reagan testified as a defense witness in the forthcoming Iran-Contra trial of former national security adviser John M. Poindexter. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene allowed the former president to give a videotaped deposition in Los Angeles last Friday and Saturday but barred reporters from attending. A transcript of that testimony was released today after Bush administration officials said it did not pose any national security problems. Reagan said he ``assured everybody that we would have to abide by the law'' during the congressional ban on Contra aid. Asked if he had any idea that a Poindexter aide, Oliver North, was giving the Contras military advice and logistical support, Reagan said: ``I guess that I had never ... had any inkling that we were guiding their strategy in any way.'' That statement came under cross-examination by Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb. Poindexter is scheduled to go to trial March 5 on charges of obstructing congressional inquiries into the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and covert administration support for the Nicaraguan rebels. Reagan also testified under oath that he never authorized Poindexter to obstruct congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair or to destroy documents. The former president said repeatedly under cross-examination by Webb that Poindexter never told Reagan that he planned to lie to Congress or to destroy documents sought by Iran-Contra probers. ``At any time, did John Poindexter ever tell you that he had in fact obstructed or impeded any congressional committee inquiry into events relating to the Iran-Contra affair?'' Webb asked. ``No,'' Reagan replied. ``At any time, did he ever tell you that he had actually destroyed any records or documents related to the Iran-Contra affair?'' Webb replied. ``No,'' the former president said. Reagan said he was never told that North had destroyed Iran-Contra documents, an act for which the former National Security Council aide was convicted of a felony last year. Asked about his dealings with North, Reagan said: ``I didn't ever have any extensive contact with him. I heard about him a great deal and reports on him and so forth.'' Reagan acknowledged that he supported the solicitation of donations from foreign governments and others who could help finance the Contra effort. Although the law banned direct U.S. military aid to the rebels, Reagan said, ``there wasn't any restriction on ... informing others as to how they could help, things of that kind. And that I did approve.'' Reagan also testified that ``I wasn't'' aware that money was being diverted from the Iran arms sales to the Contras. ``I was only aware finally that we got our 12-million-two,'' Reagan said, referring to the money the U.S. government received for providing weapons to Iran. ``May I simply point out that I had no knowledge then or now that there had been a diversion, and I never used the term,'' the former president said. ``And all I knew was that there was some money that came from some place in another account, and that the appearance was that it might have been part of the negotiated sale.'' Webb asked: ``To the extent that there was in fact a diversion of proceeds, did you in any way approve or authorize that while you were president of the United States?'' ``For heaven's sake, no,'' Reagan replied. ``And when I was once asked about that extra money and said if it was an added sum to the purchase price, what would I do, I said I would have given it back.'' The former president added: ``No one has proven to me that there was a diversion.'' ``To this day, all I know is that some sum of money over and above the $12.2 million purchase price appeared in a Swiss bank account in which it was said that account had been used on another occasions (sic) to provide help to the Contras,'' Reagan said. ``And to this day, I still with all of the investigations that have been made, I still have never been given one iota of evidence as to who collected the price, who delivered the final delivery of the weapons ... whether there was ever more money in that Swiss account that had been diverted someplace else.'' ``I am still waiting to find those things out and have never found them out,'' Reagan said. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements in connection with the Iran-Contra affair. Specifically, he is accused of covering up from Congress North's secret assistance to the Contras and knowledge by government officials of a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Poindexter's lawyers sought Reagan's testimony in an attempt to show that the president approved of his national security adviser's activities. Judge Greene ordered the release of a transcript of Reagan's eight hours of testimony but barred the news media from making copies of the videotape for broadcast. In his order, Greene rejected arguments by Poindexter and Reagan for delaying the release of the testimony. ``The press and the public were not admitted to the deposition itself; but in view of the requirement of openness of crimnal proceedings, this segment of the Poindexter criminal trial should not be kept secret,'' the judge said. ``The public is entitled to know now to what the former president testified.'' On Wednesday, the Justice Department said it would not seek to delete any portions of the Reagan tapes, indicating they did contain any sensitive or classified information. The government's refusal to allow the disclosure of certain information led to the dismissal of some major conspiracy charges against Poindexter and his co-defendants in the Iran-Contra affair. Reagan's lawyers on Tuesday urged the court not to give news organizations copies of the tapes, proposing instead that a transcript be made available at the end of the trial. Reagan's lawyers said the public should be allowed to view the tape but not copy it. In a supporting brief, the Justice Department said it ``believes that access to a former president's testimony should be no greater than the access to the testimony of other witnesses.'' Twelve news organizations have petitioned the court for release of the videotapes as soon as possible. Poindexter's lawyers have asked Greene to postpone releasing the tape until a jury is picked, arguing that broadcast of the tape would jeopardize the defendant's right to a fair trial.

DOC.HEAD: Judiciary Committee Approves Nomination of Clarence Thomas to Be Judge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with new material and editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved the nomination of Clarence Thomas, the conservative chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, to be a federal appeals court judge. The nomination was approved 12-1 with Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, voting against it. It now goes to the full Senate. Some civil rights forces had opposed the nomination because of Thomas' opposition to affirmative action programs and his other conservative views. But the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced two weeks ago that it would not stand in the way of confirmation. Thomas, one of the most visible blacks in the Republican administrations of former President Reagan and President George Bush, was nominated to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia. At his confirmation hearing last week, Thomas said state and local agencies were primarily to blame for more than 900 cases of alleged job discrimination lapsing without action. Critics from women's and senior citizens groups said the number of lapsed cases actually ran into the thousands. Metzenbaum said the responsibility rested with the commission itself. ``I was flabbergasted that he did not know that state agencies are under contract to process state age discrimination claims,'' Metzenbaum said. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said that he and Thomas ``disagree about certain aspects of civil rights policy'' and that he is concerned about the commission's failure ``to ensure that age discrimination claims were investigated within the statute of limitations.'' But, Kennedy said, ``a court of appeals judge neither makes policy nor presides over an administrative agency.'' He added that Thomas ``has the ability to serve with distinction on the court of appeals and I support his confirmation.'' If confirmed, Thomas would take the place of Robert Bork on the appeals court. Because it is located in the nation's capital, it frequently is called on to decide major governmental cases and it has often been a springboard to the U.S. Supreme Court. Bork resigned after his nomination to the Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate in the most bitter judicial fight of recent years. Thomas, born in poverty in rural Georgia, is a graduate of Yale Law School. He worked for Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., both in Danforth's Senate office and when he was Missouri attorney general. Thomas was recommended to the panel at his confirmation hearing by Danforth and by Sens. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and Charles Robb, D-Va.

DOC.HEAD: State Record $67 Million Jackpot Shared By Four
DOC.TEXT: The owners of four lottery tickets beat 1-in-14 million odds to share a state record $67 million jackpot, officials said today. Each of the winning tickets is worth $16.7 million. The winners will get a check for about $2.5 million after taxes for 20 years. The $67 million jackpot for Wednesday's drawing was the largest in the state lottery's four-year history, and sparked a ticket-buying frenzy. ``People are buying them up hundreds at a time. We even have our own little pool going here at the store just in case,'' said Adria Singleton, assistant manager at the Ramona Village convenience market in Chino. The winning numbers, drawn from a field of 1 to 49 were: 44, 27, 34, 12, 21, 41, and the bonus number, 6. The winners won't be known until the tickets are turned in for validation. California's previous top prize was $61.98 million on Oct. 29, 1988. There were three winning tickets for the October 1988 record jackpot _ two of which were held by groups of people. The jackpot ranked fourth largest in the nation, trailing a record $115 million lottery prize in Pennsylvania last year. The jackpot grew to $67 million because there hadn't been a winner in the twice-weekly lotto game since Feb. 7. The prize was also bolstered by brisk ticket sale, since a percentage of sales is added to the jackpot.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Jets Bomb Guerrilla Base in South Lebanon.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted a guerrilla base in southern Lebanon today, Israel's third air raid in less than a week in the same area, the military command said. The jets attacked a base near the village of Liba, four miles east of the port city of Sidon. All targets were hit and the planes returned safely to base, the army said. ``The targets attacked were used as organization points for assaults against Israel,'' a military statement said. It did not give the identity of the base attacked, and the extent of damage and casualties was not immediately known. It was the third Israeli air raid on guerrila targets in Lebanon since Feb. 16, when Israeli aircraft attacked a position near Sidon used by the mainstream Shiite Moslem Amal group. On Feb. 19, Israeli jets bombed a base, also near Sidon, belonging to the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a Marxist PLO faction.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Pushes Product Liability Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops 10 grafs new with hearing testimony; picks up at pvs 2nd graf, A leading; deletes pvs 4th graf, The Senate, now outdated
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today challenged Congress to help American businesses compete in world markets by passing enacting a law limiting their legal liability for their products. ``If we are serious about addressing our nation's competitiveness, we must address the excessive burdens placed on American business by our current liability system,'' said Wendell Wilkie II, general counsel for the Commerce Department. Wilkie's comments came as the Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee today considered the first nationwide product liability law, which in past years has failed to win committee approval. Wilkie said a federal law would make the rules for doing business ``clear, consistent, uniform and predictable'' and reduce ``transaction'' costs related to liability lawsuits involving potentially dangerous products. Transaction costs are attorneys' fees and other court costs associated with product liability lawsuits. A 1988 survey of business administrators by the Conference Board, an organization of business executives, showed that 40 percent of U.S. businesses said product liability had a ``major'' impact on their operations, added Wilkie. But Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., chairman of the Commerce Committee, armed with a recent report by the General Accounting Office, disputed Wilkie's claims. Hollings said the study by Congress' investigative arm showed most punitive damages awards are overturned on appeal by businesses of product liability cases. ``This goes to the heart of transaction costs,'' said Hollings. The participants in today's hearing skirted the linkage of the administration's backing of the bill with the debate over blocking development of new birth control products, including the French abortion pill. A leading consumer advocate contends administration officials, in arguing for such a law, are citing a government study that criticizes legislative and regulatory obstacles to U.S. production of RU486, the so-called abortion pill. But David Beckwith, spokesman for Vice President Dan Quayle, said Wednesday the Council for Competitiveness _ which Quayle heads _ ``took no position'' on whether existing laws create obstacles to the production of RU486 in this country. President Bush called product liability standards a legislative priority in his State of the Union address. The administration contends the current patchwork of state-by-state laws stifles new product development, harms U.S. competitiveness, encourages excessive litigation and inflates insurance costs. Beckwith said a council member raised the report by the National Research Council and the Institute of Medicine during a meeting last week with consumer advocates. The report concluded no U.S. manufacturer will enter the market to produce RU486, the so-called ``abortion pill,'' or other new birth control products unless liability laws are changed to reduce the manufacturers' risk of being sued. ``The only way the birth control issue came up was in reference to newspaper articles ... that mention the various regulatory delays'' discussing publicity about the product liability problem, said Beckwith. However, Linda Lipsen, legislative counsel for Consumers' Union, a national consumer advisory organization, said ``the administration, which has done everything to prevent the manufacture of abortion-causing drugs, (is) bemoaning the fact that liability concerns have stifled manufacturers from producing these kinds of drugs.'' ``The proponents of this legislation point to this one study as some kind of proof that innovation is stifled because of product liability,'' she said. Consumers' Union opposes the bill, contending it creates unnecessary obstacles to victim compensation. ``The justification for this legislation changes as trends change,'' said Pam Gilbert, legislative director for Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group founded by Ralph Nader. Another opponent of the legislation, Arthur Bryant, executive director of Trial Lawyers for Public Justice, said, ``The only way that product development will not be affected by liability concerns is to pass a law establishing that ... no compensation would be paid.'' Administration and business proponents of a uniform federal product liability law say the current Senate proposal would not limit damages. The bill, introduced by Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., would: create a uniform standard for imposing punitive damages in product liability litigation; allow separate legal proceedings to consider punitive damages from product liability and compensatory damages; set a two-year statute of limitations on liability claims; and allow companies to pay damages in proportion to their responsibility for harm. ``We just want to level the playing field,'' said Victor Schwartz, an attorney and leading lobbyist for businesses that want to change the liability law. ``No one knows what rules apply to them and their products.'' Opponents argue the proposal would give consumers the burden of determining the proportion of liability for manufacturers, distributors or wholesalers of goods. And they charge the federal government would be usurping states' rights to set up their own product liability systems. In fact, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, recently warned that product liability legislation would lead to federal regulation of the insurance industry.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Faces Questions on `Horrendous' January Inflation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs of Greenspan inflation comments, picks up 6th graf pvs, Economists believe...
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said today that while he was surprised by certain aspects of January's sharp jump in consumer prices, he was not worried that inflationary pressures were accelerating. Greenspan, appearing to present the central bank's semi-annual report to Congress, was questioned at length about his views on inflation in light of Wednesday's government report that consumer prices shot up by 1.1 percent in January, the biggest monthly increase in seven years. The January increase translated into an annual rate of 14.1 percent. Sen. Don Riegle, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, asked Greenspan whether such a sharp jump in prices would force the Fed to change its new forecast that consumer prices will rise by between 4 percent and 4.5 percent this year, slightly lower than last year's 4.6 percent increase. Greenspan said that he felt comfortable with the Fed's forecast although he conceded that some of the specific components of the January price surge were surprising. ``As best as we can judge, while the rate of inflation is higher than we would like, there is no evidence that it is accelerating,'' Greenspan said. ``While I did not like the statistic published (Wednesday), it did not give me any great concern,'' Greenspan said. In his prepared testimony, Greenspan repeated comments he made on Tuesday that he believed a reversal in the sharp January jump in prices was under way. He cited evidence showing that price increases in the last half of 1989 were ``appreciably lower'' than in the first six months of the year. In his testimony today, Greenspan said the Fed expects the economy to be sluggish this year, growing at an anemic rate of 1.75 percent to 2 percent. That would be the weakest performance since 1984 and far below the administration's expectations for the year. Economists believe the slow growth is part of the central bank's plan to wring inflationary pressures out of the economy. For this reason, they believe the central bank will not move to lower interest rates anytime soon, preferring to keep rates high to discourage borrowing and thus dampen economic demand. While the January price increases were indeed frightening to economists, some viewed the increase as a temporary weather-related phenomenon. Others saw more entrenched inflationary pressures. Prices at the wholesale level shot up 1.8 percent last month, a pace which translates into an annual rate of 24.1 percent. Consumer inflation did little better, rising 1.1 percent in January, the steepest one-month gain since June of 1982, the government reported Wednesday. Much of the gain in both price measures was attributed to a spurt in energy and food costs brought on by the severe December weather which depleted fuel stocks and damaged fresh fruits and vegetables. But even discounting the volatile food and energy categories, the so-called core rate of inflation climbed at an alarming 0.6 percent in January. That was highest increase in a year and one which would translate into an annual rate of 7.5 percent. The core rate of inflation is considered a better gauge of underlying inflation pressures. January's 0.6 percent increase was worrisome enough to attract attention at the White House, which termed the increase ``disappointing news.'' ``We do expect the core rate of inflation to decline steadily over the year,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. ``We are hopeful that this is a bulge that will be temporary in nature, but inflation requires eternal vigilance and we remain on a policy of wanting steady growth with low inflation.'' Fitzwater, who recently criticized the Fed for its refusal to lower interest rates, refused to say what course the Fed should pursue now, saying, ``I'll let the Fed worry about interest rates.'' Some analysts agreed with the Bush administration's assessment that inflation should ease in coming months and cautioned the Fed against overreacting to one month's numbers. ``The surge in prices should not be viewed as an acceleration in the underlying rate of inflation, but rather as a one-time increase in ... food and energy,'' said Gordon Richards, chief economist of the National Association of Manufacturers. But other economists said they were worried that labor costs, especially in the booming service sector, were beginning to move upward. ``Inflation is disturbingly high,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``This indicates an entrenched inflation that will not easily recede.'' John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services, said it was difficult to discount the January increase because so many service categories from medical care to entertainment costs were up. ``One could try to explain it as a temporary blip but there were a lot of increases outside of food and energy,'' he said. ``Greenspan says inflation is a concern and he is right.''

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Hits Georgia; High Winds and Rain Across Alabama
LaserPhoto CBS1
DOC.TEXT: A violent storm front packing tornado-like winds and at least one confirmed tornado racked parts of Georgia and Alabama this morning, flipping trailer homes and downing trees and power lines and critically injuring three people. Initial damage reports from Columbus, Ga., where the tornado touchdown was confirmed, were sketchy. In Alabama, authorities reported serious damage and injuries near Opp, which was hit by tornado-like winds shortly before dawn, and to the northeast in Pike County,. ``It shook our whole building when it came through, and we're in a concrete building,'' said Robert Booth, a radio reporter with station WOPP in Opp, a town of 7,000 about 60 miles north of the Gulf of Mexico. The storm hit the town at about 5:50 a.m., knocking out power and covering streets with the mangled remains of trees. Witnesses said windows were blown out in downtown stores, and some neighborhoods showed widespread damage. At least 15 injures were reported in Alabama. Six people required hospitalization, including three who were critically injured in Pike County when a twister or tornado-force winds demolished trailer homes. The entire state remained under a flash flood watch. The storm system coursed into Georgia from the southwest, sending a tornado spinning into Columbus at about 9:15 a.m. ``We have no severe damage that we know about,'' said Joy Burnham, the city's emergency management director. She said some damage was reported at a car dealership, and some roofs and trees were blown down. Phone lines were down in the downtown Columbus area, according to Southern Bell spokeswoman Lynne Bress. Georgia Power Co. spokeswoman Meg Reggie said only a few hundred customers were without power. It was the second tornado in downtown Columbus this month. On Feb. 10, the city was hit by one of several twisters that touched down in Georgia during a storm. In northern Georgia, where 10 inches or more of rain fell on some sections last week, the National Weather Service predicted up to 2 inches of rain today as the storms moved through. ``Everybody up here's praying for good things to happen,'' said Trion Mayor Hoyt Williams, whose town was one of the worst hit by the earlier rain. ``I don't know what protective measures to take. Do you?'' Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris has asked for $15.7 million in federal disaster aid for nine counties _ Carroll, Chattooga, Cobb, Douglas, Fannin, Gilmer, Gordon, Murray and Walker _ because of recent floods and tornadoes. A flash flood watch issued by the National Weather Service for today covered an area that included Atlanta, Athens and Rome. Harris estimated Monday that storms since Feb. 10 have killed six people and injured 32 in the state. He said 39 homes were destroyed, while 470 houses and 129 businesses were damaged. In Alabama, the most severe damage today appeared to follow a northeast path from Opp through Pike County into Barbour County. In Pike County, officials said four people were injured in mobile homes and a pickup truck was blown into a tree; in Barbour County, sheriff's deputy R.H. Johnson said four house trailers were damaged. Trees and power lines also were snapped off in Chambers, Lee, Tallapoosa, Bullock and Houston counties, and the wind was clocked at 76 mph in Dothan. An elementary school in Auburn was closed after high winds sent two trees crashing into the building. No injuries were reported. A middle school at Auburn also was closed by a power outage.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Wondering where that hubcap disappeared to? You might want to start with George Huskins. Huskins, 58, collects all those shiny wheel covers that fall by the roadside. He's got 41,000 in more than 3,100 styles, from tri-spoke caps for a Studebaker to the Checker Cabs and Indiana State Police varieties. Huskins, who has been hub-hunting for four years, estimates that 7,000 types have been manufactured since the first automobile rolled off an assembly line. Today's versions are usually made of plastic to cut costs, and they tend to fall off, he said. ``They make them a lot cheaper now, especially the after-market (replacement) caps,'' Huskins said. Huskins regularly ships hubcaps across the United States and Canada and handles orders from overseas. His collection includes many hubcaps from the past _ Dort, Whippet, Flash, Rio, Durant Edsel, Avanti _ and besides being a novelty, some are worth their weight. His most expensive hubcap is a $300 Auburn 12, from the limited-run cars manufactured in Auburn during the early part of the century. A spoked cap that was mounted over a spare tire on the back of a 1934 Ford sells for $200.

A cat with a luxuriant mustache and another with the reputed ability to warn of potential molesters won their owners cash prizes Thursday in a Cat Day Festival. The judges considered the distinctive characteristics of 120 cats in selecting the winner of the fourth annual festival for finding Japan's top cat. The top prize of 100,000 yen (about $694) went to Tsurutaro, a 6-year-old mixed breed Japanese cat, for the high number of split hairs in its mustache and its ``lovely'' relationship with its owner, Chizuru Yamamoto, 25. Bank clerk Mika Toyokawa, 23, took home the 30,000-yen (about $208) runner-up prize for a mixed breed Japanese cat named Marina, who ``always informs me with a `fu-fu' sound when a molester of women approaches the window.'' About 350 spectators attended the contest, which is held on Feb. 22 because the Japanese pronunciation of 2-22 _ ``ni-ni-ni'' _ sounds like the word the Japanese use to represent a cat's meow, ``nyan-nyan-nyan.'' An estimated 4 percent to 5 percent of Japanese households own cats, whose numbers total about 2.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: University Authorities Ban Students' Demonstrations
DOC.TEXT: The University of Nairobi has banned further demonstrations by students demanding an impartial investigation into the shooting death of Kenya's foreign minister. Philip Mbithi, the vice chancellor, said Wednesday the ban was imposed because non-students had joined a demonstration earlier in the day and pelted a presidential monument with stones in a downtown Nairobi park. ``This reflects badly on the image of the institution,'' Mbithi said. Riot police dispersed students for the first time in four days Wednesday. The clash followed the students' call for President Daniel arap Moi's resignation and the stoning of the monument, which was built last year to commemorate Moi's 10th year of rule Robert Ouko's partially burned body was discovered Feb. 9 in brushland about four miles from his family farm near Lake Victoria in western Kenya. Investigators say he had been shot once in the head. Students began demonstrating in Nairobi on Sunday. Other demonstrations occured at Egerton University, 90 miles west of Nairobi, and at Moi University, 155 miles northwest of Nairobi. Ouko was the fourth leading political figure to die violently since Kenya gained independence in 1963. None of the three previous murders was solved and in each case the government of former President Jomo Kenyatta was accused of a coverup. Moi's government has released only sketchy details of its investigation, and has called in three Scotland Yard detectives and a British pathologist to assist it. They began work Wednesday. Ouko, a father of four girls and three boys, first served as permanent secretary in the foreign ministry from 1963 to 1964. He later held high-ranking government jobs before Moi tapped him to head the foreign ministry in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Party Leadership Warns Against `Chaos' This Weekend
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party leadership joined Soviet lawmakers Thursday in calling for order this weekend, when mass rallies are scheduled nationwide, and it urged citizens to oppose attempts to create ``chaos.'' The appeal to ``the Soviet working people'' from the party's policy-making Central Committee showed the Kremlin's clear worry about the turn that might be taken by Sunday's protests, many of which are intended to voice the demands of ethnic groups or denounce more than 70 years of Communist Party rule. The Central Committee called on Communists and non-party members alike to ``rebuff all who push people to chaos, provoke conflicts, ethnic strife and enmity and create instability in society.'' The appeal was carried by the official Tass news agency and was to be printed in Soviet newspapers Friday. It follows Tuesday's decree by the Soviet legislature calling on local authorities to crack down on illegal protests Sunday and to control those demonstrations that were permitted. Rallies by various political groups are scheduled Sunday in Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev, Minsk and other major cities. On Friday, officially Soviet Army Day, anti-military protests are planned in Moscow, the Ukrainian cities of Lvov and Donetsk, and the Moldavian capital of Kishinev, organizers said. The Communist leadership acknowledged there were grounds for Soviets to be dissatisfied. ``It is understandable that people are indignant when they encounter facts of mismanagement, incompetence, irresponsibility and abuses,'' it said. But it said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms were the answer and must be supported. ``We cannot and should not reconcile ourselves to the anti-democratic and unlawful actions taken by all kinds of demagogues and politicoes,'' the party body said. ``They stir up national enmity, use brute pressure and intimidation, attempt to demoralize party and government agencies and their workers and generate enmity and bitterness, anxiety and non-confidence.'' ``These are inadmissible and intolerable actions,'' the Central Committee said. It called for national unity behind Gorbachev's program of ``perestroika,'' or social and economic reconstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl's 10-Point Plan, Other Hits Now on Records & Cassettes
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has assembled his 10-point plan and other reunification hits in a long-playing record album and cassette tape offered free to the first 100,000 East German fans. The political hit parade takes listeners back to the chancellor's now famous speech to parliament Nov. 28, when he laid out the steps to unity. ``What This Historic Hour Has Made Possible,'' the chancellor's debut album, also contains speeches during his visit to Dresden on Dec. 19 and at the Brandenburg Gate on Dec. 22, when a stretch of the Berlin Wall was knocked out to join the two sides of the divided city. The albums and cassettes produced by the federal government are available while the supply of 100,000 lasts, free to East Germans. They were made at a cost of $90,000 to West German taxpayers. On the bright blue record jacket, Kohl beams and waves over the roof of his Mercedes to well-wishers in Dresden during his Dec. 19 visit. According to Wolfgang Bergsdorf, head of the domestic department of the federal Press and Information Office, the album of Kohl speeches being distributed during East German election campaign rallies ``is already a historical document.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead in House Fire, Arson Suspected
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a house in western Pennsylvania today and killed a couple and two of their children, hours after a vacant tavern building caught fire, authorities said. Glen Campbell Fire Chief Dave Lucas said state police suspect both fires were arson. The tavern caught fire about 2 a.m. and the house, some 200 yards away, began burning about four hours later. Deputy Coronor Mike Baker identified the victims as Earl and Charmaine Marsh and two Baker children, Wanda and Ralph. He did not have their ages. Their bodies were found on the second floor, authorities said. Joe Recesky said he was staying at the home of mother-in-law, near the site of the fires, when a young man came to the door and asked for help. Recesky said he pounded on the house's windows, shouted and entered the first floor. ``I got in before the flames and smoke drove me from the first floor,'' he said. ``A can of gasoline must have exploded because my hair was singed and I was forced out.'' Lucas said there was evidence of a break-in at the tavern. Police arrested a youth at the scene and charged him with disorderly conduct and underage drinking. Police would not identify the youth.

DOC.HEAD: DOE Picks Consortium for $1 Billion Collider Contract
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON AP) _ The Energy Department today awarded a $1 billion engineering and construction contract for a a high-powered atom smasher to a team led by a New York firm, according to members of Congress. The contract was awarded to a consortium of three companies led by Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Quade and Douglas Inc. of New York City. Also on the team are CRSS Inc. of Houston and Morrison Knudsen Corp. of Boise, Idaho, officials said. Officials say the award is the largest single contract involved in building the superconducting super collider, a 53-mile underground ring where scientists would test theories about the building blocks of the universe by smashing atomic particles at high speeds. The team was chosen from three finalists selected in December out of a field of 14 to compete for the contract to build the atom smasher at a site south of Dallas in Ellis County. Terms of the contract must still be negotiated, officials said. Rep. Joe Barton, R-Ennis, whose district includes the site for the facility, said the contract is a sign the project is moving forward, despite an anticipated billion-dollar increase in cost and questions about the technology. Larry Neal, a spokesman for Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, Parsons Brinckerhoff is the lead contractor and would do the architectural and engineering contracting work, with Knudsen and CRSS doing the construction work. Congress has appropriated $225 million for the collider, including $160 million for construction work, during this fiscal year. President Bush is seeking an additional $318 million for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Because of design changes, the cost of the project is expected to increase from $5.9 billion to at least $7 billion. The collider would be the world's largest scientific instrument.

DOC.HEAD: The Soviet Union Suggests Overall Ceiling in Central Europe
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union suggested today that NATO and the Warsaw Pact limit their number of troops in central Europe to 750,000 each, an East German negotiator said. The superpowers have agreed to a ceiling of 195,000 troops each for the United States and Soviet Union in central Europe. The agreement, reached at meetings among NATO and Wasaw Pact foreign ministers in Ottawa, Canada, is to be part of a final accord on reducing troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclar arms in Europe. Negotiators hope to reach agreement on the accord before the end of this year. The new proposal, combined with East bloc nations' plans to cut their own armed forces, would lead to NATO having more manpower in the region than the Warsaw Pact, said East Germany's chief delegate at arms talks, Klaus-Dieter Ernst. Ernst said the seven Warsaw Pact countries would have a total troop strength in central Europe of 600,000 to 700,000 troops, while the West would have a total of some 1 million troops. ``That situation is totally unsatisfactory,'' Ernst said. Western sources appeared to contest Ernst's estimate, saying NATO currently has about 900,000 troops in central Europe, which covers West Germany, East Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Hungary and Denmark. In the wake of democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and their growing independence from Moscow, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have begun negotiations with the Kremlin on a total withdrawal of Soviet troops from their territories. Those talks are separate from the ongoing Vienna talks. The Soviet idea was presented at the last Vienna plenary before a three-week recess, but it was not put on the table as a formal proposal. Ernst said that the overall ceiling suggested by the Soviets would include domestic troops as well as those stationed on foreign soil. In separate negotiations, the Hungarians are seeking withdrawal of the approximately 50,000 Soviet troops stationed on their territory, while Czechoslovakia seeks the total removal of 73,500 Soviet troops from its soil. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have also announced troop cuts of their own. Both East and West also presented new proposals in an effort to narrow differences on definitions of certain armaments and treaty language for verification of any troop withdrawals. West Germany's chief delegate, Ruediger Hartmann, presented two working papers on behalf of NATO on information exchanges and conditions for inspections as part of a verification program. Ernst said he presented on behalf of the Warsaw Pact a paper on tank definitions. Definitions of weapons categories have been a major sticking point at the negotiations, which began last March. The sides also disagree on the number of combat aircrat each side should have. ``Lots of work remains to be done here,'' U.S. chief delegate, R. James Woolsey told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Meets New York Mayor, Fellow Writers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add reference to museum visit; INSERTS 3 grafs after 11th graf pvs, `The Czechoslovak...', to add detail of later events. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel started his New York visit today with breakfast at the mayor's mansion where the former dissident playwright was joined by a number of U.S. writers. The breakfast with Mayor David Dinkins was the first item on a busy schedule that included lunch with human rights advocates, a stop at an art museum and meetings with the Council on Foreign Relations, Czechoslovak-Americans and U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Havel, a former jailed dissident who was elected Czechoslovak president Dec. 29, arrived in the United States on Monday. He spoke to a joint meeting of the House and the Senate on Wednesday and met with President Bush twice. Havel's wife, Olga Havlova, did not attend today's breakfast. Havel said she was tired from their travels. Guests at the breakfast included writers Kurt Vonnegut, Edward Albee and Arthur Miller. Havel said as a playwright, he never could have conceived a plot in which he would become president. ``It is extremely strange and extraordinary,'' he said. ``But I don't have time to think about it. It is a busy job to be president.'' After breakfast, producer Joseph Papp presented Havel with a collage and said he would produce the Czechoslovak president's play, ``Slum Clearance.'' Dinkins gave Havel a crystal apple, and Kitty Carlisle Hart, chairwoman of the State Council of the Arts and a former actress, gave him a copy of ``Act One,'' the autobiography of her late husband, playwright Moss Hart. Havel said he was ``extremely happy to be once more in New York.'' He was last in New York in 1968 for the first night of one of his plays. Asked to compare his ascent to office and Dinkins' campaign to become the city's first black mayor, Havel said: ``One difference: I didn't want to be a president. But I was raised to the post by public pressure. I didn't want it, personally.'' The Czechoslovak Parliament elected Havel president a few weeks after a peaceful revolution that led to the ouster of a hard-line Communist government. Havel's caretaker government is preparing for parliamentary elections in June. Havel's next stop was the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He was greeted on the museum steps by two dozen flag-waving, cheering youngsters from the Czechoslovak School for children of Czechoslovakian diplomats. ``They've looked forward to this for months and months,'' teacher Lida Husek said. ``For us the changes in our country are very exciting. But we're so far from home. This is our way of keeping in touch, with him and with our countrymen.'' He then traveled to Cardinal John O'Connor's residence where he received a crystal star from the president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, Rabbi Arthur Schneier. On Wednesday, Havel told Congress that the United States could best help his country by pressing the Soviet Union to stay on its own road to democracy. Havel was the first of the new East European leaders to address Congress. Speaking through a translator, Havel called Czechoslovakia one of Eastern Europe's ``wayward children'' and said it wants to coordinate its return to the economic and political mainstream with Hungary, Poland and other nations emerging from 40 years of Soviet domination.

DOC.HEAD: AFL-CIO Leaders Urge Renewed Support for Eastern Strikers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with today's statement on Eastern strike; pick up 5th graf, `The pollsters ...'. Veraion moving on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: AFL-CIO leaders today urged unions to renew support for striking machinists at Eastern Airlines and declared that the nearly year-long strike ``remains as solid as ever.'' Leaders of the 14.1 million-member federation, set to adjourn their winter meeting later in the day, issued a statement saying the 8,500 machinists had inspired workers nationwide by being ``on the front lines of labor's battle against corporate greed and intransigence.'' Machinists who walked out last March have faced stiff odds with a Bush administration that doesn't ``care about the survival of Eastern Airlines'' and has sided with management in the matter, the federation said. Eastern was the only major point of contention when union leaders met with Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole earlier in the week. AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland has conceded that so far the strike has failed, but said Eastern's parent, Texas Air Corp., has not won either. Labor leaders also acknowledged they still lack enough votes in Congress to override President Bush's veto of legislation that would create a commission to settle the dispute. The Eastern situation has been a sore spot for labor leaders this week who otherwise have been buoyed by signs that organized labor may be recovering from a bleak decade. The machinists' strike marks a strong contrast to labor's recent successes by Pittston coal miners and Nynex telephone workers in the Northeast. Just today, the federation's Executive Council received a report by the Roper Organization showing that more Americans instinctively side with unions than with companies in labor disputes. ``We've been tempered, I think, by a period of fire and, in the net result, it's strengthened us,'' Kirkland said. The pollsters found, in their most recent tracking surveys, that 33 percent instinctively side with the union while 25 percent favor the company when they first hear of a strike and before they know any of the details. That was the highest level of support for unions, and the lowest for companies, recorded by the company since it posed the question to sample groups 12 years ago. Roper reports are sponsored by the AFL-CIO and 40 other organizations, including government agencies. The company conducts face-to-face interviews with new groups of 2,000 adults every five weeks. Union leaders were cheered by the results, given the decline in stature organized labor suffered in the 1980s with losses in membership. Also serving as a rallying point for labor leaders this week was the success of the Appalachian coal strike _ Pittston miners who won on key bargaining points ended their bitter 10-month strike Tuesday by ratifying a new contract. United Mine Workers President Richard Trumka, who last year brought his union back into the AFL-CIO, and others said the public looks more favorably on unions because unions have avoided ``focusing so narrowly on shop floor issues.'' ``There are 38 million Americans without health care. What's the only group that's really fighting for health care? That's organized labor,'' Trumka said. The Roper report showed that in 1981, 60 percent of Americans thought unreasonable demands by labor unions made the cost of living go up unneccesarily. That number has now dropped to 40 percent, the survey showed. Noting the decline of blue-collar jobs in the manufacturing area, the report said the image of unions had gained in the eyes of professional and white collar workers _ groups that formerly were the least likely to support organized labor. AFL-CIO leaders, who have traditionally taken a hardline approach to the Soviet Union, called on the Bush administration Wednesday to give the country most favored nation status, which would let them benefit from lower trade tariffs.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Paper Close to Rafsanjani Says Hostages Should be Freed
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian newspaper close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani said Thursday all 18 Western hostages in Lebanon should be freed because they have become a propaganda tool for Iran's enemies. Most of the captives are believed held by kidnappers loyal to Iran. ``Regardless of the West's propaganda ploys, Moslem forces, out of Islamic and humanitarian considerations, should work to get the hostages free with no precondition,'' the English-language Tehran Times said in an editorial, parts of which were carried by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency. It was the first known statement by an Iranian newspaper in support of freeing all the hostages, whose fate is believed linked to a power struggle within the Iranian government. Eight Americans, four Britons, an Irishman, an Italian, two West Germans and two Swiss citizens are captives in Lebanon. Terry A. Anderson, 42, has been held the longest. He is chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press and was abducted March 16, 1985. Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, was in Damascus, Syria, on Thursday as part of a tour with an Associated Press delegation to seek the hostages' release. Among leaders with whom she has met are Javier Perez de Cuellar, the U.N. secretary-general; Pope John Paul II, and Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Attempts to see Iranian leaders have failed. Asked in Damascus about the Tehran Times editorial, Mrs. Say said: ``I am deeply grateful. It is encouraging. I consider that Iran is not part of the problem, but part of the solution.'' Arafat told Mrs. Say in their meeting last week that Rafsanjani had the greatest influence with the kidnappers, but hard-liners in the Iranian government limited his room for maneuver. In its editorial, the Tehran Times said the struggle against Western influence in the Middle East was legitimate and should continue, but that all forces in Lebanon should work to free hostages of whatever nationality. ``They should regard the hostages as victims of imperialist policies of the West and make attempts to get them all freed,'' it said. ``Maybe 1990 will be the year for the release of all the hostages.'' It repeated Rafsanjani's demand for the release of Iran's charge d'affaires in Beirut, Mohsen Musavi, and three other embassy staff members kidnapped in north Lebanon in July 1982 by members of the Lebanese Forces, a Christian militia. All four are believed dead. Lebanese Forces commander Samir Geagea said in August 1988 he found no trace of the men after taking over the militia in 1986. Geagea blamed his predecessor, Elie Hobeika, for their disappearance and apparent murder. Rafsanjani has offered to help free the Western hostages. In August 1989, he said there were ``reasonable, prudent solutions'' to the problem. Two months later, Rafsanjani said he would not try to get them released unless the United States freed billions of dollars in Iranian assets frozen in 1979. Any statement with even a hint of conciliation is condemned promptly by factions in the Iranian government who reject the reconciliation with the West favored by Rafsanjani. Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, the former interior minister and Rafsanjani's main rival, regularly encourages groups holding hostages in Lebanon. He said in a newspaper interview last month they have ``a natural right to take hostages to inflict heavy blows on their enemies.'' Most of the kidnappers are believed linked to Hezbollah, or Party of God, a Lebanese fundamentalist Shiite Moslem group Mohtashemi helped organize in the early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Astronaut Illness, Poor Weather Delay Shuttle Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12-13th grafs, `We've never...', with 2 grafs to CORRECT that one previous launch posponed because of illness, in 1969. Picker up 14th graf pvs, `NASA officials...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Challenger Movie, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The space agency today postponed launch of shuttle Atlantis on a secret military mission until at least Saturday, as doctors treat an astronaut's cold and forecasters worry about the weather. The launch had been scheduled for today until the space agency decided Wednesday to postpone it after commander John O. Creighton suddenly developed a sore throat and head congestion. Originally, the launch was postponed to Friday morning; this morning, Creighton was described as feeling better but the launch was put off at least one more day. ``The commander is doing a lot better,'' NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. ``They're going to give him another day. And there's also the weather.'' NASA said the launch was delayed for at least 24 hours. That would put liftoff in the early morning hours of Saturday, although forecasters say the weather is unlikely to clear until Sunday. A statement late this morning said Creighton ``showed some improvement overnight, but remains under assessment.'' NASA spokesman Kyle Herring said Creighton was examined by a NASA flight physician on Wednesday morning and was treated with antibiotics. ``He does not have a fever,'' said the spokesman. ``It could be an indication of a cold coming on.'' Even without the astronaut's illness, the chances were uncertain that Atlantis could have been launched today or Friday. Air Force experts forecast a 50 percent chance today and an 80 percent chance Friday of prohibitive clouds, rain and wind. Because Atlantis' cargo is a secret spy satellite, NASA has not announced a precise launch time, saying only that a launch on Friday would come between midnight and 4 a.m. The countdown is kept secret until the final nine minutes before the rockets ignite, but sources, who asked not to be named, said the liftoff will come about 1 a.m. After launch, information about the mission is to be blacked out until an hour before Atlantis returns to Earth. The mission is expected to last four days and end with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in California. All five of Atlantis' crew members were found to be healthy during a routine medical examination on Tuesday. It was only the second time a mission had been postponed because of illness. In 1969, the Apollo 9 mission to orbit the Earth and test the lunar landing module was delayed three days after the three crew members got sick. The following year, Astronaut Thomas K. Mattingly was taken off the crew of Apollo 13, a moon mission, when doctors learned he had been exposed to the measles. He was replaced on the crew by back-up pilot John Swigert, but the launch was not delayed. NASA officials said there were no plans to replace Creighton. A space shuttle launch postponement at this point in the countdown costs the Kennedy Space Center about $247,000 in labor and materials. This figure does not include expenses at other NASA centers that also support the mission. NASA's announcement came about two hours before workers were to start pumping more than half a million gallons of propellant into Atlantis' fuel tank. Pumping the fuel would have added $377,000 to the delay cost. According to sources who asked not to be named, Atlantis' cargo is a 37,300-pound, $500 million spy satellite called AFP-731. It is said to be capable of taking high-resolution reconnaissance photos and also eavesdrop on electronic communications around the world. Sources said the satellite is to be placed into a high inclination orbit that will cover more of the Earth than satellites previously launched by the shuttle. This orbital path will carry it over most of the Soviet Union, including areas far to the north. Atlantis' flight will be 34th space shuttle mission and the sixth secret military mission.

DOC.HEAD: Blast Rips Through Tanker; Two Americans Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to ADD Pentagon comment; Pickup 5th pvs, `Crewman Wayne...'
DOC.TEXT: An explosion ripped through a U.S.-flagged petroleum tanker in the Persian Gulf today, leaving two Americans missing and setting off fires that forced the rest of the crew to abandon ship, the Navy said. A U.S. frigate patrolling nearby rescued 23 crew members from the sea, and some were injured, said Capt. Ron Wildermuth, chief spokesman for the Navy's Central Command in Florida. Two of the injured were airlifted to a hospital in Dubai. One of the rescued men said all 25 crewmen on the Surf City, a Kuwaiti tanker flying the U.S. flag, were Americans, but this was not immediately confirmed. The cause of the explosion was not known. Initial reports indicated it was an accident, said Wildermuth. In Washington, Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said there were indications the explosion was ``internal.'' He did not elaborate. Crewman Wayne Cohen said the blast occurred about 11:00 a.m. while crew members were working on a cargo tank on the ship, which was loaded with millions of gallons of highly volatile products. ``It was a huge explosion, the whole ship just blew up,'' said Cohen, 27, of Boston, who was cut by glass and airlifted to a hospital in Dubai. ``The glass in the bridge blew out. There was some panic and we all made our way to the lifeboat,'' he said. Cohen said he saw ``nothing but fire and smoke'' as he looked back at the tanker from the lifeboat. The 81,283-ton Surf City carried 17.8 million gallons of naphtha and 8.9 million gallons of gasoil, industry sources said. U.S. Navy units and the United Arab Emirates coast guard put out four blazes, but a fifth continued to burn more than six hours after the blast, and ships nearby moved away for fear of another explosion. ``The ship is half-sunk now, and it might sink totally,'' said a member of the Dubai coast guard. Shipping sources said on condition of anonymity the tanker had been loaded in Kuwait and was on its way out of the gulf. The ship was off the coast of the United Arab Emirates, near the Iranian island of Abu Musa, when the explosion occurred. Abu Musa was a stronghold of Iranian Revolutionary Guards and was used as a base to attack ships at the height of the Iran-Iraq war. There have been no attacks on shipping in the gulf since Iran and Iraq signed a cease-fire agreement in August 1988. Wildermuth said the USS Simpson was 15 miles away from the Surf City at the time of the accident and rushed to its aid. The USS Dewey, a missile destroyer, was also in the vicinity and joined the rescue operation, along with United Arab Emirates vessels, he said. The shipping sources said the Simpson, one of about 10 U.S. Navy ships in the gulf, was escorting the Surf City at the time of the accident. The Navy said direct escorts of Kuwaiti tankers by American warships stopped after the cease-fire and that U.S. warships now monitor American-flagged ships in the gulf from a distance. Kuwait put 11 of its tankers under the U.S. flag in 1987 to receive U.S. Navy protection from Iran, which was concentrating attacks on Kuwaiti-flagged vessels in retaliation for Kuwaiti aid to Iraq. Kuwait last year reached agreement with the United States to revert six of the 11 tankers to Kuwaiti registry. Surf City was one of the five remaining U.S.-flagged tankers expected to revert to the Kuwaiti flag this month. U.S. maritime law requires that all crew members of U.S. flagged ships be U.S. citizens, but an exception was made at the time of the reflagging in 1987. Cohen said all the crew of the Surf City were Americans. He identified another crewmen airlifted to the same Dubai hospital as Earl Washington, a boatswain. No other details on the injured were immediately available. The Central Command in Florida, which oversees the Navy force in the gulf, said it was told at least one of the ship's crewmen was ``British-Canadian.''

DOC.HEAD: Prince of Wales to Meet Young Christopher Wren
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Changes tenses in top two grafs and SUBS pvs 7th graf, On the prince's, with 2 new grafs to update with White House lunch
DOC.TEXT: For Prince Charles, today promised just another round of royal duties _ speechmaking, receptions, lunch with President Bush and a black-tie dinner. But it may be the most exciting day in 10-year-old Christopher Wren's life. Christopher and his mother, Sherry, of Chevy Chase, Md., were to shake hands this afternoon with the 41-year-old heir to the British throne at the American Institute of Architects, where Charles is opening an exhibit about the schoolboy's namesake, Sir Christopher Wren. The exhibit contains 120 original drawings, models, paintings, manuscripts and artifacts from Wren's design and construction of historic St. Paul's Cathedral in London, where Charles married his wife, Diana, in 1981. When young Christopher learned about the famed 17th century English architect a few years ago, his parents say, he decided to become an architect himself. The boy was invited to the AIA ceremony to meet Charles, an outspoken critic of modern architecture and an admirer of Wren's classical designs. It was unknown whether the boy is a descendant of the St. Paul's architect. Charles, who is on a weeklong visit to the United States, flew to Washington from Charleston, S.C., where he urged 100 corporate executives to look beyond short-term profits in making decisions that might affect the environment. The prince, who last visited Washington a year ago, had lunch in the White House family quarters today with Bush and his top aides, including Secretary of State James A. Baker III, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Vice President Dan Quayle. Afterward, Charles returned to the British Embassy in chill, drizzly weather while Bush presented the AIA's Gold Medal _ its highest honor _ to architect Fay Jones of Fayetteville, Ark., a former pupil of Frank Lloyd Wright. Charles and Jones will be honored guests tonight at one of the hottest attractions in town _ a black-tie, $250-a-plate AIA dinner at the National Building Museum. The 1,200 dinner seats sold out a month ago, and there are 800 people in the waiting line for tickets. The American architects lucky enough to get into the dinner _ along with members of Congress, diplomats and Hollywood celebrities _ were eagerly awaiting the prince's speech for any rhetorical fireworks it might contain. In the past, Charles has accused contemporary architects of designing ``Frankenstein monsters'' and said the London skyline has suffered more damage from architects, city planners and developers than from German bombers in World War II. Before dinner, Charles planned to attend a British Embassy reception for alumni of the Marshall Scholars program, under which the British government pays all costs for exceptional American students to study in British universities for two or three years. The prince, who began his U.S. visit by playing in two charity polo matches last weekend in Florida, will return to Britain on Friday after meeting with U.S. environmental experts at the embassy.

DOC.HEAD: King Followers Support Mandela But Are Uneasy About `Armed' Stance
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights veterans who for decades have carried the Rev. Martin Luther King's banner of non-violence are uneasy over Nelson Mandela's refusal to renounce violence but are reluctant to criticize the South African. For colleagues and followers of King, the release of Mandela this month after 27 years in prison has posed something of a moral dilemma. As longtime opponents of apartheid, they are joyful over Mandela's freedom. But the refusal by Mandela and the African National Congress to rule out the use of arms is at odds with the non-violent philosophy espoused by King. Followers of King, however, say they believe the slain civil rights leader, if alive today, would not condemn Mandela for his position. ``We still subscribe to non-violence. But we don't believe we have a right to dictate to other people how to achieve their liberation,'' said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the King-founded Southern Christian Leadership Conference. ``While I personally choose other tactics, I grant them the right to choose how to get the heels off of their necks.'' David J. Garrow, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer of King, said Thursday that supporting Mandela is less of a problem for King's followers than it would have been for King himself. ``There's no getting around the fact that King's belief in non-violence was so total and central that he could not have endorsed the tactical position of the ANC,'' said Garrow, an associate professor of political science at City College of New York. ``But I think the totality of King's commitment to non-violence was relatively unusual, even within the Southern Christian Leadership Conference,'' he said. ``I don't necessarily think there's any contradiction or alteration involved for a lot of people to say they happily endorse Mandela and the ANC.'' Those who worked closely with King said they would prefer using the principles of non-violence preached by King to overcome apartheid. But they said they can understand, because of the violence suffered by blacks in South Africa, why Mandela feels he cannot rule out violence in self-defense. ``We had this argument in the early stages of the civil rights movement,'' said King's widow, Coretta Scott King. ``We worked with people who told Martin, `If they hit me, I'll hit back.''' ``He told them, if they were going to join (the movement), they'd have to be non-violent,'' Mrs. King said in an interview last week. ``Many people in the marches were not non-violent but became non-violent as time went on.'' Mrs. King said her husband didn't condemn those who disagreed with him but tried through his own actions to demonstrate the effectiveness of non-violence. Lowery said King unequivocally opposed violence but still was supportive of the African National Congress before his assassination in 1968. The association's violence ``posed him a moral problem and a theological problem,'' Lowery said, ``but I don't know that he ever condemned the ANC.'' King frequently spoke out against South Africa's racial segregation. He advocated worldwide economic sanctions against South Africa to destroy apartheid. In a 1964 speech on South Africa, however, King said, ``We can understand how in that situation people felt so desperate that they turned to other methods, such as sabotage.'' Lowery stressed that Mandela has endorsed only defensive violence, not aggressive force. The Rev. Hosea Williams, a former Atlanta city councilman who was King's ``field general'' in the peak days of the civil rights movement, said he disagrees with the use of violence in South Africa but would not withdraw his support for the anti-apartheid effort. ``Mandela is advocating protective violence, which is much different from Dr. King's total non-violence advocacy,'' Williams said. ``We never found anything more effective than non-violence.'' Williams said the refusal of blacks to resort to violence, even after the beatings suffered by demonstrators in Alabama in 1965, drew sympathy from the public and provided support to force federal civil rights legislation. The use of violence by the ANC, Williams suggested, could jeopardize such popular support for the anti-apartheid movement. ``I'd plead with Mr. Mandela to give up on any sort of violence and resort totally to non-violence. But I certainly could not withdraw my support for the black struggle in South Africa,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: McAuliffe Family Criticizes Movie on Challenger Disaster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Among the ..., to CORRECT spelling of MacKay, McAuliffe.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: A TV movie about the Challenger disaster has upset and offended those closest to Christa McAuliffe, the New Hampshire schoolteacher who died in the shuttle explosion. Among the critics are McAuliffe's mother, Grace Corrigan, and Concord Mayor James MacKay, who said the film reduced him to tears. Mrs. Corrigan and McKay said the movie failed to capture McAuliffe's personality. Mrs. Corrigan, of Framingham, Mass., said at first it was difficult to watch a screening of ``Challenger,'' which will air Sunday on ABC. ``It started to upset me, then I said, `No, I'm not going to let it because it is only a video,''' she said in a telephone interview this week. Mrs. Corrigan, whose husband, Edward, died this year and was buried four years to the day after the Jan. 28, 1986, Challenger explosion, said actress Karen Allen failed in her attempt to portray McAuliffe. ``I didn't feel it was Christa, but I didn't think it would be,'' she said. MacKay complained that the movie invaded the McAuliffe family's privacy, and also said Allen's portrayal of the former teacher ``in no way caught the depth'' of McAuliffe's personality. MacKay said the film conjured up painful images of the ill-fated, 73-second flight and was difficult for him to watch. ``The whole thing was very emotional to me,'' MacKay said. ``I started to cry at several points.'' McAuliffe, a Concord High School social studies teacher who was the first private citizen chosen to fly in space, died with six other crew members. Bob Hohler, a reporter for The Boston Globe and author of ``I Touch the Future: The Story of Christa McAuliffe,'' said he thought the movie was ``pretty bad.'' ``It just was a pretty powerful moment in history reduced to a dull docudrama. It's real superficial,'' Hohler said. ``It cheapens history when it becomes so superficial.'' Writer-producer George Englund said he knew there would be mixed reactions to the film but defended it as ``sensitive in almost every aspect.'' NASA officials said the agency has taken no formal position on the movie, but two spokesmen said they believe sentiment at NASA uns against the film. ``It's the sort of thing that basically we think is probably too soon to be done,'' said Hugh Harris, deputy director of public affairs at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla. ``If I were guessing, people who were not involved at NASA will find it a very touching film, but there will be some people at NASA who feel it cuts close to the bone,'' said Bill Sheehan, NASA associate administrator for communication in Washington. Englund said any movie about the disaster was bound to cause debate. ``I can understand why some people would think it's too soon,'' he said. ``But ... I don't know if there ever would have been a consensus about the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Presense Prevents Pro-Democracy Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Scores of riot police, some carrying revolvers, stood guard outside a hospital Thursday to prevent a rally in memory of people killed in a fledgling pro-democracy movement. The government said 12 people have been killed since Sunday. Government spokesman Radhey Shyam Bista said the latest victim died of injures sutained Tuesday when police fired on rioters in Jadukuha, 100 miles southeast of Katmandu. Opposition sources say the official death toll is far too low and that nearly twice that many people have died since the Nepali Congress Party and a left-wing coalition began agitating to end the 29-year-old ban on political parties. Most victims have been killed by police gunfire, and some of the injured, estimated at more than 50, have been brought to Bir Hospital in the capital, Katmandu. Policemen carrying batons, and some with revolvers, blocked traffic around the hospital Thursday and asked pedestrians to leave the area, forcing organizers to cancel the memorial rally. ``We couldn't hold our program because of the police,'' said a member of the left-wing coalition contacted by telephone. But four small street-corner meetings were held near the hospital, said the activist, who spoke from an undisclosed location and refused to be identified. Police said they had no information on any meetings being held. The government of King Birendra says the campaign to lift the ban on political parties runs counter to a 1980 referendum in which voters narrowly rejected a return to a multiparty system. Nepal's two-year experiment with a Western-style democracy ended in 1961, when King Mahendra, the present monarch's father, dissolved the government of the Nepali Congress Party, accusing it of corruption and poor administration. The government accuses the opposition parties of trying to impose their version of democracy on a nation that they say already has a working democracy.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Jaime Escalante, the inspiring inner-city math teacher whose story was told in the 1988 movie ``Stand and Deliver,'' is threatening to quit. He cited a spate of letters from parents saying their children wanted to drop his advanced mathematics classes, sometimes in favor of sports. The Bolivian-born teacher said Wednesday such requests ``hurt me more than anything else'' and that parents ``don't see education as the way to succeed in this country.''
