Escalante, who gained national attention for success in teaching college-level calculus to Hispanic youths, said he also has problems with jealous colleagues, anonymous threats and a lack of school district support. Superintendent Leonard Britton said he had ordered an inquiry. Escalante, 59, said he may leave Garfield High School as early as June and seek a teaching job in San Diego, Ventura or San Francisco. Escalante, an engineer before switching to teaching, also said he may return to computer design.

Dolly Parton and Kenny Rogers say they are putting their individual careers on hold to team up for a concert tour. Rogers has played Las Vegas for 25 years, Ms. Parton for 12, but a concert Thursday night was to be their first together at a Strip resort hotel. It also was billed as the opening of a 70-city tour, although the two singers tuned up for it by playing three engagements in Canada and one in Denver. At a news conference Wednesday, the pair was asked how the Canadian pre-opening went. ``They threw us out of the country, so we walked home,'' Ms. Parton said, laughing.

Israel on Thursday awarded Ioanna Tsatsou, the widow of a former Greek president, the title Righteous of Nations for helping save the lives of Jews during the Nazi occupation of Greece. An Israeli diplomatic representative in Athens presented the award to Mrs. Tsatsou, an author and sister of Nobel laureate George Seferis. Of the 65,000 Greek Jews, only 6,500 survived the Holocaust, mostly through the efforts of Greek Christians who hid them. Mrs. Tsatsou's husband, Constantine Tsatsos, was the first president following the end of Greece's monarchy. He held the mostly ceremonial post from 1975-80 and died in 1987.

Miss America Debbye Turner says fame has its drawbacks, but wearing a crown to fund-raisers, auto shows, pep rallies and mall appearances generally has been a lot of fun. ``It was kind of fun that people would recognize me,'' she told a crowd of about 400 Wednesday at Southwest Missouri State University. ``I'd walk in a hotel lobby or down the street and people would recognize my face and stop me. I couldn't get used to it.'' The marimba-playing former Miss Missouri says she also has met President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, Bill Cosby, her idol Lionel Hampton, Bruce Willis and Janet Jackson, to name just a few. The disadvantages are a loss of privacy and the need to live out of a suitcase, she said. Once an airport porter tapped one of her traveling companions on the shoulder. ``He said, `Excuse me ma'am, was that Miss America who just went out the door?'' Miss Turner recalled. ``She said `Yes, how did you know?' ``Because she was here a couple of weeks ago and she had those same shoes on,'' the skycap replied. Miss Turner plans to go back to college after her reign ends and become a veterinarian. She said, ``Then I will no longer be Miss America, I will be Dr. America.''

An invitation by David Letterman for governors to send in half-minute videotapes about their states hasn't stirred much excitement in Texas. Gov. Bill Clements says he has never seen NBC's ``Late Night with David Letterman'' or its host. ``I haven't and don't intend to,'' Clements said, adding that he is usually in bed an hour before the show comes on. On Wednesday, Clements said, ``Why not?'' when asked if he would be interested in sending a tape for Letterman's series of ``Gubernatorial Minutes.'' But on Thursday, Rossanna Salazar, the governor's press secretary, said Clements probably would not send in a tape because of his tight schedule and the potential for biting remarks from comedian Letterman. A Letterman staff member told the Houston Post there is no intention of holding governors or states up to ridicule in exchange for the free air time.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Accepts ANC Proposal on Talks
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk on Thursday accepted a proposal by the African National Congress to send a delegation for the first formal talks between the white government and its foremost adversary. The ANC's commitment to dialogue ``is a positive step,'' reflecting a desire to ``search for solutions through peaceful means,'' said de Klerk, who lifted a 30-year ban on the guerrilla movement three weeks ago. De Klerk also made his first public statement on a controversy involving Defense Minister Magnus Malan, who has been linked in press reports to a secret military unit that allegedly assassinated anti-apartheid activists. The president, interviewed by the state-run TV network, said the allegations would be thoroughly investigated by a judicial commission, criticized the press for conducting a ``trial by media,'' and praised the role of the security forces in saving South Africa from ``anarchy and chaos.'' Opposition political leaders demanded Malan's resignation and urged de Klerk to ensure that no cover-up takes place. Malan, in statements this week, denied having ordered assassinations, but did not rule out the possibility the unit may have committed such acts. He pledged the military would not interfere with any investigations. The Star newspaper of Johannesburg quoted sources as saying Malan had been aware of the unit at least since 1987. Police investigators have said in court papers that members of the unit, called the Civil Cooperation Bureau, are suspected of involvement in the assassinations last year of David Webster, a Johannesburg human rights activist, and Anton Lubowksi, a civil rights lawyer and pro-independence activist in Namibia. De Klerk last month ordered a judicial inquiry into charges that military and police squads murdered government opponents. The commission is expected to investigate the unsolved killings of at least 60 activists in the past decade. Three former policemen have confessed to serving on death squads. Several active police officers are under investigation. The activists allegedly killed by the death squads include members and supporters of the ANC. Although it was legalized Feb. 2 as part of de Klerk's peace initiative, the ANC says its guerrilla campaign remains one of its tactics in trying to pressure the government to end white-minority domination. On Feb. 16, the ANC said from its headquarters in Zambia that it would send a delegation to South Africa to confer with de Klerk about obstacles in the way of negotiations on a new constitution. The ANC says the state of emergency must be lifted and all political prisoners freed before such talks can start. Its office in London released a list Thursday of more than 750 prisoners it said should be freed. No date for the preliminary meeting has been set. De Klerk said the government would first have to address ``legal uncertainties'' regarding exiled ANC leaders who might be liable for prosecution in South Africa. Earlier Thursday, the government said de Klerk had postponed a meeting scheduled for Saturday in Zaire with leaders of some black African nations. The ANC had urged a boycott of the meeting, saying de Klerk's reforms had not gone far enough. While welcoming the ANC's decision to pursue talks, de Klerk said it was ``disappointing that the ANC leadership continues to talk about an armed struggle and hostilities at a time when most South Africans, supported by the rest of the world, want peace.'' The government ``is committed to a new dispensation which offers peace and justice for all,'' de Klerk said. ``An armed struggle and hostilities do no fit into this pattern.'' Recently freed ANC leader Nelson Mandela helped launch the guerrilla campaign in 1961, a year after the group was outlawed. The bombing and sabotage campaign has been ineffectual in the past year and poses little threat to the government. In the port city of Durban, leaders of the ANC and a more conservative rival movement, Inkatha, opened their first head-to-head peace talks Thursday, seeking to halt a power struggle that has killed more than 3,000 people. ANC leader Walter Sisulu, arriving for the closed-door talks, said blacks in Natal Province were ``preparing themselves for peace'' after three years of savage factional warfare. Mandela is expected to appeal for reconciliation when he addresses a mass rally in Durban on Sunday. Sisulu, one of Mandela's closest associates, joined an ANC delegation that met black community leaders from around Pietermaritzburg, one of the worst-hit areas. The group then returned to Durban to meet an Inkatha delegation headed by Oscar Dhlomo, second-in-command under Zulu politician Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Both groups depict themselves as foes of apartheid, but Inkatha rejects the ANC's use of violence and opposes confrontational protest tactics. The ANC favors a socialist-oriented economy, while Inkatha favors free enterprise.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Answers, But Doesn't Always Remember
With AM-Reagan-Poindexter Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The familiar figure of Ronald Reagan flickered across television screens in a pair of federal courtrooms Thursday before one of his smallest audiences ever. Several dozen reporters _ enough to pack one courtroom at one point _ watched and listened, took notes, drifted in and out. The occasion was the first showing of the former president's videotaped testimony, taken last weekend and intended for use in the Iran-Contra trial of his one-time national security adviser, John Poindexter. Reagan testified about Iran and about the Nicaraguan Contras, about former aides Poindexter and Oliver North, about weapons and about hostages. But, perhaps most strikingly, he testified over and over during eight hours of questioning about how much he didn't remember. ``I don't recall that,'' Reagan responded when asked about the Tower investigative commission's report that North and the National Security Council were involved in aiding the Nicaraguan rebels. When lawyers read him that part of the commission report, Reagan continued to deny recollection, saying his interest had been in other findings. He was asked about American contacts with Iranian dissidents who he had hoped were in a position to form a government to succeed the Ayatollah Khomeini. ``I can't recall the dates,'' he said. When he was hospitalized for cancer, did government officials come to Bethesda Naval Hospital to inform him of negotiations? ``I recall I had visits at the hospital. I have to tell you, I can't recall just what they were all about,'' he responded. Looking relaxed, Reagan allowed an occasional smile to cross his lips, and chuckled once when lawyers began arguing about a question. Another time he thanked the judge for interceding during questions about his having quoted Abraham Lincoln. Through a smile, Reagan remarked that such questions just increase the jokes about his age. But again and again _ indeed 10 times in one 30-minute stretch _ Reagan said he didn't recall events. Was he ever told that it would be better to have Israel handle the delivery of missiles to Iran? ``No, I don't recall that.'' Did he recall being told that private individuals were involved? ``No, I don't.'' Did he know the details of providing spare parts for Hawk missiles for Iran? ``I just don't recall.'' Had he ever discussed with Poindexter what to say if the story came out? ``I don't recall, I don't recall that.'' Did he meet with Poindexter between two news conferences in November 1986. ``I don't recall.'' When he met with congressional leaders, was Poindexter present? ``I don't recall.'' Did he remember when he was informed of the Hawk missile shipment. ``I actually don't. I don't recall when I was told or who told me.'' Was that information given to him in Geneva, when he was preparing for a meeting with Soviet President Gorbachev? ``I don't have a clear recollection of what was discussed. There were so many meetings in so many different places.'' In the courtroom of Judge Harold Greene, hours of taped testimony ground on, starting before a packed house that eventually dwindled to a handful. Across the hall a couple dozen reporters drifted in an out of Judge Louis Oberdorfer's courtroom, where they were allowed to see excerpts they had requested.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Keeps Talking on Resolution Bitterly Fought by Turkey
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files; subs 3rd graf to recast that vote was to end filibuster
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today rejected an attempt to cut off debate on a proposed resolution to commemorate an ``Armenian genocide,'' a move that signals trouble for supporters of the measure. The resolution, which has infuriated Turkey and caused bitter divisions among Republican lawmakers, is sponsored by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. It would designate April 24 as a ``national day of remembrance'' of the ``Armenian genocide of 1915-1923.'' By a 49-49 vote, the Senate refused to break a filibuster against Dole's resolution. Dole needed 60 votes to end the debate. Over three days, opponents of the measure led by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., had filibustered the resolution. Despite Dole's defeat, the measure is not dead. In fact, Dole said he would ask for another cloture vote to be held next week. Two Republicans took opposite positions on the resolution debate today. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., said there is ``strong evidence'' that Armenians were the victims of a genocide 75 years ago. ``Civilians were sought out and massacred because they were Armenians,'' he said. He said he supports the resolution because the United States should always stand firm against human rights abuses. However, Sen. John Warner, R-Va., the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the historical facts are not completely known. Moreover, he said the United States should not fans instability in Central Europe at a time of great change there. The alleged massacre of 1{ million Armenians occurred in the Ottoman Empire before the establishment of the Republic of Turkey. Turks contend that at most 600,000 Armenians died and that they died of disease, famine or attacks by marauding bands during World War I. Sen. John Warner, Rr Nuzhet Kandemir, the Turkish ambassador to the United States, said in a letter to senators that the ``resolution would constitute an unwarranted and deeply offensive insult'' to his government. ``No more serious charges can be levied against a nation,'' he said. After two days of debate on the measure, the Senate scheduled the cloture vote on whether to cut off discussion. Sixty senators must vote to invoke cloture. A vote to end the debate would clear the way for a yes-or-no vote on the resolution. Key Democrats have joined the Bush administration in opposing the Dole resolution, primarily on grounds that it could jeopardize U.S.-Turkey relations. Turkey, a NATO ally, is home to U.S. military bases. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., is the leading opponent of the measure and was joined by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., Wednesday in speaking against the measure. Although Armenians suffered in the past, it would be pointless to create new problems with the resolution, said Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. The Senate risks making a decision that could ``weaken the Southern flank of NATO,'' he said. The resolution may seen ``remote and academic,'' but it is a live issue in Turkey, said Nunn. Turkey's lobbyists have said that country's government might retaliate against the United States with drastic steps, possibly even refusing to renegotiate rights for military bases. Several of Nunn's colleagues on the panel joined him in opposing the measure, including Sens. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., and James Exon, D-Neb. Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, also condemned the measure. Dole has broken with the administration on the resolution, although President Bush said during the 1988 presidential campaign that he would be inclined to remember the dead Armenians in a resolution. But Secretary of State James A. Baker III said earlier this month, ``It has been the position of prior administrations to oppose those resolutions and let history be the judge of that unfortunate episode.'' Dole and White House officials tried earlier to reach a compromise on the language in the measure, but had little success. Dole has said, however, he might offer substitute language in the form of amendments.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Premier Supports Separate EC Pacts in East Europe
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Charles Haughey said Thursday he would not support European Community membership soon for the emerging East bloc democracies but foresaw individual agreements with the former Communist states. Haughey, current president of the EC, said signals that the United States wanted to establish new ties with the 12-nation trade bloc reflected its emergence as ``very near to superpower rank'' politically and economically and as an ``anchor of stability'' in a rapidly changing Europe. He said the community would make separate association agreements with the Eastern European nations, with the exception of East Germany as part of a united Germany. ``The agreement with each country would be a semi-permanent thing,'' he said. ``It would not be something seen as a step toward membership. I can't see any major expansion of the community for some time to come, simply on the basis of size.'' Asked if the Bush administration was more interested in the community than in the special relationship with Britain, Haughey said, ``Definitely, quite clearly.'' ``There is a distinct change of emphasis and, more likely, of policy,'' he said. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III have ``clearly signaled ... that the United States now wishes to look to the community for a full, meaningful and across-the-board relationship,'' he said. During a two-day visit to Washington next week, Haughey will discuss with Bush and Baker how to set up closer U.S.-EC links. Bush has urged the community, which is to become a single barrier-free market in 1992, to accelerate moves toward monetary union and closer political ties. Baker, in a speech in Berlin in December, said Washington was seeking a closer, more formally structured relationship. Haughey said an EC-U.S. treaty would take too long to organize. The West European countries have suggested as a preparatory move regular meetings between Baker and the EC foreign ministers. Haughey's remarks appeared likely to underline what many commentators and British opposition parties see as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's increasing isolation and dwindling influence internationally. Key factors are the prospect of a powerful, united Germany, the apparent waning of the U.S.-British relationship since President Ronald Reagan left office and Britain's often isolated position in the community over issues such as the pace of European union and monetary integration. Mrs. Thatcher also is widely regarded as having come grudgingly to accept rapid German unification. Her government denies this attitude. In the latest confrontation, Britain on Tuesday defied an EC decision not to ease sanctions against South Africa in response to the white-run government's reforms and decided to drop the non-binding ban unilaterally. Irish newspapers reported prominently Thursday that U.S. administration officials denied a claim by Britain that Bush supports Mrs. Thatcher's policy. Ireland, whose bilaterial relations with Britain are colored by the troubled history of British-run Northern Ireland, accused the Thatcher administration of setting a ``dangerous precedent.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Official: Skipper Took Blame For Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Hazelwood told...'. DELETES 8th graf pvs, `The 43-year-old...', now redundant.
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard investigator said today he cannot explain why the Exxon Valdez disappeared from radar and then reappeared after is had run aground on Bligh Reef. Lt. Cmdr. Thomas Falkenstein confirmed that the Coast Guard had responsibility for monitoring the tanker during its transit into Prince William Sound, but also confirmed that the ship was not visible on radar some time before its disastrous accident. Coast Guard monitors have testified that the ship was visible on the radar after its skipper, Joseph Hazelwood, radioed that it was aground. ``If you are asking why it was off radar, and secondarily was on radar ... I don't know,'' Falkenstein said under questioning by Hazelwood attorney Michael Chalos. The 43-year-old Hazelwood, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony; and three misdemeanors _ reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The officer, who was one of the first on board the ship after it ran aground, said he smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath and immediatetly sent word to shore that someone should be sent to test the captain's blood alcohol level. He also testified that federal regulations followed by the Coast Guard required that a vessel going through the Valdez Narrows into Prince William Sound must be ``under the direction and control'' of an officer who has been certified as specially trained for that area. Hazelwood was the only officer on board with such a certification when the accident occurred, and he was not on the ship's bridge. In testimony Wednesday, an Exxon official said that Hazelwood indicated the disaster was his fault and he was to blame for the nation's worst oil spill. Paul Myers of Danville, Calif., told jurors Hazelwood appeared to be taking responsiblity as captain of the ship. But he was prevented from answering a question about whether Hazelwood also was accepting criminal blame. Hazelwood told him the ship, pride of the Exxon fleet, was damaged but safe and said there was oil in the waters of Prince William Sound, Myers recalled. ``He indicated this had happened and it was his fault. He was to blame,'' Myers said. ``He had just gone down to do some paperwork when this happened and he should have been on the bridge.'' The tanker leaked nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into Prince William Sound. The disaster killed countless birds, fish and wildlife and blackened hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Nearly a year later, it still is being cleaned up. Exxon officials announced Wednesday that the company will resume its cleanup of the remaining oil May 1. Exxon suspended its cleanup in September because of the onset of severe winter weather, but had declined to set a date for further work. The company found serious problems along about 10 of the 90 miles of shoreline its crews surveyed, said Hann Jahns, an Exxon scientist. Earlier in the trial, Hazelwood was quoted as telling a Coast Guard investigator who asked what the ship's problem was: ``I think you're looking at it.'' A witness said the anguished skipper was referring to himself. Another Exxon tanker captain on Wednesday told jurors for the first time that the giant oil company is concerned about the outcome of Hazelwood's trial. Michael Stalzer said Exxon has paid for his lawyer and for legal representation of all crew members who are testifying in the trial. ``I believe Exxon does have an interest in the outcome of this case,'' he said. Exxon is the defendant in more than 150 civil lawsuits resulting from the oil spill. But Hazelwood is the only defendant charged criminally. Stalzer, who preceded Hazelwood as commander of the Exxon Valdez and replaced him after the accident, indicated that Hazelood violated several sections of a company operating manual in his command of the ill-fated ship. Stalzer said he would not have left the ship's bridge during a potentially hazardous passage around ice in Prince William Sound. Hazelwood left the ship in control of the third mate 10 minutes before it grounded. But he said none of the violations was against the law, and that the Exxon ``bridge manual'' was merely a guideline and statement of company policies on how to run a tanker. The prosecution seeks to prove that Hazelwood's actions were reckless and endangered the property and lives of others. Stalzer described the Exxon Valdez as the newest and probably most technically advanced of the tankers in Exxon's approximately 30-ship fleet. Starting May 1, Exxon will resume its cleanup of oil remaining in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska from the nation's largest oil spill, company officials said Wednesday. Exxon suspended its cleanup in September because of the onset of severe winter weather, but had declined to set a date for further work.

DOC.HEAD: Thirty Workers Hit By Mystery Illness at New York Bridge
DOC.TEXT: Thirty toll-takers at the Triborough Bridge have been hit with a mysterious illness during the past week, prompting authorities to study everything from the air they breathe to the coffee they drink. Three workers on Thursday became the latest victims of the ailment, complaining of sore throats, headaches or dizziness. Other symptoms that have afflicted workers since the outbreak began Feb. 16 include vomiting, watery eyes and fainting. One worker required mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. Carbon monoxide poisoning was ruled out on Wednesday. On Thursday, test results showed that tap and bottled water were not the problem, officials said. ``At this point it's still a mystery and we'll just stay with it. We'll look at everything under the sun until we can get to the bottom of this,'' said Tina Casey, a spokeswoman for the city Department of Environmental Protection. The Y-shaped bridge spans the East River and connects the New York City boroughs of Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx. It is used by 160,000 vehicles a day. Barbara Richardson, a spokeswoman for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, said Thursday's illnesses marked the first time the symptoms had struck someone at the Bronx toll plaza; all other victims had been at the Manhattan plaza. It alsowas the first time the incidents occurred in the morning; the others were in the evening or afternoon, Richardson said. A year ago February, two officers were hit by a similar outbreak at the Bronx toll plaza. On Wednesday, devices were installed in each of the self-service lanes to help detect any airborne contaminants. ``In addition to using the air-monitoring equipment, we've also stationed our hazardous material people during rush hour to see if we can ever sense anything with our five senses,'' Casey said. ``You might need a sixth sense to solve it.'' Boilers, incinerators, emissions, eating habits, coffee purchased en route to work, bacteria levels and drycleaning of uniforms are being studied. Also, Casey said, pesticides and paint stored on Randalls Island, where the toll plazas converge, are being investigated, along with a Parks Department garage there. A sewage treatment plant on adjoining Wards Island has been checked. ``So we haven't exhausted all the angles but we have definitely begun looking beyond the obvious ... no matter how illogical or obscure,'' Casey said.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Panel Calls For End to State Monopoly
DOC.TEXT: A commission studying reform of Poland's radio and television recommends abolishing the state broadcasting monopoly and abolishing the committee that runs it, the official news agency PAP reported Thursday. The committee, set up by Radio and Television Committee head Andrzej Drawicz after his appointment by Poland's new Solidarity-led government, spent fur months studying ways to reshape the country's two state-run TV channels and four radio programs. The government-controlled broadcast media were used as an anti-opposition tool of the former Communist government, and the reforms to assure their independence was one of the most urgent items on the public agenda after Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki became the first non-Communist to lead an East bloc government last fall. ``The place of our radio and television institution in Poland's new socio-political system necessitates the adoption a new law on the radio and TV broadcasting system,'' the committee said. The new law, to be drafted by parliament, should dissolve the Radio and Television Committee and replace it with a national council, the panel siad. One proposal under consideration would establish a nine-member supervisory board made up of four people recommended by parliament, four put forth by the prime minister and one nominated by the employee council. The commission also advocated abolishing the monopoly on preparing and distributing radio and TV broadcasts, and allowing limited commercialization of the stations, PAP said. There has been a proposal to make the second TV channel commercial, and to sell a portion of the air time to private producers. Last week, the pro-Solidarity newspaper reported that 40 of the 124 TV managers and all the regional TV center directors had been replaced by Drawicz, and that all TV correspondents posted to socialist countries had been recalled.

DOC.HEAD: Mailman Pleads No Contest in Dog's Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A mailman faces up to a year in jail for shooting a dog to death as its owner was about to hand the letter carrier a Christmas bottle of vodka. Floyd B. Sterling, 34, pleaded no contest Wednesday to animal cruelty. The postman told police he fired in self-defense at Skippy, a German shepherd mix he maintains bit him earlier. Sterling accepted a plea bargain in which prosecutors dropped charges of carrying a concealed weapon and using a firearm in a grossly negligent manner. ``Our office felt the crux of the matter was felony cruelty to animals,'' said Deputy District Attorney David R. Lopez. ``It's a good disposition.'' Sterling could have received three years in prison if convicted on all counts. He now faces up to a year in jail and a $20,000 fine at sentencing March 29. Sterling was arrested Dec. 26 after he shot Skippy just as dog's owner, Tammie Brody, emerged from her house with his Christmas present. Brody testified that Sterling ``freaked out'' and fired a .22-caliber revolver at the dog. She maintained her dog did not menace the mailman. She was pleased with the outcome, saying, ``I just wanted justice done, not blood.'' Skippy was buried Jan. 3 at a pet cemetery in an elaborate ceremony that included a tombstone and silk-lined casket. The Postal Service paid the more than $600 cost.

DOC.HEAD: Security Tightened at Norton Air Force Base After `Terrorist Threat'
DOC.TEXT: Security was tightened at this Air Force cargo and transportation base today after authorities said they ``identified a terrorist threat'' against it. The increased security included more gate checks at the base 60 miles east of Los Angeles and more security patrols, according to statement from Col. Edward J. Sheeran, vice commander of the 63rd Military Airlift Wing. The statement did not identify the type of threat, when it was received or what it said. It said there had been no terrorist action against the base. An FBI spokesman in Los Angeles declined to comment, although Sheeran's statement said the Air Force Office of Special Investigations and the FBI were working on the investigation. Sheeran termed the increased security action as ``prudent.'' Norton Air Force Base was involved in the U.S. invasion of Panama in December, supplying C-141 cargo planes.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Mark Anniversary of 1986 Revolt Installing Aquino
Laserphoto MLA3
DOC.TEXT: Leftist groups and rebel soldiers Thursday marked the fourth anniversary of the revolt that brought Corazon Aquino to power by demanding her ouster and calling her a U.S. puppet who betrayed the rebellion. About 10,000 workers, students and slum dwellers rallied in central Manila and demanded the removal of six U.S. military bases in the Philippines. Riot police, a barbed wire barricade and fire trucks blocked about 1,000 protesters who tried to march on the presidential palace. They dispersed after a brief rally. The Revolutionary Alliance for the Masses-Soldiers of the Filipino People, a rebel military group, said it decried ``the treachery of this government and how readily it has surrendered our sovereignty to foreign powers.'' The group spearheaded a December coup attempt against Mrs. Aquino. The protest marked the anniversary of the Feb. 22-25, 1986, civilian-backed military revolt that drove President Ferdinand Marcos into exile in Hawaii and installed Mrs. Aquino as president. The government's main anniversary celebration will be held Sunday. Leto Villar, executive vice chairman of the May First Movement labor federation, said Thursday's protest was ``symbolic of a deadlock'' between the workers and the Aquino government. ``We are handing her a notice of strike,'' Villar told the demonstrators. ``Unless she can show that she would fulfill her promises of reforms ... she cannot rely on the support of the progressive forces even if her government faces another coup attempt. ``Under this regime, the people continue to wallow in poverty and Mrs. Aquino continues to be a U.S. puppet because she needs American support,'' said federation spokesman Nick Elman. The crowd chanted, ``Down with the U.S.-Aquino regime!'' and ``Out with the U.S. bases!'' Nathaniel Santiago, chairman of the militant League of Filipino Students, said Mrs. Aquino should not fear losing U.S. support in a future coup attempt, but instead should ``fear a lack of support from her own people.'' He referred to air cover provided by jets from the U.S. Clark Air Base during the first day of the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt that turned the tide against the rebellion. In a statement, the rebel soldiers accused the Aquino government of ``unparalleled corruption and insatiable appetite for revenge.'' The rebels said the Aquino government has allowed foreigners to dominate the economy and political life in the Philippines. The group, whose principal leaders were among those who began the 1986 revolt, said the administration was ``appealing abjectly for foreign intervention to save it from the wrath of a long-suffering populace with legitimate grievance.'' The Communist New People's Army issued a statement ``saluting'' Filipinos for participating in the ``people power'' revolt. ``At the same time, we are hopeful that people power will again be ignited in a revolutionary uprising toward genuine democracy and freedom,'' the statement said. Leftists are as opposed to the military rebels as they are to Aquino. They have accused right-wing officers of plotting the murder of their own leaders. The lease on the six U.S. military bases in the Philippines expires in 1991 and there is growing sentiment in the Philippines against renewing the contract.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Expels Legislator Convicted on U.S. Drug Charges
DOC.TEXT: A legislator has been expelled from Parliament for a drug-trafficking conviction in the United States. The behavior of Alfred James Verdier was ``criminal both under the laws of Liberia and that of the United States of America, and as such was an embarrassment and brought disgrace to the legislature, the government and people of Liberia,'' said a parliamentary committee statement announcing the expulsion Wednesday. Verdier, who was elected to Parliament in 1985, was arrested in New York City in June with 22 pounds of heroin, worth nearly $2 million on the street. He initially told police he knew nothing about the drugs, but at a trial this year admitted to importing them for sale in the United States. The legislator is awaiting sentencing. He faces a minimum sentence of 10 years' imprisonment for first offenders.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Suggests Overall Troops Ceiling in Central Europe
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union suggested Thursday that NATO and the Warsaw Pact limit themselves to 700,000 to 750,000 soldiers each in central Europe, an East German negotiator said. Since the Soviets and United States have agreed to 195,000 each in central Europe and East bloc nations are reducing their armies, the East will have fewer soldiers in the area than the West, said Klaus-Dieter Ernst, chief East German delegate to talks on reducing conventional military forces. Ernst said these factors would result in a maximum of 700,000 soldiers for the seven Warsaw Pact countries against about 1 million for the 16-member North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which he called ``totally unsatisfactory.'' Western sources said NATO now has about 900,000 troops in central Europe. To meet the agreed superpower ceilings, the United States will have to withdraw 60,000 soldiers. The Soviet idea came up at the last meeting before a three-week recess in the talks, which began in March 1989, but it was not presented as a formal proposal. In Washington, U.S. arms officials said they were baffled by the Soviet suggestion, which they said was made without prior consultation with other Warsaw Pact nations. ``We are so confused we cannot be indignant,'' one said, on condition his name not be used. ``They could not even get their Warsaw Pact allies to agree to it, and the Western response was, `This is a non-starter.''' Last week, the Soviet Union and United States announced an agreement to reduce to 195,000 each the number of soldiers stationed in an area covering the two Germanys, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Hungary, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Poland. Another 30,000 U.S. soldiers will be allowed in Britain and southern Europe to compensate for the great distance between the United States and Europe. The agreement, reached at a meeting of NATO and Warsaw Pact foreign ministers last week in Ottawa, Canada, is to be part of a final accord on reducing manpower, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe, which negotiators hope to conclude this year. Ruediger Hartmann, the chief West German delegate, said in his statement to the final session the negotiations ``are now moving at a rate commensurate with the rapidity of political processes in Europe,'' according to a text made available to journalists. Hungary and Czechoslovakia are negotiating for total withdrawal of Soviet troops from their territory. They and Poland have announced reductions in their own armed forces. About 50,000 Soviet military personnel are stationed in Hungary and 75,000 in Czechoslovakia. Ernst said the overall ceiling suggested by the Kremlin would include national armies and Soviet troops stationed on foreign soil. Both sides presented new proposals Thursday aimed at resolving definitions of certain armaments and treaty language on verification. Hartmann presented two working papers for NATO on information exchange and conditions for inspections. Ernst said he presented a Warsaw Pact paper on defining tanks. Definitions of weapons categories has been a major problem in the negotiations and the two sides also disagree on the number of combat aircraft each side should have. ``Lots of work remains to be done here,'' the chief U.S. delegate, R. James Woolsey, told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates St. Louis Native to Top AID Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday announced his selection of James Henry Michel to be assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development for Latin America and the Caribbean. Michel, who has been ambassador to Guatemala since 1987, would succeed Dwight A. Ink if confirmed by the Senate. A native of St. Louis, Michel, 50, is an attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Weather Hampers Attempts to Douse Tire Fire
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters trudged through thick mud Thursday trying to douse the flames on millions of burning tires after bad weather grounded three airplanes that had been used to fight the 11-day-old blaze. The fire outside Hagersville, a southeastern Ontario city about 150 miles east of Detroit, has spewed toxic fumes that forced hundreds of nearby residents to flee their homes. Environment Ministry spokesman John Steele said tests were being conducted to determine if oil runoff from the tires could affect local water supplies. ``We've found oil in the water below the surface but it's being separated and moved into holding ponds,'' Steele said, adding that it did not appear any oil had seeped more than three feet into the ground. ``The main water table that serves people in the the area is much deeper down,'' said Steele. The fire broke out at the Tyre King Recyling dump Feb. 11. The site contained 12 million to 14 million discarded tires. On Wednesday, officials launched an all-out assault on the blaze by deploying three planes usually used to fight forest fires. At the same time, ground crews wearing oxygen masks used bulldozers and backhoes to separate the tires, trying to turn a mountain of them into small stacks that could be attacked and extinguished. The planes flew all day between the dump and nearby Lake Erie, fetching thousands of gallons of water to dump on the flames along with foam. Bad weather Thursday grounded the planes, leaving the ground crew to battle the flames alone. About 40 firefighters worked at a time, on six-hour shifts. ``It's pretty slow going because of all the mud,'' Ralph D'Antonio of the Ontario fire marshal's office said after a morning visit to the Tyre King dump. ``Because of the rain there's not a lot of flames visible, but there is smoke.'' Waste water from the fire has contaminated a local creek and some farmers have been warned not to use the water for their animals. The province is supplying bottled water. Tyre King, Ontario's largest tire dump, was declared an illegal waste site in December 1985 by the government. The Environment Ministry said last week that Ontario taxpayers could end up paying an estimated $1 million to clean up the damage caused by the fire if Straza is unable to pay for it. Some environmental experts have said the fire could burn for months. The hundreds who have been evacuated from a 2{-mile radius will be eligible for compensation, the government has said.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Cracks Down on Violence With More Marked Police Cruisers
DOC.TEXT: Undercover police are driving in marked cars and some are getting into uniform as authorities try to stem the number of killings in this city, where 22 people have been slain since the beginning of the year. ``They don't shoot people in front of marked units. We're hoping the increased visibility will be a deterrent to violent crime. Hopefully that will give them pause, and give the neighborhoods a greater sense of security,'' said Superintendent Paul Evans, who heads the police Bureau of Field Services. As of Wednesday, 22 people had been shot, knifed or beaten to death. In the same time period last year, 14 people were killed. In all, there were 100 homicides in Boston in 1989 and 98 in 1988. All but six of the killings occurred in the neighborhoods of Dorchester, Mattapan and Roxbury, a lower- to middle-class area inhabited by about 150,000 people, police spokesman Jim Jordan said Thursday. This week, plainclothes police patrolled the most troubled sections of the city in 12 additional marked cars. Some undercover officers also donned uniforms before getting behind the wheel. Police would not disclose the total number of cruisers deployed. Evans said the action is a departure for the police. After Police Commissioner Francis Roache took over in 1985, there was an increase in the number of specialty units, plainclothes police and officers patrolling in unmarked cars. Evans credited the use of unmarked cruisers with boosting last year's arrest rate by 20 percent. But he added, ``More arrests does not mean less violence.'' Police believe many of the latest slayings are linked to drugs or gangs. The issue took up most of Wednesday's monthly closed meeting of the Governor's Anticrime Council, The Boston Globe cited participants as saying. State Sen. Paul White, who represents Dorchester, appealed for help from the state. Invoking memories of the tensions during the busing crisis of the 1970s, White suggested having state and metropolitan police assist Boston police. ``Those agencies helped out during busing and I think we've reached a crisis stage here,'' White said after the meeting. Response to the deployment of more marked cars was generally favorable. ``It can't get any worse out there,'' said Sgt. William Broderick, president of the Boston Police Superior Officers Federation and a critic of the administration. The new tactic, he said, ``is worth a shot.'' Georgette Watson, founder of the anti-crime program Drop-A-Dime, said, ``I think that probably will satisfy the community people, to see more uniformed police out on the street.'' Earlier this week, Deputy Police Superintendent William Celester, commenting on the numbers of shootings, said that if gang members could shoot straight, there would be even more slayings. ``Not only are drug dealers killing other drug dealers, but they also are shooting innocent people,'' Celester said. The latest killings included the shooting of a 15-year-old boy in a $5 holdup, the knifing of a 28-year-old man and the shooting of an 18-year-old found dead in a Roxbury home, police said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA is No Match for the Sniffles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `Five fearless ...' to fix spelling of `satellite.'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: The mighty microbe strikes again. Five fearless astronauts and the world's very best spacecraft were poised this week to rocket into orbit with a spy satellite that might be vital to the nation's security. NASA, the powerful technological force that conquered the moon and sent craft soaring toward distant stars, had done everything possible to prepare for the cloak-and-dagger mission. An army of engineers and technicians had given their best and were standing by, awaiting the final countdown. Then the microbe came along. Some ``bug'' so small that even a microscope might not find it had somehow invaded the pristine premises of America's space program and struck down one of the nation's best. Atlantis' commander John O. Creighton, NASA said, had developed a sore throat and congestion. It hurt to swallow and the nose was all stuffy. If he were on television, Creighton would have been the ``before'' portrait in some cold medicine commercial. If he were a 6th grader, Mom would have kept him home. But Creighton is an astronaut about ready to take the controls in a $1 billion spacecraft carrying a half billion-dollar payload. And when an astronaut crewman gets sick, everybody stays at home. The mission was postponed twice and won't go now before Saturday. It's happened before to NASA. In 1969, Apollo 9 was delayed for three days while the three-man crew recovered from the sniffles. A year later, NASA doctors learned that Apollo 13 astronaut Thomas K. Mattingly had been exposed to the measles, another mean little microbe. Mattingly was removed from the flight and back-up pilot John Swigert was put on board. As it turned out, the Apollo 13 crew almost died when an oxygen tank exploded, and Mattingly, safe at home, never developed the measles. NASA may do technological marvels and accomplish feats of wonder in outer space. But it still hasn't conquered the mighty microbe. The agency tries. Astronauts preparing for a mission are isolated for a week before launch. NASA posts warnings about the isolation and takes pains to make sure that anyone but close family wears a mask around the crew members. During the Apollo program, the isolation was even stricter. A NASA doctor caused the cancellation of plans to have President Nixon have dinner with the Apollo 11 astronauts before the launch of that first moon-landing mission. Asked two days later if he had been worried about catching a cold or something from a presidential dinner, Apollo 11 astronaut Mike Collins shook his head. ``I'm sure,'' he said, deadpan, ``that presidential germs are benign.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Predicts Up to 2.3 million East Germans Will Head West
Embargoed For Release 6 p.m. EST _ Time Set by Source
DOC.TEXT: Between 1.8 million and 2.3 million East Germans will resettle in West Germany this decade, a study said Thursday, but it did not specifically address how the rush toward reunification would affect the trend. The number of resettlers will depend in large part on the pace of political and economic reforms in what is now East Germany, according to the respected DIW research institute of West Berlin. While the comprehensive study did not specifically address the most recent steps toward unification, East Germany's economic problems are so enormous that the political joining of the two countries is unlikely to slow the migration. The prospects of massive unemployment in what is now East Germany once free-market reforms take hold and a higher standard of living in the West are likely to keep fueling the exodus. Full integration of the two countries could take several years. Already this year, about 100,000 East Germans reached the West, severely straining local governments' ability to house and provide for them. More than 340,000 East Germans made the same trek last year. They have already contributed to a massive housing shortage in one of Europe's most populous countries, while many West Germans have called for curbs on the influx. Many fear that even an expected unification will do little to halt the westward flow. DIW, officially called the Deutsches Institut fuer Wirtschaftsforschung, confirmed some of those fears. The economics research institute said if ``comprehensive reforms are put into motion quickly'' and there is hope of creating more prosperity, the number of people leaving what is now East Germany will be 1.8 million by the end of the century. DIW said that situation would lead to an average exodus of 230,000 people a year through 1995. DIW also projected a situation in which the East Germans perceive the ``reform process is being delayed.'' In that case, said the study, 2.3 million people from East Germany will resettle in the West in the 1990s. West German businesses already are entering into joint ventures in East Germany, with the agreements calling for massive layoffs to make businesses more efficient. That and other economic pressures are likely to create even further difficulties and drive more people out. Many of those leaving are young, skilled workers whose talents are desperately needed for East Germany's faltering economy. Many other problems are also afflicting East Germany, including crumbling housing and staggering pollution problems. Many of these problems will take years to resolve. East Germans aren't the only ones heading to the riches of West Germany. An estimated 377,000 ethnic Germans from other parts of Eastern Europe arrived last year, and tens of thousands are expected this year. The DIW study said that 1.3 million ethnic Germans would resettle in West Germany by the end of the decade if reforms in the rest of Eastern Europe proceed at a brisk pace. The number would be 1.6 million in the event the changes slow down. West Germany has about 62.4 million people, while the population of East Germany is a little more than 16 million.

DOC.HEAD: Columnist Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Columnist and author Victor Lasky died Thursday of cancer at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 72. Lasky, who began his journalism career as a copy boy at The New York Journal American, covered World War II in Europe for Stars & Stripes, the soldiers' newspaper. After the war, he joined The New York World-Telegram and helped write a Pulitzer-Prize-winning series on Communist infiltration of American institutions. He covered the trial of former State Department official Alger Hiss and co-authored a book about the case, ``Seeds of Treason.'' He wrote several biographies, including ``J.F.K: The Man and the Myth,'' ``Robert F. Kennedy: The Man and the Myth'' and books about Supreme Court Justice Arthur Goldberg, actor George Murphy, Jimmy Carter and Henry Ford II. In 1952, a documentary he wrote for MGM, ``The Hoaxters,'' was nominated for an Academy Award. Lasky, who was born in Liberty, N.Y., was graduated from Brooklyn College in 1940. In his later years, he was critical of journalistic misconduct and wrote for Accuracy in Media, a watchdog organization. He is survived by his wife, Patricia, of Washington and two sisters.

DOC.HEAD: Sportcaster Dick Enberg to Guest-Host `Today'
DOC.TEXT: NBC sportscaster Dick Enberg will be guest host of the ``Today'' show next week, filling in from Tuesday through Friday for vacationing Bryant Gumbel. NBC's announcement Thursday came on a day of more bad Nielsen news for ``Today,'' which for the seventh consecutive week trailed ABC's ``Good Morning America'' in the ratings. An ABC spokeswoman said that has not happened since 1985. According to A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates for last week, ABC's program averaged a 4.5 rating and ``Today'' a 3.6. ``CBS This Morning,'' which is replacing anchorwoman Kathleen Sullivan with Paula Zahn on Monday, remained in third place with a 2.8 average. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Sultan Forgives Chief Minister Who Secretly Married His Daughter
DOC.TEXT: Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah, ruler of Malaysia's Selangor State, on Thursday forgave the state's chief minister for marrying the sultan's daughter without his permission. The sultan last year had said he would never see Chief Minister Muhammad Taib or receive him in audience for secretly marrying his daughter, Tengku Putri Zahariah. At a news conference in his palace, the sultan said he was taking the action in conjunction with his 64st birthday on March 8, at which Muhammad would be allowed to read the ceremonial loyalty speech. The sultan's daughter secretly married Muhammad in 1987, but the sultan learned about it only late last year. The sultan said Muhammad had written to him three times asking for forgiveness and pledging loyalty. He said his daughter had not asked for forgiveness, but out of fatherly love he was forgiving her and reinstating her monthly allowance of $259. The sultan is a constitutional monarch. Political power is vested in the chief minister and an elected state legislature. The sultan also said he was forgiving Housing and Local Government Minister Lee Kim Sai and restoring his title of ``datuk,'' a knighthood, which he had taken away on Oct. 23, 1987. Lee was accused then of fanning anti-Malay feeling.

DOC.HEAD: UMass Chancellor to Fill President's Post
DOC.TEXT: The chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst will assume the additional role of university president after David C. Knapp steps down in March, the school announced Thursday. As president, Joseph Duffey will oversee fiscal operations at the university's three campuses at Amherst, Boston and Worchester. Knapp, 62, announced Thursday that he will leave on March 16 after almost 12 years on the job. At a board of trustees meeting, Duffey, 57, said he was taking the job with some reluctance because the university's financial state will require layoffs. ``Who would look forward to eliminating the jobs of hard-working men and women?'' he asked. Duffey, chancellor for nearly eight years, intends to bring much of the president's operation to the Amherst campus from Boston, the university said. Amherst is the largest campus in the UMass system, which has a total enrollment of about 40,000.

DOC.HEAD: Government Alleges Fraud in Sales of Water Treatment Devices
DOC.TEXT: Six nationwide telemarketing firms, all based in Arlington, Texas, have been charged with fraudulent practices involving the sale of home water treatment products, the government said Thursday. Investigators raided the telephone ``boiler rooms'' of the companies a day earlier, seized their records and obtained temporary court orders freezing their assets and barring them from future misrepresentations, the Federal Trade Commission said. The move was the seventh major enforcement action by the FTC since 1987 against firms that allegedly have preyed upon consumers' fears about the safety of their drinking water by marketing products under false or misleading claims. The Texas operation was coordinated with the Justice Department, the U.S. Postal Inspection Service and the Texas Attorney General's Office, said Barry J. Cutler, director of the FTC's Bureau of Consumer Protection. Cutler said the FTC had filed two civil complaints in U.S. District Court in Fort Worth seeking refunds to the defendants' customers and permanent injunctions against fraudulent practices in the future. One complaint was lodged against five firms, GTP Marketing Inc., Telstar Marketing Network Inc., H.S. Marketing Inc., Unitel Marketing Consultants Inc., and MBC Group Inc., all located at the same Watson Road address in Arlington. Three individuals, Todd Arnold, Stephen Gregg Echols, and Pat Arnold, also were named in that complaint. A reporter's call to those individuals, at the number listed for Unitel, was not immediately returned. Three of the companies were not publicly listed; the telephone listed at the fourth, H.S. Marketing, was not answered. The second complaint was aimed at C & L Industries, Inc., and its two officers, Ramon Haas and T. W. Bodiford. Both were said by a secretary to be out of the office and unavailable for comment on Thursday. ``Ever since water quality emerged as a consumer concern a couple of years ago, fraudulent telemarketers and others have aggressively promoted their products by using scare tactics, blatantly false claims about federal endorsements of their products, and gross exaggerations about their products' ability to cleanse and purify water,'' Cutler said. ``They offer lavish awards and prizes and money-back guarantees. They will say anything to make a sale,'' he said. In the case of C & L, which markets the ``Atlantis Water Purification System,'' the firm told prospective customers several falsehoods, including claims that a bill pending in Congress will require every home to have a water treatment device, and that its product had been endorsed by the government and was used on the U.S. space shuttle, according to the FTC complaint. Cutler said C & L also claimed that ``Unpure water killed more people last year in the United States than cholesterol and nicotine combined,'' and that its device, marketed for $450-$500, could virtually eliminate such contaminants as lead, bacteria, radon gas, acid rain, pesticides, and industrial run-off from up to 15,000 gallons or more of tap water. Not only will the device not do that, he said, but ``you could go to the hardware store and get something like it for less than $100.'' The five other firms were charged with luring in customers by mailing them postcards claiming they had won valuable awards, such as a Cadillac or $5,000 in merchandise checks. In fact, the awards required payment of ``substantial additional sums of money,'' the FTC complaint said, and when consumers called in, the firms falsely claimed they needed their credit-card numbers to verify their ``eligibility'' _ and then debited those accounts without authorization. The complaint charged further that many consumers who did order a product, such as a water treatment unit, never received it. Cutler noted that ``there are many legitimate companies selling useful home water treatment devices, and consumers who do their homework ... can get their money's worth.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Judicial Court Reinstates Injunction on Anti-Abortion Groups
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Darroline cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: The state's highest court Thursday reinstated an order barring demonstrators from blocking abortion clinics, but the group Operation Rescue said it will obey a ``higher law'' and continue to protest. The Supreme Judicial Court ruled 4-1 that the injunction places only minimal limitations on protesters and does not threaten their First Amendment rights. Darroline Firlit, a spokeswoman for Operation Rescue, which has staged several protests at clinics, said her anti-abortion group will continue its activities. ``We have an obligation before God to continue to rescue,'' Firlit said. ``In this case, we are obeying a higher law.'' Dorothy Lohmann of Planned Parenthood of Massachusetts said her organization was pleased with the decision. ``In the future, one of the things we are looking for is to have bigger fines imposed on those who break the injunction,'' she said. Under the ruling, the injunction will remain in place until the outcome of a lawsuit filed by Planned Parenthood and several clinics. They charge that Operation Rescue threatened and intimidated patients and clinic staff members. The high court's ruling reverses a single justice's decision in August to lift an injunction against the protesters. The other justices reversed Justice Joseph Nolan's ruling. Justice Francis O'Connor dissented, arguing that the injunction infringes on free speech rights and that the abortion-rights groups don't represent women claiming direct harm from the protests. Legal challenges to Operation Rescue's tactics around the country have left the organization so far in debt that it announced Jan. 31 that it was closing its national office in Binghamton, N.Y. The group is appealing a $50,000 judgment in a New York lawsuit by the National Organization for Women. However, it won a case in federal court in Los Angeles, where a judge ruled clinic blockades do not violate the rights of all prospective patients.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Testifies No `Inkling' of Arms Help to Contras
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan testified in a videotaped deposition released Thursday he never ``had any inkling'' his aides were secretly arming the Nicaraguan Contras during a congressional ban on military aid. In testimony for the upcoming trial of John Poindexter, the former president also said he remained unconvinced there had been a diversion of Iran arms sale money to the rebels _ until prosecutors confronted him with the report of the Tower Commission he appointed. Reagan said he would have expected Poindexter, his former national security adviser, to inform him of any diversion of funds to the Contras ``unless maybe he thought he was protecting me from something.'' Reagan's testimony was taken in Los Angeles last week and made available in Washington. The former president was jovial and testy by turns during eight hours _ winking at Poindexter as he took the stand and talking amiably with the judge but also answering in abrupt fashion when Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb said he wasn't addressing a question. He said at numerous points that he couldn't recall a date, a name, whether someone had told him something or not. Reagan said decisively that he agreed with a letter Poindexter sent Congress saying the White House was complying with the ban on help for the Contras _ a letter that forms part of the basis for one charge Poindexter faces. But he also said, when told by prosecutors, that he was learning from them for the first time that former National Security Adviser Robert McFarlane, Poindexter's predecessor, had pleaded guilty to misleading Congress in the affair. Reagan testified, ``It was my impression'' that National Security Council aide Oliver North's assistance to the Contras was limited to ``communicating back and forth ... on the need for the support of the Contras.'' ``I guess that I had never ... had any inkling that we were guiding their strategy in any way,'' Reagan testified under questioning by Webb. Asked what he thought North was doing, Reagan said that ``you have to have people that can be available to make contact with the leaders of the Contras ... sometimes closer than just writing a letter.'' ``It was my understanding because his name would crop up in memos and so forth that that's what he was doing,'' the former president added. Poindexter, who faces trial March 5, is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. It was Poindexter's lawyers who had won a court order to take Reagan's testimony, hoping to show Reagan had approved of the activities that led to his former adviser's indictment. However, Iran-Contra prosecutors used cross-examination of Reagan to introduce evidence that Poindexter lied to Reagan about the secret aid operation after a C-123 cargo plane was shot down over Nicaragua during a supply flight on Oct. 5, 1986. In written interrogatories to the Iran-Contra grand jury earlier, Reagan said Poindexter first told him that the sole survivor of the crash, Eugene Hasenfus was not connected with the U.S. government. Hasenfus, who was tried and convicted of terrorism by Nicaragua's Sandinista government and later released, was involved in North's secret resupply effort, according to investigators. During his videotaped testimony, Reagan said he couldn't recall which adviser told him about the crash and said he did not know if Hasenfus was connected with North's secret operation. Reagan said Thursday that ``no one has proven to me'' that profits from secret arms sales to Iran were diverted to the rebels fighting the leftist Sandinista government in Nicaragua. But later in his testimony Reagan was confronted with details of the diversion from the February 1987 Tower Commission report. ``This is the first time that I have ever seen a reference that actually specified there was a diversion,'' Reagan said of the much-publicized report. ``Is this the first time ... that you came to realize in fact that a diversion had actually occurred?'' asked Webb. ``Yes,'' replied Reagan. Webb asked whether Reagan expected Poindexter to report such a diversion to his boss. ``Yes,'' replied Reagan. ``Unless maybe he thought he was protecting me from something.'' At that point Reagan seemed to lose his train of thought, saying, ``But, no, I don't understand. This is very confusing to me about this.'' Poindexter told Congress in 1987 that he purposely didn't tell the president about the diversion in order to provide him with ``deniability.'' Reagan grew testy with Webb, who told U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene that the former president had not answered his question. Reagan retorted that he was trying to be responsive. He said he ``assured everybody that we would have to abide by the law'' during the ban on Contra military aid. Reagan also testified under oath that he never authorized Poindexter to obstruct congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair or to destroy documents. He said he was never told that North had destroyed Iran-Contra documents, an act for which the former aide was convicted of a felony last year. Reagan may have helped Poindexter by testifying that he could not recall when he knew about a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. The shipment figures in four of the five criminal charges against Poindexter. Poindexter is accused of telling Congress in November 1986 that U.S. officials didn't find out that Hawks were aboard the 1985 shipment until January 1986. Poindexter told Congress in 1987, in testimony that cannot be used in his trial, that he had given incorrect information earlier to Congress because of a faulty memory. ``I don't know when it would have been told to me or I would have known,'' Reagan said when asked about when he found out about the 1985 Hawk shipment. ``I, some place along the line, acquired that knowledge, and I don't know from whom or where.''

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Governor Suspends Press Secretary Over Lewd Remark
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Madeleine Kunin has suspended her press secretary without pay for two weeks for making a comment of a sexual nature to a woman reporter. The suspension was ordered late Wednesday, one day after Peter Freyne made the comment, which he said was a joke. The remark came when Betsy Liley of The Burlington Free Press asked him for a preview of the governor's revenue forecast. Freyne's reply: ``If you took off all your clothes and (performed a lewd act) I might tell you.'' He paused, then added: ``Even if you did that, I wouldn't tell you.'' The exchange was overheard by another reporter and a Kunin official, both of whom confirmed the comment. It came to Kunin's attention when a reporter for the Rutland Herald asked her about it for a story. On Tuesday Kunin termed the remark ``totally inappropriate. I think it was a sexist remark, but I don't think that Peter really is sexist.'' She suspended Freyne the following day after a growing number of legislators and women's groups protested. In a letter to Freyne, Kunin said, ``I found totally reprehensible your remark to a reporter. While you have apologized, I believe you need some time to reflect on the impact of that remark.'' Freyne, a former reporter, said, ``I learned my lesson. I'm no longer a member of the Fourth Estate. The cynical, sardonic, `Saturday Night Live' wit of the Fourth Estate Club is now verboten to me. If I offended Betsy or anyone, I'm terribly sorry.'' The editor of the monthly magazine Vermont Woman said the publication would call for Freyne's dismissal in its March issue. ``To have him in that position, showing such insensitivity to women is a liability to Madeleine,'' said Gayle M.B. Hanson. Kunin, the state's first woman governor, has taken an active role nationally in promoting women's participation in politics and was vice chairwoman of the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She is expected to seek a fourth two-year term in November and could face a tough race against former Gov. Richard Snelling, the leading Republican candidate.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Asks U.S. for $500 Million
DOC.TEXT: A Romanian cabinet minister on Thursday said he was seeking $500 million in aid from the United States, in addition to gifts of food. During his recent trip to Romania, Secretary of State James A. Baker III offered Romania $80 million in U.S. aid, including 500,000 tons of feed grain and 7,500 tons of butter. ``Eighty million is an important amount but let me say that it's so samll for our desperate situation,'' Minister of State Dumitru Mazilu told reporters. ``We need much more.'' ``You understand, dear colleagues and friends, how difficult it is for a mother to try to find food for children in the stores and to get nothing,'' he added. Mazilu, who said he was discussing the aid request with members of Congress, called the food situation in Romania worse than before the overthrow of Communist President Nicolae Ceausescu in December. Mazilu said that immediately after Ceausescu's overthrow the food situation improved temporarily when the new authorities blocked exports, but food supplies diminished after a few weeks, despite help from abroad. He said his country needed ``At least $500 million from the United States, but at the same time we need help from other countries. I have to underline that in Europe, France has told us it is ready to help.'' Mazilu asked for restoration by the United States of ``most favored nation'' status for Romania, an arrangement that would lower U.S. customs duties on his country's goods. Baker had said previously that the matter was being re-examined for Romania and other Eastern European countries. Poland, Hungary and Yugoslavia already have the arrangement. Mazilu was under house arrest when Ceausescu was overthrown and said he, his wife and son were in danger of execution. His mother and a brother had been killed by the Ceausescu government, he added. He was among the first leaders of the interim government but resigned a month later because, he said, ``Stalinists'' were taking it over. He rejoined the National Salvation Front on Feb. 1 when members of political parties in addition to communists were added. Mazilu, a law professor, heads a group writing a new constitution and an election law for the voting due on May 20.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Air Force Understates Weapons Costs
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force significantly understated the cost of billion-dollar weapons systems, making it ``all but impossible'' to allocate the nation's limited funds, the chairman of a Senate panel said Thursday. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found that the Air Force lacks adequate accounting systems for its $275 billion in weapons systems, inventories and other assets and annual appropriations of about $90 billion. In response to news stories on the report, Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, issued a statement criticizing the Air Force and urging the service to act quickly to rectify its accounting problems. ``This audit has uncovered some significant weaknesses which make it all but impossible for us to allocate our limited resources wisely or to identify areas that are highly susceptible to waste and fraud,'' Glenn said. Following a three-year audit, the GAO discovered that among other things, the Air Force understated the cost of the B-1 bomber by at least $7.1 billion in its financial statements. ``The Air Force accounting and financial management systems can neither provide complete and reliable financial data nor be depended upon to report accurately on the resources entrusted to its managers,'' the GAO said. A draft copy of the report was obtained by The Associated Press. The report faulted the Air Force's financial systems as being unable to provide managers with complete and reliable information on either acquisition or operating costs of aircrafts and missiles. ``The procurement cost for each B-1 bomber is reported by the Air Force to be $150 million; GAO found that the cost is, in fact, about $219 million.'' Similar underestimates exist with the F-15 and F-16 aircraft, the agency said. Charles Bowsher, U.S. comptroller general, plans to testify before the Senate panel Friday on the GAO report. Meanwhile, at the Pentagon, officials released a two-page letter the Defense Department's comptroller general sent to the GAO on the report as well as a point-by-point response to the agency's 26 recommendations. ``The department is concerned that the report may mislead some readers into thinking that the Air Force has misstated the cost of its aircraft or other programs to the Congress,'' Sean O'Keefe, the Pentagon's comptroller general, wrote. He said the Air Force reports its costs to Congress through several channels. But he also said the Air Force understands its accounting system needs improvement. The GAO report, titled ``Air Force Does Not Effectively Account for Billions of Dollars of Resources,'' found that the service reported $63.8 billion in supplies and spare parts _ eight times the inventories of General Motors. ``However, the systems used to provide accountability over these immense inventories do not provide reliable data supporting either their quantities or value,'' the GAO said. The agency also discovered that almost $630 million worth of satellites and about $5.7 million worth of engines for C-20A cargo planes that the Air Force paid for and owned were not recorded in any Air Force property or accounting system.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Presents Award to Arkansas Architect
DOC.TEXT: President Bush presented the American Institute of Architects' 1990 gold medal Thursday to Fay Jones of Arkansas, whom he praised for creating ``architecture of great power and space.'' Bush said at a White House ceremony he was restoring a tradition practiced by earlier presidents. The honor was last conferred by Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933. ``Architecture holds up a mirror to the soul of any nation,'' Bush said. Jones' award, announced in December, was for a wooden chapel built in the southern Mississippi savanna. ``Through humble materials and simple forms, Mr. Jones has created architecture of great power and and space,'' Bush said. He said Jones' buildings have ``rare beauty and dignity'' and ``touch the heart as well as the mind.'' ``Grounded firmly in his Ozark roots, Fay Jones has created a truly American architecture that is respected the world over,'' Bush said. Jones said receiving the award at the White House was ``the honor of a lifetime.'' He said ``architects everywhere are pleased that you have now re-established a tradition, after over 50 years, of having this medal presented at the White House.'' Jones, and other winners of architectural awards, were to be honored later Thursday at the institute's annual awards banquet. Prince Charles, who has had a longtime interest in architecture, was to deliver the principal address.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: off entirely.
DOC.TEXT: Q. And I guess you had concerns, did you not, at that time that Congress was going to delay. If it were _ A. Yes. Q. _ going to give any funding to the administration for the Contras or the freedom fighters, it was going to be delayed even more? Did you have concerns about that? A. We were always concerned, yes. Q. Did you and Admiral Poindexter discuss any actions that you should take with regard to Congress on getting this funding that you can think of? A. I can't think of anything more than just encouraging them to carry the battle to them. Q. To carry the battle to _ I am sorry. A. To the Congress about the need and the very definite need for continued help for these other countries down there. Q. And if you were not _ if were not able to get any money from Congress in that spring of '86, what were you prepared to do? To somehow do it anyway? A. Well, no. To find whatever way we could keep them in existence. Q. And by that you are referring now once again to _ A. To the Contras. Q. _ the third countries or private individuals? A. Yes. Them and the refugees. Their families were being _ had to be taken care of while they were out there in the field and all. Q. ... Mr. President, do you know who Oliver North is? A. Yes. Q. Could you please describe to the jury what you know about Oliver North and what his job was when he was working the White House? A. Well, he was mainly performing tasks, as I understand it, for the NSC (National Security Council), but he _ his background and record had been one of being decorate for heroism and so forth in the Vietnamese conflict, and that he had been a very bold and brave soldier _ Marine. And _ so, he was _ it was my impression, not from any specific reports or anything, that in through all of this that he was communicating back and forth between on the need for the support of the Contras and so forth. Q. When you say ``communication back and forth between,'' could you be a little more explicit for the jury? Even though you and I might know _ A. Yeah. Q. _ maybe you can explain to the jury what you are referring to? A. Well, between the Contras and their situation and ourselves and the things that we must do for them. Q. ... In 1985 and 1986, did you know _ just tell the jury generally what you knew about what Oliver North was doing with regard to helping the situation in Central America vis-a-vis the freedom fighters? A. Well, you have to have people that can be available to make contact with the leaders of the Contras and so forth, sometimes closer than just writing a letter. And it was my feeling and my understanding _ I did not meet individually with him to any extent at all. But it was my understanding because his name would crop up in memos and so forth that that's what he was doing. And I am trying to I think what the other angle. I know that there was another area too in which he participated. Well, for example, in the meeting with the Iranians, he was involved in that, and I think was actually there in the meetings with them. Whether all of the time or not, I am not familiar. Q. But in addition to Colonel North's contacts with the Contras, do you know whether or not he had any contacts or made any presentations or speeches to fund-raising groups that would raise money for the Contras within the United States, the private citizens? A. I don't know. I _ as I say, he would have been one that I cautioned that must obey the law at all times.
