And I had made it plain that I didn't think that we should be out there trying to persuade the people to give money, but we should offer that help to those who were doing that. That if they needed help in contacting the leadership of the Contras and so forth, that he would be the _ in charge of that.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: City Sues Demonstrators in School Controversy
DOC.TEXT: The city is suing a group that organized protests over the dismissal of a black school superintendent, accusing the demonstrators of breaking laws and increasing racial tension. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in state court after a federal judge rejected a similar complaint, seeks an order barring the group from further ``reckless conduct'' that disrupts education and government services. The lawsuit accuses the group Best Educational Support Team of encouraging students to skip school, using ``force, fear, intimidation and actual violence'' in sit-ins at City Hall, and acting to heighten racial tensions. The demonstrators are demanding an extension of the contract of School Superintendent Norward Roussell, whose $80,000 job ends in June. The six whites on the 11-member school board voted in December against renewing the contract, setting off the protests. There have been demonstrations almost daily since Feb. 6. The city's 11 public schools were closed for four days that week for fear of violence. Of the city's 5,800 public school students, 75 percent are black.

DOC.HEAD: Malpractice Award Frightens Obstetricians
DOC.TEXT: Some West Virginia obstetricians are turning away new patients and some say they may leave the state because of a record $15 million malpractice award. ``We're working scared,'' Dr. Ujjal Sandhu of Charleston said Thursday. ``Malpractice awards are skyrocketing. There should be some reasonable compensation to victims, but they shouldn't be made millionaires overnight.'' A state jury last week awarded a couple $15.25 million after they claimed their obstetrician failed to perform a Caesarean section to prevent brain damage to their child. Mark and Julie Robinson of Cabin Creek said Dr. Kanoj K. Biswas and the Charleston Area Medical Center should have performed the Caesarean section after her son got stuck in the birth canal during delivery. Instead, the couple said, Biswas used forceps to remove the baby, causing a cutoff of oxygen and a brain hemorrhage. Several Charleston obstetricians said in interviews that at least seven of their colleagues have stopped taking new patients. Some are leaving to practice in neighboring states with lower insurance costs, Sandhu said. ``Some will probably leave if they get a chance. I would leave,'' he said. ``I don't want to worry about losing my shirt. The patients will have to go out of state just like the doctors are leaving.'' The award may compound the growing shortage of obstetricians in the state, said Dr. Bruce Berry, chairman of the West Virginia section of the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology. The number of obstetricians in West Virginia has dropped from 135 to 65 in the last five years, Berry said. Twenty-one family practitioners also deliver babies. There were 23,045 babies born in West Virginia last year, according to the state Department of Health. Berry, of Charleston, said he quit obstetrics 14 months ago mainly because of the high cost of malpractice insurance. Dr. Paul Fulcher of Charleston, who stopped taking new patients in response to the malpractice award, said most obstetricians carry a minimum $1 million malpractice insurance. Maximum coverage is $10 million, Berry said. West Virginia physicians pay about $63,000 in liability insurance annually, up to twice as much as doctors in Virginia and Kentucky, said George Rider, executive director of the West Virginia Medical Association. The doctors' group is uncertain why insurance companies charge more for malpractice insurance in West Virginia, he said. Obstetricians fear a big malpractice judgement could ruin them financially, Fulcher said. ``Most physicians had to think long and hard about this,'' Berry said. ``But when it comes to the point where it threatens their family's security, their family has to come first.'' The average delivery costs $1,200 to $1,500, Berry said. That would rise by $500 to cover the cost of a $10 million liability policy, he said. Obstetricians have proposed the state establish a reserve fund to cover large malpractice awards, or impose a cap on such awards.

DOC.HEAD: Detained American Files Appeal for Release
DOC.TEXT: An American detained last month, purportedly for involvement with a cult known as the ``Path of Bliss,'' appealed to the Supreme Court on Thursday to gain her release, her lawyer said. Patricia E. Munday of Vermont was ``illegally detained by the West Bengal state on Jan. 27 in violation of laws, apparently for her religious links,'' said her lawyer, V. M. Tarkunde. Tarkunde said Ms. Munday, 38, is associated with Anand Marg, or the ``Path of Bliss.'' The mysterious cult was founded in West Bengal in 1955 by a former Indian Railways employee, Prabhat Ranjan Sarkar. Ms. Munday is a member of the U.N. High Commission for Refugees, said Anand Marg general-secretary Sarbatmanada Avadhoota in Calcutta, the West Bengal state capital, but was on a private visit to India. Tarkunde said a mob attacked Ms. Munday and an unidentified woman associate on Jan. 26 when they were traveling on a motorcycle near the Anand Marg headquarters in Purulia district of West Bengal. He said Ms. Munday was seriously injured but the Purulia police, instead of pursuing her complaint, detained her the next day. The lawyer said the attack on Ms. Munday was engineered by ``hooligans'' of the Marxist Communist party, which governs the state in coalition with other leftist parties. Ms. Munday, whose hometown was not released, was being held at a Calcutta hospital, said Avadhoota. Tarkunde said the Supreme Court has informed the state and federal government of Ms. Munday's petition. It has asked them to send representatives to a court hearing Friday, the lawyer said. The state government on Feb. 19 ordered Ms. Munday's deportation without providing a reason, but the deportation was stayed following an appeal to the state High Court, Tarkunde said. ``She was obviously attacked because she is an Anand Margi. There is no other reason. Somehow the people dislike the Anand Margis, but why should they be harassed?'' said Tarkunde, a prominent human rights lawyer. The Anand Marg says it has worldwide chapters with the aim of creating a socio-economic and spiritual order to replace both capitalism and communism. But the cult is also believed to practice black magic and human sacrifices, and one of its rituals involves a dance holding skulls and daggers. Members of the Marxist Communist Party have in the past clashed with Anand Marg members, who accuse the government of persecution.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: of that.
DOC.TEXT: The cross-examination which follows was conducted by Dan Webb of Independent Counsel Lawrence Walsh's staff.

Q. ... If the information that Robert McFarlane provided to Congress in 1985 was false, contained lies, and deceived and obstructed Congress, would it still be your belief that John Poindexter should readopt those false statements in responding to Congress on July 21, 1986? MR. BECKLER: Objection, your Honor. Calls for a legal conclusion. U.S. DISTRICT JUDGE HAROLD GREENE: Overruled. A. Well, I simply _ no, I did not have this information, but I have a great deal of confidence in the man who was quoted as sending these letters, McFarlane. And I have never _ I have never caught him or seen him doing anything that was in any way out of line or dishonest. And so, I was perfectly willing to accept his defense. Q. I understand. But I am just asking you, as I understand it _ am I correct, Mr. President, that the letter that you are looking at there from John Poindexter dated July 21, 1986, you, yourself, actually did not approve and authorize those letters at the time that they were sent; is that correct? A. I have no recollection of doing so. Q. ... Well, as you sit here now, do you have any recollection of approving for John Poindexter to send these specific letters to Congress? A. Well, again, it is a case of memory. I don't recall if he did or not. Q. And my question to you is: Would you have approved the sending of these letters to Congress by John Poindexter if you knew that they adopted false information that had been previously supplied to Congress by Mr. McFarlane? A. No. But I would also _ it would be very _ I would have to have it proven to me that they did. Q. ... I take it as the Chief Executive and as President of the United States, you did not want nor did you authorize your top officials of your administration to provide false information to Congress; is that a fair statement? A. That is a fair statement. Q. ... I take it that is a fair statement that you were committed to helping the Contras within any legal bounds that you could during that time period? A. Yes. Q. However, as I understand your testimony, at the same time that you were _ that you were doing that, you attempted to keep your administration's Contra assistance within the confines of the law? At least that was your goal; is that correct? A. Yes. Q. ... On direct examination, you related to some extent that your Attorney General Ed Meese on or about November 24, 1986 after making some type of evaluation and inquiry into the Iranian arms sale initiative advised you that he had discovered that there was some Swiss bank accounts involved, and that money out of the Iran arms sales appeared to have gone in some way to assist the Contras. Do you recall that? A. What I testified is that that's what was being published and carried on by the press. But to this day, all I know is that some sum of money over and above the 12.2-million-dollar purchase price appeared in a Swiss bank account in which it was said that account had been used on another occasion to provide help to the Contras. And to this day, I still with all of the investigations that have been made, I still have never been given one iota of evidence as to who collected the price, who delivered the final delivery of the weapons, or what was _ whether there was ever money in that Swiss account that had been diverted someplace else. I am still waiting to find those things out and have never found them out. Q. And at the time that the Iran initiative was ongoing, were you aware that money was being diverted away from the Iranian arms sales and diverted over to aid the Contras? Were you aware of that? A. No, I wasn't. I was only aware finally that we got our twelve million two. Q. ... Had you approved or authorized that diversion while you were President of the United States? A. May I simply point out that I had no knowledge then or now that there had been a diversion, and I never used the term. And all I knew was that there was some money that came from some place in another account, and that the appearance was that it might have been a part of the negotiated sale. And to this day, I don't have any information or knowledge that that wasn't the total amount that _ or that there was a diversion. Q. ... To the extent that there was in fact a diversion of proceeds, did you in any way approve or authorize that while you were President of the United States? A. For heaven's sake, no. And when I was once asked about that extra money and said if it was an added sum to the purchase price, what would I do, I said I would have given it back. Q. So, the answer to my question is that you did not authorize or approve it; it that correct? A. That's right. Q. At any time, sir, while you were President, did you ever approve or give authority to John Poindexter to obstruct or impede any congressional committee inquiry into events relating to the Iran-Contra controversy? A. No, I don't _ Q. And at any time did you ever approve or give authority to John Poindexter to make any false or misleading statements to any congressional committee regarding events related to the Iran-Contra controversy? A. No. And I don't think any false statements were made. Q. ... at any time, did John Poindexter ever tell you that he had plans to make or cause others to make any false or misleading statements to any congressional committees regarding events related to the Iran-Contra affair? A. There was never any such thing that he ever said to me that was false or misleading.

DOC.HEAD: Launch Delayed Another Day Because of Illness, Weather
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `NASA said...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with flight surgeons' comments; PICKS UP 10th graf pvs, `The delays ...'
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Thursday delayed the launch of Atlantis for a second day to let the shuttle's commander recover from a sore throat and to await better weather. The secret military mission to put a spy satellite in orbit is not expected to take off until Saturday morning at the earliest. The shuttle originally was scheduled for a pre-dawn liftoff Thursday but was postponed Wednesday when Navy Capt. John O. Creighton became ill, the second time the space program has delayed a flight because of a sick astronaut. NASA delayed the launch yet another day on the recommendation of doctors examining Creighton, who complained of a sore throat and congestion. ``Physicians ... report that his condition has improved, but that he still has some infection of the upper respiratory tract,'' the space agency said in a statement. ``Additionally, weather conditions presently are not expected to be satisfactory for (fueling) required for a morning launch.'' NASA said it would decide whether to proceed with a Saturday launch after examining Creighton and the forecast on Friday. Saturday's outlook was a scant 20 percent chance for liftoff because of an approaching cold front, but that was to improve to 70 percent by Sunday. In 1969, the Apollo 9 mission to orbit the Earth and test the lunar landing module was delayed three days after the three crewmen got sick. NASA said it had no plans to replace Creighton on the mission because his illness was not serious. Responding in writing to reporters' questions, NASA flight surgeons said the ``prognosis is good,'' but they didn't say when the commander might be able to fly. Creighton was quarantined, and the four other crew members were ``healthy and isolated,'' the doctors said. Changes in cabin pressure normally experienced in flight would cause Creighton pain in his present condition, they said. The delays came before technicians had begun pumping more than half a million gallons of propellant into Atlantis' fuel tank for the four-day mission, which was to end at Edwards Force Base, Calif. Pumping the fuel would have added $377,000 to the cost to Kennedy Space Center of delaying the mission. Each day's delay costs $247,000 in labor and materials. That does not include expenses at other NASA centers supporting the mission. Sources said Atlantis' cargo is a 37,300-pound, $500 million satellite capable of taking super-sharp photos and eavesdropping on electronic communications around the world. Its path will carry it over most of the Soviet Union. NASA has not announced a precise launch time since Atlantis' cargo is classified, but sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said it would take place around 1 a.m. Atlantis' flight will be the 34th shuttle flight and the sixth secret military mission.

DOC.HEAD: Sniper Fire Persists in Lebanon; Mediators Attempt Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Aoun telling news conference Geagea readying new warfare. Picks up 12th graf, Meanwhile, about ...
DOC.TEXT: Snipers exchanged gunfire intermittently in the Christian enclave Thursday and mediators tried to forge a settlement in the power struggle between rival Christian leaders. Police said about 3,000 families left east Beirut for the city's Moslem western sector, the eastern Bekaa Valley and northern Lebanon, fearing renewed clashes between the Lebanese Forces militia of Samir Geagea and army troops of Gen. Michel Aoun. A three-man Christian mediation committee called a cease-fire Saturday and has been meeting with Aoun and Geagea to try to work out a settlement. The chances of prolonging the truce darkened Thursday evening when Aoun accused Geagea of ``procrastinating to win time and prepare for a new confrontation.'' At least 681 people have been killed and 1,878 wounded since the confrontation broke out Jan. 30 and escalated into the worst intra-Christian fighting in nearly 15 years of civil war. The continued evacuation and stockpiling of weapons and ammunition by the rival forces reflected fear that clashes could break out again if mediation efforts failed, a police spokesman said. Aoun called a televised news conference at his headquarters in the presidential palace in suburban Baabda Thursday evening and told reporters: ``There is no use negotiating with Geagea. He wants another collision. We are giving the mediators deeds and he is giving them words. ``I am letting the mediators try and try until they get fed up. Then they will come to me and say they have given up. I don't give the negotiations with Geagea much chance. Procrastination is going to bring more disasters.'' Aoun made no comment on an offer by Geagea for a ``unified command'' for his 6,000-strong militia and the 19,000 troops under Aoun. Geagea made the call in an interview with the London-based Arabic language daily Al-Hayat. Geagea's offer appeared to be an attempt to put off Aoun's demand that the militia be changed into a political organization while its fighters join the army. ``All we want is political independence and the preservation of the Lebanese Forces,'' Geagea said. ``We are ready to combine the military effort (militia) with the army and the general within the framework of a joint command.'' Meanwhile, about 400 women demonstrated in east Beirut's residential district of Ashrafiyeh _ controlled by Geagea's militiamen _ demanding ``an end to the barbaric, destructive shelling of our area.'' ``We are Lebanese. We are Christians. Why have you knocked down our houses?'' the demonstrators chanted. Ashrafiyeh, which sits on the highest hill in Beirut, commands the network of roads leading to the city's port, which also is controlled by Geagea's militiamen on the southwestern tip of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Military analysts said if hostilities resumed, Aoun would try to overrun Ashrafiyeh to seize the port and ensure safe supply lines by sea. Savage fighting has inflicted an estimated $750 million worth of damage on the Christian enclave's residential districts and commercial thoroughfares. The three-man mediation committee, said in a statement it has ``achieved progress'' in its mission to defuse the explosive situation. ``The atmosphere is encouraging,'' the statement said without elaborating. The independent newspaper An-Nahar said Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat also was mediating the conflict between Geagea and Aoun. Arafat's representative in Lebanon, Zeid Wehbe, and two other PLO officials have been holding talks with the rival Christian leaders since Tuesday. They proposed a team of Arab observers disengage the warring Christian forces, An-Nahar said. The Palestinian team, according to the paper, warned both Geagea and Aoun that Syria would intervene militarily in the Christian enclave if the intra-Christian showdown were renewed. Syria, which has 40,000 troops in predominantly Moslem Lebanese areas under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the 22-nation Arab League, is the major Arab enemy of Aoun, Geagea and Arafat.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Sess Another Year of Record Prices
DOC.TEXT: Cattle producers are headed for another year of record-high market prices, an Agriculture Department analysis indicated Thursday. Total beef production by slaughter plants is expected to rise about 2 percent because of increased cattle marketings and heavier weights, the department's Economics Research Service said in its report. But an expanding U.S. population and increases in net beef exports will more than offset the larger output, the report said. That will mean less beef available on a per capita basis. Consequently, market prices of choice-grade fed steers sold on the Omaha, Neb., market in 1990 may average about $1 more than last year's record of $72.50 per pound, the report said. That would push retail prices up 1 percent to 3 percent. Hog prices also are going up and may average in the range of $47 to $53 per 100 pounds in 1990, compared with a little more than $44 last year at the major markets. ``Retail pork prices have risen in recent months, reflecting higher hog prices and wider farm-to-retail (marketing) spreads,'' the report said. ``Retail pork prices for the year may increase 6 percent to 8 percent from last year.''

DOC.HEAD: Labor Federation Urges Renewed Commitment to Eastern Strike
DOC.TEXT: AFL-CIO leaders closed their annual meeting Thursday with a call for the federation's 14 million members to send additional financial aid to striking Machinists at Eastern Airlines. ``I don't know if the strike is ever going to be over, because we're going be to there with them just as long as it takes,'' said Gerald McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The AFL-CIO's 33-member board declared that the Eastern strike ``remains as solid as ever.'' It asked unions across the country to ``adopt'' groups of Machinists and send money to help their families. The 8,500 Machinists who walked out nearly a year ago inspired workers nationwide because they've ``been on the front lines of labor's battle against corporate greed and intransigence,'' the board said. The Eastern situation was a sore spot for labor leaders during a weeklong meeting otherwise marked by optimism that organized labor is regaining political and bargaining power after a loss of stature in the 1980s. AFL-CIO leaders were jubilant in announcing Tuesday that the 10-month Pittston coal strike was ending. The Appalachian miners ratified a contract that gave them victories on health care and job security. In addition, union leaders met with prominent Democrats who are enlisting their help in the 1990 elections, which will determine who controls next year's congressional redistricting. Union leaders also received a boost with a report showing that the public's image of the American labor movement is improving. ``We've been tempered, I think, by a period of fire and, in the net result, it's strengthened us,'' AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland said. Labor officials attribute much of their improved standing to efforts on issues that affect all Americans, such as health care. In an effort to keep abortion off the week's agenda, the board named a 14-member panel to study whether the federation should adopt a pro-choice position. When union leaders met with Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole on Tuesday, Eastern was the only major point of contention. AFL-CIO leaders said their relationship with the White House has improved since the Reagan era. But the federation said the Bush administration doesn't care about the survival of Eastern and has sided with management in the Machinists' strike. Kirkland conceded that so far the strike has failed but said Eastern's parent, Texas Air Corp., had not won either. Labor leaders also acknowledged they lack the votes in Congress to override President Bush's veto of legislation that would create a commission to settle the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Reapportionment Changes, A Bit
DOC.TEXT: The political outlook may have improved a bit for the North in new Census population estimates. The South and West will wrest away some seats in the House of Representatives after the 1990 national head count _ but maybe not as many as had originally been thought. The Constitution requires seats in the House to be redistributed among states after each census. The private Population Reference Bureau analyzed a complex series of new Census estimates on Thursday, and predicted that 14 House seats will move from the Northeast and Midwest to the South and West after the census. Earlier analyses by the same group had indicated as many as 18 seats would move. The Census estimates include four sets of possible state populations for 1990, each differing slightly depending on the amount of interstate movement by people. One set included no movement, and was discounted by the private analysis group. But while reapportionment calculations based on the other three varied slightly, the overall shift in seats was consistent. The big winner will be California, gaining six seats based on the new figures. The previous calculations had called for California to gain five seats. Texas and Florida will gain three seats each, the new estimates indicate. Earlier calculations had shown Texas adding four seats and Florida three. Arizona and Georgia, which had previously been expected to gain two seats apiece, are now expected to add one, the new study said. Virginia also will gain one, as had been expected. North Carolina would add one seat under two of the estimates, but would remain unchanged under the third. On the losing side, New York is still expected to lose three seats. Pennsylvania, which had been expected to drop three, now appears likely to lose just two. Ohio, Illinois and Michigan will drop two each, the same as previously expected. Also unchanged are losses of one seat each by West Virginia, Iowa, Kansas and Massachusetts. Wisconsin, which had been expected to lose a seat, would not do so under the new figures. And Montana would lose a seat under two estimates but not under the third. Following the 1990 census, the Census Bureau will present the White House with the final state population figures and the new reapportionment numbers.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion on U.S.-Flag Tanker; Two Americans Believed Killed
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-flag Kuwaiti tanker loaded with naphtha and diesel fuel exploded Thursday in the Persian Gulf and two American crewmen were believed killed. The other 23 seamen, all Americans but one, abandoned the burning ship and were rescued by a U.S. Navy frigate. U.S. sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said remains had been found in the water but it was not clear whether they were of one or two people. A U.S. military spokesman said he could not confirm the report. Other American military sources said the two men missing, and evidently killed, were the captain and first mate of the 81,283-ton Surf City but further identification would have to come from the owners, the Kuwait Oil Tanker Co. No one at the company was available for comment Thursday night. Capt. Ron Wildermuth, chief spokesman for U.S. Central Command headquarters in Tampa, Fla., said there were no reports of mines from the Iran-Iraq war in the area and ``initial reports indicate the explosion was internal.'' The Surf City exploded 20 miles off the United Arab Emirates, said U.S. officials and shipping sources in the gulf. ``It was a huge explosion, the ship just blew up,'' said Wayne Cohen, 27, of Boston, who was standing watch on the bridge. He and crewman Earl Washington, from Louisiana, were cut by flying glass when the pilot house windows shattered, Cohen said. ``There was some panic,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``We made our way to the lifeboat.'' Both were among survivors picked up by the missile frigate USS Simpson, and were taken to a hospital in Dubai. Cohen, a member of the Surf City crew since September, said he looked back as the lifeboat reached the Simpson and saw ``nothing but fire and smoke.'' Late in the day, the tanker was reported still burning and taking on water. Wildermuth said U.S. warships and other craft in the area were ``standing off'' in case of another explosion in the highly volatile cargo. The Surf City was among 11 Kuwaiti tankers given U.S. flags in 1987 so the Navy could protect them from Iran, which had made Kuwait's merchant fleet a target because it supported Iraq in the war. In 1987-88, the Surf City made dozens of trips unscathed under U.S. escort. No armed attacks or minings have been reported in the gulf since Iran and Iraq agreed to a cease-fire in August 1988. An Iranian Silkworm missile badly damaged a sister tanker, the Sea Isle City, at Kuwait's main loading terminal Oct. 19, 1987. Two months earlier, the reflagged supertanker Bridgeton struck an Iranian mine on the Navy's first convoy up the gulf. Direct escort ended five months after the truce, but U.S. Navy ships still monitor the movements of U.S.-flag tankers. Thursday's explosion occurred as the Surf City was sailing out of the gulf through one of its busiest shipping lanes, between the United Arab Emirates and Abu Musa, an Iranian island. Cohen said some work was being done on one of the ship's starboard cargo tanks about midway down the 700-foot deck, where the explosion occurred. He said the missing men were in the area. The Simpson, on patrol three miles away, was observing the Surf City visually and on radar, officials said. The missile destroyer USS Dewey, another of the 10 U.S. warships on duty in the gulf, also went to the scene, as did several patrol craft and helicopters from the Emirates. A statement from the Kuwait Oil Tanker Co. said the fire spread quickly from the blast point toward the stern, where the engine room, bridge and crew's quarters are located. It said the tanker was listing and salvage tugs were trying to recover it. Shipping executives said the tugs were forced to stay clear because of the fire. When the ships were put under the American flag in 1987, an exception to U.S. maritime law was made that let them sail with foreign rather than exclusively American crews. That changed a year ago, when six of the ships were removed from U.S. registry. The United States extended the contract for the other five, including the Surf City, on condition they use American crews. Central Command officials said they could not explain why the Surf City carried a ``British-Canadian'' chief engineer.

DOC.TEXT: Q. If he did that, you never knew about it? A. No. Q. I knew very little about either one of them or _ but I had heard their names connected with such things. Q. ... Do you recall an incident occurring involving a pilot named Gene Hasenfus that was shot down over Nicaragua carrying arms to the Contras? A. I have a memory of a plane that was shot down, and that one of the people who turned out unhurt but all right was an American citizen. And I had no knowledge that he was involved in any way, nor do I recall his indicating that he was in _ of having anything to do with the government and our program, but there he was and, apparently, a prisoner. Q. And my question to you is: Do you recall who the first person was in government who told you that Gene Hasenfus, who was shot down over Nicaragua, had no connection to the United States government or the National Security Council? Do you know who told you that? A. I do not recall who told me that, but that was the information that I had. Q. ... As I understand your statement under oath in the interrogatories, which I believe you accept as a truthful statement, Admiral Poindexter assured you that the Hasenfus operation had no connection to the United States government whatsoever. Is that what you state there? A. Yes. And I opened that statement with saying to the best of my knowledge I first learned of the Hasenfus crash from Admiral Poindexter. Q. I understand. And you gave a date there that you believe you learned it on October 7, 1986; is that correct? A. Well, let me find that. October 7, '86, yes. Q. And you go on to say under oath in your interrogatory that when Poindexter told you that Hasenfus had no connection to the United States government whatsoever, you go on to say, ``When I asked whether John Singlaub might be involved in this operation, as had been reported in the press, I was told no by Admiral Poindexter.'' Do you say that? A. Yes. Q. Mr. President, when your Tower Commission reported back to you in March of 1987, did the Tower Commission not tell you, Mr. President, Oliver North and your National Security Council were involved in 1985 and 1986 in assisting the Contras militarily and paramilitarily? Do you recall that being told to you by your Tower Commission? A. I don't recall that, and I can only tell you _ Q. I will try to _ A. _ that my interest in that commission was to find out the thing that I still do not know, and that was how did there turn out to be more money than the 12.2 million for the TOW tank missiles, who delivered and who _ obviously, it seemed to me that someone must have raised the price for those, but that was never found out. I still do not know. And then to talk as they do about a diversion of money that was found in that Swiss bank account, I have no information at all that there was ever any more money than was in the account when it was found, or that any diversion to anyone had been attempted of that money ... Judge Greene: ... The letter from Mr. McFarlane (to Congress) apparently indicates that no effort has been made or will be made to provide military or paramilitary _ support for military or paramilitary operations in Nicaragua. The Tower Commission report appears to indicate that Col. North did make expenditures for Contra military equipment, supplies, and so on. Do you find that the two are consistent with each other, or if they are inconsistent, do you find that the second one brands the first one as a falsehood? I think that is what he is trying to find out. A. Well, I have to say there's _ in the wording of all of this, possibly there is a _ it could be int interpreted that other way. I had not because I am remembering my telling those same people to be helpful to private citizens who were trying to do something that the Congress of the United States refused to do and abandoning its responsibility. Q. Mr. President, in connection with your statement or testimony that as you looked at McFarlane's letter to Congressman Barnes, as you looked at it this morning and said that it looked okay to you, did you consider and do you remember that Mr. McFarlane, the man who sent the letter, has pled guilty in open court to withholding information from Congress in connection with that letter? A. No, I was not aware of that. Q. ... Is it fair to say that as the year 1986 went on, you were generally aware that there were some shipments of weapons to Iran under the finding that you signed on January 17th, but you don't _ but you, yourself, are not aware of the underlying operational details? A. No, I am not. Q. ... One of the things, am I correct, that you did not ever know about and were never advised of is that the iranians were being charged a price substantially in excess of the price that the United States was receiving for the weapons; is that correct? You were never aware of that? A. No. That is the thing that I have been talking about for a long time that I am still waiting to find out, who raised the price on them.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: White House Opposes New Sanctions While South Africa Makes Progress
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration opposes placing more economic sanctions on South Africa because, ``When someone is starting to do the right thing, you don't kick them,'' an official said Thursday. Herman Cohen, the assistant secretary of state for African affairs, predicted South Africa's white-ruled government might be able to satisfy conditions that could lead to the removal of U.S. economic sanctions ``in the next three months.'' ``In my opinion, the end of officially sanctioned racial oppression in South Africa is on the horizon,'' he said during an appearance before two House subcommittees. ``This is the beginning of an exciting new phase that will determine the shape of a non-racial, democratic South Africa.'' But Cohen said the Bush administration objects to a House resolution that would tighten the sanctions by preventing U.S. banks from rescheduling South African debt. He said you don't ``kick'' people when they're on the right path to reform. Cohen's comments came as a bipartisan congressional group pledged to keep sanctions in force until South Africa's President F.W. de Klerk meets all conditions for the lifting of sanctions. Congress imposed the sanctions in 1986 over the veto of then-President Reagan. The sanctions spell out specific things the South African government must do in order for Washington to remove them. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., who co-sponsored a companion measure to the House resolution, said the bill's backers were ``mindful of the real progress being made in South Africa. We also recognize that it is only a beginning.'' Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., said ``As we celebrate the release of Nelson Mandela, the personification of the struggle against white minority rule in south Africa, this resolution keeps up focused on the goal for which he has sacrificed so much: total dismantling of apartheid and the creation of a genuine non-racial democracy in South Africa.'' De Klerk has released from prison Nelson Mandela, head of the African National Congress, and lifted the bans of the ANC and other black political organizations. Several Republicans endorsed the resolution, including Sens. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., and Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan.

DOC.TEXT: Q. Now, at any time prior to November of 1986 while the Iranian initiative was going on, do you recall any conversation with your National Security Adviser John Poindexter in which he in any way hinted or suggested or in any way told you anything about these excess profits and the diversion to the Contras? A. There was never any such conversation because the only information we had was that there was money in excess over the 12.2 million that had been deposited in a Swiss bank account. Q. Let me see if I can help refresh your memory from your Tower Commission, what they told you. ... Do you see there the portion that I called to your attention? A. I have just seen it, and I have to tell you to my recollection, this is the first time I have ever seen that. ... This report _ this is the first time that I have ever seen a reference that actually specified there was a diversion. Q. My question is: If he (Poindexter) knew about it, you would have expected him to tell you about it; is that correct? A. Yes. Unless maybe he thought he was protecting me from something. But, no, I don't understand. This is very confusing to me about this. ...

DOC.HEAD: White House, Governors Oppose Increasing Unemployment Tax
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration Thursday said it opposed a House bill that would increase taxes on employers to protect the jobless from a sudden cut in unemployment benefits in a severe recession. The National Governors' Association said it also objected to the bill, which would raise the federal unemployment insurance taxable wage base from $7,000 to $10,000. The bill by Reps. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y.; Donald Pease, D-Ohio, and Sander Levin, D-Mich., is aimed at averting a repeat of the 1981-82 recession when cash-starved states cut benefits and restricted eligibility as their jobless rates soared above 10 percent. ``We see no programatic justification for such an increase,'' Deputy Assistant Labor Secretary Carolyn Golding told the House Ways and Means subcommittee on human resources, which is chaired by Downey. Ms. Golding said the Unemployment Trust Funds now have state and federal reserves totaling $45 billion. She said one state, Michigan, still owes $800 million from the $14 billion borrowed by 26 states in 1982-84 to meet benefit payments. ``Some states remain in positions that could require borrowing if such a downturn occurred,'' Ms. Golding said, but ``there has been significant overall improvement in the solvency of the trust funds.'' Despite the improvement, congressional auditors in the General Accounting Office said Thursday the reserves ``still appear to be inadequate to handle a severe recession.'' At the end of 1989, only six states had enough reserves to maintain benefits in a severe recession for 18 months, the target recommended in the past by the Labor Department and most state employment security administrators, the GAO said. And the overall system has only 11 months of recession-level benefits in reserve, compared with a 22-month reserve two decades ago, the auditors said. Congress' decision in 1982 to make states pay interest on money they borrowed to maintain benefits has made the system more solvent, the GAO said, but at a cost of higher unemployement insurance taxes and reduced eligibility. But Ohio Employment Services Administrator Ellen O'Brien told the hearing that instead of increasing taxes, the government should redivide the tax pie so states get a bigger share. ``Employers who finance this system through the Federal Unemployment Tax Act are investing enough money to provide adequate service,'' she said. ``No new taxes are necessary to return the program to its proper funding level.'' As the program now works, most covered employers pay into the system a minimum gross tax of 6.2 percent on the first $7,000 in annual wages to a worker on their payroll. That tax rate would fall to 6 percent at the end of this year. Of the $436 now collected each year per worker, $56 goes to the federal government and the other $380 goes to the states, which adjust the actual tax rates on each employer according to the firm's unemployment experience. Thirty-six states have adopted floors above the mandated $7,000 level, ranging from $7,100 in Connecticut up to $20,900 in Alaska.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Facing Possible Death Sentence Asks High Court For Help
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for an Alabama youth facing a possible death sentence in his home state asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to overrule the District of Columbia court that ordered his extradition. Gerald Fisher, attorney for the 17-year-old boy who has been identified in court proceedings by the initials O.M., said the petition for Supreme Court review automatically will postpone the District of Columbia court order approving his extradition until the high court decides whether to hear the case. O.M. is charged with arson and murder in the death of 14-month-old Tamal Jackson, who was killed in the May 1988 firebombing of an apartment in a Gadsden, Ala., housing project. If returned to Alabama and certified for trial as an adult, he could face the death penalty. Two uncles of O.M., 32-year-old Yul Devoe Guice, and an 18-year-old identified only by the initials S.T., also face arson and murder charges in the same case. Guice is being held in an Alabama prison on an unrelated charge and S.T. is being held by District of Columbia authorities. S.T. also is fighting extradition to Alabama, but his case has been put on hold by District of Columbia court officials until the final disposition of the O.M. case. O.M., who is black, has attracted widespread attention in his long fight to avoid extradition because of his contention that he cannot get a fair trial from the predominantly white judicial system in Etowah County, Ala., where his father and another relative died while in police custody.

DOC.HEAD: Record Store Owner Found Innocent of Obscenity
DOC.TEXT: A small-town jury Thursday acquitted a record store owner of obscenity charges for selling a sexually explicit tape by a rap group. The Circuit Court jury took less than 1{ hours to decide in favor of Tommy Hammond, who earlier was found guilty in Municipal Court in what the American Civil Liberties Union called the nation's first obscenity conviction for music. Hammond had appealed that conviction and was granted a trial in the higher court. He was charged with violating a 1983 city ordinance against obscenity for selling ``Move Somethin''' by the group 2 Live Crew. The ordinance carries a fine of $500. The group records on the Skyywalker label, which paid half Hammond's legal fees in the first round of the legal fight in Alexander City, a town of about 14,000. Judge James Avery told jurors their verdict ``certainly will help people in the future on how to approach this type of thing _ in other cities in Alabama and across the nation. ... You've taken part in a historic case.'' Scattered applause broke out in the courtroom after the verdict was announced. Hammond said he expected to be found innocent. ``When you start messing with First Amendment rights, you ought to be protected. People in this community feel that way,'' he said. During the four-day trial, jurors listened to the tape's street-language lyrics, which include explicit lines about oral and anal sex and sadomasochism. At issue was whether the tape, which has sold more than 1 million copies, violates accepted community standards _ part of the doctrine laid down by the U.S. Supreme Court during the 1970s. Juror Eddie Futral said the 2 Live Crew tape wasn't any more offensive than other music, videotapes or magazines that are available in Alexander City and were introduced as evidence by the defense. ``When they showed all the things that were tolerated in the city at the time, I couldn't see any difference between them,'' Futral said. Defense attorney Bobby Segall had urged jurors to protect ``the freedom of every citizen of Alabama _ the right to say that which is unsayable.'' ``Where in the world do you draw the line on what obscenity is?'' he asked. He said the Eddie Murphy movie ``Raw'' is as sexually explicit as the tape and that the movie had been shown at a theater in town. ``If you want obscenity stopped, you can stop it,'' prosecutor Danny Brown said in closing arguments. ``There is no question he knew the nature and character of that work. ... It exhibits a total disregard for women.'' Police Chief Lynn Royall testified that he listened to less than a minute of the tape before deeming it obscene and authorizing Hammond's arrest. He said he was concerned about the music's effect on teen-agers.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Party Leaders Threaten to Quit Over Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir reaction. Pick up 9th graf pvs, Labor's move ... Minor editing to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the center-left Labor Party on Thursday threatened to quit Israel's coalition government unless the Cabinet adopts compromises within two weeks aimed at starting an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. The 107-member Labor Bureau passed a resolution saying ``there is a need for an immediate decision on issues that will ensure the continuation of the peace process and a further delay will cause serious harm to Israel.'' It added: ``The ... condition for the continuation of the National Unity government is the continuation of the peace process.'' Cabinet approval of the compromises, which would mean allowing deported Palestinians and east Jerusalem residents to participate in peace talks, would require Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc to drop its opposition to the moves. Disagreements over the peace process have threatened to break up the Likud-Labor partnership at least four times, but Thursday's resolution was the strongest by Labor since formation of the government in December 1988. It comes at a time when Shamir faces a potential split in his own party over demands by hard-liners that he rule out any compromise in the peace process. Shamir's chief Likud rival, Ariel Sharon, who quit as trade minister four days ago over disagreements on peace moves, urged the prime minister to unite against any compromise. ``Shamir should reject the Labor ultimatum immediately,'' he said. Shamir, interviewed on Israel television, said he never received any ultimatum and added: ``We will discuss every issue in its own time and hour as is obligated.'' The Likud faction in Parliament issued a statement rejecting the Labor threat, saying ``the fate of the nation or foreign policy will not be determined with a stopwatch,'' Israel TV reported. Labor's move came after Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, the party's No. 2 man, eased his demand that Labor remain in the Likud-led coalition. He told Israel army radio he changed his mind after Egypt, which has been representing the Palestine Liberation Organization in U.S.-brokered peace efforts, gave ``reasonable answers'' on the makeup of a Palestinian peace delegation and the agenda for a dialogue. Rabin denied Labor's move was an ultimatum, but he also said Egypt's answers could put Israel in the role of holding up the peace process. ``If the delay comes from here, there is doubt whether there is a point in the continuation of the government,'' he said. The resolution was adopted unanimously by the Labor Bureau, which runs the party's day-to-day affairs, at a meeting in Tel Aviv. It calls for Labor's government ministers to bring the compromise steps to a Cabinet vote within two weeks. Rabin and Labor's leader, Vice Premier Shimon Peres, disagreed on when the party should consider quitting the government. Rabin said the Cabinet could hold more than one meeting on the issue, but Peres it would be ``the end of the story'' if a Cabinet vote was not taken by March 7. The party has scheduled a meeting on March 15 for its 1,300-member Central Committee to consider the party's continuation in the government. The compromises that Labor wants are part of U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's effort to revive Israel's stalled plan for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Baker has urged an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue to help set up the elections, which would lead to limited autonomy for the territories and later talks on their final status. The compromises call for Palestinians in the initial talks to include six residents of the occupied lands, two deportees brought back from exile and two residents of Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem who have other homes in the territories. The talks would focus on the elections but could include opening statements on other issues. The compromise is intended to satisfy PLO demands to include overseas Palestinians, while recognizing Israel's insistence that it will only negotiate with residents of the occupied lands. Environment Minister Ronnie Milo, a confidant of Shamir, repeated Likud's opposition to the compromises. ``Deportees and east Jerusalem Arabs, this is something that is not included in the initiative of the Israeli government,'' Milo told army radio. Israel annexed Arab east Jerusalem after it was captured from Jordan along with the West Bank in the 1967 Middle East War.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Chief Says Third World Poses Increasing Risk to U.S. Security
DOC.TEXT: The spread of ballistic missiles and other modern weaponry in the Third World poses a growing threat to U.S. security, the Navy's top officer told Congress Thursday. Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, chief of naval operations, said that while a lowering of superpower tensions made global warfare less likely in the 1990s, U.S. armed forces will be challenged to protect American security in ``an era of violent peace.'' ``There was a time when conflict in developing countries conjured a vision of simple, low-tech warfare that would not require sophisticated weapons. That time has passed,'' Trost told the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense. ``Today, around the globe, developing countries are armed with `First World' weapons,'' he said, and as a result ``virtually any nation or group of terrorists can bring capable and deadly weapons to bear.'' Thus the United States should remain able to project its naval power worldwide, he said. In pleading with Congress to avoid big cuts in Navy manpower and weapons programs, Trost sounded a theme that lawmakers have heard from all service branches in recent weeks. The Bush administration has proposed trimming the defense budget next year by about 2 percent, after inflation, but momentum is building in Congress to cut much more deeply in response to the waning of the Cold War. Trost acknowledged that ``perhaps we are at the end of the Cold War.'' But he stressed that a well-equipped military still was needed to handle hostilities in the Third World. Trost said 102 countries in addition to the United States and the Soviet Union now have cruise missiles. By the year 2000, at least 15 countries will be producing their own ballistic missiles, he said. Trost also said 14 countries besides the two superpowers have chemical weapons and 11 are suspected of developing them. He said three countries besides the superpowers have bacteriological weapons and 15 may be developing them.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants Protections for Disabled Made Part of Civil Rights Act
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's opposition to a new civil rights bill has forced officials to seek changes in another bill that specifically protects the rights of the nation's 43 million disabled people. The issue, centering on how to punish employment discrimination, arose Thursday during testimony by an administration official before a House committee reviewing the proposed Americans With Disabilities Act. The proposed disabilities law would guarantee the rights of disabled people to employment, goods and services. A version that was passed by the Senate last September was a delicate compromise that had been negotiated with the White House. The administration, however, opposes a more recently submitted bill, the Civil Rights Act of 1990. That bill would give more enforcement clout to the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by making it possible to seek compensatory and punitive damages for employment discrimination. ``Enactment of this proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990 would significantly expand the remedies available under the ADA to include compensatory and punitive damages,'' James P. Turner, acting assistant attorney general for civil rights, told the House Small Business Committee. Turner said the administration has opposed including compensatory and punitive damages in the disabilities act just as it has in other civil rights legislation. ``Inclusion of such extraordinary relief as punitive damages is simply unwarranted in a statutory scheme as new, bold and complex as the provision of disabilities rights concepts to the American business community,'' he said. Turner proposed that the disabilities bill instead outline specific sanctions without reference to the broader Civil Rights Act. He said he was not trying to hold the disabilities bill ``hostage'' but instead was trying to speed up its passage in view of the anticipated fight against the 1990 civil rights act. The administration proposal is anathema to advocates of the disabilities bill, who reject any effort to give the disabled civil rights protection that differs from the protection afforded to blacks, other minorities and women. ``We cannot understand why the Bush administration would oppose monetary damages for victims of intentional discrimination,'' said Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of 185 rights groups. ``And we are incredulous that the administration would be willing to treat persons with disabilities differently from other victims of intentional discrimination,'' Neas said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Shows Surplus _ But Only for a Month
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 5-6, bgng, The surplus..., with 3 new grafs to include effect of S&L bailout borrowing
DOC.TEXT: The government posted its first monthly budget surplus of fiscal 1990 in January, but the federal deficit after four months still totaled nearly 60 percent of the amount permitted for the entire year. Despite January's $9.92 billion surplus, the deficit for the first four months of the fiscal year totaled $59.78 billion, the Treasury said Thursday. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law limits the fiscal 1990 imbalance to $100 billion. The deficit last year was $152.1 billion. The 1990 deficit through January was 7.7 percent lower than that for the first four months of fiscal 1989. January's surplus contrasted with a $14.6 billion imbalance during December. Much of the surplus was due to a surge in revenue from individual income tax collections. However, the surplus also was inflated artificially by S&L bailout borrowing. The Treasury reported that individual tax receipts in January totaled $56.04 billion, up 50 percent from December collections. Individual income tax receipts are expected to remain high through the April 15 deadline for filing 1989 returns. Receipts were inflated in January by $5 billion borrowed through a special off-budget agency called the Resolution Funding Corp. Normally, government borrowing does not count as revenue. Overall receipts totaled $99.54 billion in January, up 11.5 percent from January 1989. Outlays were $89.62 billion, a 3.6 percent increase over the same month a year ago. The deficit is the difference between revenue and spending. So far this fiscal year, receipts totaled $328.3 billion, up 5.6 percent from the first four months of fiscal 1989. Outlays totaled $388.1 billion, up 3.3 percent from the October-January period of fiscal 1989. As usual, the biggest spending categores were for the military, Social Security and other programs in the Department of Health and Human Services and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $21.1 billion in January and $92.6 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $286.8 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $19 billion last month and $78.5 billion for the year. It is projected to total $224.6 billion for the year. Other HHS programs, including Medicare and Medicaid, totaled $16.2 billion in January and 59.7 for the year. It is projected to total $191.2 billion for the year. Interest on the national debt totaled $16.8 billion in January and $94.4 billion for the year. It is projected to total $254.9 billion for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Who Was Joint Chiefs' Chairman in 1985? Don't Ask Reagan
With AM-Reagan-Poindexter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: During his videotaped deposition, former President Reagan had trouble recalling who was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in 1985. Asked about a 1985 report on a Central American trip made by Army Gen. John Vessey, Reagan was asked to explain who Vessey was. ``Oh dear,'' Reagan said. ``I could ask for help here. The name I know is very familiar.'' Richard Beckler, defense attorney for Reagan's former national security adviser John M. Poindexter, offered a hint, telling the former president the memo ``is in connection with a trip by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.'' ``Well, that _ I don't _ I don't think this was my military aide, but obviously he was in a positioin to do this if he was the chief of staff,'' Reagan replied. Vessey was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from June 1982 to September 1985. After reading the report, Reagan determined that the memo was from Vessey to then-Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger about discussions with Honduran officials.

DOC.HEAD: East Proposes Reduced Armed Forces in United Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling to Hoffmann thruout and adds 2 grafs with report on Modrow. Restores dropped word in 10th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The two Germanys should reduce their combined military by two-thirds when they unite, and some U.S. and Soviet soldiers should remain during the unification process, the East German defense minister said Thursday. Adm. Theodor Hoffmann said the armed forces should be purely defensive and both states should remain in their respective alliances until they are reunited under a new European security system. West Germany belongs to NATO and East Germany is in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. About 380,000 Soviet soldiers are stationed in East Germany and NATO has more than 300,000 in West Germany, including about 250,000 Americans. Hoffmann said a joint German military should be reduced to about 300,000 men initially, and later to 150,000-200,000. All three services _ army, navy and air force _ should be retained because all are essential to defense, he told a news conference. Gen. Hans Deim, East Germany's delegate to Vienna talks on reduction of conventional forces, told the reporters anything over 300,000 men ``would cause security concerns of our neighbors, especially France and Poland.'' West Germany has 490,000 military personnel and East Germany says its armed forces have shrunk from 170,000 men to 100,000 in recent months. Until a new European system supplants NATO and the Warsaw Pact, Hoffman said, U.S. and Soviet soldiers should remain on German territory ``even if this becomes symbolic at a certain time.'' The United States and Soviet Union have agreed to reduce their troop strength in central Europe to 195,000 each. Most of the reductions will be made in Germany. Keeping some U.S. and Soviet troops until unification under a new security system would preserve stability in Europe, Hoffmann said, and described fears of a hasty union as justified. ``Although unification is unstoppable, it is going faster than the process of uniting all of Europe'' and Europeans have ``legitimate security concerns'' about it, the defense minister said. ``Our neighbors have had bitter experiences with a united Germany,'' he added, recalling the two world wars of this century. Talks with the West German military on merging forces could begin soon after East Germany's first free elections are held March 18 and a new government is formed, Hoffmann said. The victorious World War II Allies _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ have agreed on a two-stage plan for reunification. After talks between the Germanys on merging their political, economic and legal systems, the four powers are to join them for discussions of the international ramifications. Some Europeans worry about the formula, called ``two plus four'' and Poland wants a peace treaty guaranteeing its borders. On Thursday, Britain expressed support for the Polish demand. Poland also has demanded a role in the ``two plus four'' talks, and on Thursday, government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer repeated East Germany's agreement. One-third of what is now Poland belonged to Germany before World War II and the Poles are concerned about possible German territorial claims. In West Germany, ZDF television quoted government spokesman Dieter Vogel as saying only the government of a united Germany could give Poland a guarantee of its borders. He said Poland would be consulted during the ``two plus four'' negotiations. Hoffmann explained the East German military proposals just before Helmut Kohl, the West German chancellor, visits the United States for weekend talks with President Bush on reunification. Moscow insists that a united Germany be neutral, but the United States and the Western allies want it in NATO. West German officials have proposed membership in the Western alliance, with no NATO troops stationed in what now is East Germany. The East Germans announced plans Thursday for a law that would permit broad private ownership of industry and allow former owners to regain companies nationalized by the Communist government ousted last year. It reassured citizens there would be no food prices increases before the elections and said emergency action was being taken to ensure adequate supplies. Manfred Flegel, minister of trade and supply, said the announcement of plans to abolish food subsidies had caused a fourfold increase in the demand for staples. Sueddeutsche Zeitung, a West German newspaper, said Premier Hans Modrow would not run in the East German election but Andre Brie, campaign manager for the re-named Communist Party, said no decision had been made. Modrow is a reform-minded Communist who became premier in December. East Germany's Communists now call themselves the Party of Democratic Socialism.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Physicians to Help the Poor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2 grafs of color for 13th graf pvs, For his
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised Thursday to help find ways ``to restore common sense and fairness'' to the medical malpractice system, and urged physicians to provide more free care for the needy. Bush made the twin promise and appeal in a speech at the centennial celebration of one of America's premier medical schools, the Johns Hopkins University. Despite devoting more than 11 percent of its Gross National Product to health care _ the biggest share of any country _ ``American medicine still faces unprecedented problems,'' Bush said. He enumerated some of the maladies: medical malpractice, the plight of the 37 million Americans with no health insurance, the AIDS epidemic, drug addiction, an aging population and other conditions with ``staggering'' costs. Despite spending $600 billion a year on health care, the United States trails other industrialized countries in life expectancy and ranks 22nd in the developed world in infant mortality, the president said. Bush noted that he had instructed Health Secretary Louis Sullivan ``to lead a Domestic Policy Council review of options on the accessibility, cost and quality of America's health-care system. ``This administration is committed to health-care policies that improve health-care quality while restraining costs,'' said Bush. Some faculty and students were staging a protest against Bush's being awarded an honorary doctorate of human letters from Hopkins. Several hundred students and others gathered outside the hall where bush was speaking to protest the honorary degree. They chanted ``Health Not Stealth,'' and ``George Bush Go Away.'' David Dafashay, a 19-year-old sophomore from Williamsburg, Va., carried a sign reading, ``Dr. Bush? Get Real.'' ``He spends no money on housing for the poor and no money on a national health-care plan. ... It's ridiculous,'' Dafashay said. On Wednesday, Dr. Philip Zieve, chief physician of the Francis Scott Key Medical Center, charged the Bush administration with paying ``lip service'' to human needs while doing ``almost nothing to deal with the problems of homelessness and very little to deal with the problems of AIDS.'' Inside, Bush was joined on stage by more than two dozen eminent scientists also honored by the university, including two Nobel Prize winners. He joked that he didn't understand half the words in their citations, but felt like the youth who put a rope around his mongrel and brought him to a pet show at Madison Square Garden. The lad didn't expect to win, Bush said, but knew he'd be in some ``fine company.'' As for his administration's efforts to make ``better, more affordable health care ... more accessible,'' he said that heightened efforts to reduce infant mortality and expanded Medicaid eligibility for women and infants ``are just two of the steps we are taking to help.'' He said his administration is also proposing the largest biomedical research budget and the largest overall research budget in U.S. history. Bush has proposed a $7.9 billion budget for the next fiscal year for the National Institutes of Health, a $300 million increase over this year. ``To keep American medicine the best in the world, individual health care professionals and institutions must make our medical system responsive and responsible,'' said Bush, urging the physicians to apply ``fiscal discipline'' to their own rising fees. ``And I ask you, today, to avoid the understandable urge to practice `defensive medicine' where doctors fearing litigation too often dictate treatment that is unnecessary,'' he said. ``We've got to restore common sense and fairness to America's medical malpractice system,'' Bush said. ``I have directed the Domestic Policy Council to determine steps the federal government can take to help alleviate this serious situation.'' He said Americans must ``remember a simple truth: Not every unfortunate medical outcome is the result of poor medicine. You cannot make life risk-free.'' Bush said the fear of malpractice ``has not only hurt medical innovation and treatment. It's also hurt medical volunteerism.'' He reminded his audience, ``Many doctors used to give a day a week to the needy. And I'm convinced that, if not for the liability issue, many more would donate time today.'' He said the medical community has a special responsibility ``to reach out to those most in need.'' Hopkins receives more federal research money than any other university, in excess of $500 million a year, including $175 million for biomedical research alone.

DOC.HEAD: Most in Congress Oppose Bush's Proposed Medicare Cuts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposal to slow the growth of Medicare by $5.5 billion next year would hit hospitals too hard and should be rejected, according to letters released Thursday signed by a majority of the House and Senate. The overwhelming opposition means that the single biggest piece of deficit reduction in the president's fiscal 1991 budget is in serious jeopardy. The protest letters were not much of a surprise. Congress has been reluctant in recent years to make deep cuts in Medicare, which helps 33 million elderly and disabled people pay hospital and doctors' bills. Signed by members of both parties and sent to the House and Senate budget committees, the two letters complained that hospitals are already under financial pressures. ``Cuts in the Medicare program of the magnitude that the president is proposing can only make the situation worse and will pose a real threat to health care for the elderly and disabled,'' said a letter to Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., signed by 51 senators. A similar letter from 227 of the 435 House members to House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said Bush's plan ``threatens to diminish both access to and quality of care.'' Medicare is one of the fastest-growing federal programs. It is expected to cost $104 billion this year _ about one-twelfth of the entire federal budget _ and grow to $183 billion by 1995. In recent years, lawmakers searching for ways to reduce the budget deficit have responded to pressures from hospitals, doctors and elderly constituents and been reluctant to make deep Medicare cuts. Last year, Bush proposed restraining Medicare spending by $5 billion. Congress eventually approved $2.8 billion in savings. Of the $37 billion in deficit cuts the president proposed in the 1991 budget he released last month, the largest piece was the $5.5 billion in reduced Medicare spending.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Says Being Followed By Secret Police; Police Outside Gov't Offices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Calciu in second reference is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A priest forced into exile by Nicolae Ceausescu said Thursday he is being followed by agents of the ousted dictator's Securitate secret police, which the new government has said it disbanded. Dozens of uniformed police guarded government headquarters Thursday, a day before the ruling Provisional Council of National Unity was to discuss a proposed decree giving the military more power to control demonstrations. A double row of soldiers in green uniforms formed a semicircle around the muddy front lawn and signs told pedestrians not to loiter. Fifteen armored personnel carriers were parked in front of the building. An anti-government crowd stormed and ransacked the headquarters Sunday while soldiers stood aside. They said they had orders not to shoot at protesters. Rumors had circulated that citizens unhappy with the interim government would protest in Victory Square, outside the headquarters, to mark two months since Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22 after 24 years in power. He was executed three days later. State television broadcast scenes of street protests that helped bring down the Communist dictator. More than 400 people demonstrated Thursday in Timisoara, the western city where the revolt began, for more democracy and closer ties with Western Europe, a participant reported. He said demonstrators also condemned the pace of the investigation into the assault by security forces on unarmed protesters in Timisoara that started the uprising. Police confirmed a demonstration had taken place but would not give details. The Rev. Gheorghe Calciu Dumitreasa, 64, a Romanian Orthodox priest and human rights activist, told a news conference he had been ``followed around by agents of the Securitate,'' Ceausescu's hated secret police. He accused the National Salvation Front, which dominates the ruling Provisional Council of National Unity, of trying to impede his humanitarian mission ``because they are not democratic and still oppress the people.'' ``On Monday, the Front tried to lie about my visit here, saying I was here for political reasons,'' he said. Calciu accused the Front of spreading the ``disinformation'' that a Mass he intends to celebrate Friday in Bucharest's central University Square on Friday ``is in fact a political demonstration.'' ``The Front is afraid because they are not honest men; otherwise I wouldn't be watched by the Securitate,'' he said. Calciu, spiritual leader of the Romanian World Congress and a priest at Holy Cross Church in Alexandria, Va., also recommended a purge of ``compromised religious authorities ... to give the church back its dignity.'' His reference was to clerics who collaborated with Ceausescu, who discouraged religious practice. Calciu was imprisoned by Communist regimes for 21 years, in 1948-64 and 1979-84, then expelled in 1985. He said he intends to return to Romania permanently. The provisional government said recently it had disbanded the Securitate. In Washington, Minister of State Dumitru Mazilu of Romania said he was seeking $500 million in aid from the United States, in addition to gifts of food. During his recent trip to Romania, Secretary of State James A. Baker III offered $80 million, including 500,000 tons of feed grain and 7,500 tons of butter. Mazilu said that was ``so small for our desperate situation; we need much more.'' Also Thursday, a dispatch from the official news agency Rompres denied that the killing Feb. 8 in Rosiori village of a member of the National Peasants Party was politically motivated. On Wednesday, the party spokesman in Bucharest said Vasile Velescu, a farmer, was the victim of a political murder. Rompres quoted police and a local prosecutor as saying Velescu was beaten to death ``with fists and feet'' by two young men with whom he had quarreled. Representatives of 12 ethnic minorities in Romania met with Vice President Carol Koraly to ask for guarantees of minority rights and reopening of schools in the Turkish, Serbian and Bulgarian languages. Koraly described the meeting as positive, but gave no details.

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes In Southeast; Flood Threat Across East, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Tornados touched down Thursday in Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia as a powerful storm surged through the Southeast. Heavy rain threatened floods from Florida to Michigan. The twisters and accompanying thunderstorms damaged dozens of homes and left at least 15 people injured. The first two tornadoes touched down just after midnight in Pass Christian, Miss., on the Gulf Coast about 25 miles west of Biloxi. At least 30 homes were damaged, but no injuries were reported. Over the next several hours, heavy rain flooded two dozen homes and washed out a bridge in Hattiesburg, Miss., forcing the closure of about 40 streets. A tornado touched down just before dawn at Opp, Ala., injuring about 10 people and toppling trees and power lines throughout the town. As the storm moved northeastward, it left a path of destruction across several rural Alabama counties. Altogether, at least 15 people were injured in Alabama. Shortly after 9 a.m., a tornado touched down at Columbus, Ga. There were no reports of injuries or major damage. Thunderstorm winds were clocked at 74 mph at Auburn, Ala., and 76 mph at Dothan. There were almost two dozen reports of damage from thunderstorm wind gusts across east central and southeast Alabama and west-central and northern Georgia. Heavy rains threatened floods elsewhere. Flood watches were posted for the southern half of lower Michigan and northern Indiana, as well as the mountains and foothills of North Carolina, northern Georgia, eastern Alabama and northwest Florida. Flood watches were also out for the northern third of Ohio, northwestern South Carolina, southern Vermont and portions of upper New York state. Two inches of rain fell at Fort Wayne, Ind., early Thursday, causing several streams in northeastern Indiana to overflow their banks. At noon, rainshowers and occasional thunderstorms extended from Florida, Georgia and Alabama into western South Carolina and North Carolina. Rain also reached across western and central Virginia, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, New York, Ohio, southern lower Michigan, Indiana, Illinois and from Missouri and southeast Kansas through Oklahoma. Snow was falling over northern lower Michigan, southern Wisconsin and east-central Iowa. Fog with occasional rain extended across the Pacific Northwest. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at noon included 1.9 inches at Montgomery, Ala., 1.66 inches at Fort Wayne, Ind., 1.46 inches at Toledo, Ohio, 1.31 inches at Detroit and 1.25 inches at Tallahassee, Fla. In the Priblof Islands of Alaska, winds were expected to drive the wind chill factor down to 40 below zero overnight. The low temperature for the nation Thursday morning was 1 degree above zero at Gunnison, Colo. High temperature records for the date were broken or tied in Augusta, Ga., where it was 79, Boston (63), Concord, N.H. (57), Portland, Maine (53) and Warmick, R.I. (61).

DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS 1 graf to RESTORE dropped matter
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from former President Ronald Reagan's testimony as a defense witness in the Iran-Contra trial of his former national security adviser, John M. Poindexter: The testimony begins with direct examination by Poindexter's lawyer, Richard W. Beckler.

Q. ... Well, I take it there came a time _ well, the first time, on Nov. 13th (1986), you made an address to the nation. This is about the Iranian missile project. A. Yes. To _ to explain that we were not doing business with Khomeini. Quite the contrary. We were keeping it very secret from him what we were doing. Q. Then you also about six days later, on November 19th ... you again went before the American public and had a press conference on that same subject, six days later? A. ... In my memory, there was a _ there was a second time, and that was when the attorney general had located a paper which revealed that there had been more money than the twelve million two (hundred thousand dollars) that we had received, and that it had been deposited in a Swiss bank account, and that that account had been used in some way by people helping the Contras. ... Q. ... between the Nov. 13th and the Nov. 19th addresses that you made to the nation, did you receive information from Admiral Poindexter that enabled you to make those presentations to the public? A. I don't recall. Q. ... The day before that, November 12th, you attended a meeting with congressional leaders, and we understand that that was first to tell Congress what was going on, so to speak, before you went to the public on that situation. Do you have any recollection of that meeting with Congress? A. I know that someplace in there there were two meetings, depending on the two various times, that we corrected the story, that I did meet with the congressional leadership, members of both parties. Q. Do you recall just _ I am not asking you to be at all specific. But do you recall generally what was discussed with Congress at that meeting on November 12th? A. Well, it was mainly my explaining to them what the situation was and how it had come about. ... Q.
