Do you recall at that meeting whether or not you mentioned to the congressional leaders anything about this Hawk missile shipment that had taken place back in the previous November of 1985? A. No. I don't recall ever reporting that to anyone. ... Q. Mr. President, at some point, do you recall Admiral Poindexter _ this is now in November of 1986. Do you remember Admiral Poindexter telling you that people in the White House were having trouble remembering _ or some of those events in 1985 on the Hawk missile shipment, there were differing recollections of the events? A. No. I don't recall hearing that. Q. Do you recall in 1986 meeting at all with (Attorney General Edwin) Meese and asking him if he can lend a hand in straightening out the recollections of various people? A. No. My memory of Mr. Meese's participation was when, after all of that thing had broken, that he was the one who located a piece of paper in some office that indicated that there was additional money. And that was _ his participation was as attorney general in case there was something untoward that was waiting there to haunt us. And that was where I got the knowledge about the extra money, and that is the only thing that I remember about from him. Q. ... Do you recall Secretary of State Shultz coming to you in November of 1986 _ this is in that Nov. 19th-Nov. 20th time frame of 1986 _ and telling you about a Hawk missile shipment that took place back in December of _ excuse me _ November of 1985? A. I don't recall that. Q. Now, did there come a time, Mr. President, in 1984 _ early 1984 _ when it looked like funds that Congress had provided for Contra support were running out? Do you recall that time frame? A. Yes. Q. Do you recall what your instructions were to your top people at that time as to what ought to be done about this? A. Yes. My instructions were that whatever we did in trying to maintain the existence of the Contras should be done within the law. I emphasized that at every time. And I knew that there were groups of citizens who were on the side of the Contras and who were soliciting funds to be of help to the Contras. And I told them that maybe some of these citizens, these people, wouldn't know who to contact or how to contact the proper people to deliver the aid that they had raised for them. And that I did not believe it was violating the law if our people who knew, had the answer to those questions, would tell them, inform them as to how they could make contact. But, again, I emphasized no solicitation. We were not going to go out and try to solicit groups to do this. And I suggested at the time that it wouldn't be against the law if we had an opportunity to mention to some of our democratic allies that they should have the same interest that we had with regard to the freedom fighters. But, again, as I say, always emphasized within the law. ... But from the very beginning we all had to battle and fight to get any funding from Congress for the Freedom Fighters, and finally then they shut it off entirely.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Remain Without Tap Water
DOC.TEXT: Officials in central France said Thursday bacteria had been cleared from drinking drinking water, but authorities elsewhere warned pregnant women of nitrate pollution. Health officials in the eastern city of Belfort told 20,000 residents to continue drinking bottled water or to add chlorine to tap water. About 100,000 residents of the region were told on Wednesday not to drink tap water because bacteria resulting from last week's heavy rains and flooding clouded the water. Officials now say the water should be safe to drink by Saturday. The problems have raised new worries about water pollution in France and the national environment minister has criticized farmers for their use of fertilizers. In central France, authorities at Chateauroux and Delos told 60,000 people a bacterial infestation had been cleared and lifted a five-day ban on drinking tap water. Warnings were posted for pregnant women not to drink tap water laced with dangerous levels of nitrates in 10 communities in the western Maine-et-Loire region and 21 communities in the southern Haute Garonne region. Regional authorities often warn ailing residents of the rural areas of western France to avoid the water, which is polluted with nitrates from fertilizers. The communities are suffering from the water contamination a week after Source Perrier SA issued its worldwide recall of the popular Perrier sparkling water. Traces of the cancer-causing chemical benzene, which occur naturally in the underground spring, were found in some bottles. On Wednesday, another mineral-water bottler, the Societe Generale des Eaux Minerale de Vittel, announced it would withdraw 1 million to 2 million bottles of its domestically consumed Hepar water from the shelves. Supplies of Hepar were contaminated Jan. 10-11 when water sitting in an aboveground tank was contaminated by a filter clogged with alkane, a hydrocarbon, Director Alain Dorfner said. On Thursday, the director of the Centres Leclerc supermarket chain said he intends to drill for spring water in Brittany in western France and offer it free to citizens. ``Everything is ready for this,'' said Edouard Leclerc. The issue took on added urgency Tuesday when Environment Minister Brice Lalonde declared that farming practices were ``a black point'' on French efforts to keep water clean. Representatives of France's politically powerful farmers called his statement a ``brutal'' attack, but said agricultural interests were willing to work with the government to protect the quality of water.

DOC.HEAD: Top Winners at 32nd Grammys Survived Years of Struggle for Attention
DOC.TEXT: Bonnie Raitt toiled at the blues for nearly two decades before winning armfuls of Grammys, and ``Wind Beneath My Wings'' lay around since 1982 before winning record and song of the year for Bette Midler. Miss Raitt's triumph and the victory of Miss Midler's pop version of an often-recorded country tune at the 32nd annual Grammy Awards spotlighted the quirky nature of the rules and reflexes of the Recording Academy. Now 40, Miss Raitt put out nine albums and was unsuccessfully nominated for Grammys several times before she released ``Nick of Time'' last year. And rather than a career peak, the LP was a comeback from a mid-'80s plunge that included being dropped by her label, Warner Bros., in 1983. Backstage at the Shrine Auditorium after collecting her fourth Grammy Wednesday night, Miss Raitt was the victorious underdog. ``I feel like the guy that just beat Mike Tyson,'' she said. ``The critics and peers said finally she made a great record.'' Her Grammys were for album of the year _ shared with producer Don Was _ best female pop vocal for the LP's title track, best female rock vocal for the album, and best traditional blues recording for her collaboration with John Lee Hooker on the ``I'm in the Mood'' track from his ``The Healer'' album. ``It means those of us that love R&B are going to get a chance again,'' Miss Raitt told fans in the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. The road to acclaim for ``Wind Beneath My Wings,'' recorded by Miss Midler for the movie ``Beaches,'' was almost as long. Writers Larry Henley and Jeff Silbar penned the song in 1982 and it was recorded first by singer Gary Morris. ``Well, I thought that's pretty obscure, maybe nobody bought that record,'' Miss Midler said backstage. ``And then it turned out after I recorded it that like a hundred people had recorded this song and it had never crossed over.'' Others who tried it before Miss Midler included Willie Nelson, B.J. Thomas, Perry Como, Ray Price, Judy Collins and Sheena Easton. In ``Beaches'' the song underscored the theme of lifelong friendship between two women, one of whom dies. ``It's the biggest record of my career,'' she said. ``I had a platinum record (1 million units) on `The Rose' but this went double platinum.'' Though the song is old, the Academy's annual awards are for actual recordings released in an eligibility period which this time extended from Oct. 1, 1988, to Sept. 30, 1989. Midler's version was released Jan. 13, 1989. Song of the year Grammys went to writers Henley and Silbar. Miss Midler and longtime producer Arif Mardin shared the record of the year glory. ``I think one of the most rewarding things about the song is that we got tremendous mail from people and there was a lot of inspirational letters like `I was quarreling with my wife, I wanted divorce, we make up after hearing this song,''' Mardin said. The 3{-hour show was viewed in 17.4 million households, according to overnight Nielsen ratings. That was an increase of 3 million households over last year's show, which at 14.4 million households had the lowest viewership since only 11.2 million watched in 1975. However, the number of viewers set no records. Wednesday's show had a Nielsen rating of 18.9 percent of the nation's 92.1 million television homes. The 1984 show, when Michael Jackson's ``Thriller'' won album of the year, had a rating of 30.8 and was viewed in 25.8 million households, Nielsen said. Other highlights of the Grammys included a best new artist honor for Milli Vanilli. In the R&B category Soul II Soul won group performance for the ``Back to Life'' single and best instrumental for ``African Dance.'' Bobby Brown won male vocal for his ``Every Little Step'' single and Anita Baker won female vocal for the ``Giving You The Best That I Got'' LP. Miles Davis received a lifetime achievement award and Grammys for best jazz solo instrumental and big band jazz instrumental for his ``Aura'' LP. Composer-arranger David Grusin also came out a big winner, with three awards for his theatrical movie music. Michael Bolton's plaintive single ``How Am I Supposed To Live Without You,'' won male pop vocal, and the tender love ballad ``Don't Know Much,'' by Linda Ronstadt and Aaron Neville, won duo pop performance. Don Henley, who started the evening with four nominations, won only the male rock vocal performance for his ``The End of the Innocence'' album. ``Traveling Wilburys Volume One,'' the effort of the late Roy Orbison, Jeff Lynne, Tom Petty, Bob Dylan and George Harrison, earned only the rock group vocal performance Grammy. Living Colour's single ``Cult of Personality'' won hard rock performance and Metallica's single ``One'' earned best metal performance. ``Bust A Move'' by Young M.C. was the best rap performance. The country vocal collaboration Grammy went to Hank Williams Jr. and his late father for the time-defying duet on ``There's A Tear in My Beer,'' in which the younger Williams' voice was dubbed on an old recording by his dad. Canadian country singer k.d. lang won best female vocal performance in that category for her LP ``Absolute Torch and Twang.''

DOC.HEAD: Panel Approves Black Revolutionary Statue For Mall
DOC.TEXT: A foundation honoring Black History Month won initial approval Thursday for the design of a memorial to black Americans who participated in the American Revolution. The memorial, which would be the first on the Washington Mall dedicated to blacks, honors some 5,000 soldiers and freedom-seekers who have received relatively little recognition from historians. ``It was the beginning of the struggle for freedom in America,'' said Maurice Barboza, a Plainville, Conn., native and president of The Patriots Foundation, the group promoting the memorial proposal. ``The Declaration of Independence galvanized the struggle for freedom in America.'' The National Capital Memorial Commission on Thursday unanimously approved the design for the memorial, which is to be located on the Mall near the reflecting pool, midway between the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument and not far from the Vietnam War Memorial. Although the memorial will refer only to the Revolutionary War, it will serve as a reminder, Barboza said, of the contribution blacks made in the Civil War and the Vietnam War. Unveiled for the first time in model form Thursday, the memorial consists of 13 figures _ one for each of the original colonies _ in various roles black Americans played during the Revolution. The figures would be made of bronze and placed on grnite pedestals. The figures would include soldiers and civilians, men, women and children. Barboza said the foundation must raise $4 million and receive approvals from two more federal boards _ the Fine Arts Commission and the National Capital Planning Commission _ by October 1991 or forfeit the land on the Mall.

DOC.HEAD: US Sets Stiffer Terms For Dealing With Sandinistas If They Win Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First 3 grafs recast, picking up 4th graf pvs, The secretary
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III set tough terms Thursday for normalizing U.S. relations with Nicaragua if the Sandinista government wins Sunday's election and reserved the right to determine if the contest is fair. Baker's testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee means U.S. hostility toward the Nicaraguan government would not automatically end if the Sandinistas triumph at the polls. He said the United States would insist on ``a substantial period of good behavior,''including an end to support for leftist insurgents in neighboring El Salvador and reconciliation with domestic political opponents _ before ending economic sanctions and restoring full diplomatic relations. The secretary accused the government of President Daniel Ortega of intimidating opponents and poll watchers besides denying visas to congressional observers. The leading opposition group _ the United National Opposition, headed by Violeta Chamorro _ has received U.S. aid in its bid to govern the country. Baker said that the Unites States is ``prepared to recognize a government that wins a free election.'' But he then set conditions that must be met for the restoration of normal relations and asserted U.S. authority to judge the elections. ``Before we talk about normalizing relations (if Ortega is re-elected), ... we must see a sustained period of good behavior. ``The government of the United States must be satisfied that there will continue to be open political space in Nicaragua. Then we can consider beginning to look at how we might normalize'' relations, including lifting the trade sanctions. Answering a question from Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., Baker said, ``It seems to me that if you believe in democracy you believe in respecting the results of a free and fair election.'' But he added, ``The United States must reserve the right to make the judgment (as to) whether the election is free and fair.'' Observer groups, including one led by former President Carter and another sponsored by the United Nations, will assess the election and ``arrive at reasoned judgments'' about its fairness, the secretary said. ``But, in light of experience, the United States needs to make its own judgment.'' The Nicaraguan government, in denying visas to congressional observers appointed by President Bush, argued that the observers could not be objective because the United States is providing money to the Chamorro campaign. While the United States has never broken relations and maintains an embassy in Managua, it is staffed by only a handful of American diplomats. The last U.S. ambassador was expelled in July 1988. The Reagan administration provided military aid to the Contra rebels until Congress suspended it in February 1988. The Bush administration is using economic and diplomatic pressures against the Sandinistas, while holding to a trade embargo imposed in 1985. In an hour of testimony before the House committee, Baker also: _Credited the Chinese government with freeing some political prisoners, toning down its anti-U.S. rhetoric and showing interest in receiving Peace Corps volunteers. _Said the administration would consider holding negotiations to withdraw short-range nuclear weapons from Western Europe if NATO and the Warsaw Pact conclude a treaty to reduce troops and conventional arms. The treaty, now in negotiations in Vienna, would leave up to 225,000 American soldiers in Western Europe and 195,000 Soviet troops on foreign soil. _Showed impatience with a lack of progress in starting negotiations between Israel and Palestinian Arabs. Baker, who meets on Friday at the State Department with Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, said: ``We need action. We have done a lot of talking; the time for action is coming very close.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Albanians Strike, Boycott Schools
DOC.TEXT: Police, soldiers and tanks patrolled Kosovo on Thursday, a day of strikes and school boycotts by ethnic Albanians to protest alleged human rights violations in the poor southern province. Passive resistance continued despite harsh measures by federal authorities, who imposed a nighttime curfew Wednesday and deployed army units in an effort to quell unrest. At least 28 ethnic Albanians have been killed in outbursts of violence over the past month between police and residents demanding more autonomy for the province, which adjoins Albania and is Yugoslavia's poorest region. The same number were reported killed a year ago when Serbia made constitutional changes giving it nearly complete control over Kosovo, which had been an autonomous province within the Serbian republic. Ethnic Albanians, most of whom are Moslems, make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people. Outnumbered Slavs, predominantly Christian, claim they are harassed by the majority. No large protests were reported Thursday, but thousands of ethnic Albanians continued strikes and school boycotts to protest the state of virtual martial law. A joint statement by the seven unofficial organizations of ethnic Albanians issued in Pristina, the provincial capital, denounced alleged ``police brutality.'' ``Police are storming schools, hospitals, houses, churches and mosques where they intimidate, loot and beat up people,'' it said. The charges could not be confirmed. The statement asked ethnic Albanians to stop street protests ```because it would lead to more repression'' by the authorities, and appealed for a discussion of solutions by ``all democratic forces in Serbia.'' Serbian authorities and the Serbs in Kosovo have rejected dialogue with ethnic Albanian groups, describing their leaders as ``hostile elements'' who should be jailed. Serbia says it needs control of the province to prevent persecution of the Slavic minority. They say Albanian ``terrorists and separatists'' want to secede from Yugoslavia and make Kosovo part of Albania. Police in bulletproof vests patrolled towns in the province Thursday, aided by army tanks and armored vihicles. In Belgrade, the federal government said the measures taken in the province ``have as their purpose the creation of the necessary preconditions to enable'' talks to begin on ``a political solution of the problems in Kosovo,'' the official news agency Tanjug reported. ``Such a dialogue is indispensable in order to thwart efforts of separatist forces'' a government statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Hurt as Tornadoes, High Winds Rage Across South
DOC.TEXT: A powerful storm rose out of the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday and surged through the South, spinning off tornadoes that ripped apart homes, toppled trees and injured dozens of people. The tornadoes touched down along the Gulf Coast of Mississippi and in several places in rural Alabama. A powerful blast of wind also swept through Columbus, Ga., but weather officials were uncertain whether it was a tornado. Heavy thunderstorms or rainshowers also were reported from Florida to Michigan, posing a threat of floods in some places. The wet weather was the result of low pressure that was pulling moisture northward out of the Gulf. The first two tornadoes were reported shortly after midnight in the Gulf Coast town of Pass Christian, Miss., where at least 30 homes were damaged, the National Weather Service said. The storm drove northeastward during the night and a tornado touched down just before dawn in Opp, Ala., damaging more than 40 homes and two businesses, and destroying two mobile homes. ``It shook our whole building when it came through, and we're in a concrete building,'' said Robert Booth, a reporter with radio station WOPP. The twister knocked out power, covered streets with the mangled remains of trees and blew out windows. Ten people were injured, one seriously enough to be hospitalized. Later tornadoes were reported in Pike and Barbour counties, to the northwest of Opp. Three people were critically injured in Pike County, where the twister hit about 10 miles south of the town of Troy. It ripped apart three mobile homes and deposited a pickup truck in a tree. A spokeswoman at Edge Regional Medical Center in Troy said two women, ages 86 and 44, and a 67-year-old man were listed in critical condition. At South Macon High School in Alabama's Macon County, secretary Portia Johnson said 11 girls suffered cuts and scrapes when the ceiling collapsed in a girl's restroom about 7:30 a.m. In Auburn, an elementary school was closed after two trees crashed into the building. The high winds also leveled a U.S. Department of Agriculture barn and tore part of the roof off the campus police station at Auburn University. In Columbus, Ga., which is just across the border from Alabama, the storm struck with tornado-like winds shortly after 9 a.m. The storm ripped the roof off a service station, knocked out power and phone service in parts of the downtown area and injured two people, who were treated for lacerations and released from the Medical Center, officials said. Wind damage also was reported in LaGrange, Ga., where two mobile homes were destroyed and about eight other homes were damaged. Trees also were uprooted, but no injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Break Up Anti-Government Protests With Tear Gas, Clubs
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers used tear gas and clubs to disperse hundreds of student deomonstrators Thursday in what has become the largest outbreak of anti-government protest in years. The government and the state-run news media have been silent about the protests, which began Monday when students angered by cuts in water and power service demanded democracy and the resignation of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. At one point, Thursday's protesters assembled outside the state television offices in suburban Cocody, shouting: ``Tell the truth! Tell the truth!'' They fled when soldiers and police attacked them with truncheons. Students said they tried to march on the presidential offices, but police and soldiers blocked them less than a mile from the university. Earlier in the day, police attacked more than 300 students as they protested peacefully at the state university campus in Cocody, singing ``Greetings, Land of Hope,'' the national anthem. A local resident said police and soldiers also fired tear gas at students who fled and tried to continue the demonstration. Armed police in riot helmets sealed off the campus, but lifted the blockade later the campus appeared calm. Students said many had been injured since Monday. Police beat students who set two cars ablaze Monday night, and on Tuesday officers charged students who smashed the windows of two buses. This pro-Western nation in West Africa, one of the continent's richest, is struggling with a recession that has brought unemployment, salary cuts and declining living standards. Houphouet-Boigny, officially 84 years old but believed to be in his 90s, has ruled Ivory Coast as a one-party state since independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Business, Administration Support National Product Liability Law
DOC.TEXT: Business executives and a Bush administration official said Thursday that a national product liability law is essential to U.S. competitiveness in the world market. ``If we are serious about addressing our nation's competitiveness, we must address the excessive burdens placed on American business by our current liability system,'' said Wendell Wilkie II, general counsel for the Commerce Department. A federal product liability law would make the rules for doing business ``clear, consistent, uniform and predictable,'' Wilkie said in testimony before the Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee. State laws ``are more burdensome and unpredictable than those in any of our other trading partners,'' he added. Senator Robert Kasten, R-Wis., author of a bill to establish a national law, said member nations of the European Economic Community already had adopted uniform product liability guidelines which would increase their advantage in global markets. ``We're going to be in a position very quickly in which Germany, France and England are going to have uniform laws while Wisconsin, Minnesota and Illinois are going to be further apart,'' Kasten said. Kasten's bill would create a uniform standard for imposing punitive damages in product liability lawsuits and estblish a two-year statute of limitations for most product liability claims. Claims by workers injured by durable goods such as factory machinery would have a 25-year statute of limitations. The measure would allow separate trials or settlements of punitive damages and compensatory damages and allow companies to pay damages in proportion to their responsibility for harm. Businessmen Howard Fark and Robert C. Holland said change was needed in the current system to stop the rapid rise in business insurance costs. Wilkie said a uniform law also would reduce ``transaction costs'' _ attorneys' fees, damage awards and other court costs _ associated with lawsuits involving potentially dangerous products. But Commerce Committee Chairman Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., blamed businesses for the rise in insurance and legal costs and challenged the need for federal intervention in product liability. Others, including Vincent L. McKusick, chief judge of the Maine Supreme Court, and Michael Box, an Alabama state representative, argued that the federal government should aid state enforcement instead of ``tinkering'' unnecessarily with state law. Hollings cited a 1989 congressional study that showed ``About half the plaintiffs' attorneys received no fee.'' The study by the General Accounting Office also found that most punitive damages are overturned on appeal, said Hollings, adding, ``this goes to the heart of transaction costs.'' The GAO reviewed court records of 305 product liability cases resolved in trials from 1983-85 in Arizona, Massachusetts, Missouri, North Dakota and South Carolina. Proponents acknowledge the Kasten bill might not directly reduce transaction costs but said the bill would encourage faster resolution of disputes because it requires that lawyers who refuse reasonable out-of court settlements must pay all attorneys' fees. Congress has attempted to develop a federal product liability law since the 1970s, and President Bush made it an administration legislative priority in his State of the Union address last month.

DOC.HEAD: State Trooper Says He was Told Tanker Captain was Drunk
DOC.TEXT: A state trooper who was summoned to the grounded Exxon Valdez to deal with an allegedly drunken skipper testified Thursday that when he arrived, Capt. Joseph Hazelwood didn't seem impaired. The trooper, Michael J. Fox, said at Hazelwood's criminal trial that Coast Guard officials told him ``the captain was drunk and they wanted me to take care of it.'' He assumed ``they needed help wrestling this drunk off the tanker.'' But when he arrived aboard a Coast Guard boat at the scene of the nation's worst oil spill, Fox said, the situation wasn't as he expected. ``When I got there I was expecting a brawl,'' Fox testified. ``But it was kind of quiet and dark and everyone was gazing out the windows.'' He said he asked Hazelwood what was the problem. It was then, he said, that Hazelwood referred to himself in the much-quoted comment, ``You're looking at it.'' The skipper didn't seem drunk or impaired in any way, the trooper testified. ``He had bloodshot eyes and was smoking cigarettes,'' Fox recalled. ``I didn't notice any alcohol. He had morning breath, bad breath. ... He seemed unimpaired.'' The 43-year-old Hazelwood of Huntington, N.Y., is charged in state court with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The Exxon Valdez leaked nearly 11 million gallons of Alaskan crude oil, which blackened hundreds of miles of rocky coastline and killed countless birds, fish and wildlife. Exxon has spent some $2 billion trying to clean up the mess. Also Thursday, a Coast Guard officer's testimony that he smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath was challenged on the basis of remarks the witness made earlier in a television interview. Jurors were shown a tape of a CBS interview by Connie Chung, who asked Lt. Cmdr. Thomas Falkenstein if he smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath shortly after the tanker grounded. ``I never talked to him face-to-face like we're talking. It was side-by-side and staring out at the pilot house across the deck. We were close, 2{ feet, and I smelled alcohol in and around the area,'' Falkenstein said on the television broadcast. Falkenstein testified in the trial that he detected alcohol on the skipper's breath. The prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Brent Cole, who has been trying to prove Hazelwood had been drinking, asked if there was anyone else present in the area when Falkenstein smelled liquor. He said there wasn't. Hazelwood's attorney, Michael Chalos, asked if the captain appeared impaired or intoxicated. ``That was the first time I had met Captain Hazelwood,'' said the witness. ``I saw no signs of impairment.'' Falkenstein, who is executive officer of the Coast Guard's marine safety office in Valdez, was questioned at length about a key issue _ whether the Exxon Valdez was required to have an officer on the bridge with a pilot's license for Prince William Sound. He said federal regulations required that a certified officer directly control the ship, but the regulations were eased twice after the opening of the Alaska pipeline in the late 1970s. Ultimately, they permitted a ship to cross the area without a licensed pilot if visibility was two miles or more, Falkenstein said. Hazelwood was the only officer on board with such a license when the accident occurred, and he wasn't on the bridge.

DOC.HEAD: European Doctors Freed by Rebel Group
DOC.TEXT: Sudanese guerrillas have released two European doctors who were kidnapped earlier this month and forced to treat rebels, a French relief agency said Thursday. After the freed doctors arrived Thursday at the airport in Nairobi, Kenya, the international group Doctors Without Borders suspended its aid programs in Sudan. ``Aid activities are becoming impossible and put the lives of our teams in danger,'' a statement released by the agency's Paris headquarters said. ``We have become targets.'' Talks had been under way for weeks between the rebels and the agency to win freedom for 28-year-old Martin Ruppert of the Netherlands and Christine van Haegenoth, 26, of Belgium. They were kidnapped Feb. 3 from their home in Malakal, a garrison city on the Nile about 370 miles south of Khartoum. They had been working on a long-term nutritional project. The agency statement did not say when or where they were released and did not mention their physical condition, but previous statements have said they were in good health. The statement said the agency's French and Belgian sections had withdrawn all their personnel, about 70 workers, from the African country, where southern rebels are fighting civil war against the government in Khartoum. Most personnel of the French section were withdrawn after unidentified attackers shot down a plane in December carrying two of its doctors, a French pilot and a Sudanese working for the United Nations. All aboard were killed. Workers in the Belgian section began leaving after the kidnapping.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Says No Need For U.S. Concern Over Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: The government repeated its pledge Thursday not to make nuclear weapons and told the United States it should not worry about France's agreement to sell a nuclear power plant to Pakistan. President Francois Mitterrand of France announced Wednesday he was lifting a 14-year-old ban on the sale of nuclear energy to Pakistan to allow the sale. The State Department criticized the decision to make the sale without requiring Pakistan to comply with international safeguards on its nuclear programs. A Pakistani Foreign Ministry spokesman repeated the government's oft-stated promise not to produce a nuclear weapon and told a news conference: ``The United States reaction to the French decision to sell Pakistan a nuclear power plant is not well-founded.'' Pakistan has not signed the International Non-Proliferation Treaty and says it will not do so without India, which also refuses to sign. The United States and several other nations have repeatedly expressed concern that Pakistan is close to making a nuclear weapon. Islamabad denies it. ``Pakistan is fully aware of the United States concerns about nuclear proliferation and it has reassured the world, time and again, that its nuclear program is entirely peaceful,'' said the Foreign Ministry spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``France is a sovereign state,'' he said in reply to a question of whether the United States or any other country could pressure Paris to renege on the deal. ``France will stand by the deal.'' In 1976, France reneged on a deal to sell Pakistan a nuclear reprocessing plant. Pakistani officials said Paris canceled that sale because of U.S. pressure. The new plant will be installed at Chashma, 120 miles southwest of Islamabad. No official cost was given, but it was believed to be about $1.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: California School Says It Gets Letter From Noriega
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega, writing to teen-age students from a Florida jail cell, claimed that thousands of innocent Panamanians were killed by the U.S. invaders of his country last December, school officials said. ``That was the Christian Christmas that the troops and government of your country gave to a small country of 2 million people,'' says a letter apparently signed by the deposed Panamanian leader. Written in Spanish on a single sheet of yellow legal paper, dated Dec. 31 and postmarked Miami, the letter condemns the United States ``for killing thousands of children, men, women, old people and people from the Army, innocents, in my country on Dec. 20.'' U.S. officials put casualties at 500. The letter was a response to a request from eighth-grade students at Suzanne Middle School in Walnut, 25 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. ``It's really wild for the kids. For the first time in their lives, they're in contact with someone in the news, so they're in shock, but they're starting to feel good about it,'' teacher Alan Haskvitz said Thursday. Haskvitz said he didn't attempt to authenticate the letter that arrived Tuesday, but he believes it is genuine because ``the tone of the letter ... sounds like him.'' Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. forces Jan. 3, is held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center In Dade County, Fla. His March 5 trial date on drug conspiracy charges has been delayed indefinitely. Calls to the jail and Noriega's attorneys to confirm he sent the letter weren't immediately returned Thursday. Defense attorneys were in Geneva conferring with the International Red Cross on Noriega's prisoner-of-war status. ``We are interested in getting your side of the story on the Panama invasion,'' the social studies class wrote. ``Would you please tell us what happened, how you plan to escape jail (sentence), how is the food and your family?'' The response was translated into English by student Patricia Garcia, 14, who also rendered the students' letter in Spanish, Haskvitz said. The letter thanked the students for their interest, defended Noriega's actions and complained about negative publicity he's received. ``The press of your country ... has misinformed and distorted the image of a nationalistic and patriotic leader who struggled, struggles and will struggle for the sovereignty of his country, Panama,'' the letter said. The letter said there are 1,000 prisoners of war, including civilians, under U.S. control. U.S. authorities said anyone detained by U.S. troops were either released or turned over to Panamanian authorities. Student Lisa Isomura, 14, said the correspondence was a valuable lesson. ``Mr. Haskvitz told us there are two sides to everything, but most of us didn't really know what was going on until we got the letter,'' she said. ``Now, we know Mr. Noriega's side as well.'' The letter will be published in an upcoming issue of the school newspaper Challenger, Haskvitz said, conceding he was surprised the students were able to locate Noriega. ``They tracked him down using plain old-fashioned detective skills,'' said the teacher. He added that the class has a new, follow-up assignment: to ask President Bush to respond to Noriega's allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Testimony: Top Commanders Beat Arabs In Violation Of Orders
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: An army officer told a military court Thursday that soldiers often beat Palestinian detainees in violation of orders, Israel radio said. The testimony by Lt. Col. Ephraim Fein came a day after the U.S. State Department released a report saying Israeli soldiers often ignored regulations and many unauthorized killings by soldiers went unpunished. Fein, former commander of the elite Givati Brigade, testified in the trial of four Givati reserve soldiers accused of beating two Palestinian detainees in the occupied Gaza Strip in February 1988. One detainee later died. A defense attorney also cited previous testimony as saying that Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, at that time the army chief in the Gaza Strip, beat a Palestinian who refused orders to clear a stone roadblock. Mordechai is now chief of the army's Central Command, which includes the occupied West Bank. At least 13 Palestinian teen-agers were wounded by army gunfire Thursday in scattered clashes in the occupied lands, hospital officials said. They said a 15-year-old girl was shot in the leg while trying to stop soldiers from beating her brother during an army raid in Qalqilya. The army confirmed that six Arabs were wounded in the Gaza Strip and said it was checking the other reports. At least 658 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt, now in its 27th month. Forty-three Israelis have died, and more than 180 Palestinians have been slain by their fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators. The Givati trial revived debate in Israel over army policy of beating Palestinian suspects in the occupied lands. Beatings became widespread after Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin in January 1988 authorized soldiers to beat Palestinians during violent demonstrations. Fein, who testified for the prosecution, told the court that at the time of the beatings at the center of the case, his soldiers were ``in a situation close to war.'' ``The orders were changed and eroded to keep up with the fast pace of events,'' he said. Fein also recalled an incident in which he himself violated orders on beatings. ``When they (soldiers) arrested an Arab, they bound his hands and feet and blindfolded him. One soldier helped him get down from the jeep, and he spit at the soldier. I slapped the Arab in an instinctive reaction,'' the radio quoted Fein as saying. The army said Thursday it had captured three Palestinian fugitives in the West Bank wanted for attacks on Israeli targets. They also allegedly killed two Arabs suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities. A military commander interviewed on Israel TV said the three were involved in the public execution Feb. 16 of an alleged informer who was hacked to death while hundreds watched.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-President of Wedtech Gets Five Months in Prison
DOC.TEXT: The former president of Wedtech Corp., whose testimony helped convict a congressman and a friend of ex-U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese III, was sentenced Thursday to five months in prison for his role in the corruption scandal. Anthony Guariglia was one of four officials of the New York-area military contractor who pleaded guilty in 1987 to federal charge of conspiracy to commit bribery and conspiracy to commit mail fraud. Guariglia testified at the racketeering trials of former U.S. Rep. Mario Biaggi and E. Robert Wallach, the San Francisco attorney who is a close associate of Meese. Both were convicted of receiving illegal payments from Wedtech officials ``This Wedtech scandal has certainly been a disgrace to this great country,'' Guariglia said to U.S. District Judge Charles E. Stewart. He said he was remorseful and ashamed of his actions. Stewart sentenced Guariglia to five months in prison and three years' probation. He also ordered the defendant to get counseling for a gambling addiction. The judge said Guariglia could subtract from the prison sentence the time he served since last month, when prosecutors revealed that he had violated his cooperation agreement by lying on the witness stand at Wallach's trial. Assistant U.S. Attorney Baruch Weiss said Guariglia admitted he lied when he testified he hadn't gambled, which would have violated a court order. Guariglia had actually incurred a $17,000 gambling debt at a Puerto Rican casino in late 1988, Weiss said. The perjury issue has prompted a request by Wallach's attorneys for a new trial. Gary Naftalis, a Wallach attorney, said a motion was filed earlier this month with the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals asking that the case be returned to the trial judge so he can consider granting a new trial. Wallach's attorneys are seeking a hearing on the scope of Guariglia's perjury. ``Obviously it seems plain to us that Wallach should not be convicted based on testimony of an admitted perjurer,'' Naftalis said in a telephone interview. ``It undermines the integrity of the entire prosecution.'' Wallach was convicted in August after a four-month trial of illegally receiving $425,000 from Wedtech to influence Meese and other government officials as part of Wedtech's efforts to gain government business. The company went bankrupt in 1986 after allegations of corruption were made public. Wallach was sentenced to six years in prison for his racketeering conviction but is free pending appeal, which is being handled by a group of attorneys that includes Robert Bork, the former U.S. Supreme Court nominee. Guariglia was the last of the four Wedtech officials who cooperated to be sentenced. The others are former Wedtech vice chairman Mario Moreno, sentenced to 18 months in prison; Wedtech co-founder Fred Neuberger, sentenced to two years and three months in prison; and Larry Shorten, a Wedtech financial official, who received probation.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Black Judicial Candidate Clears Committee Hurdle
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTs 2 new grafs after 6th graf pvs bgng: `Thomas said ...; to UPDATE with Pryor critical of record; pick up 7th graf pvs: `An underlying ...
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to block confirmation of conservative civil rights official Clarence Thomas as an appeals judge largely dried up Thursday as a Senate panel voted to send his nomination to the floor for final action. ``His capacity and competence I think are beyond attack,'' Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said as the Senate Judiciary Committee voted 12-1 in favor of the nomination. Critics conceded afterward that the full Senate was all but guaranteed to confirm Thomas, who as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission over the last eight years was one of the most visible blacks in the Reagan administration. Only Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, among committee members, voted against sending the nomination to the floor. Just weeks ago, conservative supporters of Thomas and civil rights forces were digging in for a fight, with senior citizens groups complaining that the commission has allowed thousands of age-bias cases to expire without action. Thomas said that state fair-employment commissions were to blame. But Thomas came in for renewed criticism late Thursday as Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., inserted a statement in the Congressional Record, complaining that several thousand age-discrimination claimants ``during Chairman Thomas' watch lost their rights largely due to EEOC neglect and mismanagement.'' Pryor, chairman of the Senate Aging Committee, said many answers that Thomas gave senators who asked about the problem at his confirmation hearing ``appeared to be shaky attempts at revisionist history.'' Pryor said he had not yet decided how to vote on confirmation. An underlying concern among congressional liberals clearly was speculation that within a few years Thomas could be ripe for advancement to the Supreme Court. ``I have some concerns about this man in terms of whether I could support him for the Supreme Court,'' Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis., declared. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., also said he might view a Thomas nomination for the Supreme Court in a different light. Biden said that standards for a Supreme Court justice are higher than those for the appeals bench. Thomas is under consideration for the vacancy left by the resignation of Robert Bork from the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. Bork resigned after the Senate rejected him for the Supreme Court at the close of the most embittered confirmation fight in decades. Thomas, who climbed from an impoverished childhood in rural Georgia to graduation from Yale law school, is an outspoken critic of racial hiring quotas and affirmative action programs. Civil rights forces have long been cool to him because of these views. Steam drained out of efforts to block his confirmation, however, when Benjamin Hooks, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said two weeks ago that he would not take part in the effort. The Alliance for Justice, a liberal court-watcher group that was among the severest critics of the nomination, issued a statement after committee action, saying it was ``clear that senators hold grave doubts about the nominee's qualifications.'' It said his performance on the bench ``will be watched carefully to determine whether he is truly committed to the rule of law.'' Metzenbaum, a leading congressional liberal, told the committee he had initially expected to vote to confirm Thomas but changed his mind at the confirmation hearing when Thomas blamed state fair employment agencies for problems involving numerous age-discrimination cases. In these cases, the statute of limitations for action expired before the complaints were processed. ``I was flabbergasted that he did not know that the state agencies are under contract to process state age-discrimination claims,'' Metzenbaum said. He said the federal commission is responsible for enforcing the contract and regulating the actions of the state agencies.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas in Peru Kill Mayor, Councilman
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas killed six people in a series of attacks, including a village mayor and councilman, but police tracked down and killed three of the rebels, authorities said Thursday. At least 60 mayors now have been killed by the Shining Path insurgency in the last 14 months. Police in Ayacucho said the rebels shot Mayor Raul Palomino and Councilman Juan Escalante, both from Anco, 205 miles southeast of Lima. Police said the two were killed Monday in an attack on the Ayacucho home where they were staying, but were not immediately identified. An Interior Department statement said guerrillas also killed a police sergeant Thursday in Atalaya, a jungle town 235 miles southeast of Lima. Three of the rebels later were killed by a police patrol sent to pursue them. Another rebel was injured but escaped, according to the report. Police in Huancayo, 140 miles east of Lima, said Shining Path guerrillas simultaneously broke into three homes there Wednesday and stabbed and shot to death two students and a peasant, then left notes accusing each victim of theft. The Shining Path has been trying topple to Peru's elected government since 1980. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan May Have Hurt Poindexter Though Trying to Help
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS grafs 16-17: ``Michael Bromwich;'' SUBS 4th graf: ``But Iran-Contra'' to CORRECT usage, convince sted persuade
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Reagan's videotaped deposition gave Iran-Contra prosecutors new ammunition for the trial of John M. Poindexter even though the former president tried hard to help his former national security adviser. Reagan endorsed the truthfulness of a letter Poindexter wrote to Congress assuring lawmakers that White House aides were not helping the Nicaraguan rebels in violation of a congressional ban. The former president, who winked and nodded at Poindexter when he took the witness stand, said he was ``in total agreement'' with the letter and hadn't authorized anything but the truth. But Iran-Contra prosecutors charge the letter was a false statement to Congress. And if they can convince Poindexter's jury of that, Reagan's statements about what he did or didn't authorize could be a problem for his former aide. Prosecutor Dan Webb said to Reagan concerning the truthfulness of the letter, ``You do understand that is a matter that ultimately the jury will have an opportunity to determine in this case, don't you?'' U.S. District Judge Harold Greene ordered that remark stricken from the record, but the jury in Poindexter's case will in all likelihood face that question. Part of Poindexter's defense, as outlined in court papers, is that he had no reason to lie to Congress because his activities were authorized by the president. But Reagan, during cross-examination by Webb, said he never authorized Poindexter to lie to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. ``At any time did you ever approve or give authority to John Poindexter to make any false or misleading statements to any congressional committee regarding events related to the Iran-Contra controversy?'' Webb asked. ``No, and I don't think any false statements were made,'' Reagan said, again trying to defend Poindexter. During the videotaped deposition, taken last week in Los Angeles and shown Thursday in Washington, Reagan testified that members of the National Security Council staff were in contact with the Nicaraguan Contras during the congressional ban on direct U.S. military aid. But during cross-examination, Reagan said he never ``had any inkling'' that Poindexter's aide Oliver North was helping devise military strategy for the Contras. The former president contended that there was no diversion of U.S.-Iran arms sale proceeds to the rebels until Webb confronted him with details of such a diversion in the report of the commission Reagan appointed to investigate the Iran-Contra affair. ``To the extent that there was in fact a diversion of proceeds, did you in any way approve or authorize that while you were president of the United States?'' ``For heaven's sake, no,'' Reagan replied. Michael Bromwich, who was on the Iran-Contra prosecution team in North's trial, said that Reagan's lack of knowledge about North and Poindexter's activities could be damaging for the defense. ``Reagan seems to have very little idea of what was going on so he certainly didn't authorize or approve of what North or Poindexter was doing doing based on full knowledge of the facts,'' said Bromwich, now a Washington lawyer. Reagan's statements could help prosecutors contend that the former president was deceived by the man he entrusted to advise him on the most sensitive matters of government. At one point, Reagan said he couldn't recall which government official told him that a C-123 transport plane shot down over Nicaragua was not connected with the U.S. government. But Webb showed Reagan the written answers he gave to the Iran-Contra grand jury, in which the former president stated that Poindexter had told him that the crash's sole survivor, Eugene Hasenfus was not part of the covert resupply operation run by North. Hasenfus' involvement in the secret resupply efforts is well documented and the prosecutors could argue to jurors that Poindexter lied about this to Reagan. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., who was a recipient of one of Poindexter's letters when he chaired the House Intelligence Committee, said Reagan's testimony ``takes away one of the defenses that Admiral Poindexter was asserting.'' ``That defense was that he was specifically authorized to do what he did,'' Hamilton said. Hamilton said he expects the defense will rely more on the notion ``that the president created a certain environment or climate in the White House that gave the signal or the impression to Admiral Poindexter that he could do what he did.''
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE _ James Rowley covers the Justice Department for
DOC.TEXT: the Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Says Czechoslovakia Will be More Active in United Nations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: in 7th graf, ``do regard'' is cq
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia told Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Thursday his newly democractic nation intends to be more active in the United Nations. At the end of his first official visit to the United States, he told reporters Czechoslovakia does not seek a role in negotiations on German reunification, but understands Poland's desire to participate in talks that could affect its borders. One-third of what is now Poland was in Germany before World War II and the Poles are worried about possible territorial claims by a united Germany. Havel, a dissident playwright who often was jailed by the Communist regime that collapesd last year, evaded a question about his talks with President Bush and whether the administration rebuffed his government's request for reduced levels of U.S. and NATO troops in Europe. ``This question has been raised in my conversation with Mr. Bush and it came out that we understand each other better than before,'' he said. Czechoslovakia also is negotiating with the Soviet Union for withdrawal of the 75,000 Red Army soldiers stationed in Czechoslovakia. Later, Prime Minister Marian Calfa told the news conference: ``We do regard the presence of U.S. troops in Europe as a stabilizing factor. ``We believe European stability should not depend so much on military forces and we should seek a security system that could replace the current forms ... a new system (so that) the presence of any foreign troops on the territory of any country would be unnecessary.'' Calfa said the United Nations can play a major role in international relations, but emphasized, ``It is much more important that we play a more substantial role in the U.N. than we have played until now.'' Havel spoke in the same vein earlier to Perez de Cuellar and said Czechoslovakia was eager to pursue a more active and independent course in the world. He and Havel spoke in Czech and their comments were translated by an interpreter.

DOC.HEAD: Conditions Exist For Fair Nicaraguan Election, Observer Says
LaserPhotos MGA7,10,11
DOC.TEXT: A top election observer said Thursday that a fair vote is possible this weekend despite charges of planned fraud or violence by both the ruling Sandinistas and their opponents. ``I ask that all Nicaraguans be allowed to exercise their right to vote peacefully'' on Sunday, Joao Baena Soares, secretary-general of the Organization of American States, said at a news conference. He specifically asked ``those involved in military activities'' _ both the Sandinista army and the U.S.-backed Contra guerrillas _ not to interfere. The campaigning has halted for a three-day cooling-off period. President Daniel Ortega told a news conference that the huge crowd that greeted his closing speech Wednesday night was a sure sign of victory. Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, Ortega's major rival, countered that Ortega made a ``desperate speech, without foundations, full of tired rhetoric.'' She told a lunch in her honor that the Sandinistas had tried to split her United National Opposition, but the 14-party coalition's ``maturity'' prevailed. Mrs. Chamorro and her running mate, Virgilio Godoy, said they expected to win Sunday's election despite the turnout Wednesday of 300,000 supporters for Ortega, a huge showing in a country with 1.75 million registered voters. She noted that the Sandinistas had brought in supporters from towns and cities for miles around and said that many were too young to vote, although that was not apparent to other observers. Ortega appeared determined to strike a statesmanlike note at his news conference, especially regarding the United States. More than 400 journalists were in attendance. U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III told the House Foreign Affairs Committee Thursday that even if the Sandinistas win a fair vote, relations would not be normalized ``until we see a substantial period of good behavior,'' including a halt to support for leftist rebels in El Salvador. Asked if he thought Baker was setting new conditions, Ortega said he expected to be able to negotiate security and other issues with the United States after the election. Ortega was asked five times if Nicaragua would promise to halt aid to El Salvador's guerrillas, but he said only that a regional agreement exists calling for suspension of aid. He said the United States should stop helping the Contras before pointing a finger at someone else. Asked if the Sandinistas would give up power if they lost Sunday's vote, Ortega said his party would ``respect the will of the people'' but that a political defeat does not ``transfer total power to the victors.'' The issue has become a point of contention because senior Sandinista officials have said they would not yield control of the army and police if they lose. Ortega said the question was ``conceptual'' in any case. ``Hypothetically, there is no chance of an electoral victory for any other party in Nicaragua,'' he said. Ortega hopes to force the United States to help disband the Contras and normalize relations with a victory certified by international observers, but Baker said the United States would not necessarily accept the observers' word. Baena Soares became indignant when asked if the OAS was favoring the Sandinistas. He said nobody had made that accusation and that the observers would ``maintain our integrity, our impartiality and above all our independence.'' ``The conditions exist for a fair election,'' said Soares, who heads a contingent of more than 400 observers. One of them, former U.S. Attorney General Elliot Richardson, toured provincial election centers in northern Nicaragua. Cardinal Manuel Obando y Bravo told reporters the Sandinistas ``have changed during the electoral campaign. I would like to interpret that as a permanent change.'' The Roman Catholic prelate often has leaned toward the government. Obando said he would vote Sunday for the first time in his life because, after years of civil war, ``We must make an effort to resolve our problems through civilized methods.'' He refused to reveal his choice, but added, ``If Nicaragua does not put an end to violence, violence will put an end to Nicaragua.''

DOC.HEAD: CDC Predicts 2.3 Million Alzheimer's Cases By 2000
DOC.TEXT: At least 2.3 million Americans will suffer from severe, debilitating dementia such as Alzheimer's disease by the close of this decade, federal health officials predicted Thursday. A California study, meanwhile, finds that two out of three Alzheimer's patients are women and one in four is under 65. ``As the U.S. population ages, the public health impact of dementias is increasing in importance,'' the Centers for Disease Control said in its weekly report. An estimated 1.6 million Americans currently suffer from severe dementia _ most often Alzheimer's disease, but also some with Parkinson's disease, Huntington's chorea or dementia-inducing strokes, CDC researchers reported. ``By the year 2000, at least 2.3 million persons are expected to be affected,'' the Atlanta-based agency said. The estimated annual cost of care and related expenses for patients with severe dementia in 1985 was as much as $48 billion, the CDC said. Alzheimer's disease is a progressive brain disorder marked by dementia _ an inability to remember, reason or understand what is going on. The cause is unknown, and no cure is available. A survey of 439 patients with Alzheimer's at six California treatment centers from 1985-87 showed that 298, or 68 percent, were women, according to data from the Institute for Aging at the University of California at San Francisco. While the California patients do not represent an accurate national survey, Alzheimer's is more frequent in women than in men, said Dr. Charles Helmick, a CDC Alzheimer's expert. And while the disease is often regarded as an affliction of the very old, 106 of the California patients _ or 24 percent _ were under 65. ``It's been recognized it can occur in middle age,'' Helmick said. ``It's more prevalent among the older population, and age is certainly a risk factor, but there are people in middle age affected by this.'' The largest numbers of Alzheimer's patients in the California study were in their 70s. Ages of patients ranged from 45 to 92. Most of the California patients _ 66 percent _ were referred to the special treatment centers by family members, most often because of an obvious memory problem.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Expels Maverick Special Investigators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Gdlyan throughout.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has expelled two special investigators who earned national fame for their role in a corruption inquiry in the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan, one of the investigators said Thursday. Telman Gdlyan said he and and Nikolai Ivanov had been expelled by a majority vote of Moscow party officials of their local party cell at a meeting at the General Prosecutor's office Wednesday. The two investigators were expelled on charges of violating the law and for their political activities, Gdlyan said by telephone Thursday. Gdlyan and Ivanov spearheaded an investigation into corruption in Uzbekistan and won their elections last year to the national parliament partly on the popularity of their investigation that reached the Politburo, particularly conservative member Yegor K. Ligachev. Ivanov in May alleged that Ligachev had accepted a bribe, but for months afterward, a prosecutor said the investigation proved the allegations were untrue. However, the general prosecutor's office, after an eight-month inquiry, accused the two investigators of forcing confessions and other improprieties. In recent weeks, small groups of citizens have been demonstrating sporadically near Red Square on behalf of the two investigators, accusing the party of persecuting the two men. Gdlyan said the general prosecutor had provided no charges against him and Ivanov, and that he believed he had been expelled from the party in order to destroy efforts to investigate corruption within the Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Reportedly To Visit Britain
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: South African black leader Nelson Mandela intends to visit Britain in April, but it is not known if he will talk with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the British Broadcasting Corp. said Thursday. The Foreign Office said it could not confirm the report, and the BBC did not give the source of its information. No exact date was given, but the report said Mandela wants to visit during Easter. Easter Sunday falls on April 15. During the visit, Mandela will address a rally at London's Wembley Stadium, the BBC said. Mandela was released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison as part of the reforms launched by the white-minority government of President F.W. de Klerk. Mandela has urged the world to continue economic sanctions against South Africa to maintain pressure for more reform. But Mrs. Thatcher, who previously invited Mandela to visit her, insists easing sanctions would benefit reform by rewarding de Klerk for the progress he has made.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Prince Demonstrators Hail Prince Charles
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with 10 grafs new material, picks up 2nd graf: ``On a,'' DROPS grafs 5-6: ``Charles, an,'' now redundant. FYI, the lede we expected from the text at 8 p.m. EST has been delayed. We will have another lede based on the speech, scheduled to begin at 9:30 p.m. EST, but the timing is uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Charles, arriving at an exhibit after lunching with President Bush, was greeted by approving demonstrators who applauded his battle for traditional architecture and hailed him as ``Our Knight in Shining Armor.'' Emerging from his limousine on the steps of the historic Octagon House, the Prince of Wales was obviously delighted to be met by a cluster of placards whose slogans included: ``Hurrah Prince Charles,'' and ``Humane Architecture _ Happy People.'' ``He saw the sign, `Shining Knight in Armor,' and he said, ``Gee Whiz,'' said Thomas J. Eyerman, a member of the Board of Regents of the American Architectural Foundation, one of the sponsors of the event. ``He was absolutely shocked that in America that people would have signs talking about architecture, calling him a shining knight in armor,'' Eyerman said. The pro-prince demonstrators told reporters they represented organizations that fought a long and ultimately unsuccessful fight to save Washington's historic Rhodes Tavern from demolition. The prince's objective at Octagon House, used as a temporary executive mansion by President James Madison after the British army burned the White House in 1814, was to view an exhibit commemorating the design of London's St. Paul's Cathedral by the leading British architect of the 17th century, Sir Christopher Wren. Octagon House, built in 1800, is now a museum of the American Institute of Architects. Charles married his wife, Diana, in St. Paul's in 1981. The prince reacted to the layout of architectural renderings and models with animation, looking at each exhibit closely, pointing out details and asking questions of one of his guides, Eric Evans, dean of St. Paul's. The works on display have never before been assembled as a unit and the prince was quoted by architects with whom he spoke as hoping they also could be shown in London. As the prince was inspecting the exhibit, America's leading architects gathered at a glittering black-tie gala for a royal critique of their work. On a chill, drizzly day, the 41-year-old heir to the British throne dined in the White House family quarters with Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle. The other luncheon guests included Secretary of State James A. Baker III, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, British Ambassador Sir Antony Acland and Henry Catto, U.S. ambassador to London. Bush escorted Charles down a red carpet to his Rolls-Royce limousine after lunch and shook hands with the prince, who wore a dark gray, double-breasted pinstripe suit. The busy schedule for Charles' one-day Washington visit also included an embassy reception for alumni of the Marshall Scholars program, under which the British government pays all costs for exceptional American students to spend two or three years at British universities. Later, Charles was the star attraction at a sold-out awards banquet for 1,200 architects, members of Congress, diplomats, Supreme Court justices and Hollywood celebrities at the National Building Museum. The prince's dinner speech gave him another opportunity to criticize the worst examples of modern architecture and appeal to his audience to design more attractive, comfortable buildings that are scaled to human needs and respect the surrounding landscape. Back home, Charles has angered some architects but won the applause of much of the British public with his contention that the London skyline has suffered more damage from architects, city planners and developers than from German bombers in World War II. In ``A Vision of Britain,'' a book he published last year, Charles accused some modern architects of creating ``Frankenstein monsters, devoid of character, alien and largely unloved.'' He says some new buildings in London remind him of word processors or nuclear power plants. Honored at the banquet was architect Fay Jones of Fayetteville, Ark., a former pupil of Frank Lloyd Wright who won the AIA's prestigious Gold Medal. Bush presented the award to Jones at a White House ceremony after the lunch for Charles. The prince will end a weeklong U.S. tour on Friday, when he meets with American environmental experts at the British Embassy before he returns to London. Charles began his visit last weekend by playing in two benefit polo matches at Vero Beach, Fla. He met Wednesday with 100 corporate executives in Charleston, S.C., to promote private investment in poor urban neighborhoods and plead for business cooperation in protecting the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Figure Clines Indicted
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf: ``There was,'' with 2 grafs bgng: ``Clines and,'' reax from Clines' lawyer and detail on case
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Reagan-Poindexter Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An operative in Oliver North's secret supply network to the Nicaraguan Contras was indicted Thursday on charges of failing to report some of his income from arms sales. The indictment says that Thomas G. Clines, 61, a business partner of Iran-Contra figures Richard Secord and Albert Hakim reported receipts of $265,000 for tax year 1985 and $402,513 for 1986 from the arms business and other income sources. However, the four-count indictment, returned by a federal grand jury in Baltimore, alleges that Clines failed to report to the Internal Revenue Service that he had foreign accounts totaling more than $10,000. Two counts of the indictment accuse him of underreporting the gross receipts. Each count carries a maximum penalty of three years imprisonment and $100,000 in fines on conviction. The other counts accuse Clines of failing to report his foreign accounts, with maximum penalties on conviction for each charge of 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. During the period in question, Hakim set aside more than $972,000 in commissions for Clines, who is a former CIA agent, in an offshore entity codenamed C. Tea, according to a congressional report on the Iran-Contra scandal issued in 1987. Clines and his lawyer regard the decision to bring the case as an ``ill-advised'' step taken by ``overzealous prosecutors,'' said his attorney, Paula Junghans. Clines intends to defend himself ``to the fullest,'' she added. Sources familiar with the matter say Clines filed an amended tax return for 1985 in the fall of 1987, nearly a year after the Iran-Contra affair came into public view, reporting additional expenses and additional income. Clines takes the position that he has reported all his income from the Contra transactions, say sources familiar with Clines' situation. He collected the money in connection with his work for ``the Enterprise,'' the complex of foreign corporations and Swiss accounts which Hakim and Secord used to move money in the Iran-Contra affair. Hakim is a key witness in the investigation of Clines, according to other sources familiar with the investigation. Hakim was placed on two years' probation and fined $5,000 on Feb. 1 for his role in the Iran-Contra affair. At the request of his friend Secord, Clines helped procure arms for the Contra rebels starting in 1985. In addition to locating a European arms dealer as a source of weapons, Clines helped arrange for shipping and lined up crews to transport the supplies to the rebels. Clines worked for the CIA for 30 years. He was an agent in Southeast Asia, was involved in the Bay of Pigs invasion in Cuba and became director of training in the directorate of operations, also known as the clandestine services. He also was a close associate of Edwin Wilson, the former CIA agent who is serving 52 years in federal prison for illegally selling guns and explosives to Libya. Clines pleaded guilty in 1984 on behalf of his wholly owned company to inflating bills submitted to the Defense Department for shipping U.S. military equipment to Egypt. He was fined the maximum $10,000 and paid the government $100,000 on behalf of his firm, Systems Services International.

DOC.HEAD: Two Planes Tap Tails at Atlanta Airport
DOC.TEXT: A KLM airliner being pushed from a terminal at Atlanta Hartsfield International Airport bumped into the tail of a Delta Air Lines plane waiting to roll onto a taxiway Wednesday night. Airport spokesman John Braden said there were no injuries, and slight metal damage to the planes. When the mishap occurred shortly before 7:30, passengers for Delta Flight 405 to Dallas were getting on board for an 8:30 p.m. departure, said Delta spokesman Bill Berry. The KLM plane, Flight 622 for Amsterdam in the Netherlands, was rescheduled for a 9 p.m. departure, according to a KLM reservations supervisor. Braden said the KLM Boeing 747 was being pushed back from the gate by a tug when it bumped into the tail of the Delta MD-88. ``One of our crewmen on board said, `It felt like we'd hit a pothole,''' Berry said. Questions on the number of passengers on the KLM flight and other details were referred to a KLM public information telephone number, but it was not answered Wednesday night.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Denies Directing Soviet Immigrants to Occupied Lands
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS grafs 6-11: ``The Shamir-Bush,'' to incorporate related material from a0722 AM-Arens
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir told President Bush on Thursday that the Israeli government is not directing new Soviet immigrants into occupied lands, Bush's spokesman said. Shamir's comments, in a morning phone call to Bush, seemed designed to allay U.S. concerns that stepped up settlement of Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza could torpedo fragile peace efforts. ``The prime minister stated that Jewish immigration into Israel was a separate matter from the question of settlements, and that the Israeli government had no policy of directing where the new immigrants would live,'' said Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater. At the same time, Fitzwater said in a statement, Bush ``reiterated U.S. opposition to any settlement activity.'' The United States opposes any expansion of settlements in the territories Israel seized in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. The Shamir-Bush call came as the Israeli foreign minister, Moshe Arens, arrived in Washington for a meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday to discuss prospects for Mideast peace negotiations. Baker has tried for months to arrange a three-way session in Washington with Arens and Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid. It would be followed by talks between Israel and Palestinian Arabs. But Baker told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that the agenda and the composition of a Palestinian delegation remained unsettled. ``The time for action is coming very, very close,'' Baker said. Meanwhile, Shimon Peres, the Israeli finance minister, told Cable News Network that the Palestine Liberation Organization has accepted a formula for a Palestinian delegation. Peres, who heads Israel's opposition Labor Party, said it would be a non-PLO delegation, including one or two Palestinians who were expelled from Israel and one or two who reside in East Jerusalem. Israel has refused to negotiate with the PLO. Earlier this week, Fitzwater said the administration did not believe ``that encouraging Soviet emigrants to settle there is helpful to the peace process.'' Despite Shamir's denial of any such policy, the Soviet Union decided this week against allowing direct flights to Israel, largely because of Arab concerns over the settling of Soviet Jews in occupied lands. In his phone conversation, Shamir ``thanked the president for U.S. support of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union, for opposing anti-semitism, and for supporting the restoration of diplomatic relations as well as the establishment of direct flights between the U.S.S.R. and Israel,'' Fitzwater's statement said. Bush ``thanked the prime minister for his statement and said that the United States would continue to support free emigration from the Soviet Union,'' the statement added. The president also told Shamir he hoped ``the peace process could move forward'' to pave the way for a proposed meeting soon in Cairo of Israeli and Palestinian peace negotiators. Using standing diplomatic language, Fitzwater's statement said Shamir's call was described by both leaders as ``helpful and constructive.''

DOC.HEAD: Unocal Agrees to Record Settlement in San Pablo Bay Pollution Case
DOC.TEXT: Union Oil agreed Thursday to a $5.55 million court settlement stemming from the pollution of San Pablo Bay, in what lawyers called the largest civil penalty in the history of the federal Clean Water Act. The settlement resolves a longstanding dispute over pollution that environmentalists contended took place between April 1979 and February 1988 in the bay, which is located about 15 miles northeast of here and is part of San Francisco Bay. ``We're elated,'' said attorney Stephan Volker of the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, Inc. Volker, who filed suit against the company in 1984, credited the litigation with exposing and halting ``systematic manipulation of the self-monitoring program on which the Clean Water Act is based.'' ``This should send a strong message to other polluters: Clean up your operations or face the prospect of being hauled into court and paying a substantial penalty,'' Volker said. John Barg, the attorney handling the case for Union, which has been acquired by Unocal, declined to comment on the settlement. Unocal spokesman Jeff Callender emphasized that the settlement did not constitute an admission of fault. ``The company maintains that many of the alleged violations are the result of misunderstandings'' regarding provisions of the Clean Water Act, he said. ``We remained confident of our position but the case has dragged on for six years and we felt it was time to put it behind us,'' Callender said. Union Oil employees testified during the dispute that the company repeatedly and deliberately violated the terms of its waste water discharge permit and failed to report the violations, Volker said. The settlement followed years of legal battles. Although the courts initially found in favor of Union's position, subsequent rulings went against the company. In December 1988, U.S. District Court Judge Samuel Conti ruled that Union Oil had violated its federal waste discharge permit 200 times, including nine bypasses of its treatment plant in the town of Rodeo. A trial had been scheduled for this month. The wastes that flowed into the Bay included phenols and other potentially cancer-causing substances such as benzene, toluene, acetone and trichloroethylene. Conti said the company had saved from $20 million to $60 million by failing to install adequate treatment equipment. The penalty was described by the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund as the highest ever paid as the result of a civil lawsuit under the federal Clean Water Act. The previous high was $3.2 million awarded in a New Jersey case last year.
