DOC.HEAD: Mom's Advice to Eat a Balanced Diet Still Good to Follow
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans know a balanced diet is the healthiest one, but they don't eat that way, according to a national poll. Moderation seems to be a tough prescription to follow. ``Americans are surprisingly knowledgeable about nutrition and health, but when it comes to translating facts into food choices, most still opt for quick fixes and the latest health fads,'' Nancy Wellman, president of the American Dietetic Association, the nation's largest group of food and nutrition professionals, said last week at a news conference to announce results of a Gallup survey. Ninety-five percent of those polled said balance, variety and moderation are the keys to healthy eating, and 83 percent said they were fairly or very concerned that what they eat might affect their health. Sixty-four percent said they were eating more fiber, and nearly half said they had increased their intake of calcium. Nearly three-quarters said they were trimming fat from their diets and roughly two-thirds reported cutting out saturated fats, cholesterol and fried foods. But only 8 percent said they were eating more vegetables, while 15 percent said they'd added fish oil to their diets. ``Despite their awareness of basic nutrition principles, many consumers seem to view food as medicine,'' said Margo A. Denke, a nutrition research scientist at the University of Texas. ``They think adding or eliminating a particular food or ingredient will automatically prevent or cure illness. Such an approach is not only unrealistic, it can also prove harmful.'' Part of the trouble is a perception that there are ``forbidden foods,'' which seems to make people crave the foods they try to do without and then feel all the guiltier when they splurge on them. ``Prohibition of food creates guilt,'' Wellman said. ``And guilt destroys good intentions and can lead people to actually overeat or binge on those forbidden foods.'' Thirty-five percent of those surveyed said high-fat foods cannot be part of a healthy diet. ``The thing that surprised me is that people are still going to extremes not in their best interest, particularly women who are eliminating dairy foods when there are good, tasty low- and even non-fat foods in that category,'' Wellman said in a telephone interview. She also cited a ``continuing misconception that red meat cannot be part of a healthy diet.'' The advice most moms gave out about a moderate, balanced diet remains ``useful and durable,'' Wellman said. ``One of my favorite special-occasion treats is a hot fudge sundae,'' she said. ``I realize I can't have one for dessert every night, yet it would be off-base to think I could never eat one.'' The Gallup Organization conducted the telephone survey of 772 American adults Dec. 11-28 for the ADA and the non-profit, food industry-funded International Food Information Council. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
The ADA and IFIC published a pamphlet, ``10 Tips to Healthy Eating,'' available free by sending a stamped, self-addressed business-sized envelope to: 10 Tips, P.O. Box 1144, Rockville, Md., 20850.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon, Feb. 26

DOC.TEXT: Retail prices made their steepest jump in 7{ years last month as consumers suffered from the left-over effects of December's high food and fuel costs, the government said. The 1.1 percent increase in the Labor Department's seasonally adjusted Consumer Price Index was the largest since a 1.1 percent gain in June 1982, the department said Wednesday. It said 60 percent of the January increase came in food and energy prices, as frigid weather in December drove down fuel stocks and damaged fresh fruits and vegetables, driving prices up.

Digital Equipment Corp., hurt by a sluggish U.S. computer market, said it may expand its voluntary severance program substantially to cut the company's payroll and slash costs. The computer company, the world's second largest behind International Business Machines Corp., saw its earnings fall 39 percent for the six months ended Dec. 31. Spokesman Mark Steinkrauss also said Wednesday the company is ``walking a fairly thin line'' on whether it will report a profit for the quarter ending in March.

Creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert said they would seek a bankruptcy court investigation of up to $350 million in year-end bonuses paid shortly before the firm's collapse. The payments were set in December and were not made with any knowledge the firm would go out of business, a Drexel spokesman said Wednesday. Drexel's parent filed for bankruptcy court protection last week. ``We're talking about bonus payments so large they arguably put Drexel into bankruptcy,'' said William G. Schopf Jr., general counsel of First City Bancorp. of Texas Inc., which is owed $25 million.

Texas Instruments Inc. has produced its first memory device capable of storing 16 times as much information as the current generation of widely used memory chips, which store 1 million bits. The first device was produced at TI's Dallas chip research and manufacturing complex Feb. 12, Robert W. England, vice president of the company's semiconductor group, said Wednesday. On Feb. 13, IBM said it had built its first 16-million-bit memory chip.

Texas Air Corp., the nation's largest airline company, has agreed to sell half its prized computer reservation system for $250 million to General Motors Corp., the companies said. The deal with GM's Electronic Data Systems Corp. subsidiary marks the first time a non-airline company has participated in an airline reservation system, Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo told a news conference Wednesday. Lorenzo denied suggestions that the partial sale of System One was intended to help bail out financially struggling Texas Air or to ease pressure caused by the strike and bankruptcy proceeding at its Eastern Airlines subsidiary.

Apple Computer Inc. announced plans to lay off 3 percent of its work force as a way to cope with what analysts call rising customer dissatisfaction, sagging profits, management turmoil and sinking employee morale. Apple Chairman John Sculley on Wednesday blamed the 400 layoffs on a slowdown in the U.S. personal computer industry, which after three years of double-digit growth is expected to grow no more than 9 percent in 1990. The cuts in Apple's 13,500-member work force will become effective in two months.

A top bank regulator urged Congress to be careful in reforming deposit insurance, warning that many proposals could hurt the nation's financial system. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said Wednesday attempts to inject more market discipline into the banking system will involve trade-offs, including greater financial instability and reduced consumer protection. ``Any simple solutions ... could be counterproductive _ perhaps doing more harm than good,'' he told the House Banking Committee.

Carl Icahn, owner of Trans World Airlines Inc., is carrying out his promise to shrink the airline unless its pilots agree to a 10 percent pay cut. Icahn announced Tuesday he would sell two Boeing 747s outright and would sell and lease back six Boeing 767s in a deal that would add $350 million to TWA's coffers. Icahn and his employees have been fighting for months over the fate of TWA, which a decade ago was one of the nation's biggest airlines, although neither side appears to be gaining any ground.

Avon Products Inc. plans to sell its remaining 60 percent stake in Avon Japan to a private Japanese mail order company and its president in a cash deal valued at $450 million. The big beauty products company decided to withdraw from Japan after concluding that it would be too costly to try to prosper there, an intensely competitive environment in which Avon has had little success expanding its market share. Avon, which started the Japan subsidiary about 20 years ago, sold 40 percent of the company, or 27.1 million shares, on the open market in 1987 for $220 million.

Stock prices closed moderately lower Wednesday, rebounding somewhat from an early plunge. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed down 13.29 points at 2,583.56. The dollar ended mostly higher. Gold prices rose in New York and Hong Kong but slipped in Europe. Bond prices finished higher. Live cattle futures plummeted the permitted daily limit; feeder cattle futures also fell sharply while pork futures advanced; coffee futures rose sharply; grains and soybeans were higher; precious metals retreated; and oil futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Abitibi Plans Price Increase; Industry Observers Say `Good Luck'
DOC.TEXT: A planned price hike by one of the world's largest newsprint producers is unlikely to take effect because supply is plentiful and growing at a brisk rate, analysts and newspaper officials say. Abitibi-Price Inc. notified customers this week it plans to raise the list price of newsprint by $35 a metric ton, or 5.4 percent, to $685 a metric ton. Any broad increase would be the first since an industrywide 6.6 percent price hike on Jan. 1, 1988. While the list price has remained steady, actual selling prices and newsprint makers' profits have declined. Edward Ahern, a marketing director for Abitibi's sales unit, said the increase is effective June 1. The Toronto-based company, the world's second largest newsprint maker behind Fletcher Challenge of New Zealand, told customers the increase is necessary because it is losing money on current newsprint sales, Ahern said. ``I sent all our suppliers a letter saying I think it's ridiculous,'' said Homer Taylor, vice president of supply for Knight-Ridder Inc., one of the nation's largest newspaper groups. ``With consumption and operating rates dropping and supply increasing and discounts increasing, it just doesn't make any sense.'' ``We don't think it's the right time,'' said Bill Hee, purchasing manager for Gannett Supply Corp., owned by the largest U.S. newspaper chain. ``It's not based on supply and demand. There is plenty of paper around.'' Taylor said the price announcement was a repeat of last year's failed attempt to increase prices, and conditions in the industry have deteriorated since then. Advertising linage is down substantially and consumption at most of Knight-Ridder's more than 30 newspapers is flat to lower, he said. The American Newspaper Publishers Association said daily consumption declined 0.3 percent industrywide last year. Consumption fell 5.1 percent in the Northeast, where newspaper retail advertising dropped substantially due to financial troubles at store chain owner Campeau Corp. It rose 5.1 percent in the West, however. Demand for newsprint has held up mainly because Knight-Ridder and other newspaper companies are stockpiling supplies in anticipation of possible labor problems in Canada, Taylor said. Mill workers in Canada have asked for a hefty wage increase and have threatened to strike if demands are not met when their contracts expire on April 30. ``Conditions are worse this year in terms of making a price increase stick,'' Taylor said. ``They see all this purchasing and are reading it as consumption.'' Knight-Ridder has increased its inventories to about 50 days from 36 days, Taylor said. Gannett recently raised its inventories about three days to 45 days, Hee said. Industry analysts also are skeptical that the increase will take effect. ``Wishful thinking,'' said George B. Adler, analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. ``There's too much newsprint capacity _ excessive.'' Adler said North American capacity is continuing to increase in 1990 and is not expected to slow until next year. Meanwhile, many Canadian newsprint makers are experiencing problems because of widespread discounting, a common industry practice. While the current list price is $650 a metric ton, the actual selling price to customers is about $530 a ton, Adler said. Abitibi on Monday reported a fourth-quarter loss and lower 1989 profits and blamed it on lower newsprint prices. The results follow Abitibi's warning to employees last month of possible mill shutdowns and job cuts this year. Nonetheless, part of the price increase could take effect, particularly if Canadian employees decide to strike, said Robert Duncan, analyst with Wood Gundy Inc. in Toronto. Eastern Canada is the world's largest single source of newsprint.

DOC.HEAD: NBC, News Corp., Cablevision, Hughes in Direct-to-Home TV Pact
DOC.TEXT: A $1 billion project to deliver as many as 108 channels of television programming via satellite to home dishes small enough to fit on a window sill is being developed by a group of four major media companies. Wednesday's announcement left plenty of unresolved questions about the service, including what programs would be made available and how much the service would cost. But there is no rush: the service is not expected to debut until 1993. Media industry analysts say the venture, called Sky Cable, would provide expanded choices for viewers, encourage production of more TV programming and raise competition for cable operators. But they also note that several obstacles remain, including overcoming the industry's track record of failed direct-to-home satellite TV ventures in the United States. The partners are General Electric Co.'s National Broadcasting Co.; Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd.; Cablevision Systems Corp., a cable system operator and programmer based in Woodbury, N.Y.; and Hughes Communications Inc., a satellite technology concern owned by General Motors Corp. The partners said they had signed a memorandum of understanding for the venture, which they said would be the first high-power Direct Broadcast Satellite service. They said the service would be competitively priced, but specific program offerings had not been determined yet. The service would be an addition to rather than a replacement for existing cable service, they contended. But some analysts disagreed. Peter Appert, who follows the media business for the investment firm C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell, said Sky Cable poses ``a significant competitive threat'' to the cable industry. ``If I can can get 108 channels priced competitively, I don't see why I need cable if they can deliver as promised and the quality is as promised,'' he said. Sky Cable would use the most powerful satellites ever launched for commercial communications purposes and be capable of delivering both high-definition television and standard video signals, as well as digital quality audio. The companies said the new venture likely would be the first to introduce HDTV to the United States on a broad scale. The venture will cost about $1 billion, including an equity investment of about $335 million. Each of the partners plan to contribute equal amounts of the equity once they reach a definitive agreement. At a news conference, the promoters displayed a receiving dish measuring 12 to 18 inches across that they said would be used for Sky Cable. They said they expected the dish would cost about $300, much less than the $2,000 to $3,000 price tag on bulkier, conventional dishes. A few programs would be available free of charge to dish owners, but subscribers would have to pay for other programming, which may include multi-channel packages, single channels and pay-per-view programs. ``This won't replace cable,'' said Charles Dolan, chairman and chief executive of Cablevision. Dolan said cable operators will be asked to install, service and handle billing for Sky Cable. Subscribers also will be able to sign up on their own. Previous efforts to launch direct-to-home service in the United States have made little headway. Such services are available in Great Britain and Japan. Appert said past U.S. efforts often failed because the receiving dish was cumbersome, channel capacity was limited and the signal often was distorted. Earlier this month, a group of nine U.S. cable operators and GE's American Communications unit announced a venture to offer 10 channels of programming later this year via a GE satellite. Robert Thomson, an executive at Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator and a member of the cable group, said the Sky Cable plans won't affect his group's satellite broadcast plans. Sky Cable ``will be competitive to cable,'' he said, but cable companies have an advantage of a large programming and customer base and a flexible and secure transmission system. News Corp. offers a satellite-delivered TV service in Great Britain, but startup losses have been heavy. Murdoch said the British service has 600,000 subscribers and needs 2 million to become profitable. The American Sky Cable service will need between 3 million and 5 million subscribers to break even, Murdoch said. Murdoch and Robert Wright, president of NBC, said there are no plans to offer their respective TV networks, Fox and NBC, on the Sky Cable. But Cablevision and NBC jointly own the Consumer News and Business Channel, Bravo, Sports Channel America and 10 regional sports channels. Murdoch said his company may provide programming for Sky Cable. News Corp. operations include Twentieth Century Fox Films and TV show production.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Air Agrees to Sell Half of Reservation System to GM Unit
DOC.TEXT: A subsidiary of General Motors Corp. has become the first non-airline company to participate in an airline reservation system by signing a deal with Texas Air Corp., the nation's largest airline company. Under the agreement announced Wednesday, Texas Air will sell half its computer reservation system for $250 million to Electronic Data Systems Corp. Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo denied suggestions that the partial sale of System One, under discussion since September, was intended to help bail out financially struggling Texas Air or to ease pressure caused by the strike and bankruptcy proceeding at its Eastern Airlines subsidiary. The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday that Houston-based Texas Air has offered some of its own cash, notes and potentially even its own stock to Eastern's unsecured creditors. ``Texas Air is not entering into this transaction because of a need for cash,'' Lorenzo said at a news conference, adding that his company is gaining a ``strong partner'' in the increasingly competitive reservation business. EDS Chairman Les Alberthal, ticking off the benefits of the deal to Texas Air, said, ``First and foremost, Frank did get our cash.'' Edward Starkman, an airline analyst at PaineWebber Inc., called the agreement ``a cash infusion for the company.'' The president of Eastern's striking Machinists blasted the sale, which he said allows Lorenzo to reap a windfall from the reservation system that once was one of Miami-based Eastern's most important assets. ``If this deal is allowed to stand, they're going to be playing right into the hands of yet another big Lorenzo scam,'' said Charles E. Bryan, president of Machinists District 100 in Miami. He called the deal ``a Lorenzo embezzlement'' and said he would never buy another GM car. The partial sale of System One must be approved by U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York, where Eastern filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors last March 9, five days after the start of a strike. David I. Shapiro, the court-appointed examiner for Eastern, is aware of the new agreement with EDS, as is the committee representing the airline's unsecured creditors, Texas Air spokesman Art Kent said. ``They obviously didn't object to it,'' he said. Lorenzo didn't confirm or deny the Journal report on Texas Air offering its own cash and equity to Eastern's creditors. Previously, Texas Air has strived to keep itself and its Continental Airlines subsidiary separate from Eastern's troubles. ``We own Eastern Airlines. Eastern Airlines is not some sort of distant cousin,'' Lorenzo said. ``We are going to do those things that are sensible and reasonable.'' The airline chief also reiterated he has no plans to merge Eastern with Continental, or to liquidate Eastern. He said negotiations on a reorganization plan have been continuing with creditors after Eastern's exclusive right to file a plan expired Tuesday. ``Liquidation of Eastern Airlines doesn't make sense for anybody,'' Lorenzo said. ``Eastern Airlines is coming along well. ... Eastern has a game plan.'' System One Chairman Dick Murray told the news conference that other airlines eventually could join Texas Air and Dallas-based EDS as partners in the system, which enables travel agents to book reservations for airlines, hotels, car rentals and other traveler needs. If other airlines joined, Texas Air's stake wouldn't be allowed to fall below 10 percent, he said. Possible future partners mentioned by Murray included Pan Am Corp., America West Airlines and Alaska Airlines. The partial sale of System One is a radical move for Lorenzo, who has underlined the importance of computer reservation systems to airlines' competitiveness. Those systems have been undergoing rapid changes and consolidations recently. Delta Air Lines recently merged its reservation system with PARS, an operation jointly owned by Trans World Airlines and Northwest Airlines. American Airlines' Sabre reservation system has been seeking a partner after the Justice Department quashed its plans to link up with Delta's system. United Airlines, USAir and four foreign airlines comprise the rival Covia reservations system. In addition to the work it performs for GM, EDS is involved in health insurance, government and financial institution data processing.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Expects to Institute Cutbacks
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp., looking to slash costs to counter a slowdown in the U.S. computer market, might cut its workforce by expanding a voluntary severance program, a company official says. Digital also has reported ``bugs'' in its VAX 9000 mainframe machine, a new product the company hopes will reverse a slide in earnings. But the company and analysts said Wednesday the problems were minor and should not affect sales significantly. Digital, the world's second-largest computer company behind International Business Machines Corp., saw its earnings fall 39 percent for the six months that ended Dec. 31. Furthermore, the company is ``walking a fairly thin line'' between the prospects of reporting a profit or a loss for its fiscal third quarter, which ends in March, said Mark Steinkrauss, director of investment relations. Digital blames the earnings drop on a lackluster computer market in the United States, which has forced other companies to make cutbacks as well. To reduce costs, Steinkrauss said the company recently started considering ``a substantial expansion of the voluntary incentive program.'' The company last year offered a voluntary severance package to several hundred employees in Salem, N.H., but analysts said Digital now appears to be looking to cut several thousand workers. ``We've never itemized what the numbers might be,'' Steinkrauss said. The company is considering many alternatives, and although Steinkrauss would not rule out layoffs, he noted that Digital has ``never had any layoffs.'' Digital also has reassigned hundreds of employees from manufacturing to sales, he said. ``Digital is aggressively addressing the issue of cost control internally,'' said Terry Shannon, an analyst with International Data Corp., a Framingham firm that studies the computer industry. ``But it's like a super-tanker that takes five miles to stop or turn around.'' Shannon said a reasonable estimate on the number of jobs to be cut would be 5,000 or more. Digital employs about 125,900 worldwide, and more than 70,000 in the United States. ``Cost cutting is necessary at all computer companies,'' said Barry Bosak, an analyst with Smith Barney in New York. ``The earnings get squeezed and that puts the company under the gun.'' But he added that Digital is in relatively good shape despite the need to make cuts. Digital is hoping to boost its earnings with the introduction of the VAX 9000 mainframe, with first deliveries scheduled for the fourth quarter, beginning in April. ``We've had some bugs in the machine,'' Steinkrauss said. ``But none have been unidentifiable and none have been unsolvable.'' Such problems are common with a new product and should not hurt sales of the machine, he said, adding: ``There's been no major slippage in the shipping schedule.'' Shannon said the initial glitches in the VAX 9000 should have a ``minimal impact.'' ``I don't view this as being tantamount to meaning the product doesn't work,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Engaging In Shrinking Strategy
DOC.TEXT: Following through on a threat to shrink Trans World Airlines Inc. unless pilots accept a 10 percent pay cut, owner Carl Icahn said he would sell eight jets to raise $350 for TWA's coffers. Icahn announced he would sell two Boeing 747s outright and would sell and lease back six Boeing 767s. Icahn and his employees have been fighting for months over the fate of TWA, which a decade ago was one of the nation's biggest airlines. ``We're doing what the pilots told us to do,'' Icahn said in a telephone interview with the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. ``They said, `Go ahead and shrink the airline,' so we're shrinking it.'' Icahn did not return phone calls Wednesday to his office in Mount Kisco, N.Y., where TWA is headquartered. TWA operates a large hub and employs 8,000 people in St. Louis. Icahn also has been talking about selling more TWA routes, a process begun two months ago when he agreed to sell the airline's Chicago-to-London route to American Airlines. Possible buyers for TWA routes include smaller domestic airlines that are looking to expand, like Southwest Airlines Co. or America West, as well as large European carriers that want a larger U.S. presence, like British Airways and SAS. Although experts generally don't consider shrinkage to be a good long-term strategy, consolidating could allow a carrier to reduce costs and make better use of its equipment and employees in selected markets. The pilots say the decision of whether TWA gets bigger or smaller has little to do with them. Kent Scott, chairman of TWA's pilot union, has said he doesn't see how the $80 million in concessions sought by Icahn would help the airline, which is burdened with $2.7 billion of debt and a fuel-guzzling fleet of aircraft, the oldest among major American carriers. Meanwhile, Icahn resumed negotiations this week with TWA's mechanics, who have been working under an old contract for more than a year and have repeatedly said they would not accept any deal involving concessions. ``Carl Icahn has to decide which way to go,'' said Jim Carey, an airline analyst at the Washington-based consulting firm, Airline Economics Inc. ``It's up to him and I assume it depends on whether he can get wage concessions.'' Two other factors may prove to be more important in determining TWA's future, as well as the shape of the airline industry in general. One is the cost of jet fuel, which is about 50 percent higher than a year ago. These higher prices are forcing carriers to look for additional revenue, analysts say. ``If we don't see some relief by the summer it's going to be hard for anybody to avoid making some big decisions,'' said Carey, who is senior vice president for operations at Airline Economics. The other factor is the declining rate of growth in air passenger traffic. According to Avmark International, a general aviation consulting firm based in Arlington, Va., revenue passenger miles have grown at 5 percent or less for the last seven months. And analysts say a good portion of the increases have come as a result of discounted tickets. For the first part of 1989 and most of 1988, revenue passenger miles grew 10 percent and more, said Paul Turk, an analyst with Avmark. ``The downturn in traffic is going to make the weaker airlines even weaker,'' Turk said. ``We're going to see further consolidation.''

DOC.HEAD: Developers Oppose Delay in Announcing Which Stores to Close
DOC.TEXT: Federated and Allied department stores have asked a federal bankruptcy judge for more time before announcing which outlets the companies will close as part of their Chapter 11 reorganization. But some of the country's largest shopping center builders planned to ask Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. to deny the retailers' request at a hearing today. Lawyers for JMB Realty Corp. and Melvin Simon & Associates argue that giving the Cincinnati-based retailers more time would hurt tenants of shopping malls that are anchored by such Federated and Allied stores as Lazarus or Bloomingdale's. The developers said a delay also could scuttle planned projects. Under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, a company filing for protection from creditors has 60 days to decide whether to end lease agreements. For Federated and Allied, which sought bankruptcy court protection Jan. 15, the deadline is March 14. In a motion filed Feb. 7, the companies asked to extend the decision until a reorganization plan is in place _ which is expected to be in mid-May. ``We think our request is very realistic and warranted,'' said Carol Sanger, spokeswoman for Federated Stores Inc., parent of Federated and Allied. But lawyers for Indianapolis-based Melvin Simon, which controls 66 million square feet of retail space in 200 shopping centers, said the extension request ``is excessive and unreasonable and should be denied.'' The lease issue has become an obstacle for Melvin Simon, which plans to build the $625 million Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn. The mall is envisaged as the largest in the world, but uncertainty about a Bloomingdale's store planned for the mall is delaying a $600 million loan needed to start construction. Officials of Federated Stores Inc. have said they plan to close only a few of their less-profitable stores. Ms. Sanger added, ``We are not talking about an inordinate amount of a time extension. We're only talking about 60 days as things stand now.'' JMB Realty has plans to renovate a shopping center in the Chicago suburb of Skokie to include a new Bloomingdale's. Equitable Life Assurance Co., which owns 14 malls that include a Federated or Allied store, also is fighting the extension.

DOC.HEAD: Transportation Department Won't Help D&H
DOC.TEXT: Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner says he hopes the failing Delaware & Hudson Railway will be able to find a ``competitive'' solution to its financial problems. ``We have been watching with a great deal of interest the D&H situation,'' Skinner said Wednesday. ``But I feel strongly that you can only do so much and I would hope that they will work their way out of that situation.'' Skinner said the Transportation Department would not even ``request'' that a competing but financially healthy railroad help D&H out. ``We are not in the business anymore of taking a competitor or taking an organization that is not making it and forcing some company to take that responsibility on on a non-profit basis,'' he said at a breakfast meeting with reporters. ``We have to find a competitive way for that service to be provided.'' Nevertheless, Skinner said he hoped the bankruptcy trustee could work out a merger or trackage agreement to save D&H, the nation's oldest continually operating railroad. In June 1988, D&H filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law. The railway has debts of about $100 million. The D&H runs from the New York-Canadian border south to the Potomac Yard outside Washington, and from Albany, N.Y., west to Buffalo, N.Y. Last week, the Interstate Commerce Commission voted to allow three railroads to continue operating on D&H tracks while the trustee works out a plan to operate the line temporarily with subsidies from the states of New York and Pennsylvania, several other railroads and some shippers. The reprieve lasts until Friday night. Meanwhile, two Canadian railroads that had been trying to buy D&H have said they are still interested in working out a deal. Earlier this month, the trustee, Francis P. Dicello, recommended that D&H be sold to Canadian Pacific Ltd., which bid $35 million for the system. But the sale fell through when CP was unable to secure rights to run on Conrail tracks that connect with the D&H system. The Canadian National Railways had made a $45 million offer but lost its financial backing before it could make a formal bid last week. The D&H, which began in 1824 as a canal company, runs 20 to 25 trains daily. It owns 569 miles of track and has rights to another 1,012 miles. A shutdown would put 672 employees out of work.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Down, Employee Complaints Up
DOC.TEXT: Nordstrom Inc. stock stabilized after a two-day slide knocked 15 percent off its value, but bad news continued as a union official reported a flood of complaints and claims for back pay from the retailer's sales clerks. ``We're getting a lot of inquiries from stores around the country, with employees saying they want to get paid for work already done,'' Joe Peterson, president of Local 1001 of the United Food and Commercial Workers union, said late Wednesday. Nordstrom stock rose 75 cents Wednesday to $28.50 after dropping $5 on Friday and Tuesday. From its summertime high of $42.50 a share, Nordstrom stock has dropped 35 percent in value. Forty percent of the stock is owned by Nordstrom family members. Peterson said the union, which represents 2,000 of Nordstrom's 3,000 sales clerks in Washington state, had received more than 100 telephone calls a day in the past two days, and took in paperwork with more than $200,000 in claims by current and former Nordstrom employees. The calls followed an order from the state's Department of Labor and Industies last week requiring Nordstrom to pay two years' worth of unpaid overtime to its hourly employees in the state, he said. ``I think a lot of employees have been emboldened by the state findings,'' he said. ``We were averaging 15 to 20 calls a day up until the state findings.'' Meanwhile, Peterson said, the National Labor Relations Board was siding with the union on a complaint from last year that Nordstrom was attempting to bargain directly with workers, bypassing the union. He said the NLRB informed him Wednesday it was issuing a complaint against Nordstrom. Efforts to reach Nordstrom family members Wednesday night were unsuccessful. The company said Tuesday it was considering filing a lawsuit against the state to overturn the Department of Labor and Industries ruling, which cannot be appealed. The administrative ruling cited infractions that included failing to calculate overtime for some duties and lapses in bookkeeping. Peterson said the union has received claims so far totaling more than $2.4 million. Claims could soar to the hundreds of millions if the union goes through with a nationwide class-action lawsuit, as it has threatened, he said. Nordstrom has disputed the cost figures put out by the union. Peterson said the union didn't want to take legal action and would rather settle its differences with the company at the bargaining table. Nordstrom's stock also has been hurt by the company's announcement this week that fourth-quarter earnings will be lower than a year earlier. A decline would be the first since Nordstrom went public 19 years ago. Outside securities analysts had expected a 10 percent gain. The company also was the subject of an unflattering front page story in The Wall Street Journal Tuesday that detailed employee complaints, including the alleged practice of workers going ``off the clock'' to perform tasks such as stocking shelves, attending company meetings and delivering items to customers. Employees were quoted as telling of pressure to produce sales or be fired, and of back-stabbing efforts pitting employee against employee. Peterson said he felt Nordstrom didn't have to give up its niche in the marketplace but would have to change its practices toward employees. ``Their system fosters unfair labor practices, illegal employment practices and a lack of due process for employees,'' he said. Nordstrom has 60 stores in Washington, Oregon, California, Alaska, Virginia and Utah. It plans 16 more, including moving into Illinois, New Jersey, Maryland, Minnesota, Indiana, Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the LEONIA, N.J.-dated PM-Jaguar Recall story sent for WED PMs, Feb. 21, as f0017, are asked to use the following corrective. The story was written through, making this correction, late in the cycle as f0149.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported incorrectly on Feb. 21 that Jaguar XJ-2 models are being recalled for possible braking and cruise-control problems. The story should have said Jaguar XJ-S models are being recalled.

DOC.HEAD: Resorts Gets Two-Year License Renewal
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc. says the two-year casino license renewal it received from state regulators will help it shake free of bankruptcy and recover from the decline that has hit the Boardwalk's first gambling hall. The Casino Control Commission said Wednesday in its unanimous decision to renew the license that the gaming company must report monthly on its troubled finances. Company President David C. Hanlon said Resorts, the parent company to Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, can live with those restrictions. ``The conditions are essentially financial reporting conditions,'' he said. ``Hopefully, two years from now we'll be a strong company.'' As for now, the company is trying to restructure its debt-riddled finances in bankruptcy court, which the commission said it considered in its decision. ``The mere filing of a Chapter 11 action does not, in and of itself, warrant a conclusion that a company lacks financial stability,'' said acting commission Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong. ``The bankruptcy action is but one, albeit significant factor.'' She said Resorts had shown during commission hearings last week that it could become financially stable within the two-year license period under a ``flat growth'' scenario. Last month, Resorts won $14.3 million from gamblers, an 11 percent drop from the $16.1 million registered in January 1989, according to commission figures. The casino's ``win'' for all of 1989 dropped 6.4 percent to $227.4 million compared to the year before. Win is the amount of money gamblers lose, and does not take into account expenses. It is not profit. Under the flat growth forecast, Resorts will post a $500,000 cash deficit at the end of the year because of an extensive refurbishing program, the commission said in its ruling. The commission imposed conditions recommended by the Division of Gaming Enforcement that Resorts file monthly balance sheets, income statements and statements of cash flow and working capital. Resorts officials also must advise regulators on a monthly basis of significant deviations from financial projections and from prior financial performance. The commission stopped short, however, of requiring the casino to report daily or weekly, or to set a specific cash balance that would trigger the imposition of restricted accounts to ensure that wages, taxes and progressive jackpots are paid. Hanlon said he was pleased with the decision and confident the opening April 2 of the neighboring Taj Mahal casino would reverse the decline of the first gaming hall to open on the Boardwalk in 1978. Ironically, the Taj Mahal, a property originally owned by Resorts, led to some of its financial problems as construction costs since 1983 until its sale to Donald Trump in 1988 diverted money from Resorts and its capital expenditures. Hanlon emphasized the importance of Resorts' plans to win approval of its restucturing plan from bondholders and a bankruptcy judge. The plan seeks to shed about $400 million of the $927 million that Griffin assumed to finance his November 1988 purchase of the property from Trump. Griffin sold Trump the Taj Mahal in return. ``Our first priority is restructuring,'' Hanlon said after the hearing. ``We're going full speed ahead with it. Anthony J. Parrillo, the director of the Division of Gaming Enforcement, said the division was satisfied with the ruling, but took issue with the commission's refusal to set a $7.5 million cash balance trigger or to consider a worst-case scenario of less than flat growth. Ms. Armstrong said the commission could re-open the license process any time during the next two years. However, she also said Resorts had not hit the depth of the now-defunct Elsinore's Atlantis Casino Hotel, which in May became the first casino to close its doors after the commission found the gaming hall was insolvent.

DOC.HEAD: Honda Fights Subaru Over Trademarking Legacy Name
DOC.TEXT: Honda Motor Co. Ltd., which makes the Acura Legend car, said it has filed a complaint seeking to block a trademark for the Subaru Legacy car name. Bob Butorac, a spokesman for Honda's U.S. marketing arm in California, said Wednesday that his company is not challenging use of the Legacy name. Honda, however, does not want a trademark granted for the Legacy, Butorac said. He declined to elaborate. Honda's challenge was filed in December with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office in Arlington, Va., Butorac said. Telephones at the patent office were busy Wednesday afternoon. Fred Heiler, a Subaru spokesman, said an application for the Legacy trademark was filed July 29, 1989, by Fuji Heavy Industries Inc. of Japan, parent company of Subaru of America Inc. Heiler said his company conducted 2{ years of research into the Legacy name before using it on its compact car made in Japan and Lafayette, Ind. ``I think we did our homework,'' he said. ``Then this sort of comes out of left field, frankly.'' The Legacy's base price is about $15,000. A fully-equipped Legend, the top of Honda's Acura line of luxury cars, sells for about twice as much. Two other trademark battles involving automobile names were fought and resolved last year. General Motors Corp. and the Italian weapons maker Fabbrica D'Armi Pietro Beretta S.p.A. last May settled a suit bought by the gun-maker against GM for using the name Chevrolet Beretta. As part of the settlement, GM agreed to pay $500,000 to the Beretta Foundation for Cancer Research and Treatment. Chevrolet kept the name. In March 1989, a federal appeals court in New York turned aside a challenge by Mead Data Central Inc. of Dayton, Ohio, to Toyota Motor Corp.'s use of the name Lexus for a line of luxury automobiles. Mead Data markets a legal information retrieval service called Lexis. Two models of Lexus cars went on sale last September.

DOC.HEAD: Tektronix to Cut 600 From Payroll
DOC.TEXT: Tektronix Inc. will lay off 600 employees by late May because an anticipated sales increase has not materialized. Most of the layoffs will occur in Washington County in the Test and Measurement Group, Doug Babb, spokesman for the Beaverton-based electronics company, announced Wednesday. The Test and Management Group manufactures various products, including Tektronix's original product line, oscilloscopes. The group typically accounts for more than half Tektronix's sales, but its volume recently has declined at a faster rate than the company's other lines of business. Other employee cuts will occur in Tektronix operations that handle U.S. and international distribution channels. Babb said some employees to be laid off were told the news before Wednesday morning's public announcement while others had not yet been chosen. As required by the federal plant closure law, each employee involved will get 60 days' layoff notice and the opportunity to apply for posted vacancies elsewhere in the company, Babb said. ``We expected our new product flow would provide us with enough growth to begin to show earnings improvement,'' David P. Friedley, Tektronix's president, said in a prepared statement. After expenses for the cuts, plus taxes and other costs, are subtracted, the Beaverton-based company probably will post a loss for the quarter ending March 3, company officials announced. Friedley attributed the company's problems partly to weak demand in the defense, computer and semiconductor industries. ``Our product line and market positions remain strong,'' he said, ``but we must get our expenses into line with our revenue.'' The 44-year-old company manufactures electronic testing and measuring gear, television control room equipment, computer monitors and printers, and sophisticated computers known as work stations. The job cuts will continue a series of layoffs and job eliminations that have occurred at Tektronix since the early 1980s, when it was Oregon's largest employer with more than 24,000 workers worldwide. As of the last quarter ended Nov. 11, it had 15,136, of whom about 8,800 worked in the Portland-Vancouver, Wash., area. About 100 were cut from Tektronix last summer and 1,000 others were dropped between March and May 1988. Tektronix also recently announced it would close its plant on the English Channel Island of Guernsey, laying off 200 there and consolidating the manufacturing in Holland. Tektronix, whose sales have remained essentially flat since 1984, has gone back and forth between profits and losses in recent quarters. In the quarter that ended Nov. 11, it made a penny-a-share profit. For the present quarter, Wednesday's announcement said the company's operating income before taxes and interest expense would be ``near break-even.'' But those and employee severance expenses, which could reach $20 million, will push the company into the red, the announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: Pharmaceutical Company Combines Research, Medical Departments
DOC.TEXT: Upjohn Co. says it is forming one division to oversee drug development from discovery and testing to use in treating patients. Upjohn's pharmaceutical research and medical affairs divisions will be combined into a new corporate entity, Upjohn Laboratories, by April 1, the company said Wednesday. One goal is to focus research on areas where developments are most in demand, such as cardiovascular disease, cancer and viral diseases including acquired immune deficiency syndrome, Upjohn spokesman Joseph E. Galligan said. ``We can make the most rational use of our resources by focusing them on programs and projects that are closely tied to medical needs and market demands,'' said Theodore Cooper, Upjohn chairman, president and chief executive officer. Upjohn Laboratories will include facilities in Kalamazoo, Tsukuba, Japan, and Crawley, England. It also will oversee research efforts in Sweden, France, England and West Germany funded through Upjohn's European Discovery Center program. Dr. Jerry R. Mitchell, formerly vice president for pharmaceutical research, will be president of Upjohn Laboratories, the company said. Galligan said it hadn't been determined how employment would change under the reorganization. Upjohn has been making belt-tightening moves, including an offer of early retirement incentives in November for its 1,100 employees in the United States and Puerto Rico who were 55 and older. There have been 612 takers.

DOC.HEAD: Guess Jeans Needed Nakashes' Money, Attorney Says
DOC.TEXT: Jordache jeans merely provided investment capital when it bought into Guess jeans, a Jordache lawyer said, calling a lawsuit against the Nakash family a case of ``seller's remorse.'' Attorney Howard Weitzman also denied on Wednesday allegations by the Marciano brothers, who founded Guess, that the Nakash brothers sought to steal Guess designs for their Jordache line. ``The evidence will show that the Marcianos _ at the time the deal was made _ needed money,'' Weitzman said in his opening statement to a Superior Court jury. ``The evidence will show the (Marcianos') intent was to sell the company to the Nakashes,'' he said. ``The evidence will show that the Nakashes said, `Rather than just buy (the company), let's form a partnership.''' The Marcianos are seeking more than $500 million in damages plus a return of the Nakashes' half ownership of Guess. The latter part of the decision is up to Superior Court Judge Norman Epstein. Last year, a jury did find that the Nakashes intended from the start to steal for Jordache the trendy Guess designs that were catching the fancy of the fashion world. This week's proceedings launch the penalty phase of the trial. Weitzman contended that the Beverly Hills-based Marciano brothers were looking for outside financing before the Nakashes of New York agreed to purchase a half-interest in Guess in 1983. The Israeli-born Nakashes paid the Marcianos $4.75 million and extended a credit line as part of the deal, Weitzman said. Guess' sales have since skyrocketed, with sales volume exceeding $400 million in 1988, Weitzman said. ``This lawsuit is about seller's remorse,'' he said. The French-born Marciano brothers, Maurice, Armand, Paul and Georges, founded Guess in 1981 with an investment of $170,000. A frozen account containing the Nakashes' accrued share of Guess profits now contains more than $93 million, and the division of that account also is at stake. The Marcianos also contend the Nakashes were responsible for destroying a Guess fashion subsidiary, Gasoline. The Marcianos also have named as defendants a Hong Kong couple, Lee Sec Mon and his wife, who manufactured Jordache products in the British Crown Colony. They allege the Lees were to have manufactured Gasoline designs as well but diverted materials to Jordache. Weitzman told the jury he would show that ``the demise and destruction of Gasoline was caused by the Marcianos' failure to live up to their commitments.'' The Nakashes have filed a counter suit against the Marcianos in Superior Court as well as a federal court lawsuit that accuses them of racketeering.

DOC.HEAD: VMS Names New CEO
DOC.TEXT: VMS Realty Partners has named one of its founders, Joel A. Stone, president and chief executive officer, replacing Jeffrey Park. Park's departure comes just three months after he was brought in as a representative of Xerox Credit Corp., a subsidiary of Xerox that owns 25 percent of VMS. Wednesday's announcement comes a week after VMS, one of the nation's largest real estate companies, suspended ``non-essential'' payments to lenders and to its eight publicly owned mortgage investment funds, citing ``severe cash flow problems.'' Stone said Park left because of a difference of opinion with the company's founders. ``We acknowledged in November that we were in a difficult position,'' said Stone. ``The partners in VMS feel that the kind of decision-making that we need should be done by a partner. ``Jeff had signed up with the company with the intention of moving it ahead,'' Stone said. ``Following our decision to change direction, he decided this was not the place for him,'' Stone said.

Stock prices advanced broadly this morning in early, moderate trading after the Tokyo market and other overseas exchanges regained strength. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 7.66 points to 2,591.22 in the first half hour of trading. Advancing issues outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 620 up, 286 down and 467 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.87 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the key Nikkei index rose more than 400 points in early trading, but then plunged on a wave of computer-guided selling by foreign institutions. But the Japanese market recovered as investors gradually returned and computerized buy programs kicked in. By the close, the Nikkei index gained 92.51 points, or 0.25 percent, to move to 35,826.84. On Wednesday, the Nikkei plummeted more than 3 percent for its third-worst drop ever. The plunge helped set off a tumble on Wall Street, but the U.S. markets later recovered as institutional investors took advantage of bargains. This morning, the NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 0.30 to 181.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.63 at 353.58. On Wednesday, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed down 13.29 points to 2,583.56. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 577 up, 963 down and 455 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 159.24 million shares, up from 147.30 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Considering Tax Breaks for Charitable Contributions Abroad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government is considering giving companies more tax breaks for charitable contributions abroad amid concern friction may grow over Japanese investments in the United States, an official said today. The Foreign Ministry proposed the tax measure, and the Finance Ministry will consider it for implementation in the fiscal year starting April 1991, the Foreign Ministry official said. Full details of the measure were not made public. At a meeting last week, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama told leading businessmen he was concerned that Japan's image in the United States was in serious trouble. He urged Japanese businesses to contribute to U.S. communities in which they have businesses. Nakayama said the problem underlying Americans' fears about Japan ``is their feeling that Japan's policy objectives and the Japanese way of thinking are not clear and that it is impossible to guess where Japan's huge economic power is headed, and under what philosophy or principles. ``In short, there are an increasing number of Americans who think `The Japanese are faceless' or `There is no knowing what they are thinking.''' Tax regulations now permit Japanese companies abroad to deduct only contributions that promote Japanese culture, such as museum exhibits or cultural exchanges, the official said on condition of anonymity. Foreign branches of Japanese companies may, however, deduct contributions from foreign tax bills. The new proposal was designed to allow new foreign branches to make charitable contributions even before they turn a profit and must pay taxes abroad. Parent companies in Japan would be able to deduct contributions from their Japanese taxes, the official said. Japan has a weak tradition of corporate philanthropy, and business executives _ some as concerned about Japan's image abroad as the Foreign Ministry _ have said incentives are needed to encourage companies to become better corporate citizens in the United States. The Foreign Ministry's proposal will take time to work through the Finance Ministry, the official said. It must be studied in detail to determine its impact on tax revenues, he said. It would not, however, require approval by Parliament, the official said. Japan's foreign investment, especially in the United States, soared in recent years as Japanese companies built factories, bought foreign companies and real estate and sought land and labor cheaper than at home. Some investments provoked controversy in the United States, such as last year's purchase of Columbia pictures by Sony Corp. and the purchase of a controlling interest in New York's Rockefeller Center by Mitsubishi Estate.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Computer Laying Off 3 Percent of Work Force
DOC.NOTE: EDS: grafs 11-12 NEW to UPDATE with Macintosh price cuts; uppicks 11th graf pvs: ``Apple is ...
DOC.TEXT: In yet another step to cope with sagging profits and a sluggish market for personal computers, Apple Computer will lay off 3 percent of its work force as part of a major cost-cutting campaign. ``Although the transition we are experiencing is by no means an easy one, it is necessary to build an even stronger business foundation for the future,'' John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement Wednesday. Since December, Apple has been embroiled in a tumultuous restructuring that has included the resignation of the head of the company's domestic division. Also, the company's new products developer, Jean-Louis Gassee, reportedly is preparing to depart. The company also has implemented pay freezes, cuts in profit-sharing and even dropped company parties. Analysts say Apple must deal with rising customer dissatisfaction, sagging profits, management turmoil and worsening employee morale. ``This is an extremely important year for Apple, particularly in terms of product development and stability in the executive suite,'' said Benny Lorenzo, an analyst at Volpe, Covington & Welty in San Francisco. The most significant problem for Apple is its eroding position as the biggest supplier of easy-to-use computers, a position that has allowed it to charge substantially higher prices than competitors like IBM and Compaq Computers. Microsoft has released its Windows programs, a graphical interface that attempts to offer a user-friendly alternative to the Macintosh interface. Hewlett-Packard Co. also has unveiled a similar system called New Wave. Analysts say Apple's products are still easier to use, but not as much as they once were. Separately on Thursday, Apple announced immediate cuts of 10 to 17 percent off the suggested retail prices on all models of its Macintosh SE and SE@30 personal computers and LaserWriter IINT and IINTX printers sold domestically. David Hancock, senior vice president of marketing, said the cuts would allow Apple ``bring the Macintosh personal computing experience to more people.'' ``Apple is now paying the price for decisions they made several years ago when it elected to go for short-term profit gain, rather than taking advantage of its leading position to go for greater market share,'' said Jonathan Seybold, publisher of Los Angeles-based Seybold Report on Desktop Publishing. Sculley blamed the 400 layoffs on a slowdown in the U.S. personal computer industry, which after three years of double-digit growth is expected to grow no more than 9 percent in 1990. But analysts have faulted the world's second-largest personal computer maker for neglecting and even alienating its traditional customers. Apple failed to meet a critical customer need by not introducing an inexpensive updated version of its original Macintosh, which has loyal users worldwide. Instead, Apple introduced expensive Macintosh models for corporate use, where profits are greater. After numerous delays, Apple also released a portable computer considered by many as costly, bulky and difficult to read. Apple's stock rose 50 cents to $34 a share in national over-the-counter trading Wednesday. Most of the cuts in Apple's 13,500-member work force, which become effective in two months, will be made in domestic marketing and distribution and in personnel, finance, community and government affairs and customer service. The company will continue hiring workers for research and development and for its domestic sales force. Hirings also will continue in Apple's European and Pacific divisions. ``Most everybody left at the company is making a big sigh of relief, but Apple will still have the problem of low morale in its product development division that remains to be corrected,'' said Abigail Christopher of International Data Co., a market researcher in Framingham, Mass. Apple had sales of $5.3 billion last year, up about 25 percent from 1988. In the final three months of last year, however, sales rose only 6 percent and profits fell 11 percent. That was the third consecutive quarter of lower profits and came during the traditionally strong Christmas season. Dealers reportedly were angered that Apple did comparatively little holiday marketing for its 13-year-old Apple II line and support products, prompting customer fears that the company would abandon the machine that catapulted it to prominence. Lack of effective marketing also apparently crimped sales of the Macintosh Plus and Macintosh SE, the least expensive products in the Macintosh line. Many Apple employees increasingly have been complaining about the company's turmoil, especially the numerous restructurings since co-founder Steven P. Jobs was ousted in a 1985 power struggle with Sculley. ``These latest moves are basically the undoing of the last reorganization, and that's been the pattern,'' said Seybold.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Officials Discuss Trade Problems
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE today's trade talks; SUBs 13th graf to add comment from Japan trade ministry official; picks up 14th graf, `U.S. officials ...'
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials today accused Japan of not doing enough to reform deep-rooted business traditions and economic behavior that contribute to Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. After the first of two days of trade talks, members of the U.S. delegation complained that Japanese plans to help ease the trade imbalance ``hadn't gone as far as we hoped.'' ``It is very important to note that some progress has been made. But frankly, much more needs to be done,'' said a member of the U.S. delegation, who briefed reporters on condition he not be identified. U.S. trade negotiators had said going into today's session that they expected quick results in addressing the underlying causes of the persistent U.S.-Japan trade imbalance. U.S. trade negotiators are under heavy pressure from Congress to demonstrate progress in the 9-month-old talks, which are aimed at changing deep-rooted factors in both economies that contribute to the U.S. trade deficit with Japan. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills has said she expects ``a plan of action and a realistic down payment that shows resolve on both sides'' by this summer. The $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan accounted for 45 percent of 1989's $108.58 billion U.S. deficit. In two earlier rounds of talks, U.S. officials said Japan's high savings and investment rates, its land policies, exclusionary business practices and corporate alliances, inefficient retail distribution networks and pricing mechanisms all act as trade barriers. Japan, in turn, said inadequate savings and investment in the United States, short-term corporate strategies by U.S. firms, ineffective labor training and education and insufficient export promotion were structural factors underlying the trade imbalance. After talks in September and November, U.S. officials complained that the Japanese side had shown little evidence of flexibility or willingness to act quickly, while Japanese officials said such far-reaching changes could not be expected overnight. Japanese officials today explained a recently announced program involving tax, tariff and import promotion policies, NHK reported. The measures include tax incentives for importers and elimination of tariffs on 1,004 items. The immediate U.S. reaction to the Japanese presentation was ``severe,'' NHK said. An official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, speaking on condition of anonymity, concluded after the day's talks that it would take more time for the two sides to iron out their differences. U.S. officials had earlier reacted with caution to the measures, expressing skepticism over whether the import-boosting policies would really increase purchases of foreign-made goods. Another key area of contention is Japan's Large Retail Store Law, which requires firms wanting to open department stores or supermarkets to obtain consent from existing smaller stores that are generally reluctant to face competition from larger, more efficient retail outlets. The lengthy, complicated process of opening a large store takes about 10 years. In addition to protecting less efficient retailers and thereby driving up prices, the U.S. side says the law tends to restrict imports by limiting the number of foreign-owned stores and by restricting openings of large stores that tend to sell more imported products than traditional small stores. Williams said the U.S. side would call for abolition or revision of the law. Washington is also likely to urge an easing of laws restricting use of bank credit cards. While department stores and finance companies allow incremental payments on credit, purchases made with bank credit cards must be paid off entirely within one month _ a regulation that U.S. officials say tends to restrict overall consumer spending, and therefore spending on imports. On Friday, U.S. officials are expected to explain Washington's plans to increase low savings and investment rates and to bolster the competitiveness of U.S. firms.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures Falter As Rain Moistens Croplands
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely in reaction to precipitation overnight in key U.S. crop areas. One storm system brought beneficial rain to eastern Kansas in the heart of the wheat country while another poured welcome precipitation on the Midwestern corn and soybean region from central Iowa east into Illinois and Indiana. Other bearish factors this morning included a Brazilian soybean crop estimate from a semi-official Brazilian agency that was higher than expected, and indications that the Agriculture Department has rejected bids from Morocco and Sri Lanka for U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. With the slight early losses, the markets appeared to have lost momentum for further increases after Wednesday's moderate gains. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1 cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.85\ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $2.42\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with March at $1.36 a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 1} cents lower with March at $5.69\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with frozen pork bellies up sharply on technical factors. Live cattle were .03 cent to .45 cent higher with April at 75.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .35 cent higher with March at 80.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .03 cent lower to .28 cent higher with April at 48.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.35 cent to the limit 2 cents higher with March at 53.50 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled sharply lower on Wednesday while most pork futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Low-Calorie Fat Substitute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout. A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a low-calorie fat substitute made from milk and egg-white proteins for use in frozen desserts. The product, called Simplesse and described as an ``all natural'' fat substitute, is manufactured by the NutraSweet Co. It is designed to have the taste and texture of fat but with fewer than half the calories. The first product to be made with Simplesse will be a frozen dairy dessert called Simple Pleasures, which the company said has the creamy taste of ice cream but with significantly reduced calories and cholesterol. The FDA approved the company's petition to affirm that the food additive is ``generally recognized as safe.'' Simplesse is approved for use in frozen dessert products only. The company would have to get further FDA approval to use it in other foods, said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit. NutraSweet, a subsidiary of St. Louis-based Monsanto Co., also developed aspartame, the artificial sweetener marketed under the name NutraSweet. The FDA approved Simplesse for use as a thickener or texturizer in frozen dessert products. Simplesse contains proteins from egg whites or milk, or a combination of both. Foods containing Simplesse will have to include the product on their labels because some people are allergic to eggs or milk or both, the FDA said. Simplesse has also been approved for marketing in West Germany, the United Kingdom, Switzerland, Japan, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. The FDA is reviewing a petition from Kraft Inc. seeking approval for the use in frozen desserts of a fat substitute made from egg whites and milk proteins. Also under review is a petition from Proctor & Gamble Co. which wants to use a sucrose polyester called Olestra as a partial subsitute for fats and oils in shortenings, salad oils and cooking in the home and by the food service industry. Lisa Lefferts, staff scientist at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said the group has no safety concerns about Simplesse. However, the group has recommended that the FDA monitor the impact of products such as Simplesse on the American diet. ``Will we eat more and more double-dip ice creams and eat less nutritious foods, or will they help us lower our fat intake? We don't really know,'' Lefferts said. The company said Simple Pleasures will be introduced in chocolate, strawberry, rum raisin, coffe, peach and toffee crunch, and other flavors would be added later. As an example, the company said, Simple Pleasures Strawberry contains 120 calories and one gram of fat per four-ounce serving, compared with 250 calories and 15 grams of fat for the same amount of a leading `superpremium'' brand. Monsanto's stock surged as word of the FDA approval circulated on Wall Street, rising $4.37{ in early trading to $112.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Eurotunnel Names Director General Of The Tunnel Project
DOC.TEXT: Eurotunnel SA, the consortium building a tunnel under the English Channel, named a new director general for the project part of an agreement with its contractors. Eurotunnel said Wednesday Bechtel executive vice-president John Neerhout had been nominated to the position, replacing Alastair Morton, whose appointment had led to a dispute between Eurotunnel and the project's contracting group, Trans-Manche Link. Morton will hold the title of director general of Eurotunnel, the Anglo-French consortium said. Late Tuesday, Eurotunnel and TML struck a deal to defuse a financial crisis that had placed the tunnel project's future in doubt. Neerhout's appointment was part of the agreement. TML was unhappy with Morton's appointment and refused to sign a key financing agreement with Eurotunnel and creditor banks. The move effectively cut off all loan monies to Eurotunnel and forced the company to negotiate a settlement with the contractors. Eurotunnel issued a written statement late Tuesday saying the agreement allowed the parent company to draw on new loans from the banks. Eurotunnel also will comply with a court order to pay TML some $116 million in back fees. Morton had served as Britain's chief of project, responsible for negotiating with contractors. He developed a reputation as a tough bargainer and contractors viewed him as insensitive to their point of problems with cost overruns and delays. Alistair Fleming and Keith Bernard, deputy director general for contruction and deputy director general for transportation, will report to Neerhout, the Eurotunnel statement noted. The Anglo-French consortium said Morton also will remain as national president of Eurotunnel for Britain. Andre Bernard holds the position on the French side. Bernard will be the sole president of the common council which is responsible to all stockholders for the management of the group. Neerhout will also answer to the council.

DOC.HEAD: ICI Posts 13-percent Drop in Profit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `ICI said... to CORRECT second dollar amount to $581 million; PICKS UP 4th graf, `The company...
DOC.TEXT: Imperial Chemical Industries PLC, Britain's largest chemical concern, said Thursday its fourth-quarter pre-tax profit fell 13 percent, but that it still managed to post a 4.1-percent gain for the year. The fourth-quarter performance was hurt by a year-end slide in petrochemicals and plastics prices, the company said. ICI said its pre-tax profit for the three months ended Dec. 31 came to 296 million pounds, the equivalent of about $506 million, compared with 340 million pounds, or $581 million, in the same period a year earlier. The company said it does not provide net profit figures on a quarterly basis. It said earnings per share came to 26.7 pence, or 46 cents, compared with 30 pence, or 51 cents. Sales gained 10.4 percent to 3.3 billion pounds, or $5.6 billion, from 2.99 billion pounds, or $5.1 billion. For the year, ICI said its net profit rose 27 percent to 1.06 billion pounds, or $1.8 billion, from 837 million pounds, or $1.4 billion a year earlier. Earnings per share came to 135 pence, or $2.31, compared with 129.7 pence, or $2.22. Sales rose 13 percent to 13.2 billion pounds, or $22.6 billion, from 11.7 billion pounds, or $20 billion. The year's results were helped by strong profit growth in pharmaceuticals which offset flat performances in most other areas of the company's operations.

DOC.HEAD: Sony Reports Higher Quarterly Profits
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp. on Thursday said its third-quarter profits jumped 45 percent on strong sales gains in all of its electronic divisions and following the acquisition of Columbia Pictures. Net income for the quarter ended Dec. 31 totaled $293 million, compared with $202 million a year earlier. Net income per depositary share on a fully diluted basis was 85 cents, compared with 65 cents a year ago. Sony's net sales grew 42 percent to $6.01 billion from $4.29 billion a year earlier. The company said all of its elecronics divisions in all geographic regions posted sales gains. Sony noted particularly strong growth in the United States and in Europe, where sales soared 59 percent and 48 percent, respectively. Sales growth in Japan was slower, at a 30-percent rate. Booming business in eight-millimeter videotape recorders pushed sales of video equipment up 35 percent. Sony sold some 800,000 eight-millimeter video recorders in the quarter, up 550,000 units from a year earlier. The company expects to sell 2.4 million compact units in fiscal 1989, a spokesman said. Audio equipment sales rose 32 mainly on strong sales of compact-disk players. Several hit albums pushed recording sales _ including records, compact disks and video software _ up 72 percent. Results from Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., which Sony purchased in November for $3.4 billion, and the Gruber-Peters Entertainment Co. were included on the balance sheet for the first time during the quarter. Film sales for the two companies in November added $203 million to Sony's balance sheet. Sony had no revenue from films prior to the acquisitions. Sony said that the decline of the yen in 1989 added about 10 percentage points to overall sales growth in the third quarter by raising the value in yen of overseas sales. With stable exchange rates, sales growth would have been around 32 percent, according to a company spokesman. Sony said its average exchange rate on sales in the third quarter was 142 yen to the dollar, compared with 124 yen to the dollar in the year-earlier quarter. For the first nine months of the fiscal year, net income jumped 57 percent to $636 million, or $1.93 a share, from $406 million, or $1.35 a share in the year-earlier period. Sales for the nine months totaled $14.69 billion, up 31 percent from $11.23 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Reports $566 Fourth-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Pinnacle West Capital Corp. said Thursday it lost $566 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, primarily because of discontinued operations of its MeraBank and Malapai Resources Co. subsidiaries. The Resolution Trust Corp., created last year by Congress to dispose of the assets of failed thrifts, took control of MeraBank Jan. 31. Pinnacle West Chairman Richard Snell said the holding company was trying to sell Malapai, a uranium-mining subsidiary. Pinnacle West reported a loss of $6.53 per share in the quarter on revenue of $312 million. In the same 1988 period, the company said it lost $126.7 million, or $1.45 per share, on $325 million. For the full year, Pinnacle West lost $551 million, or $6.36 per share, on revenue of $1.51 billion, compared with a net profit of $4.2 million, or 5 cents a share, on $1.46 billion in revenue in 1988. Writing off the two ailing subsidiaries as discontinued, Pinnacle West said income from continuing operations was $125 million last year, compared to $153 million in 1988. Under an agreement with the government, Pinnacle West must complete a $450 million caital infusion into MeraBank by March 31. It then will be free of other obligations to the foundered thrift. The capital infusion is recorded as a non-recurring loss taken in the 1989 fourth quarter. No tax benefit was provided in the loss because Pinnacle West doesn't know when or to what degree a benefit can be realized, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Drivers Union Calls Strike Against Greyhound, No Talks Scheduled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, `The union...', to add current average salary for driver, based on company calculations. Also moved on general news wire.
DOC.TEXT: Contract negotiations between Greyhound Lines Inc. and its drivers' union have broken off, and a strike has been called for 12:01 a.m. March 2, the company said today. No discussions currently are scheduled between the company and the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, said George Gravely, a spokesman for the Dallas-based company that operates both Greyhound and Trailways, the only nationwide intercity bus systems. The union, which represents 6,300 drivers plus other maintenance and office workers, did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment. Gravley said the company received a letter today saying the strike would take place. The rank-and-file earlier had authorized a strike. Gravley said the company, which has been advertising for permanent replacement drivers in anticipation of a strike, would continue to operate. ``We have 600 people in school ... and are still taking applications,'' he said. The two sides had been negotiating since Friday in Phoenix, where the union is based, but remained far apart on wage issues. Joint meetings Friday and Monday, plus separate sessions with a federal mediator on Tuesday, failed to result in an agreement, Gravley said. The company, taken private three years ago in two deals totaling about $470 million, had offered a three-year contract worth about $63 million. Gravely said the union initially had sought a pact valued at $561 million, but reduced that to $475 million. The union wanted wage increases of 66 percent over the life of the contract, including a 50 percent raise in the first year. Greyhound offered a first-year increase of 7 percent. Currently, the average bus driver makes $24,743 a year, according to the company. ``It is an excellent offer from a company that lost $20 million over the last three years, and it is all this company can afford,'' said Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey, who led the buyout of the bus company from Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp. ``The union has not disputed the fact that we cannot afford to pay more than we have offered,'' he said. ``Instead, union leaders have told us repeatedly that an employer's ability to pay is `irrelevant.''' Besides the 6,300 drivers, the union represents 1,600 office workers and 1,475 maintenance workers.
