DOC.HEAD: Strawbridge & Clothier: Family-Owned Beacon in a Treacherous Retailing Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS age of company to 122 years in second graf
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: While some grand old American retailers have stumbled into bankruptcy court and others simply have vanished, one major department store is thriving with its founder's great-grandchildren in charge. Of the three major U.S. department store chains controlled by descendents, 122-year-old Strawbridge & Clothier is the oldest and the only one to last through four generations of potential sibling spats and inheritance squabbles. Strawbridge's has grown steadily through the takeover obsession of the 1980s in which many rivals became sodden with the debt obligations of new owners, some of whom didn't know much about the business. Perhaps the most notorious example is the Campeau Corp. of Canada, which bought Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and several other famous chains in the late 1980s for billions of dollars in borrowed money, then sought bankruptcy protection for them last month because it couldn't repay debts. Strawbridge's, by contrast, has expanded with its own money over the past decade. It has added four department stores and 10 discount stores in the Philadelphia area, considered one of the birthplaces of modern-day retailing. The company has 13 department stores and 23 discount stores in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware. Its presence is a beacon for Philadelphia shoppers who have witnessed Lit Brothers and Gimbels go broke and Wanamakers, the country's first retail department store, sold twice. Strawbridge's has been as steady as the modest Quaker family that runs it. Eighteen of its 20 top executives have been with the company at least 25 years and more than half its 110 mid-level managers have worked for the store 15 years or more. Strawbridge's claims one of the lowest turnover rates on the sales floor. It has surpassed traditional big brother Wanamaker's as the king of the city's department stores. Wanamaker's, coincidentally, once again is for sale. For its 1989 fiscal year ended in July, Strawbridge's earned $27.9 million on sales of $921.1 million. The company's sales are expected to exceed $1 billion in fiscal 1990. While many competitors' profits are drained by creditors or retained for a parent company, Strawbridge's has reinvested earnings in expansion and upkeep. ``The independence of the company is the major contributing factor to what we think of and call the uniquely personalized character of Strawbridge & Clothier,'' Francis R. Strawbridge III, chairman, once said in response to a lawsuit filed by an outside investor who wanted to buy the company in 1986. His uncle and family patriarch, G. Stockton Strawbridge, described the effort to remain family controlled as ``an ever present objective comparable to inhaling and exhaling.'' In an effort to avoid attracting the attention of would-be raiders, the camera-shy Strawbridge family resists press interviews about the business. One executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, attributed the family's unity to good fortune as well as G. Stockton Strawbridge's efforts at maintaining a tight-knit relationship. Strawbridge & Clothier is now run nearly entirely by the Strawbridge family. The Clothier family, whose wealth was devastated by the Great Depression, sold most voting shares in the 1930s. A Clothier sits on the board of directors, but is the only descendent of the founder involved with the stores. For family businesses, surviving beyond three generations can be difficult because interest in running the business often wanes from one generation to the next, said Ronald H. Drucker, a family business consultant with Philadelphia-based accountants Laventhol & Horwath. ``The problems pop up more in the third generation than the second,'' said Dean Schuckman, a partner and management consultant with the accounting firm Price Waterhouse. ``If the family is more sharing of the founder's vision, you're going to find less conflict among the siblings.'' For Strawbridge & Clothier, fertility has helped. The Strawbridges have been able to pick those interested and talented from a large pool of offspring. Strawbridge children aren't encouraged to enter the business, but if they want to pursue a career in retailing, they have to work at least a year at another major department store before entering Strawbridge's training program. Four members of the fourth generation work at the company. One fifth generation member, daughter of company President Peter S. Strawbridge, joined the advertising department in January after three years at Filene's in Boston. Francis R. Strawbridge III; his brother, David W. Strawbridge, personnel vice president; cousin Peter Strawbridge and his brother, Steven L. Strawbridge, treasurer and secretary, have 12 children among them and there are scores of other fifth generation children. Two other major department store chains still are family operated. Dillard's, based in Little Rock, Ark., started in 1938 and is still run by 75-year-old founder William Dillard. Nordstrom Inc., based in Seattle, is operated by the grandsons of the founder, who started the firm in 1901. Strawbridge's first opened in 1868 on the site of Thomas Jefferson's old U.S. Secretary of State office in downtown Philadelphia. Justus C. Strawbridge, then 30, took his landlord's son-in-law, Isaac H. Clothier, also 30, on as a partner in his fledgling dry goods store. The three-story house at the corner of Eighth and Market streets has grown to take up most of the block and anchor a downtown shopping mall. Since then, the company has had many offers, but faced its most serious challenge in 1984 when a New York investor named Ronald Baron was amassing shares in the company for a takeover attempt. Two years later, the Strawbridges defeated Baron by purchasing a crucial bloc of stock from dissident family member Robert E. Strawbridge III, who appeared ready to sell. The cost of retaining family control was $40 million. As an additional defense, the company has established a preferred class of stock that has 10 votes per share. Common stock has one vote per share. The board decides who can buy preferred stock. An executive who spoke on condition of anonymity said the company has considered, two or three times, a debt-financed restructuring to protect itself from more takeover attempts. But that alternative has been rejected by the family because it would divert too much money into debt payments. Without anxious junk-bond holders waiting to be paid or short-term investors looking for quick gains, Strawbridge's has been able to spend its profits on store improvements and maintenance. ``In plowing back those earnings they are able to keep our stores up to date, fashionable, attractive, exciting and places where people really like to shop, the lone Clother board member Isaac H. Clothier IV once said during the takeover fight with Baron. ``Nothing looks Dinty at Strawbridge and Clothier.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Overtakes Britain as Top Importer of Tea
DOC.TEXT: Although the British are indisputably the world's biggest tea fans, preliminary estimates released Thursday show that Britain for the first time lost its position as the world's top tea importer _ to the Soviet Union. Moscow's tea imports rose 92,000 metric tons last year to a record 227,000 tons, pushing the Soviet Union into first place, according to the independent business information concern the Economist Intelligence Unit. In its latest review of key commodity markets, the Economist Intelligence Unit estimated British imports totaled about 160,000 tons last year. The Rome-based Food and Agriculture Organization put British imports at 116,400 metric tons in the first nine months of 1989, down from 125,100 in the same 1988 period. The Soviet Union has increased the amount of tea it imports steadily since 1986, when its own tea crop grown in Georgia was severely damaged by fallout from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. Particularly heavy Soviet tea buying toward the end of last year, which coincided with crop problems in India, Sri Lanka and other key tea exporting countries, helped push world wholesale prices to three-year highs. At the peak last October, the average price paid at the weekly London tea auction hit $2,885 per ton. The price at this week's sale was at a six-month low of $2,095, according to the Tea Brokers' Association. The price decline is the result of improved supplies following a recovery in production in India and Sri Lanka toward the end of last year, traders said. The prospect of a supply shortfall for the second year running could lift the average price in 1990 to $2,360 a ton from $2,103 last year. The Economist Intelligence Unit said it expected Soviet imports to hold steady this year because it would be difficult to cut supplies ``during the present upheavals.'' Shortages of food and other goods have exasperated Soviet citizens and aggravated political turmoil at a time of serious unrest in some Soviet republics.

Stock prices rose today in moderate trading after the Tokyo market and other overseas exchanges regained strength and bargain hunters began buying. The market also benefitted from a firming in the price of U.S. government securities, analysts said. The bond market was boosted by comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who told a Senate committee that he sees no evidence inflation is accelerating and that it may in fact be decreasing. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 23.20 points to move to 2,606.76 by 3 p.m. EST. Advancing issues outnumbered losers by almost 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 900 up, 530 down and 498 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 148.95 million shares as of 3 p.m. In Tokyo, the key Nikkei index rose more than 400 points in early trading, then plunged on a wave of computer-guided selling by foreign institutions. But the market recovered as investors gradually returned and computerized buy programs kicked in. By the close, the Nikkei gained 92.51 points, or 0.25 percent, to 35,826.84. On Wednesday, the Nikkei plummeted more than 3 percent for its third-worst drop ever. The plunge helped set off a tumble in London and New York, but the U.S. markets later recovered as institutional investors took advantage of bargains. Dudley Eppel, managing director of equity trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp., said Wall Street exhibited optimism today. ``The fact that it acted acted so darn well yesterday when the rest of the world was falling apart gave some of the U.S. players hope that this market could hold in here awhile,'' he said. Philip Morris, one of the most active NYSE issues, was up | to 38\. The company said its Kraft General Foods division would aggressively seek acquisitions by about 1991. Union Carbide, another active blue-chip issue, was up 1\ at 23} amid rumors of a possible takeover bid or the spinoff of one of its divisions. The company declined comment. Among other blue chips, American Telephone & Telegraph was up \ at 39, IBM was down [ at 104} and General Electric was up } to 61\. Monsanto jumped 5~ to 113} on news that the Food and Drug Administration approved the company's fat substitute, Simplesse, which Monsanto says it initially will market as a low-calorie fat replacement in frozen desserts. UAL dropped 3\ to 129. The Wall Street Journal reported that the airline company's chairman, Stephen Wolf, decided not to back a union-led employee buyout that didn't include him. Pfizer, one of the most-active issues on the NYSE, fell 3~ to 59~ on news reports that the pharmaceutical maker could face a major product-liability case over a heart value once sold by a subsidiary. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.07 to 182.14. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.27 at 354.22.

DOC.HEAD: Paulson Drops Learjet Acquisition Plan
DOC.TEXT: The group that is acquiring Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. has let its $60 million agreement to buy Learjet Corp. expire, due to fears that the bankruptcy filing by Learjet's parent Integrated Resources Inc. could hamper the deal. A spokesman for Gulfstream said the company's chairman, Allen E. Paulson, decided to drop plans to acquire the corporate jet maker out of concern that the bankruptcy case could lead to a bidding fight for Learjet. Integrated, a diversified holding company based in New York, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors on Feb. 13. That same day, a group led by Paulson and the investment firm Forstmann Little & Co. announced an agreement to buy Gulfstream for $825 million from Chrysler Corp. and a letter of intent to buy Learjet. ``Because of the complications of the bankruptcy filing, the possibility of an approval (of the Learjet sale) by the bankruptcy court would take too long to resolve and could end up in a bidding situation,'' said Gulfstream spokesman Al Balaban. Although Learjet was not included in Integrated's bankruptcy filing, the sale of Learjet would need bankruptcy court approval, said Learjet spokesman Bill Robinson. ``We still are an asset of Integrated Resources,'' he said. Following the Gulfstream announcement Thursday, Learjet said it would begin accepting other offers for the company. Integrated has been trying to sell Learjet, which is based in Wichita, Kan., since August. ``As a matter of fact, we have an interested company visiting our plant today,'' Robinson said. Balaban said Paulson's top priority now wass completing the acquisition of Gulfstream, the Savannah company he founded in 1978. Chrysler bought Gulfstream from Paulson for $637 million in 1985 and made it part of its Chrysler Technologies Corp. subsidiary. Chrysler put the maker of corporate jets up for sale as part of its move to concentrate on building cars and trucks. Learjet this week lost a U.S. Navy subcontracting bid worth more than $1 billion to produce more than 200 Tanker Transport Trainer System aircraft, but Balaban said that had nothing to do with Pauslon's decision to back away from Learjet.

DOC.HEAD: Five-Year Note Yields Rise
DOC.TEXT: Yields on five-year Treasury notes rose in Thursday's auction to the highest level since last May. The average yield was 8.53 percent, up from 7.77 percent at the last auction on Nov. 29, 1989. It was the highest rate since five-year notes averaged 8.72 percent on May 25, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8{ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,980.50. A total of $8.05 billion in notes was sold out of bids totaling $30.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Midland Posts Loss for 1989
DOC.NOTE: EDS: restores dropped word `charge' in lead; UPDATES with court ruling and associated charge; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Midland Bank PLC on Thursday reported it lost $374 million in 1989 after an exceptional $1.5 billion charge mostly to cover losses on loans to lesser developed countries. The loss compared with a profit of $718 million, or 92 cents a share in 1988. The bank said that on a pre-tax basis, it lost $446 million, compared with a profit of $1.19 billion a year earlier. Total operating income came to $5.4 billion, up 11 percent from $4.9 billion. The exceptional charge included $1.4 billion against principal due on loans to various lesser developing countries, it said. Total loan exposure to less developed countries rose to $8.2 billion last year from $7.3 billion in 1988. The charge also included $53 million to cover potential losses associated with a British court judgment last year voiding interest-rate swap contracts with municipal councils in Britain. The appellate High Court on Thursday ruled that interest-rate swaps by certain councils were unlawful. The bank's assets totaled $107 billion at the end of the year, compared with $95 billion at the end of 1988. The bank didn't break out quarterly or half-year results. It isn't required to under British law.

DOC.HEAD: San Jacinto Wants $1.4 Billion From Parent Southmark
DOC.TEXT: San Jacinto Savings and Loan Association has filed a $1.4 billion claim against its parent Southmark Corp., saying the junk-bond built company now in bankruptcy court forced it to make bad loans. Southmark had envisioned San Jacinto as its core business after emerging from bankruptcy court proceedings. Southmark last month submitted a Chapter 11 reorganization plan calling for the sale of nearly all assets except San Jacinto. Southmark on Thursday reported a net loss of $56.8 million on revenue of $267 million for its first quarter ending Sept. 30, 1989. That compared with net income of $1.14 million on revenue of $561 million in the same 1988 period. After allowing for a dividend on special stock, the per-share results amount to a loss of $1.24 in the 1989 period against a loss of 20 cents in the 1988 period. Southmark said the lower revenue was offset in part by shrinking administrative expenses, plus $31 million in interest saved by the bankruptcy filing. The report was delayed while the company formulated its reorganization plans. A plan submitted in court last month called for retaining Houston-based San Jacinto and turning over remainding assets to creditors after pumping an additional $100 million into the thrift. But creditors Wednesday called the plan unworkable and asked U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Steven Felsenthal for permission to submit their own reorganization proposal that would surrender the thrift to regulators and quickly liquidate the remaining company. A hearing on the creditors' request to end Southmark's exclusive right to propose a plan is scheduled for March 14. San Jacinto's $1.4 billion claim against Southmark seeks payment for $584 million in bad syndication loans guaranteed by Southmark and as much as $376 million in loans made at the direction of the company. San Jacinto is the only large savings institution in Texas that hasn't been seized or sold by federal regulators. When Southmark bought the thrift in 1983, it entered into agreements with regulators to maintain the institution's net worth above required minimums. The thrift said its tangible capital had fallen about $19.5 million below regulators' minimum levels. San Jacinto claims Southmark owes another $274 million to meet the new risk-based capital requirements imposed by last year's federal thrift bailout legislation. The creditors claim the thrift is losing $10 million a month and is failing to meet its business plan, according to court papers filed by a group of the company's creditors. They say the proposed $100 million injection still would leave San Jacinto short of minimum capital requirements, putting the S&L at risk that regulators could seize it at any time. Southmark representatives, citing continuing negotiations between the company and its creditor group, declined to comment on the committee's contentions. The creditors are mainly holders of over $1 billion in junk bonds. Southmark filed for protection from creditors last July after saying it could not meet payments on more than $1.1 billion in mainly high-yield bonds. Southmark used the bonds to finance an expansion into an $8 billion asset company with holdings including campgrounds, insurance companies and a chain of nursing homes, in addition to various real estate enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: Highest VA Rate Goes to 10 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Veterans Affairs said Thursday it is raising its maximum interest rate for federally backed VA home mortgages by one-half percentage point to 10 percent, effective Friday. ``The higher rate is a response to current demands of the financial markets for higher yields on long-term investments,'' the department said in a statement. The department had lowered the rate to 9.5 percent from 10 percent last July 17. The department said it also will increase by one-half percentage point the maximum rates on a variety of other loans. Rates on graduated payment mortgages will go to 10.25 percent; home improvement loans, 11.5 percent; manufactured home loans, 12.5 percent; manufactured home lot-only loans, 12 percent; and manufactured home and lot loans, 12 percent. VA home loans may be used to purchase, improve or refinance a house or condominium, and to purchase or refinance a manufactured home. In the fiscal year ending last Sept. 30, the department guaranteed more than 188,000 home loans amounting to a total of $14.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: First Day Of Trade Talks Yields Less Than Expected, Both Sides Say
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials engaged in trade negotiations with Japan said Thursday that country has not done enough to address the underlying causes of the persistent U.S.-Japan trade imbalance. At the conclusion of the first of two days of talks, U.S. delegates complained that Japan's plans to help ease its $49 billion trade surplus with the United States ``hadn't gone as far as we hoped.'' In particular, Japan is moving too slowly in changing its high savings and investment rates, land policies, exclusionary business practices, inefficient retail distribution networks and pricing mechanisms, U.S. officials said. ``It is very important to note that some progress has been made. But frankly, much more needs to be done,'' said a member of the U.S. delegation, who briefed reporters on condition he not be identified by name. On Friday, it is the United States' turn to explain what it is doing to change American practices that contribute to the imbalance. U.S. officials said they would outline Washington's plans to increase the low U.S. savings and investment rates and to bolster the competitiveness of American firms. The talks, called the Structural Impediments Initiative, were launched last May after years of exchange rate adjustments and other steps failed to significantly reduce the imbalance. This round of talks, originally set for early January, was postponed at Japan's request until after national parliamentary elections Sunday that kept the Liberal Democratic Party in power. ``Because of the election, we did lose time and we believe strongly that we need to get moving quickly and move forward to some solutions,'' said Deputy U.S. Trade Representative S. Linn Williams. After the delay, U.S. officials said, they expected Japanese leaders to produce plans for both long-term measures and immediate actions to tackle structural trade problems. U.S. trade negotiators are under heavy pressure to demonstrate progress in the talks to stave off protectionist trade legislation in Congress. ``The political realities are such that SII is not viewed with... patience and therefore if that process is going to yield results it needs to yield a sort of midterm dividend payment very quickly,'' David C. Mulford, U.S. Under Secretary for International Affairs, told a business audience in New York Thursday. ``We would all lose if the failure to remove these impediments leads to more, rather than less, protection.'' U.S. officials say Japan's high savings and investment rates, its land policies, exclusionary business practices, inefficient retail distribution networks and pricing mechanisms all indirectly restrain trade. On Thursday, Japanese officials explained measures in a draft budget before Parliament to boost staffing of Japan's Fair Trade Commission, its anti-monopoly enforcement authority; to increase spending on public infrastructure such as roads and sewers, and to reform the retail distribution system. They also explained revisions of Japan's land use law aimed at curbing real estate speculation and increasing the supply of available land in urban areas. The U.S. side contends that excessive land prices in Japan drive up the cost of doing business, making it harder for foreign firms to sell their products here. ``We carefully explained the steps that we're taking and in many areas received an assessment from the U.S. side, but other areas remain where there were still differences. It's going to take more time,'' said an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, speaking on condition of anonymity. Members of the U.S. delegation said the presentations ``represented new actions and some progress, but it's clear to us they haven't gone as far as we hoped with bold, new thinking.'' ``Too often today, instead of new ideas on how to solve the problems, we heard simply a defense of the status quo,'' one U.S. official said. U.S. officials said they made a number of suggestions on possible revisions of Japan's Large Retail Store Law. The law requires firms wanting to open department stores or supermarkets to obtain consent from existing mom-and-pop stores generally reluctant to face competition from larger stores. In addition to protecting less efficient retailers and thereby driving up prices, the U.S. side says the law tends to restrict imports by limiting the number of foreign-owned stores and by restricting openings of large Japanese stores that tend to sell more imported products than traditional small stores. After structural talks in September and November, U.S. officials complained that the Japanese side had shown little evidence of flexibility or willingness to act quickly, while Japanese officials said such far-reaching changes could not be expected overnight. Williams characterized the latest talks as ``neither successful nor disappointing.'' But he said the talks were ``on the right track. In many ways I wish we had gotten on the track earlier.'' Japan says U.S. problems contributing to the trade imbalance include inadequate savings and investment, the short-term nature of U.S. corporate strategies, ineffective labor training and education and insufficient export promotion. Both delegations said they expected to produce an interim report on progress in the structural talks by early April after an additional meeting in March. A final report is expected by summer.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Chief Predicts Higher Profit But Lackluster Sales
DOC.TEXT: Despite expectations of only modest sales growth, Avon Products Inc.'s chairman on Thursday said earnings will improve substantially this year. James E. Preston, chairman and chief executive officer, also said the company has had conversations recently with various investors holding stakes in Avon, including investment partners in Chartwell Associates. ``We're expecting substantial improvement in earnings for the company in 1990 on a modest increase in sales,'' Preston told a meeting of Wall Street analysts. He also estimated that the company's debt will be shaved to about $275 million by the end of this year from about $630 million now. Avon cut its debt by about $500 million last year, he said. In the current first quarter, Preston said net income will be up ``nicely'' on a slight decline in sales. He attributed the anticipated earnings growth to cost reduction programs and lower interest expenses and tax rates. Preston didn't provide specific figures. But he did say the planned sale, announced Wednesday, of Avon Japan will produce an after-tax gain of about $180 million this year. Avon has agreed to sell its 60 percent stake in Avon Japan to a private Japanese mail order company for $408 million in cash at the closing _ $338 million plus $70 million in advance royalties. Another $42 million in advance royalties is to be paid 18 months later. Last year Avon had a profit of $54.6 million, or 34 cents a a share, after a deficit of $404.5 million, or $6.79 a share, in 1988 when it had $545.6 million in losses from discontinued operations. Meanwhile, Preston said in response to a question that he and other Avon executives have had conversations with stockholders with significant holdings of Avon, including two separate groups led by Minneapolis-based investor Irwin Jacobs and Texas financier Robert M. Bass. He characterized the contact with these two groups as ``positive, supportive and helpful.'' At a meeting with Chartwell, a limited partnerhip, Preston said Avon repeated that the big New York-based beauty products company is not for sale. Chartwell, which holds about 9.1 percent of Avon's stock, has said it intends to launch a proxy fight to win four seats on Avon's 11-member board. A proxy battle is an attempt by a person or group to take over a company or oust its management by obtaining enough proxies _ the legal right to exercise a shareholder's vote _ to influence a corporate election. Partners in Chartwell include a subsidiary of Dallas-based Mary Kay Corp., the privately held parent of Mary Kay Cosmetics, a direct seller of beauty products. Avon is the world's biggest direct sales company. Preston said he emphasized to Chartwell that Avon's sales representatives wouldn't welcome any link to Mary Kay whatsoever. ``Over time Mary Kay has become the enemy to Avon representatives,'' he said. Chartwell has maintained that if it decided to pursue Avon, it wouldn't propose a combination of it and Mary Kay.

DOC.HEAD: Hit New Record in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 497 money market mutual funds rose by $3.57 billion in the latest week to an all-time high of $390.68 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday broke the earlier record of $387.48 billion set in the week ended Feb. 7 and followed a drop of $375 million in the week ended Feb. 14. That decline originally was reported as $374.1 million but was revised. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 244 general purpose funds rose $1.33 billion to $132.55 billion, assets of 101 broker-dealer funds increased $992.2 million to $165.46 billion, and assets of 152 institutional funds rose $1.25 billion to $92.67 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds was 7.65 percent in the week ended Tuesday, unchanged from the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.67 percent from 7.68 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 43 days, unchanged from the previous week, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.28 percent as of Wednesday from 6.29 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was 5.07 percent, unchanged from the previous week. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.87 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.88 the previous week. Yields were 7.93 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.94 percent; 7.95 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 7.94 percent; and 7.99 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.00 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Introduces Electronic Film Editor
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. on Thursday unveiled an electronic film-editing system that marks the company's entry into the emerging field of hybrid electronic photography. The Premier image enhancement system uses electronics to take the place of a razor blade or airbrush in manipulating a film image. It can be used for retouching, cropping, creating composite images, or changing the color, balance and contrast of a photograph. ``Electronics is going to take over the manipulation and storage of images in many ways,'' said Raymond H. DeMoulin, head of Kodak's professional photography division. Kodak's experience in traditional photography gives the company an edge in hybrid technology, said Eugene Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Hybrid systems such as Premier have the potential to improve the quality of photographic prints, which could increase sales of conventional film products that are Kodak's mainstay, Glazer said. Premier, introduced at the Photo Marketing Association International convention in Las Vegas, is faster and produces higher quality images than systems already on the market, DeMoulin said. The system is made up of a film reader and film writer, identical gray boxes the size of a large chest of drawers, and a computer workstation based on a modified Sun Microsystem computer. The film reader accepts color negatives, color transparencies or lithographic films, which it scans at a resolution of up to 3,600 picture elements, or pixels, per inch. The digitized image can then be edited in a variety of ways using an electronic pen or ``puck.'' The film writer writes the altered image on new film _ either color transparencies or color negative film _ creating a high-quality second-generation original. Images can also be stored on 8mm videotape or transmitted electronically. DeMoulin said the quality of the final product is indistinguishable from that of the original. Premier operates on the red-blue-green continuous tone technology of film, rather than the cyan-magenta-yellow-black technology of graphic arts systems, DeMoulin said. Kodak's final display in New York City's Grand Central Station _ a huge photograph of a plump red apple floating behind the city's skyline _ was made on Premier. Making the composite picture the traditional way would have meant hours of cutting around the fine details of the skyline with a razor blade and then rephotographing it with the picture of the apple, said Robert Blakey of Kodak's Professional Photography Division. Premier's zoom feature allowed the picture of the skyline to be enlarged, making it easier to edit tiny details. The system, which will be sold beginning this fall for under $500,000, is targeted at full-service photo labs doing advertising work, magazine art or other large photo displays, DeMoulin said. He said Kodak eventually hopes to produce smaller, simpler models to serve smaller labs and professional photographers.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Against Yen
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK (qh4he dollar rose against the Japanese yen in lackluster trading Thursday but finished mostly lower against other major currencies. Gold prices fell worldwide. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $415.70 a troy ounce, down $2.30 from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $416.20 an ounce, off $1.60. Traders said the spotlight was fixed on the Japanese yen, which lost ground against most major currencies. The dollar rose to its highest level since September against the yen, which languished amid dimmed prospects for higher interest rates. The market had been expecting the Bank of Japan to hike the nation's key discount rate. ``Japan's interest rates are a lot lower than everybody else's interest rates,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston. ``Given that, people are looking for a much weaker yen.'' High interest rates make a country's fixed-income securities attractive to investors, who need hard currency to make their investments. Earlier in Europe, the dollar put in a mixed performance while confined to well-established ranges. When trading shifted to the United States, the dollar appeared to firm but ultimately finished lower against all major currencies except the yen. ``Cross-rates are mostly it,'' said a dealer at a British commercial bank. ``The dollar is really sidelined.'' In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 145.23 yen, up 0.08 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar traded at 145.90 yen. In New York the dollar continued to rise, closing at 146.53 yen, up from 145.50 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound held steady at $1.7145. In New York it cost $1.7133 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.7125. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday included: 1.6717 West German marks, down from 1.6725; 1.4755 Swiss francs, down from 1.4795; 5.6620 French francs, down from 5.6730; 1,236.00 Italian lire, down from 1,238.00, and 1.1949 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1983. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday included: 1.6695 West German marks, up from 1.6645; 1.4725 Swiss francs, down from 1.4735; and 5.6580 French francs, up from 5.6500. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $417.45 a troy ounce, from $418.85 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $417.25, from $419.50 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $2.85 to close at $416.83. Silver prices also fell. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery slipped to $5.268 an ounce, from $5.272 on Wednesday. In London the metal fell to a late bid price of $5.28 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $5.33.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Rise
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices rose Thursday despite persistent concerns that crude oil supplies continue to exceed demand. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, inched up 1 cent to $21.75 a 42-gallon barrel. Analysts said Wednesday's American Petroleum Institute report showing a 3.7 million barrel drop in crude oil stocks to 344.9 million barrels last week helped firm front-month prices. Otherwise, the April contract would have declined as the market focuses on refinery mainentance slowdowns scheduled for March and April which will reduce refiners' short-term demand for raw oil. ``We're looking at a soft demand schedule,'' said John Hill, energy analyst with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. May crude oil closed 13 cents higher at $21.73 and June rose 19 cents to $21.59. Hill said the narrow spread between the April and May contracts suggests the possibility that the April contract will go lower in coming days. Refined products futures also rose despite the API data that showed a rise in inventories. March unleaded gasoline increased 0.84 cent to 60.25 cents a gallon, April advanced 0.89 cent to 61.09 cents and May closed 0.86 cent higher at 64.94 cents. No. 2 heating oil for March delivery gained 0.62 cent to 58.15 cents a gallon, April edged up 0.23 cent to 56.98 cents and May added 0.36 cent to 55.96 cents. Analysts said cold weather helped lift heating oil prices despite the API data.The API report, released after the close of trading Wednesday, showed that gasoline stocks rose 2.1 million barrels to 240 million barrels and distillate inventories increased 2.6 million barrels to 119.3 million barrels.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Futures Reach 7-Month Highs on Supply Worries
DOC.TEXT: Coffee futures prices reached seven-month highs Thursday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange in a rally fueled by supply worries and strong technical signals. On other commodity markets, precious metals weakened; petroleum futures rose; wheat and corn futures advanced while soybeans retreated; and most livestock and meat futures moved higher. Coffee futures settled 1 cent to 2.25 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March up 1.52 cents at 91.16 cents a pound, the highest close for March coffee since July 21 and the highest for a near-month coffee contract since July 6. Analysts linked the advance to perceptions that high-grade coffee beans are becoming more difficult to obtain and speculation that more coffee-producing nations may be forced to cancel coffee shipments due to dwindling old-crop supplies and poor growing conditions for the new crop in South America. Mexico reportedly canceled some of its export commitments two weeks ago. Coffee prices have been climbing steadily back this year from the 14-year lows reached last fall after the International Coffee Organization suspended export quotas on July 3, exposing coffee prices to free-market forces. Since the year began, coffee for March delivery has risen from less than 80 cents to more than 91 cents a pound, a gain of nearly 15 percent in just six weeks. The ease with which the market has ascended through price levels of expected resistance has attracted chart-based buying. ``On the technical side, the charts are looking very, very strong,'' said Arthur Stevenson, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. A meeting next week of U.S., Central American and Colombian trade representatives in Guatemala is seen by some analysts as a step toward eventual reinstatement of coffee export quotas. But other observers see little chance of any movement on the issue in the near future. ``Particularly with prices going up, there's going to be less interest in reinstating quotas,'' said Sandra Kaul, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Precious metal futures retreated in reaction to a stronger dollar and a stronger U.S. stock market, although stock prices fell after the metal futures markets closed. Gold finished $2.30 to $2.60 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with February at $415.70 a troy ounce; silver was 0.4 cent to 1.3 cents lower with March at $5.273 a troy ounce. Energy futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange with strength stemming from Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report, which showed lower-than-expected U.S. supplies of distillates and crude. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent to 18 cents lower with April at $20.65 a barrel; heating oil futures were .23 cent to .66 cent higher with March at 58.15 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .35 cent to .89 cent higher with March at 60.25 cents a gallon. Supply concerns pushed wheat and corn futures prices moderately higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade but soybean futures closed lower amid profit-taking. The contract for March delivery of wheat rose 5 cents amid indications of dwindling supplies certified as deliverable against the contract. Next Wednesday is first notice day for March wheat, the first chance for traders to declare their intentions to deliver grain against futures contracts. Wheat futures settled \ cent lower to 5 cents higher with March at $3.89{ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 3 cents higher with March at $2.45 a bushel; oats were { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.37{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 3 cents lower with March at $5.68 a bushel. Frozen pork belly futures soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting strong technical signals and projections for stronger demand from bacon slicers. Live cattle futures settled .07 cent lower to .35 cent higher with April at 75.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .45 cent higher with March at 80.42 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent to .73 cent higher with April at 48.65 cents a pound; pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with March at 54.15 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Measures Rise
DOC.TEXT: Three measures of the nation's money supply each rose in the week ended Feb. 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, edged up $100 million to a seasonally adjusted $798.6 billion from a revised $798.5 billion the previous week. The prior week was initially reported at $799.2 billion. The central bank said the measure known as M2 rose $3.0 billion to a seasonally adjusted $3,252.5 billion from a revised $3,249.5 billion the previous week. The previous week's figure had been reported at $3,251.7 billion. An even broader measure, M3, rose $3.4 billion to a seasonally adjusted $4,068.9 billion from $4,065.5 billion. The previous week's figure was initially reported at $4,067.8 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 6.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 4.2 percent, also within the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,226.2 billion, a 4.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4.067.8 billion, up 3.2 percent, while M1 rose 4.9 percent to an average of $794.4 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $1.659 billion a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $1.037 billion the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net borrowed reserves averaged $355 million in the latest two weeks, compared with net free reserves of a revised $378 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $298.5 billion in the latest two-week period, down from $300.5 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Taking $300 Million Charge For Litigation Costs
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. on Thursday lowered its fourth quarter and 1989 profit estimates by $300 million to account for legal costs and additional cleanup charges associated with last year's Alaska oil spill. The revision marked the first time the world's largest oil company has included litigation expenses in its spill-related charges, which now total more than $2 billion. It also coincides with Alaska Attorney General Douglas Baily's disclosure that Justice Department and Exxon attorneys might file a plea bargain settlement Friday over pending criminal charges for environmental damages from the spill. A dollar amount involved in a possible settlement has not been disclosed. The additional charge announced Thursday brings to $800 million the amount Exxon deducted for out-of-pocket, spill-related expenses in the fourth quarter. ``New developments and assessments led to the revised estimate of future costs associated with the Valdez accident,'' Exxon said in a statement released late Thursday. Spokesman Bill Smith declined to provide details except to say they were for ``past as well as anticipated'' litigation, cleanup and environmental restoration expenses. ``We haven't broken it down,'' Smith said. Smith said the company did not know whether the company plans to add additional charges in 1990 for legal or other costs. An Exxon tanker that ran onto a reef last March 24 in Alaska's Prince William Sound spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil, fouling miles of shoreline and killing fish and other wildlife. In addition to the charges, there are 170 spill-related lawsuits pending against Exxon. For the fourth quarter, Exxon estimates its earnings will total $485 million, or 37 cents a share, down 65 percent from $1.4 billion, or $1.06 a share, in the comparable 1988 period. Exxon earlier estimated fourth-quarter profits of $785 million, or 61 cents a share. Revenue was up 15 percent in the quarter to $26.6 billion from $23 billion. For all of 1989, Exxon revised its earnings estimate to $3.5 billion, or $2.74 a share, from its earlier $3.8 billion, or $2.98 a share. That was a 34-percent drop from $5.3 billion, or $3.95 a share, in 1988. Revenue was $96.1 billion compared with $88.6 billion. The latest provision comes on top of charges totaling $880 million in the first and second quarters and more than $400 million in insurance proceeds that Exxon has said it expected to have available to help pay for spill-related cleanup costs. Exxon annnounced this week that it would return to Alaska on May 1 to clean up remnants of the spill. Exxon's announcement followed a Coast Guard declaration essentially ordering the company to return. Although Exxon has said it would continue the cleanup this spring, it also has worried state and environmental officials by insisting that the wind and wave action would make cleaning unnecessary this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Integrated Posts $184 Million Loss in Latest Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The fallen financial services company Integrated Resources Inc. said Thursday that it lost $184 million in its third quarter, reflecting the problems that led to its recent filing for bankruptcy court protection. The company said the loss amounted to $24.81 a share for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with a profit of $3.84 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the period plummeted to $33.5 million from $104.4 million a year earlier. Integrated said the loss resulted from ``liquidity and financial problems'' and reflected writedowns on its assets that the company either sold or planned to sell as it tried to deal with those problems. The onetime high-flying concern filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws on Feb. 13 after some of its creditors balked at restructuring more than $1.6 billion in debt. Integrated had tried to build a financial services empire with about $800 million in junk-bond fincancing provided by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., but was unable to meet the high interest payments due on the debt. Integrated's filing for bankruptcy court protection came within hours of Drexel's parent seeking the same protection. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Integrated said it lost $1.22 billion, or $165.53 a share, in contrast to a profit of $23.7 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier. Nine-month revenue fell 32.7 percent to $214.2 million from $318.2 million a year earlier. Integrated said it was forced to write down the carrying value of assets of certain publicly offered limited partnerships that Integrated sponsored and managed and now expects to sell. Integrated said it also had losses from operations as its financial problems impaired its ability to market investment programs. In addition, the loss reflects the lower than expected price the company received in selling several of its key fianancial services businesses to Broad Inc., a Los Angeles-based financial services concern. Integrated sold the businesses, which included brokerage, asset management and life insurance businesses, for $95 million last month, well below the $450 million that it had hoped to receive.

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Shoppers Say They Still Like The Store, Despite Labor Violations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, Nordstrom is... with 3 grafs to UPDATE with company statement, editing to conform. Picks up 11th graf, ``It's premature...
DOC.TEXT: For years, the sterling image of wonderful service and quality merchandise at the Nordstrom's department store chain has been the envy of the retail industry, and fueled expansion, customer loyalty and high profits. Now that image has been tarnished by a state labor finding that the company doesn't properly compensate its sales force and by worker allegations the behind the quality service is often-grueling pressure to produce sales. But some shoppers say they're not ready to stop buying at Nordstrom, even though their visits have become somewhat of a guilt trip. ``I will probably still shop here because of their merchandise, but I don't agree with the way they treat their employees,'' said Annette Voeller, a communications manager said outside Nordstrom's flagship Seattle store. ``I don't think I'll stop shopping there, but it's nice to pay the employees,'' said Angela Kristie, a sportswear saleswoman at competitor Frederick and Nelson who passes up her 20 percent employee discount to buy shoes at Nordstrom. The state Department of Labor and Industries last week found Nordstrom systematically made employees perform work-related duties without compensation, and ordered it to pay them two years' worth of overtime. The finding stemmed from a complaint by the United Food and Commercial Workers union, which said clerks were expected to deliver merchandise to customers' homes, do inventories and attend company pep talks on their own time. The union estimates workers in Washington are owed up to $40 million while California employees of the store are owed $300 million. ``Their system fosters unfair labor practices, illegal employment practices and a lack of due process for employees,'' said Joe Peterson, president of Local 1001. Nordstrom issued a statement Thursday saying it accepts ``full responsibility for any pressure employees have felt to perform these duties without pay,'' spokeswoman Kelley Tormey said. Nordstrom already has given employees compensation claim forms and instituted a new policy in which employees sign special timesheets when they go on customer deliveries so that they get paid, Tormey said. Nordstrom is exploring whether one of the state's findings, regarding calculation of overtime, was based on correct interpretation of the law, said Tormey. ``It's premature to talk about the size of the impact (of the findings on the company's image),'' she said. ``We're very, very concerned.'' The rulings come as the company is in contract negotiations with the union, which claims to represent around 1,400 of the 3,000 sales clerks in Washington. The last contract expired July 31. The state's findings have divided employees as well as shoppers. While some complained of hours of unpaid work, others saw the issue as a ploy to ensure the union's survival. ``To make out that people are oppressed here is insane,'' said David Fehrenbacher, a women's shoes salesman who says he works regular hours to pull $30,000 a year before profit-sharing. ``It's not too bad for just standing there selling shoes. You don't need a college degree and you don't need a technical background,'' Fehrenbacher said. Whatever the outcome of the dispute, it is likely to affect Nordstrom's profitability, analysts said. The conflict is being watched widely by retailers because of the industry-wide trend toward reinstituting commission sales, which was led by Nordstrom. Nearly all Nordstrom salespeople receive a base salary of $9.85 per hour plus commission. Nordstrom generates about $400 of retail sales per square foot of floorspace, about twice the industry average. Sales help earnings are also about twice the industry average. The company's pretax profit margin of about 8.5 percent annually is one of the highest in the highly competitive industry. Analysts said Nordstrom's profitability is enhanced by off-the-clock work, but that quantifying the amount is difficult. However, they said, changing the commission system to compensate employees would be costly. ``There's no doubt that (the profitability) is partly attributable to off-the-clock work,'' said Carol Palmer, retail analyst with Duff and Phelps in Chicago. ``If a union-type mentality takes over, it's the worst thing that could happen.'' If the company alters its commissions policy due to the union dispute, other retailers will adapt that to their own needs, analysts said. ``Everyone's going into commission programs. I don't think the trend will be derailed. There will be a correction in the commissions system and it will continue,'' said Pam Stubing, vice president with Moody's Investor Service in New York. But analysts and shoppers say Norstrom also benefits from a strong merchandise lineup and its no-questions-asked returns policy. Nordstrom has 60 stores in Washington, Oregon, California, Alaska, Virginia and Utah. It plans 16 more, including moving into Illinois, New Jersey, Maryland, Minnesota, Indiana, Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York. From its high of $42.50 a share last summer, Nordstrom stock has dropped 35 percent in value, closing Thursday at $29.25 a share. Forty percent of the stock is owned by members of the founding Nordstrom family. The stock stabilized Wednesday after a two-day slide knocked 15 percent off its value. Nordstrom's stock also has been hurt by the company's announcement this week that fourth-quarter earnings will be lower than a year earlier. A decline would be the first since Nordstrom went public 19 years ago and a marked reversal from analyst estimates of a 10 percent gain.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, `Pfizer, another ...,' to fix typo in ``valve.''
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices ended mixed Thursday in moderate trading after a last-minute selloff sparked by a rumor about a Japanese scandal. Earlier, issues rose following renewed strength on the Tokyo market and buying by bargain hunters. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed down 8.79 to 2,574.77. At midday it had been up as much as 30 points. Advancing issues nearly matched declining issues in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 715 up, 753 down and 508 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 184.32 million shares, up from 159.24 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 214.69 million shares. In Tokyo, the key Nikkei index was on a roller coaster until the close, when it was up 92.51 points, or 0.25 percent, to 35,826.84. On Wednesday, the Nikkei plummeted more than 3 percent for its third-worst drop ever. The plunge helped set off a tumble in London and New York, but the U.S. markets later recovered. The market Thursday also benefited from a firming in the price of U.S. government debt securities, analysts said, and comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan. Greenspan told a Senate committee that he sees no evidence inflation is accelerating and that it may be decreasing. Dudley Eppel, managing director of equity trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp., said Wall Street exhibited optimism Thursday until prices slipped in the last hour. Gordon L. Smith, a managing director at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., a Baltimore brokerage, said computerized sell programs linked to stock-index futures kicked in during the last hour of trading. Selling also apparently was sparked by rumors of a stock-related scandal in the Japanese government, he said. The reports, which Smith called ``ill-defined,'' could not be confirmed or denied immediately. Philip Morris, one of the most active NYSE issues, was up { to 38[. The company said its Kraft General Foods division would aggressively seek acquisitions by about 1991. Union Carbide, another active blue-chip issue, was up 1[ at 23| amid rumors of a possible takeover bid or the spinoff of a division. The company declined to comment. Among other blue chips, American Telephone & Telegraph was down | at 38[, IBM was down 1] at 103{ and General Electric was up [ to 60|. Monsanto jumped 4] to 112\ on news that the Food and Drug Administration approved the company's fat substitute for food products, Simplesse. UAL dropped 5} to 126{. The Wall Street Journal reported that the airline company's chairman, Stephen Wolf, decided not to back a union-led employee buyout that didn't include him. Pfizer, another active NYSE issue, fell 4\ to 59{ on news reports that it could face a major product-liability suit over a heart valve once sold by a subsidiary. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $10.60 billion, or 0.33 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 0.79 to 180.28. Standard & Poor's industrial index lost 2.79 to 375.35, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 1.97 to 325.70. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.23 to 422.75. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 0.40 to 353.35.

DOC.HEAD: Justice-Exxon Agreement Near; Alaska Rejects Draft Proposal.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 6 new grafs to update with Alaska rejection of draft agreement, comments by Baily and Hair. Pickup 3rd graf pvs: Justice etc. Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department and Exxon Corp. are near agreement on settling possible criminal charges over last year's massive Alaska oil spill, several sources said Thursday. But Alaska officials said late Thursday they would not endorse a tentative agreement outlined by the Justice Department and hoped improvements can still be made that would make it acceptable to the state. ``Under the proposed agreement the federal government would abandon its commitment to Alaska to assist with its civil claims against Exxon,'' complained Alaska Attorney General Douglas Baily. He told reporters that the Justice Department was trying to force the state to make ``a hasty endorsement'' of a plea bargaining agreement that amounted to little more than ``a pig in a poke'' and falls short of ensuring full restoration of damaged resources. Environmental groups and a congressman also called the plea bargaining inappropriate, accusing the Bush administration with ``pushing for a quick settlement'' that would allow Exxon to escape more severe criminal penalties. ``From all accounts the Bush adminstration is giving Exxon a wink and a nod ... a mere slap on the wrist,'' said Jay Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation. Justice Department spokesmen would only confirm that plea negotiations have been under way with Exxon, whose tanker Exxon Valdez released 11 million gallons of oil off Alaska in Prince William Sound last March. It was the country's worst oil spill. But several sources both in and out of the government, all speaking on condition that they not be identified, said a settlement could be announced as early as Friday. Exxon announced Thursday it was taking another charge against earnings of $300 million for litigation costs in connection with the spill, bringing the company's total costs to more than $2 billion. The Justice Department talks with Exxon were said to revolve around possible penalites of up to $500 million, to be paid over a number of years by Exxon into a natural resources restoration for Prince William Sound. One source said that under the draft agreement Exxon, would have to pay only $150 million initially with the rest of the $500 million spread over seven years with each payment subject to challenge by Exxon. ``If you read the fine print it could be substantially less'' in actual payments overall, said the source, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. In addition, Justice has sought a lesser criminal fine, but the amount could not be learned Thursday night. Exxon attorneys have tried to limit the amount of money they must pay directly to the U.S. Treasury as criminal penalties, preferring to pay most of the penalties into the restoration fund, sources said. There was no answer at Exxon's offices in New York Thursday evening. Earlier in the week, company spokesmen declined to discuss the discussions with the Justice Department. Environmental lawyers said that money paid for restoration under the criminal settlement could be tax deductible as an ordinary cost of doing business and later may be used to reduce future assessements against Exxon under various civil proceedings. Criminal penalties could not be deducted from future assessements, nor would they be tax deductible. Under two criminal statutes used by federal prosecutors in oil spill cases, fines of up to double the cost of the cleanup could be levied. ``The administration is moving too quickly,'' said Mike Matz of the Sierra Club and chairman of the Alaska Coalition, a group of environmental and civic organizations. ``Exxon is responsible for the worst environmental tragedy since Three Mile Island and the Justice Department wants to punish them with little more than a slap on the wrist.'' Bob Adler, a spokesman for the Washington-based Natural Resources Defense Council, said no settlement should be signed before the extent of long-term damages to natural resources is even known. He said $500 million would be ``grossly inadequate'' In Alaska, state officials accused the Justice Department of abandoning their state. ``If the latest draft of this agreement is imposed Alaska would find itself on the short end of the stick. We are being asked to accept a pig in a poke. ... And that pig smells awfully bad,'' said a statement issued by the offices of Gov. Steve Cowper and Attorney General Douglas Baily. Meanwhile, attorneys representing plaintiffs in civil suits against Exxon filed a petition in federal court in Anchorage asking that any plea bargaining agreement be subject to an open court hearing before becoming final. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., also criticized the Justice Department bargaining with Exxon, saying the agreement ``may not provide full damages'' and might jeopardize the rights of other parties seeking damages from Exxon. Miller, chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources, said the Bush administration was moving too quickly. ``The criminal investigation hasn't even reached the stage of indicting,'' Miller told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Chevrolet Doubles Some Rebates, Trims Others
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s Chevrolet Division said it has raised rebates from $500 to $1,000 on 1989 and 1990 Camaro and Cavalier models delivered through May 2. Meanwhile, rebates will be reduced from $750 to $500 on 1989 and 1990 Astro minivans delivered March 8 through May 2, Chevrolet said Wednesday in a statement. Buyers of those and certain other Chevrolet cars and trucks may forgo rebates and opt for loan rates ranging from 6.9 percent to 10.9 percent, depending on the length of the contract, the statement said.
